('91', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. AN ANALYSIS 1
('91', 0, 2, 3, 57) After four days of searching examination of the State Paper 2
('91', 0, 3, 4, 119) issued by the Cabinet Mission and the Viceroy on behalf of the British Government, my conviction abides that it is the best document the British Government could have produced in the circumstances.
('91', 0, 3, 5, 317) It reflects our weakness, if we would be good enough to see it.
('91', 0, 3, 6, 381) The Congress and the Muslim League did not, could not agree.
('91', 0, 3, 7, 442) We would grievously err if at this time we foolishly satisfy ourselves that the differences are a British creation.
('91', 0, 3, 8, 558) The Mission have note come all the way from England to exploit them.
('91', 0, 3, 9, 627) They have come to devise the easiest and quickest method of ending British rule.
('91', 0, 3, 10, 708) We must be brave enough to believe their declaration until the contrary is proved.
('91', 0, 3, 11, 791) Bravery thrives upon the deceit of the deceiver.
('91', 0, 3, 12, 840) My compliment, however, does not mean that what is best from the British standpoint is also best or even good from the Indian.
('91', 0, 3, 13, 967) Their best may possibly be harmful.
('91', 0, 3, 14, 1003) My meaning will, I hope, be clear from what follows.
('91', 0, 3, 15, 1056) The authors of the document have endeavoured to say fully what they mean.
('91', 0, 3, 16, 1130) They have gathered from their talks the minimum they thought would bring the parties together for framing India’s charter of freedom.
('91', 0, 3, 17, 1264) Their one purpose is to end British rule as early as may be.
('91', 0, 3, 18, 1325) They would do so, if they could, by their effort, leave united India not torn asunder by internecine quarrel bordering on civil war.
('91', 0, 3, 19, 1458) They would leave in any case.
('91', 0, 3, 20, 1488) Since in Simla the two parties, though the Mission suceeded in bringing them together at the Conference table (with what patience and skill they could do so, they alone could tell), could not come to an agreement, nothing daunted, they decen ded to the plains of India, and devised a worthy document for the purpose of setting up the Constituent Assembly which should frame India’s charter of independence, free of any British control or influence.
('91', 0, 3, 21, 1937) It is an appeal and an advice.
('91', 0, 3, 22, 1968) It has no compulsion in it.
('91', 0, 3, 23, 1996) Thus the Provincial Assemblies may or may not elect the delegates.
('91', 0, 3, 24, 2063) The delegates, having been elected, may or may not join the Cons tituent Assembly.
('91', 0, 3, 25, 2146) The Assembly having met, may lay down a pro cedure different from the one laid down in the Statement.
('91', 0, 3, 26, 2248) Whatever is
('91', 0, 4, 27, 2260) 1 An advance copy of this was sent to Sir Stafford Cripps.
('91', 0, 4, 28, 2319) 2 Vide Appendix “Statement of Cabinet Declaration and Viceroy”, 16 5 1946.
('91', 1, 0, 1, 2394) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 1, 1, 2, 2434) binding on any person or party arises out of the necessity of the situation.
('91', 1, 1, 3, 2511) The separate voting is binding on both the major parties, only because it is necessary for the existence of the Assembly and in no otherwise.
('91', 1, 1, 4, 2653) At the time of writing.
('91', 1, 1, 5, 2677) I took up the Statement, reread it clause by clause, and came to the conclusion that there was nothing in it binding in law.
('91', 1, 1, 6, 2802) Honour and necessity alone are the two binding forces.
('91', 1, 1, 7, 2857) What is binding is that part of it which commits the British Government.
('91', 1, 1, 8, 2930) Hence, I suppose, the four members of the British mission took the precaution of receiving full approval of the British Government and the two Houses of Parliament.
('91', 1, 1, 9, 3095) The Mission are entitled to warm congratulations for the first step in the act of renunciation which the Statement is.
('91', 1, 1, 10, 3214) Since other steps are necessary for full renunciation, I have called this one a promissory note.
('91', 1, 1, 11, 3311) Though the response to be made by India is to be voluntary the authors have naturally assumed that the Indian parties are well organized and responsible bodies capable of doing voluntary acts as fully as, if not more fully than, compulsory acts.
('91', 1, 1, 12, 3557) Therefore, when Lord Pethick Lawrence said to a Press correspondent 1,“If they do come together on that basis, it will mean that they will have accepted that basis, but they can still change it, if a majortiy of each party they desire to do so, ” he was right in the sense that those who became delegates, well knowing the contents of the Statement, were expected by the authors to abide by the basis, unless it was duly altered by the major parties.
('91', 1, 1, 13, 4008) When two or more rival parties meet together, they do so under some understanding.
('91', 1, 1, 14, 4091) A self chosen umpire (in the absence of the one chosen by the parties, the authors constitute themselves one) fancies that the parties will come together only if he presents them with a proposal containing a certain minimum, and he makes his proposal, leaving them free to add to, subtract from or altogether change it by joint agreement.
('91', 1, 1, 15, 4430) This is perfect so far.
('91', 1, 1, 16, 4454) But what about the units?
('91', 1, 1, 17, 4480) Are the Sikhs, for whom the Punjab is the only home in India, to consider themselves against their will, as part of the section which takes in Sindh, Balu chistan and the Frontier Province?
('91', 1, 1, 18, 4670) Or is the Frontier Province also against its will to belong to the Punjab, called “B” in the Statement, or Assam to“C” although it is a predominantly non Muslim pro vince?
('91', 1, 1, 19, 4842) In my opinion, the voluntary character of the Statement
('91', 1, 2, 20, 4898) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Pethick Lawrence”, 19 5 1946.
('91', 2, 0, 1, 4951) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 3
('91', 2, 1, 2, 4991) demands that the liberty of the individual unit should be unimpaired.
('91', 2, 1, 3, 5061) Any member of the sections is free to join it.
('91', 2, 1, 4, 5108) The freedom to opt out is an additional safeguard.
('91', 2, 1, 5, 5159) It can never be a substitute for the freedom retained in paragraph 15(5) which reads:
('91', 2, 2, 6, 5245) Provinces should be free to form groups with executives and legisla tures and each group could determine the Provincial subject to be taken in common.
('91', 2, 2, 7, 5396) It is clear that this freedom was taken away by the authors by section 19 which“proposes” (does not order) what should be done.
('91', 2, 2, 8, 5524) It presupposes that the Chairman of the Constituent Assembly at its first meeting will ask the delegates of the Provinces whether they would accept the group principle and if they do, whether they [would] accept the assignment given to their Province.
('91', 2, 2, 9, 5776) This freedom inherent in every Province and that given by 15(5) will remain intact.
('91', 2, 2, 10, 5860) There appears to me to be no other way of avoiding the apparent conflict between the two paragraphs as also charge of compulsion which would immediately alter the noble character of the document.
('91', 2, 2, 11, 6056) I would, therefore, ask all those who are perturbed by the group proposal and the arbitrary assignment, that, if my interpretation is valid there is not the slightest cause for perturbation.
('91', 2, 2, 12, 6247) There are other things in the document which would puzzle any hasty reader who forgets that it is simply an appeal and an advice to the nation showing how to achieve independence in the shortest time possible.
('91', 2, 2, 13, 6457) The reason is clear.
('91', 2, 2, 14, 6478) In the new world that is to emerge out of the present chaos, India in bondage will cease to be ‘the brightest jewel’ in the British crown it will become the blackest spot in that crown, so black that it will be fit only for the dustbin.
('91', 2, 2, 15, 6715) Let me ask the reader to hope and pray with me that the British crown has a better use for Britain and the world.
('91', 2, 2, 16, 6829) The ‘brightest jewel’ is an arrogation.
('91', 2, 2, 17, 6869) When the promissory note is fully honoured, the British crown will have a unique jewel as of right flowing from due performance of duty.
('91', 2, 2, 18, 7006) There are other matters outside the Statement which are required to back the promissory note.
('91', 2, 2, 19, 7100) But I must defer that examination to the next issue of Harijan 1 .
('91', 2, 3, 20, 7167) NEW DELHI, May 20, 1946 Harijan, 26 5 1946
('91', 2, 4, 21, 7210) 1 Vide “Vital Defects”, 2 6 1946.
('91', 3, 0, 1, 7244) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 3, 1, 2, 7284) 2. LETTER TO LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE
('91', 3, 2, 3, 7319) VALMIKI MANDIR, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, May 20, 1946
('91', 3, 3, 4, 7373) DEAR LORD,
('91', 3, 4, 5, 7384) As the matters we discussed yesterday morning and the day before were very important and affected and still affect my attitude and corresponding action, I think it worth while to reduce a summary to writing.
('91', 3, 4, 6, 7592) You can correct me if there is a mis understanding.
('91', 3, 4, 7, 7644) This may even help you wherever necessary.
('91', 3, 4, 8, 7687) I may add that I have conveyed to the Working Committee of the Congress the purport, to the best of my ability, of our talks.
('91', 3, 4, 9, 7813) With this preface I proceed to give the summary.
('91', 3, 4, 10, 7862) 1. You were good enough to assure me that you will see to it that European members of Provincial Assemblies, neither voted at the elections of delegates to the Consituent Assembly nor expected to be elected by the electors of non Muslim delegates.
('91', 3, 4, 11, 8110) 2. Election of the possible 93 delegates on behalf of the States would be determinded by the Nawab Sahib of Bhopal and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('91', 3, 4, 12, 8254) In the absence of an agreed solution, there should be no election of delegates on behalf of the States, the function of looking after the interests of the Princes and their people devolving upon the Advisory Committee referred to in clause 20 of the State Paper.
('91', 3, 4, 13, 8517) 3. In view of the fact that there is no machinery in British Baluchistan analogous to the Provincial Assemblies, it should be treated as the special concern of the Constituent Assembly and should be included in the function of the Advisory Committee.
('91', 3, 4, 14, 8768) Meanwhile it should be the duty of the Interim National Government to set up machinery to bring Baluchistan on a par with the other Provinces.
('91', 3, 4, 15, 8911) 4. I ventured to suggest that Paramountcy should cease even while independence is at work in fact, though not in law, till the Constituent Assembly has finished its labours and divised a constitution.
('91', 3, 4, 16, 9112) Sir Stafford saw danger in acting upon my suggestion.
('91', 3, 4, 17, 9166) I hold the opposite view.
('91', 3, 4, 18, 9192) Acceptance of my proposal would vivify the people of the States as if by a stroke of the pen.
('91', 3, 4, 19, 9286) And the Interim
('91', 4, 0, 1, 9302) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 5
('91', 4, 1, 2, 9342) Government would be a boon to the Princes who, though the creation of the Paramount Power and dependent on it for the continuance of their existance, still chafed under its heavy hand.
('91', 4, 1, 3, 9527) The immediate end of Paramountcy would test the sincerity of the Princes and the Paramount Power.
('91', 4, 1, 4, 9625) But if this Indian feeling did not find an echo in your hearts, I personally would be satisfied with Sir Stafford’s view that Para mountcy which had been admittedly use to protect the Princes against their people in the shape suppressing their liberty and progress, should for the time continue for the protection and progress of the people.
('91', 4, 1, 5, 9967) If the people of the States are backward, it is not because they are different in kind from the people of the direct British parts of india but because they have been groaning under a double yoke.
('91', 4, 1, 6, 10164) I endorsed also the suggestion that Paramountcy should be exercised in consultation with the National Government.
('91', 4, 1, 7, 10278) 5. I have written to you on my difficulty on gouping.
('91', 4, 1, 8, 10332) 1 I need say nothing more on the subject, pending reply to it.
('91', 4, 1, 9, 10395) 6. Whilst I appreciate your and Sir Stafford’s frankness, I would put on record my conviction that independence would in fact be a farce, if the British troops are in India even for peace and order within, or danger from without.
('91', 4, 1, 10, 10625) The condition of India after the labours of the Constituent Assembly are over will in this respect be no better than now.
('91', 4, 1, 11, 10747) If the position about the troops persists, “indepen dence next month” is either insincere or a thoughtless cry.
('91', 4, 1, 12, 10859) Accep tance of “Quit India” by the British is unconditional, whether the Constituent Assembly succeeds or fails in bringing out a constitution.
('91', 4, 1, 13, 11003) A drastic revision of the attitude is a necessity in every case.
('91', 4, 1, 14, 11068) Finally it can in no way be contended that in the face of the troops, there would be natural behaviour in the Constiuent Assembly.
('91', 4, 1, 15, 11199) 7. As to the Interim Government, the more I think and observe, the more certain is my feeling that a proper National Government resposible in fact, if not in law, to the elected members of the Central Legislative Assembly, should precede the summons of the election of members of the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 4, 1, 16, 11505) Only then, and not before, can a true picture of coming events be presented.
('91', 4, 1, 17, 11582) The food crisis demands immediate formation of a strong, capable and homogeneous National Government.
('91', 4, 1, 18, 11684) Without it, deep and universal corruption cannot end
('91', 4, 2, 19, 11737) 1 Vide “Letter to lord Pethick Lawrence”, 19 5 1946.
('91', 5, 0, 1, 11790) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 5, 1, 2, 11830) without it the psychological effect will not be produced in spite of the landing on India shores of expected grain from outside.
('91', 5, 1, 3, 11959) Every day’s delay in forming such a Government is agony added to the agony of famished millions of India.
('91', 5, 1, 4, 12065) There can therefore be no question of party whether the Government is allowed to be formed by the Congress or the Muslim League.
('91', 5, 1, 5, 12194) The best and incorrouptible men or women from India are wanted for the purpose.
('91', 5, 1, 6, 12274) I was therefore glad to find that the Viceroy was already moving in the matter as quickly as possible.
('91', 5, 2, 7, 12377) Your sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('91', 5, 3, 8, 12406) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, pp.193 5

('91', 5, 5, 10, 12495) NEW DELHI, May 20, 1946
('91', 5, 6, 11, 12519) AMRIT, Your two notes.
('91', 5, 6, 12, 12542) I am glad you are having some well deserved rest.
('91', 5, 6, 13, 12592) I still say don’t hurry, don’t worry.
('91', 5, 6, 14, 12630) I shall give you timeby notice.
('91', 5, 6, 15, 12662) I do not know when I shall be able to leave; not this week, I fear.
('91', 5, 6, 16, 12730) While there is opportunity, give ample time to your brothers.
('91', 5, 6, 17, 12792) Of course you will serve wherever you are.
('91', 5, 6, 18, 12835) I would like you to be by my side but not at the expense of your brothers or your health and not in this heat so long as it is avoidable.
('91', 5, 6, 19, 12973) Now you stay with Dalip as long as he wants you.
('91', 5, 6, 20, 13022) And of course you are free to come whenever you want to.

('91', 5, 6, 22, 13097) Pyarelal must give you news about the Mission.

('91', 7, 4, 6, 15107) 6. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('91', 7, 5, 7, 15137) NEW DELHI, May 20, 1946 It being my silence day, I only want to say to you that for India it is a day for deep and serious thinking.
('91', 7, 5, 8, 15270) We should do nothing in haste.
('91', 7, 5, 9, 15301) For, we are deeling with the destinies of dumb millions.
('91', 7, 5, 10, 15358) It therefor becomes our bounden duty that, with God as witness, we should think only of the country with its 40 crores of people, not of our petty selves nor of our respective communities or groups.
('91', 7, 5, 11, 15557) And whatever we decide we should act upon without fear or shame.
('91', 7, 5, 12, 15622) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 21 5 946
('91', 7, 6, 13, 15655) 7. MANGO SEED KERNEL
('91', 7, 7, 14, 15676) A friend has sent me an extract from Current Science showing how mango seed kernel is a fair substitute for cereals and fodder: 3
('91', 7, 8, 15, 15806) I have known this use from my early youth.
('91', 7, 8, 16, 15849) But no one seems to have thought of conserving this seed for food.
('91', 7, 8, 17, 15916) The mango season is upon us and, though much time has been lost, it will be a good thing if every mango seed is saved and the kernel baked and eaten in the place of cereals or given to those who need it.
('91', 7, 8, 18, 16120) Every ounce of food saved is so much gained.
('91', 7, 8, 19, 16165) DELHI, May 21, 1946 Harijan, 26 5 1946
('91', 7, 9, 20, 16204) 1Vide “Speech at Nankana Saheb”, 3 3 1921. 2 It being Gandhiji’s silence day his written message was read out after the prayers.
('91', 7, 9, 21, 16333) 3 The extract is not reproduced here.
('91', 7, 9, 22, 16371) It showed how from chemical analysis mango seed kernels had been found to be rich in rich in carbohydrates and fats.
('91', 8, 0, 1, 16488) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 9
('91', 8, 1, 2, 16528) 8. A FAIR HIT
('91', 8, 2, 3, 16542) A report from New Delhi dated 16th April, published in The Times of India of the 18th says that at a prayer meeting held on Tuesday evening 1 you said:
('91', 8, 3, 4, 16694) 1. “The machinery and even engineers were all foreign.
('91', 8, 3, 5, 16749) He had no enmity with machinery.
('91', 8, 3, 6, 16782) Mills, he said, could not remove the poverty of India, but on the other hand had deprieved crores of villagers of their work and practically ruined them.
('91', 8, 3, 7, 16936) Those Indians responsible for ruining the villages had become foreigners and as such they should live in foreign countries.”
('91', 8, 4, 8, 17061) How can you reconcile this statement with the gentlemen who form the Board of Trustees of the Kasturba Memorial Fund, the primary aim of which is to improve conditions in villages?
('91', 8, 4, 9, 17242) Majoriy of these gentlemen are indus trialists and owners of mills.
('91', 8, 4, 10, 17310) Can they, who are responsible for ruining the villages, and still continue to ruin them by their mills, be ever capable of sincere help in improving the condition of villagers?
('91', 8, 5, 11, 17487) 2. You have so often talked and written against the curse of black market.
('91', 8, 5, 12, 17562) How many of the trustees of the Kasturba Memorial Fund can lay their hands on their hearts and say they have not dealt in the black market either as buyers or sellers?
('91', 8, 5, 13, 17730) This is a fair hit.
('91', 8, 5, 14, 17750) That mill oweners and such others have joined the Kasturba Trust is a compliment to my ahimsa.
('91', 8, 5, 15, 17845) Though I express my opinions strongly, there is no sting in them, nothing personal.
('91', 8, 5, 16, 17929) I have no sense of shame in befriending millowners whose business, I hold, should be stopped, not forcibly but by reason.
('91', 8, 5, 17, 18051) Education of the public could bring about results which no force can.
('91', 8, 5, 18, 18121) I must say in favour of the capitalist class trustees that they never interfered with the decision of non capitalist trutees.
('91', 8, 5, 19, 18247) Indeed, they have always helped by their knowledge.
('91', 8, 5, 20, 18299) The combination is good and beneficial to the Trust.
('91', 8, 5, 21, 18352) Their sincerity cannot be questioned; for, they have faith in their capacity and the modern trend.
('91', 8, 5, 22, 18451) As to black market, I do not know that any of the trustees have black market dealings.
('91', 8, 5, 23, 18538) But should I discover any, I should think twice before inviting them to leave the Trust.
('91', 8, 5, 24, 18627) They have not imposed themselves on the Trust.
('91', 8, 5, 25, 18674) DELHI, May 21, 1946 Harijan, 26 5 1946
('91', 8, 6, 26, 18713) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 16 4 1946.
('91', 9, 0, 1, 18758) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 9, 1, 2, 18799) 9. HYPNOTISM OF ENGLISH 1
('91', 9, 2, 3, 18825) The foregoing letter 2 is from a fellow worker in the cause.
('91', 9, 2, 4, 18886) He knows what he is writing about.
('91', 9, 2, 5, 18921) Nor are the facts referred to by him unknown to the Indian public.
('91', 9, 2, 6, 18988) The question is how to break the spell that the English language exercise over us.
('91', 9, 2, 7, 19071) It is an essential part of our struggle for swaraj or else we shall have to revise our definition of swaraj.
('91', 9, 2, 8, 19180) In slavery, the slave has to ape the manners and ways of the master, e.
('91', 9, 2, 9, 19252) g., dress, language, etc.
('91', 9, 2, 10, 19278) Gradually he developes a liking for it to the exclusion of every thing else.
('91', 9, 2, 11, 19355) When the British yoke is lifted and we are independent, this infatuation with the English language will automatically go.
('91', 9, 2, 12, 19477) In the meantime, let those who have realized the harm that this infatuation has done to the country, make it a point to use Hindustani or their mother tongue only.
('91', 9, 2, 13, 19641) It is a fact that the editors of English newspapers earn ten times as much as the editiors of newspapers in the Indian languages.
('91', 9, 2, 14, 19771) The remedy for it also lies in our hands.
('91', 9, 2, 15, 19813) The market value of English will find its natural level, once the British empire over India goes, for the simple reason that India cannot affod to pay on a lavish scale.
('91', 9, 2, 16, 19983) India is a poor country, and so long as the lot of the poorest of the poor remains unameliorated, we have no right to draw fat salaries.
('91', 9, 2, 17, 20120) The fact, however, is that it rests with the newspaper reading public to raise or reduce the prestige and price of the Indian languages newspapers.
('91', 9, 2, 18, 20268) If they will cease to regard English papers as their gospel and transfer their patronage to Indian language newspapers instead, the proprietors will be compelled soon to take note of the change and adjust their policies accordingly.
('91', 9, 2, 19, 20501) Something like that is happening already.
('91', 9, 2, 20, 20543) There was a time when Indian languages newspapers had a poor circulation compared to English.
('91', 9, 2, 21, 20637) Now the scales are reversed.
('91', 9, 2, 22, 20666) Indian languages newspapers are increasing both in number and circulation.
('91', 9, 2, 23, 20741) But those who are running newpapers in Indian languages also owe a duty in the matter even like the newspaper reading public.
('91', 9, 2, 24, 20867) The language of the newspapers in the Indian languages is often poor and the writing appearing in them lack originality.
('91', 9, 2, 25, 20988) Newspapermen alone can remove these defects.
('91', 9, 2, 26, 21033) NEW DELHI, May 21, 1946 Harijan, 26 5 1946
('91', 9, 3, 27, 21076) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 26 5 1946. 2 Which is not reproduced here

('91', 10, 1, 2, 21215) 10. NATURE CURE IN KANCHANGAON 1
('91', 10, 2, 3, 21248) I settled down and started work in Uruli Kanchan in response to the invitation of the inhabitants there in the hope of making it a model nature cure centre for the villages of India.
('91', 10, 2, 4, 21431) The people of the village had promised their co operation.
('91', 10, 2, 5, 21490) They were to have provided the land and erected buildings on it.
('91', 10, 2, 6, 21555) But that has not yet materialized.
('91', 10, 2, 7, 21590) They have given the money.
('91', 10, 2, 8, 21617) But that is not enough for buying land and buildings on it.
('91', 10, 2, 9, 21677) Their acitve interest in it is more important than mere monetary aid 2 .
('91', 10, 2, 10, 21750) According to the reports received from co workers there, the inhabitants of Kanchangoan have begun to understand and appreciate nature cure.
('91', 10, 2, 11, 21891) And the workers have developed such self confidence that they won’t mind if I do not return there before June.
('91', 10, 2, 12, 22002) They say that the people are co operating with them so whole heartedy that they can well afford to wait till I descend from Mahabaleswar and Panchgani at the end of the warm season.
('91', 10, 2, 13, 22184) All this has filled me with hope 3 .
('91', 10, 2, 14, 22221) Nature cure consists of two parts.
('91', 10, 2, 15, 22256) Firstly, to cure diseases by the taking the name of God or Ramanama and secondlyy, to prevent illness by the inculcation of right and hygienic living.
('91', 10, 2, 16, 22407) The report from the village says that the inhabitants are co operating with them in keeping the village clean.
('91', 10, 2, 17, 22518) I hold that where the rules of personal, domestic and public sanitation are strictly observed and due care is taken in the matter of diet and exercise, there should be no occasion for illness or disease.
('91', 10, 2, 18, 22722) Where there is absolute purity, inner and outer, illness becomes impossible.
('91', 10, 2, 19, 22799) If the village people could but understand this, they would not need doctors, hakims or vaidyas.
('91', 10, 2, 20, 22896) In Kanchangoan there are hardly any cows.
('91', 10, 2, 21, 22938) That is unfortunate.
('91', 10, 2, 22, 22959) There are some she buffaloes.
('91', 10, 2, 23, 22989) But all the evidence that has come to me so far shows that buffalo’s milk is no match for cow’s in the health giving quality.
('91', 10, 2, 24, 23115) The vaidyas specially recommend cow’s milk for patients.
('91', 10, 2, 25, 23172) I, therefore, hope that people of Uruli Kanchan will keep

('91', 13, 1, 3, 26975) What I want to tell you is that redemption in that song is promised us here and now, if we fulfil the necessary conditions.
('91', 13, 1, 4, 27099) They are firstly, self purification and, secondly, obedience to the Law.
('91', 13, 1, 5, 27172) It is vain, it is demoralizing to except that in the life to come to God will vindicate His title as Redeemer by saving us while we continue to carry the load of sin on our heads in this life.
('91', 13, 1, 6, 27365) A businessman who lies and cheats his simpleminded, ignorant customers cannot hope to be saved.
('91', 13, 1, 7, 27461) It has been said that to one who is good the whole world becomes good.
('91', 13, 1, 8, 27532) That is true so far as the individual is concerned.
('91', 13, 1, 9, 27584) But goodness becomes dynamic only when it is practised in the face of evil.
('91', 13, 1, 10, 27660) If you return good for good only, it is a bargain and carries no merit, but if you return good for evil, it becomes a redeeming force.
('91', 13, 1, 11, 27795) The evil ceases before it and it goes on gathering volume and momen tum like a snowball till it becomes irresistible.
('91', 13, 2, 12, 27913) So much for the individuals.
('91', 13, 2, 13, 27942) How could a slave country like India be redeemed?
('91', 13, 2, 14, 27992) he next asked.
('91', 13, 2, 15, 28007) His reply was that a slave country owes the continuation of its slavery to the vices which slavery engenders.
('91', 13, 2, 16, 28117) The way of self purification, therefore, is also the way of redemption for a slave country.
('91', 13, 2, 17, 28209) It was no use putting off hopes for redemption to future state.
('91', 13, 2, 18, 28273) If they failed to gain redemption here they would probably miss it in the life hereafter too.
('91', 13, 2, 19, 28367) Let us therefore turn the searchlight inward and purge ourselves of all dross.
('91', 13, 2, 20, 28446) If we shed our petty quarrels and animosities and forget all communal differences and petty distinctions the foreign troops would find their ocupation gone and nobody would be able to keep us in servitude for a day.

('91', 17, 0, 1, 34306) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 17, 1, 2, 34347) You who have served under Subhas Babu, as veteran fighters have proved your mettle on the battlefield.
('91', 17, 1, 3, 34450) Success and failure are, however, not in our hands, but in God’s hands alone.
('91', 17, 1, 4, 34528) Netaji told you when bidding good bye to you that, on your return to India, you must put yourselves under the Congress discipline and act according to its policy.
('91', 17, 1, 5, 34691) Your object, as I have been told, was only to free India, never to help the Japanese.
('91', 17, 1, 6, 34777) You failed in your direct objective, i.
('91', 17, 1, 7, 34817) e., to defeat the British.
('91', 17, 1, 8, 34844) But you have the satisfaction that the whole country has been rousded and even the regular forces have been stirred into a new political consciousness and have begun to think in terms of independence.
('91', 17, 1, 9, 35045) You have achieved a complete unity among the Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Christians, Anglo Indians and Sikhs in your ranks.
('91', 17, 1, 10, 35166) That is no mean achievement.
('91', 17, 1, 11, 35195) What, howevr, you realized under conditions of freedom outside India, you have now to sustain and keep alive under Indian conditions.
('91', 17, 1, 12, 35329) That will be your real test.
('91', 17, 1, 13, 35358) If you have imbitbed the spirit of non violence, you will remain free men at heart even here.
('91', 17, 1, 14, 35452) For instance, no government on earth can make men, who have realized freedom in their heart, salute against their will.
('91', 17, 1, 15, 35572) If they threaten to kill them they will offer their necs to them, but refuse to submit.
('91', 17, 1, 16, 35660) The odds are that a soldier’s spirit will revolt against such coldblooded murder.
('91', 17, 1, 17, 35742) Thus, whether they live or die it will be as free men.
('91', 17, 1, 18, 35797) They will never be slaves.
('91', 17, 1, 19, 35824) If you will become free men at heart, the whole of India will be free.
('91', 17, 1, 20, 35895) They might imprison you.
('91', 17, 1, 21, 35920) You will welcome it or you can tell them that you will be a corpse before they can put you in prison.
('91', 17, 1, 22, 36022) Both alternatives are open to a non violent soldier and both call for bravery of the highest order.
('91', 17, 1, 23, 36122) Our task is no less than to reinfuse life into the 400 millions of India.
('91', 17, 1, 24, 36196) We have to dispel fear from their hearts.
('91', 17, 1, 25, 36238) On the day they shed all fear, India’s fetters shall fall and she will be free.
('91', 17, 1, 26, 36318) Years ago I said at Nankan Sahib 1: “Sikhs have given proof of their martial valour.
('91', 17, 1, 27, 36403) But the consummation of Guru Govind Singh’s idea will be reached only when they will substitute for their kirpans 2
('91', 17, 2, 28, 36519) the sword of the spirit or non violence.” So long as one wants to retain one’s sword, one has not attained complete fearlessness.
('91', 17, 2, 29, 36649) No power on earth can subjugate you when you are armed with the sword of ahimsa.
('91', 17, 2, 30, 36730) It ennobles both the victor and the vanquished.
('91', 17, 2, 31, 36778) Netaji has fired you with a new spirit.
('91', 17, 2, 32, 36818) That spirit can now be kept alive only
('91', 17, 3, 33, 36857) 1 On March 3, 1921; “Speech at Nankana Saheb”, 3 3 1921. 2 Swords
('91', 18, 0, 1, 36923) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 19
('91', 18, 1, 2, 36964) through non violence.
('91', 18, 1, 3, 36986) Above all, you must never beg or throw yourselves on any body’s charity.
('91', 18, 1, 4, 37059) Because you have risked your lives for India’s sake and fought for her on the Imphal plain, you must not expect to be pampered in return.
('91', 18, 1, 5, 37197) If you do that, you will lose all worth like salt that has lost its savour.
('91', 18, 1, 6, 37273) You should prefer to earn your bread by the sweat of your brow, but refuse to beg or accept charity.
('91', 18, 1, 7, 37374) In short, you have to show the same degree of bravery and courage of the non violent types as you have done in the use of arms hitherto.
('91', 18, 1, 8, 37511) India is a very poor country and we should all work for our living.
('91', 18, 1, 9, 37579) There is plenty of land available for all.
('91', 18, 1, 10, 37622) If you want land you will have it.

('91', 18, 1, 15, 38010) Graduation in this work is more heroic than winning the Victoria Cross.
('91', 18, 2, 16, 38082) Then followed questions and answers.
('91', 18, 3, 17, 38119) Q. How can one who has spent his whole life in fighting take to ahimsa with success?
('91', 18, 3, 18, 38204) Are not the two incompatible/ A. I do not agree.
('91', 18, 3, 19, 38253) Badshah Khan is a Pathan.
('91', 18, 3, 20, 38279) But today he has become a soldier of non violence.
('91', 18, 3, 21, 38330) In his land the sword and the gun are considered essential even for settling private disputes.
('91', 18, 3, 22, 38425) But he has fully imbibed the principle of non violence.
('91', 18, 3, 23, 38481) The whole thing depends upon your attitude of mind.
('91', 18, 3, 24, 38533) Tolstoy too served in the army.
('91', 18, 3, 25, 38565) Yet he became the high priest of non violence in Europe.
('91', 18, 3, 26, 38622) We have not yet realized fully the power that is non violence.
('91', 18, 3, 27, 38685) If the Government had not arrested me in 1942, I would have shown how to fight Japan by non violence.
('91', 18, 3, 28, 38787) Even at the time of the threatned Japanes invasion, I preached resistance to the enemy through non violence.
('91', 18, 3, 29, 38896) The British did not believe me.
('91', 18, 3, 30, 38928) They thought how could we fight the Japanses non vio lently?
('91', 18, 3, 31, 38989) But I am telling you I have got faith in my ability to fight non violently.
('91', 18, 4, 32, 39065) Q. Surely, it is no breach of ahimsa to use the sword in self defence?
('91', 18, 4, 33, 39136) A. No, it is not necessary to use force.
('91', 18, 4, 34, 39177) You should be prepared even to lay down your lives.
('91', 19, 0, 1, 39229) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 19, 1, 2, 39270) Even Wavell, Auchinleck 1 or Hitler does not use the sword with out necessity.
('91', 19, 1, 3, 39349) But that does not make it ahimsa.
('91', 19, 1, 4, 39383) It is himsa, whatever its justification.
('91', 19, 2, 5, 39424) Q. You cannot take the world along with you if you adopt ahimsa.
('91', 19, 2, 6, 39489) You have to choose the one or the other.
('91', 19, 2, 7, 39530) A. There again I disagree.

('91', 20, 2, 3, 41414) Coming back to the text of the song that had been distributed, he once again explained in detail the inner meaning of the ideal set forth in it.
('91', 20, 2, 4, 41559) The conception of a country where there were was no suffering and no sorrow, might at first sight strike one as Utopian.
('91', 20, 2, 5, 41680) Nevertheless, they wanted their country to be such a country and he had even allowed himself to say the other day that the announcement of the Cabinet Mission contained in it the germs of that fulfilment 1 .
('91', 20, 3, 6, 41888) The poet in that song, had not only set forth the ideal but also mentioned the conditions for its realization.
('91', 20, 3, 7, 41999) Those conditions were freedom from illusions and regrets, delusion and desire.
('91', 20, 3, 8, 42078) Such a country, however, was nowhere to be found on this earth.
('91', 20, 3, 9, 42142) The poet, therefore, in order to be logical and true, had said that it was within us— it was identifialble with the realm of the spirit within.
('91', 20, 3, 10, 42286) It connoted swaraj, that is to say, self rule or rule over self.
('91', 20, 3, 11, 42351) A person who had perfect mastery over self could realize in his person the ideal depicted in the song.
('91', 20, 3, 12, 42454) As he had remarked on the previous day, to a person who is good, the whole world becomes good.
('91', 20, 3, 13, 42549) If millions did that, the Kingdom of God would be realized on earth.
('91', 20, 3, 14, 42618) But even if all did not, there was no need for the individual to despair.
('91', 20, 3, 15, 42692) He could make a beginning with himself straight away in the faith that what he did today the rest would do tomorrow.

('91', 26, 5, 22, 53149) There is nothing there worth seeing as yet.
('91', 26, 5, 23, 53193) Even the land has not been bought and no buildings have been built.
('91', 26, 5, 24, 53261) Now let us take the main question.
('91', 26, 5, 25, 53296) The tendency of looking to the West in order to make progress in whatever we do, should be checked.
('91', 26, 5, 26, 53396) If we have to go the West to learn nature cure, it cannot be of much use to India.
('91', 26, 5, 27, 53479) Nature cure is a thing which anyone can practise in the home.

('91', 26, 5, 29, 53613) It is such a simple thing that everyone can learn it.

('91', 26, 5, 31, 53746) Ramanama is the very foundation of nature cure of my concep tion.

('91', 28, 6, 8, 56242) 35. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 4
('91', 28, 7, 9, 56273) NEW DELHI, May 24, 1946 5
('91', 28, 8, 10, 56299) A correspondent had written to Gandhiji pointing out how some people superstitiously wrote Ramanama on their clothes so as to wear it “next to the hearts”.
('91', 28, 8, 11, 56455) Other wrote Ramanama millions of times minutely on a piece of paper which they afterwards cut up into small bits and swallowed so that they could claim that Ramanama had enered into them!
('91', 28, 8, 12, 56643) Another correspondent had asked him whether he had prescribed Ramanama as the sovereign remedy for all ills because Rama was God’s anointed and was a descedent of Dasharatha, the illustrious King of Ayodhya.
('91', 28, 8, 13, 56851) There were people who thought that he was self deluded and was trying to delude others by adding one more to the thousands of superstitions which filled this superstition ridden land.
('91', 28, 8, 14, 57035) He had no answer to such criticism.
('91', 28, 8, 15, 57071) He only said to himself, what did it matter if truth was abused and fraud practised in its name by others?
('91', 28, 8, 16, 57178) So long as he was sure of his truth he could not help proclaiming it fear of its being misunderstood or abused.
('91', 28, 8, 17, 57290) Nobody in this world possesses absolute truth.
('91', 28, 8, 18, 57337) This is God’s attribute alone.
('91', 28, 8, 19, 57368) Relative truth is all we know.
('91', 28, 8, 20, 57399) Therefore, we can only follow the truth as we see it.
('91', 28, 8, 21, 57453) Such pursuit of truth cannot lead anyone astray.
('91', 28, 9, 22, 57502) He reitrated Rama whose name he prescribed as the infallible remedy for all ills was neither the historical Rama nor the Rama of those who used the name as a charm or black magic.
('91', 28, 9, 23, 57682) Rama whose name he prescribed as a cure all was God, by taking
('91', 28, 10, 24, 57745) 1Eldest son of Jamnalal Bajaj 2 The latter is written under another of this date.
('91', 28, 10, 25, 57827) 3 Addressee’s mother 4 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 5 From The Hindustan Times, 26 5 1946
('91', 29, 0, 1, 57931) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 29, 1, 2, 57972) whose name devotees attained purity and peace, and he claimed that it was the one infallible remedy for all ailments whether mental, spiritual or physical.
('91', 29, 1, 3, 58128) It was, of course, possible to cure physical ailments by going to doctors and vaidyas.
('91', 29, 1, 4, 58215) But Ramanama enabled one to become one’s own doctor or vaidya and to find the elixir of healing within oneself.
('91', 29, 1, 5, 58327) Even when the ailment could not be cured, because physically it was incurable, it enabled one to endure it with equanimity and peace of mind.
('91', 29, 1, 6, 58469) A person who has faith in Ramanama would not run from pillar to post and dance attendance at the doors of celebrated doctors and viadyas in order to prolong existence anyhow.
('91', 29, 1, 7, 58644) Nor is Ramanama meant to be taken only when the doctors and vaidyas have failed.
('91', 29, 1, 8, 58725) It is meant to enable one to do without them altogether.
('91', 29, 1, 9, 58782) For a believer in Ramanama it is the first as well as the last remedy.

('91', 30, 1, 2, 59825) 37. SALARY OF M. L. A.S
('91', 30, 2, 3, 59849) Q. The monthly salary of an M.L. A. is Rs. 200. He is a mofussil member and, as such, is entitled to a daily allowance of Rs. 15 when the Assembly is in session.
('91', 30, 2, 4, 60011) Besides that, he may draw conveyance [allowance] of Rs. 2/8 for any day on which he attends the meeting of the Assembly.
('91', 30, 2, 5, 60132) Moreover, he is entitled to ‘travelling allowance’ for his journey from the usual place of residence to the city at the rate of one and a half time first class fare but he cannot draw ‘travelling allowance’ and ‘daily allowance’ for the same day.
('91', 30, 3, 6, 60379) 1. (a) Should such a person as a representative and servant of the poor draw the salary?
('91', 30, 4, 7, 60468) (b) Would he be absolved from the wrong if he gave the whole amount to the local Congress Committee or the institution under which he is working for constructive work?
('91', 30, 5, 8, 60636) (c) If so, would it not mean that the end justifies the means?
('91', 30, 6, 9, 60699) 2. He will have to live in the city when the Assembly is in session and has to incur some other expenditure for discharging his duties and responsibilitie as an M. L. A.
('91', 30, 7, 10, 60869) (a) In the circumstances, may he, consistently with his ideal, draw the daily allowance to meet the expenses?
('91', 30, 8, 11, 60979) (b) If so, and if it be not permissible to draw a part of it, should he draw the whole of it and give the balance to the institution under which he is working.
('91', 30, 9, 12, 61139) (c) In that case, may he, consistently with his ideal, spend the balance or part thereof for his family, which will have otherwise to depend upon the charity of friends to make the two ends meet?
('91', 30, 10, 13, 61335) 3. (a) Should he draw the conveyance allowance (meant for his conveyance inside the city for attending meeting) when the daily allowance will be more than sufficient to cover all his expenses including the conveyance?
('91', 30, 11, 14, 61553) (b) Should he avail of costly conveyance for attending meetings, if he usually travels in tram cars and buses?
('91', 30, 12, 15, 61664) 4. If suh a member travels third class on principle, what should he do regarding drawing ‘mileage allowance’ if it is not permissible to draw at lower rate than one and a half first class fares?
('91', 30, 12, 16, 61859) A. In my opinion, the salary and allowances drawn by the gentlemen of the various Assemblies are out of all proportion to the
('91', 31, 0, 1, 61985) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 31, 1, 2, 62026) services they render to the country.
('91', 31, 1, 3, 62063) The scales fixed are on the English pattern, not at all compatible with the income of this country—the poorest in the world.
('91', 31, 1, 4, 62188) Therefore, the answer I suggest is that Ministers should, with the consent of the Assemblies, reduce the whole scale in accordance with requirements and, in the meantime, either the amount taken should be handed to the party to which the member belongs, drawing what the party has fixed or, if that be not possible, drawing what his conscience thinks just for himself and his family and devoting the balance to some items of the constructive programme or some such public activity.
('91', 31, 1, 5, 62670) The money allowed has to be drawn but nobody is obliged to use it for [him] self except to the extent needed.
('91', 31, 1, 6, 62780) No question here arises of the end justifying the means.
('91', 31, 1, 7, 62837) NEW DELHI, May 25, 1946 Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 31, 2, 8, 62879) 38. RIDICULING RAMANAMA 1
('91', 31, 3, 9, 62905) Q. The Ramanama bank in Benares and wearing clothes printed with Ramanama is, in my opinion a caricature of Ramanama.
('91', 31, 3, 10, 63023) Don’t you think that under these circumstances your telling the people to take to Ramanama as a sovereign remedy for all ailments is likely to encourage ignorance and hypocrisy?
('91', 31, 4, 11, 63201) A. You are right.
('91', 31, 4, 12, 63219) There is so much superstition and hypocrisy around that one is afraid even to do the right thing.
('91', 31, 4, 13, 63317) But if one gives way to fear, even truth will have to be suppressed.
('91', 31, 4, 14, 63386) The golden rule is to act fearlessly upon what one believes to be right.
('91', 31, 4, 15, 63459) Hypocrisy and untruth will go on in the world.
('91', 31, 4, 16, 63506) Our doing the right thing will result in their decrease, if anything, never in their increases.
('91', 31, 4, 17, 63602) The dangr is that when we are surrounded by falsehood on all sides we might be caught in it and begin to deceive ourselves.
('91', 31, 4, 18, 63726) We should be careful not to make a mistake out of our laziness and ignorance.
('91', 31, 4, 19, 63804) Constant vigilance under all circumstances is essential.
('91', 31, 4, 20, 63861) A votary of truth cannot act otherwise.
('91', 31, 4, 21, 63901) Even an all powerful remedy like Ramanama can become useless for lack of wakefulness and care, and become one more addition to the numberous current superstitons.
('91', 31, 4, 22, 64064) NEW DELHI, May 25, 1946 Harijan, 2 6 1946

('91', 32, 1, 2, 64250) 39. NATURE CURE FOR THE POOR 1
('91', 32, 2, 3, 64281) Q. Is it not a cruel joke to ask the poor villager to live on orange juice when he cannot afford even ordinary diet?
('91', 32, 2, 4, 64398) He has to work throughout the day to feed his wife and children.
('91', 32, 2, 5, 64463) His land and his children mean more to him than life itself.
('91', 32, 2, 6, 64524) Nature cure is meant for the rich who have plenty of money and time at their disposal.
('91', 32, 3, 7, 64611) If you really wish to serve the villagers through nature cure, you should see that the right type of nature cure homes are started every where.
('91', 32, 3, 8, 64755) At these homes the patients should get free food, clothing and bedding.
('91', 32, 3, 9, 64827) And, if the patient happens to be a wage earner, arrangements should be made to support his family.
('91', 32, 4, 10, 64927) You have said nature cure means reorientation of the way of living.
('91', 32, 4, 11, 64995) Is it not necessary that education in that direction should form a necessary part of nature cure treatment?
('91', 32, 4, 12, 65103) A. The question betrays the correspondent’s ignorance.
('91', 32, 4, 13, 65158) He has not taken the trouble to read carefully what I have written on the subject.
('91', 32, 4, 14, 65241) Nature cure implies that the treatment should be the cheapest and the simplest possible.
('91', 32, 4, 15, 65330) The ideal is that such treatment should be carried out in the villages.
('91', 32, 4, 16, 65402) The villagers should be able to provide the necessary means and equipment.
('91', 32, 4, 17, 65477) What cannot be had in the villages should be procured.
('91', 32, 4, 18, 65532) Nature cure does mean a change for the better in one’s outlook on the life itself.
('91', 32, 4, 19, 65615) It means regulation of one’s life in accordance with the laws of health.
('91', 32, 4, 20, 65688) It is not a matter of taking medicine free from the hospital or for fees.
('91', 32, 4, 21, 65762) A man who takes free treatment from the hospital accepts charity.
('91', 32, 4, 22, 65828) The man who accepts nature cure never begs.
('91', 32, 4, 23, 65872) Self help enhances self respect.
('91', 32, 4, 24, 65905) He takes steps to cure himself by eliminating poison from the system and takes precautions against falling ill in the future.
('91', 32, 4, 25, 66031) The central feature of nature cure treatment is Ramanama.
('91', 32, 4, 26, 66089) 2 But it must come from the heart, if it is to be a remedy for all one’s ailments 3 .
('91', 32, 4, 27, 66175) Orange juice is not an essential part of nature cure treatment.
('91', 32, 5, 28, 66239) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 2 6 1946. 2 The Hindi here adds: “A man feels secure with Ramanama.” 3The Hindi adds: “And the observance of the laws becomes imperative for Ramanama to come from the heart.
('91', 32, 5, 29, 66469) In such a situation man becomes free from all ailments.
('91', 32, 5, 30, 66525) It involves neither any expenditure nor any discomfort.”
('91', 33, 0, 1, 66582) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 33, 1, 2, 66623) Right diet and balanced diet are necessary.
('91', 33, 1, 3, 66667) Today our villages are as bankrupt as were are ourselves.
('91', 33, 1, 4, 66725) To produce enough vegetables, fruits and milk in the villages is an essential part of the nature cure scheme.
('91', 33, 1, 5, 66835) Time spent on this should not be considered a waste.
('91', 33, 1, 6, 66888) It is bound to benefit all the villagers and ultimately the whole of India.
('91', 33, 1, 7, 66964) It is true and nature cure homes of the right type should be opened in the villages and the cities.
('91', 33, 1, 8, 67064) God willing, this will be done.

('91', 33, 2, 11, 67220) 40. DRAFT LETTER TO LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE 1
('91', 33, 3, 12, 67264) May 25, 1946 I have to answer your letter of 22nd instant which was read to my colleagues.
('91', 33, 3, 13, 67355) They wanted me to refer at the time of acknowledging your letter to some of the points in it.
('91', 33, 3, 14, 67449) 1. You yourself admit that your scheme is a recommendation.
('91', 33, 3, 15, 67509) There fore at no stage can there be any compulsion read into it.
('91', 33, 3, 16, 67574) The Con gress has never taken the power nor has it any desire to compel a single unit.
('91', 33, 3, 17, 67661) And I know, as a matter of fact, that neither the Frontier Province nor Assam nor the Sikhs of the Punjab will submit to any compulsion.
('91', 33, 3, 18, 67798) They have signified their intention of not joining any group whatsoever.
('91', 33, 3, 19, 67871) All I wish to say is that the scheme cannot be used for the purpose of compelling acceptance by any unit or group.
('91', 33, 3, 20, 67986) The whole beauty of it resides in its voluntary character which should not be impaired.
('91', 33, 3, 21, 68074) 2 But, of course, it will be open to all persons and parties in the Constituent Assembly to reason with any units.
('91', 33, 3, 22, 68189) Naturally the decision on major communal issues will be guided by the provision thereon of the Statement.
('91', 33, 3, 23, 68295) 2. As to the last three lines of paragraph 3 of your letter, obviously, adequate provisions for the protection of minorities must be part of the instrument of the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 33, 3, 24, 68480) But I assume that the Constituent Assembly will be the sole judge of adequacy.
('91', 33, 4, 25, 68559) 1 Gandhiji had prepared this draft for Abul Kalam Azad.
('91', 33, 4, 26, 68615) 2 The addressee in his letter had said that grouping was “an essential feature of the scheme which can only be modified by agreement between the two parties”.
('91', 34, 0, 1, 68774) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 35
('91', 34, 1, 2, 68815) 3. Willingness to conclude a treaty will always be there.
('91', 34, 1, 3, 68873) But the treaty must be a voluntary act on the part of Independent India.
('91', 34, 1, 4, 68946) If it pre supposes compulsion, there is no Independence.
('91', 34, 1, 5, 69003) 4. As to the last paragraph of your letter, I can understand the post ponement of the declaration of legal independence till after the publi cation of the charter of independence framed by the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 34, 1, 6, 69218) But I cannot understand the paragraph, if independence in fact does not take place immediately the contemplated interim government is established.
('91', 34, 1, 7, 69365) 5. Have you any objection to the release to the Press of our corres pondence.

('91', 39, 0, 1, 74889) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 39, 1, 2, 74930) 49. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 39, 2, 3, 74961) NEW DELHI, May 25, 1946 2
('91', 39, 3, 4, 74987) Gandhiji explained the conditions under which alone Ramanama could become an effective remedy for the three fold malady, to which man was subject.
('91', 39, 3, 5, 75134) The first condition was that it should come from the heart.
('91', 39, 3, 6, 75194) What did that mean?
('91', 39, 3, 7, 75214) People did not mind going to the ends of the earth to find a cure for their physical ailments which were much less important than the mental or spiritual.
('91', 39, 3, 8, 75369) Man’s physical being is after all perishable.
('91', 39, 3, 9, 75415) It cannot, by its very nature, last for ever.
('91', 39, 3, 10, 75461) And yet man makes a fetish of it while neglecting the immortal spirit within.
('91', 39, 4, 11, 75539) A man who believed in Ramanama would not make a fetish of the body but would regard it only as a means of serving God.
('91', 39, 4, 12, 75658) And for making it a fit instrument for that purpose, Ramanama was the sovereign means.
('91', 39, 5, 13, 75745) To install Ramanama in the heart required infinite patience.
('91', 39, 5, 14, 75806) It might even take ages.
('91', 39, 5, 15, 75831) But the effort was worth while.
('91', 39, 5, 16, 75863) Even so success depended solely on the grace of God.
('91', 39, 6, 17, 75916) Ramanama could not come from the heart unless one had cultivated the virtues of truth, honesty and purity within and without.
('91', 39, 6, 18, 76042) Every day at the evening prayers they repeated the shlokas describing the man with steadfast intellect.
('91', 39, 6, 19, 76146) Every one of them, said Gandhiji, could become a sthitaprajna—the man with steadfast intellect—if he kept his senses under discipline, ate and drank and allowed himself enjoyment and recreation only to sustain life for service.
('91', 39, 6, 20, 76374) If one had no control over one’s thoughts, if one did not mind, for instance, sleeping in a hole of a room with all doors and windows shut, and breathing foul air or drinking dirty water, recitation of Ramanama was in vain.
('91', 39, 7, 21, 76598) That, however, did not mean that one should give up reciting Ramanama on the ground that one had not the requisite purity.
('91', 39, 7, 22, 76721) For, recitation of Ramanama was also a means for acquiring purity.
('91', 39, 7, 23, 76788) In the case of a man who repeats Ramanama from the heart, discipline and self control will come easy.
('91', 39, 7, 24, 76890) Observance of the rules of health and hygiene will become his second nature.
('91', 39, 7, 25, 76967) His life will run an even course.
('91', 39, 7, 26, 77001) He will never want to hurt anyone.
('91', 39, 7, 27, 77036) To suffer in order to relieve others’ sufferings will become a part of his being and fill him with an ineffable and perennial joy.
('91', 39, 8, 28, 77167) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 From The Hindustan Times, 26 5 1946
('91', 40, 0, 1, 77250) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 41
('91', 40, 1, 2, 77291) Let them therefore, said Gandhiji, persevere and ceaselessly repeat Ramanama during all their waking hours.
('91', 40, 1, 3, 77399) Ultimately, it would remain with them even during their sleep and God’s grace would then fill them with perfect health of body, mind and spirit.
('91', 40, 2, 4, 77544) Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 40, 3, 5, 77562) 50. VITAL DEFECTS Intrinsically and as legally interpreted, the State Paper 1 seems to me to be a brave and frank document.
('91', 40, 3, 6, 77686) Nevertheless, the official interpretation would appear to be different from the popular.
('91', 40, 3, 7, 77775) If it is so and prevails it will be a bad omen.
('91', 40, 3, 8, 77823) During the long course of the history of British rule in India, the official interpretation has held sway.
('91', 40, 3, 9, 77930) And, it has been enforced.
('91', 40, 3, 10, 77957) I have not hesitated before now to say that the office of the law giver, judge and executioner is combined in one person in India.
('91', 40, 3, 11, 78088) Is not the State Document a departure from the imperialistic tradition?
('91', 40, 3, 12, 78160) I have answered ‘yes’.
('91', 40, 3, 13, 78183) Be that as it may.
('91', 40, 3, 14, 78202) Let us try to glance at the shorcomings.
('91', 40, 3, 15, 78243) The Delegation, after a brief spell in Simla, returned to Delhi on the 14th instant, issued their Statement on the 16th, and yet we are far from the popular government at the Centre.
('91', 40, 3, 16, 78426) One would have thought that they would have formed the Central Government before issuing the Statement.
('91', 40, 3, 17, 78530) But they issued the Statement first and then set about the search for the formation of the Interim Government.
('91', 40, 3, 18, 78641) It is taking a long time coming whilst the millions are starving for want of food and clothing.
('91', 40, 3, 19, 78737) This is defect No.
('91', 40, 3, 20, 78756) 1. The question of paramountcy is unsolved.
('91', 40, 3, 21, 78800) It is not enough to say that paramountcy will end with the end of British rule in India.
('91', 40, 3, 22, 78889) If it persists without check during the interim period, it will leave behind a difficult legacy for the independent Government.
('91', 40, 3, 23, 79017) If it cannot be ended with the establishment of the Interim Government, it should be exercised in co operation with it and purely for the benefit of the people of the States.
('91', 40, 3, 24, 79192) It is the people who want and are fighting for independence, not the Princes who are sustained by the alien power even when they claim not to be its creation for the suppression of the liberties of the people.
('91', 40, 3, 25, 79402) The Princes, if they are true to their professions, should welcome this popular use of paramountcy so as to accommodate themselves to the sovereignty of the people envisaged
('91', 40, 4, 26, 79576) 1 Vide Appendix “Statement of Cabinet Delegation and Viceroy”, 16 5 1946.
('91', 41, 0, 1, 79650) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 41, 1, 2, 79691) under the new scheme.
('91', 41, 1, 3, 79713) This is defect No.
('91', 41, 1, 4, 79732) 2. Troops, it is declared, are to remain during the interim period for the preservation of internal peace and protection against external aggression.
('91', 41, 1, 5, 79882) If they are kept for such use during the period of grace, their presence will act as a damper on the Constituent Assembly and is more likely than not to be wanted even after the establishment of independence so called.
('91', 41, 1, 6, 80101) A nation that desires alien troops for its safety, internal or external, or has them imposed upon it, can never be described as independent in any sense of the term.
('91', 41, 1, 7, 80267) It is an effete nation unfit for self government.
('91', 41, 1, 8, 80317) The acid test is that it should be able to stand alone, erect and un bending.
('91', 41, 1, 9, 80395) During the interim period we must learn to hop unaided, if we are to walk when we are free.
('91', 41, 1, 10, 80487) We must cease from now to be spoon fed.
('91', 41, 1, 11, 80527) That these things are not happening as we would wish is to be accounted as our weakness, be the causes whatever they be, not the cussedness of the British Government or their people.
('91', 41, 1, 12, 80710) Whatever we get, will be our deserts, not a gift from across the seas.
('91', 41, 1, 13, 80781) The three Ministers have come to do what they have declared.
('91', 41, 1, 14, 80842) It will be time to blame them when they go back upon the British declarations and devise ways and means of perpetuating the British rule.
('91', 41, 1, 15, 80980) Though there is ground for fear, there is no sign on the horizon that they have said one thing and meant another.
('91', 41, 2, 16, 81094) NEW DELHI, May 26, 1946
('91', 41, 3, 17, 81118) Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 41, 4, 18, 81136) 51. FLAGS AND UNIFORMS
('91', 41, 5, 19, 81159) A correspondent writes:
('91', 41, 6, 20, 81183) During the recent election meetings I was astonished at the number of flags— not to speak of the special uniforms worn by the Congress volunteers for the occasion.
('91', 41, 6, 21, 81347) In these days of cloth shortage, is not the use of cloth for flags and special uniforms a criminal waste?
('91', 41, 6, 22, 81453) Flags and uniforms are in order when they are in their time and place.
('91', 41, 6, 23, 81524) They are easily an abomination when they take the place of bread.
('91', 41, 6, 24, 81590) Satisfaction of hunger has precedence over everything.
('91', 41, 6, 25, 81645) Simi larly, flags and uniforms cannot replace cloth for wear.
('91', 41, 6, 26, 81707) Hence, if the correspondent is right, Congressmen and others will have to be strictly
('91', 42, 0, 1, 81793) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 43
('91', 42, 1, 2, 81834) economical in the use of flags and uniforms for demonstrative purposes.
('91', 42, 1, 3, 81906) NEW DELHI, May 26, 1946 Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 42, 2, 4, 81948) 52. QUESTION BOX
('91', 42, 3, 5, 81965) PEACEFUL STRIKES 1
('91', 42, 4, 6, 81984) Q. How should a strike be conducted so that hooliganism and violence are avoided?
('91', 42, 5, 7, 82066) A. A strike should be spontaneous and not manipulated.
('91', 42, 5, 8, 82121) If it is organized without any compulsion there would be no chance for goondaism and looting.
('91', 42, 5, 9, 82215) Such a strike would be characterized by perfect co operation amongst the strikers.
('91', 42, 5, 10, 82298) It should be peaceful and there should be no show of force.
('91', 42, 5, 11, 82358) The strikers should take up some work either singly or in co operation with one another, in order to earn their bread.
('91', 42, 5, 12, 82477) The nature of such work should have been thought out beforehand.
('91', 42, 5, 13, 82542) It goes without saying that in a peaceful, effective and firm strike of this character, there will be no room for rowdyism or looting.
('91', 42, 5, 14, 82677) I have known of such strikes.
('91', 42, 5, 15, 82707) I have not presented a Utopian picture.
('91', 42, 5, 16, 82747) NEW DELHI, May 26, 1946
('91', 42, 6, 17, 82771) WHY DOCTORS?
('91', 42, 7, 18, 82784) Q. Why do you go to the doctors for examination and diagnosis and not to the vaidyas?
('91', 42, 8, 19, 82870) A. The vaidyas do not possess the knowledge of the human body as the doctors do.
('91', 42, 8, 20, 82951) The basis of diagnosis in Ayurveda is the theory of tridosh 2. They have not got to the bottom even of that.
('91', 42, 8, 21, 83060) The doctors are ever carrying on research and making new discoveries.
('91', 42, 8, 22, 83130) One either goes forward or backward.
('91', 42, 8, 23, 83167) Nothing remains static in the world.
('91', 42, 8, 24, 83204) Those who become static, become lifeless.
('91', 42, 8, 25, 83246) God alone is static, but amazing as it may sound, He is described both as motionless and full of motion.
('91', 42, 8, 26, 83351) Moreover, doctors and vaidyas are my friends.
('91', 42, 8, 27, 83397) The doctors have clung to me.
('91', 42, 8, 28, 83427) One 3 of them has become more than my own daughter.
('91', 42, 9, 29, 83479) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 2 6 1946. 2 The three disorders in the human system, viz., gas, bile and phlegm 3 Sushila Nayyar
('91', 43, 0, 1, 83635) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 43, 1, 2, 83676) One’s own daughter can leave her father; how can one who has chosen to become a daughter?
('91', 43, 1, 3, 83766) The vaidyas themselves use, though indifferently, the methods of diagnosis used by the doctors or else they advise the patient to go to the doctors for it.
('91', 43, 1, 4, 83922) The viadyas possess the knowledge of certain drugs which they use effectively.
('91', 43, 1, 5, 84001) But the doctors, vaidyas and hakims all slave for money.
('91', 43, 1, 6, 84058) They do not take to the profession purely from a spirit of service.
('91', 43, 1, 7, 84126) That some of them have that spirit does not contradict my statement.
('91', 43, 1, 8, 84195) Nature cure is the only thing which has come into existence purely from the point of view of selfless service.
('91', 43, 1, 9, 84306) Today even that has become a means of making money.
('91', 43, 1, 10, 84358) Thus money has taken the place of God.
('91', 43, 1, 11, 84397) The doctors examine me, but I depend on none but God.
('91', 43, 1, 12, 84451) He is the Master of every breath I take.
('91', 43, 1, 13, 84492) If He wills it, He will keep me up to 125 years.
('91', 43, 1, 14, 84541) If not, He might carry me off any moment, leaving the medical friends staring as helpless spectators.
('91', 43, 1, 15, 84643) NEW DELHI, May 26 11946
('91', 43, 2, 16, 84667) WHO IS RAMA?
('91', 43, 3, 17, 84680) Q. You have often said that when you talk of “Rama” you refer to the Ruler of the universe and not to Rama, the son of Dasharatha.
('91', 43, 3, 18, 84811) But we find that your Ramdhun calls on “Sita Rama”, “Raja Rama”, and it ends with “Victory to Rama the Lord of Sita”.
('91', 43, 3, 19, 84929) Who is this Rama if not the son of the king Dasharatha?
('91', 43, 3, 20, 84985) A. I have answered such questions before.
('91', 43, 3, 21, 85027) But there is some thing new in this one.
('91', 43, 3, 22, 85068) It demands a reply.
('91', 43, 3, 23, 85088) In Ramdhun “Raja Rama”,“Sita Rama” are undoubtedly repeated.
('91', 43, 3, 24, 85149) Is not this ‘Rama’ the same as the son of Dasharatha?
('91', 43, 3, 25, 85203) Tulsidas has answered this question.
('91', 43, 3, 26, 85240) But let me put down my own view.
('91', 43, 3, 27, 85273) More potent than Rama is the Name.
('91', 43, 3, 28, 85308) Hindu Dharma is like a boundless ocean teeming with priceless gems.
('91', 43, 3, 29, 85376) The deeper you dive into it the more treasures you find.
('91', 43, 3, 30, 85433) In Hindu religion God is known by various names.
('91', 43, 3, 31, 85482) Thousands of people doubtless look upon Rama and Krishna as historical figures and literally believe that God came down in person on earth in the form of Rama the son of Dasharatha, and that by worshipping Him one can attain salvation.
('91', 43, 3, 32, 85718) The same thing holds good about Krishna.
('91', 43, 3, 33, 85759) History, imagination and truth have got so inextricably mixed up, it is next to impossible to disentangle them.
('91', 43, 3, 34, 85871) I have accepted all the names and forms attributed to God as symbols denoting one formless omni present Rama.
('91', 43, 3, 35, 85981) To me, therefore, Rama described as the Lord of Sita,
('91', 43, 4, 36, 86035) 1 As in Harijanbandhu; Harijan, however, has “27”.
('91', 43, 4, 37, 86086) 2 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 2 6 1946.
('91', 44, 0, 1, 86152) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 45
('91', 44, 1, 2, 86193) name, inscribed in the heart, removes all suffering, mental, moral and physical.
('91', 44, 1, 3, 86274) NEW DELHI, May 26, 1946 Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 44, 2, 4, 86316) 53. LETTER TO MARGARET BARR
('91', 44, 3, 5, 86344) NEW DELHI, May 26, 1946
('91', 44, 4, 6, 86368) DEAR MARGARET, Yours of 9 4 1946, I have kept long for use.
('91', 44, 4, 7, 86428) I have read and reread it.
('91', 44, 4, 8, 86455) So long as you give rewards you will be giving prizes.
('91', 44, 4, 9, 86510) The line of distinction is thin.
('91', 44, 4, 10, 86543) The whole system of examinations has to go before prizes do.
('91', 44, 4, 11, 86604) The ancient system of saying which teacher taught you and how much was the only right thing.
('91', 44, 4, 12, 86697) But in this age of competition, this reversion won’t answer till people are tired of the thing.
('91', 44, 4, 13, 86793) Let us silently pray, work and wait.
('91', 44, 4, 14, 86830) I destroy your letter.
('91', 44, 4, 15, 86853) BAPU MISS MARGARET BARR MALKI, SHILLONG
('91', 44, 5, 16, 86893) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('91', 44, 6, 18, 86942) 54. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 44, 7, 19, 86973) NEW DELHI, Sunday, May 26, 1946
('91', 44, 8, 20, 87005) Gandhiji in his discourse after the prayers informed the gathering that he would be leaving for Mussoorie day after tomorrow (Tuesday).
('91', 44, 8, 21, 87141) He had been advised by his doctors to spend two months of the hot weather at some hill station to enable him to build up sufficient reserve for the rest of the year.
('91', 44, 8, 22, 87307) He could not do so this year for reasons they all knew.
('91', 44, 8, 23, 87363) He had decided to go to Mussoorie in preference to Panchgani or Simla, as it was nearer.
('91', 44, 8, 24, 87452) He would come back when the Congress President or the Cabinet Mission might require him.
('91', 44, 9, 25, 87541) Gandhiji said that they had been coming to the prayer gatherings daily in order to join him in reciting Ramanama or rather in learning how to do so.
('91', 44, 9, 26, 87690) Ramanama could
('91', 44, 10, 27, 87705) 1 The Hindustan Times report has been collated with Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 45, 0, 1, 87796) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 45, 1, 2, 87837) not be taught by word of mouth.
('91', 45, 1, 3, 87869) But more potent than the spoken word was the silent thought.
('91', 45, 1, 4, 87930) A single right thought can envelop the world.
('91', 45, 1, 5, 87976) It is never wasted.
('91', 45, 1, 6, 87996) The very attempt to clothe thought in word or action limits it.
('91', 45, 1, 7, 88060) What man has ever succeeded in expressing fully thought in word or in action?
('91', 45, 1, 8, 88138) Then, why not go into perpetual silence, one might ask.
('91', 45, 1, 9, 88194) In theory that is possible.
('91', 45, 1, 10, 88222) But it is very difficult to fulfil the conditions by which silent thought can wholly replace action.
('91', 45, 2, 11, 88323) He for one could not claim to have attained the requisite intensity or control over thought.
('91', 45, 2, 12, 88416) He could not altogether keep out useless or irrelevant thoughts from his mind.
('91', 45, 2, 13, 88495) It required infinite patience, vigilance and tapashcharya 1 to attain that state.
('91', 45, 3, 14, 88577) He was not indulging in a figure of speech, he continued, but had meant it literally when on the previous day he had told them that there was no limit to the potency of Ramanama.
('91', 45, 3, 15, 88756) But in order to experience that, Ramanama had to come from a heart that was absolutely pure.
('91', 45, 3, 16, 88849) He himself was striving to attain that state.
('91', 45, 3, 17, 88895) He had envisaged it in the mind but had not fully realized it in practice.
('91', 45, 3, 18, 88970) When that stage was reached, even the recitation of Ramanama would become unnecessary.
('91', 45, 4, 19, 89057) He hoped they would continue to recite Ramanama in their homes severally and in company during his absence.
('91', 45, 4, 20, 89165) The secret of collective prayer was that the emanation of silent influence from one to the other could be of help in their spiritual striving.
('91', 45, 5, 21, 89308) The Hindustan Times, 27 5 1946, and Harijan, 2 6 1946
('91', 45, 6, 22, 89362) 55. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('91', 45, 7, 23, 89390) The Indian Deputation 2 from South Africa have made a great stir in India.
('91', 45, 7, 24, 89465) They propose to approach the U. N. O. with a view to enlisting the latter’s sympathy.
('91', 45, 7, 25, 89551) But the legislation is going through.
('91', 45, 7, 26, 89589) The Indian High Commissioner will be withdrawn as he should be.
('91', 45, 7, 27, 89653) What little aid he can render is nothing compared to the indignity of representing a country whose inhabitants are to be treated as an inferior race.
('91', 45, 7, 28, 89803) This new caste is worse than the ancient but dying institution of India which has some redeeming features, even while it is dying.
('91', 45, 7, 29, 89934) But the new civilized edition has none.
('91', 45, 7, 30, 89974) It shamelessly proclaims that white civilization requires the erection of legal barriers
('91', 45, 8, 31, 90063) 1 Penance 2 Lead by Sorabjee Rustom; vide “Interview to South African Delegation”, after 1 4 1946.
('91', 46, 0, 1, 90162) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 47
('91', 46, 1, 2, 90203) in order to protect itself against Asiatics and Africans.
('91', 46, 1, 3, 90261) The Indians in South Africa are bearing a heavy burden which they are well able to discharge.
('91', 46, 1, 4, 90355) Satyagraha, the mightiest weapon in the world, was born and bred there.
('91', 46, 1, 5, 90427) If they make effective use of it, it will be well with the sacred cause they are handling.
('91', 46, 1, 6, 90518) It is not one of making it easy for a handful, to be permitted to live and trade there if they wear the badge of inferiority called years ago by an Englishman of South Africa “dog’s collar”.
('91', 46, 1, 7, 90709) The cause is the cause of the honour of India and through her of all the exploited coloured races of the earth, whether they be brown, yellow or black.
('91', 46, 1, 8, 90861) It is worth all the suffering of which they are capable.

('91', 46, 2, 10, 90960) 56. LETTER TO SIR STAFFORD CRIPPS
('91', 46, 3, 11, 90994) NEW DELHI, May 27, 1946
('91', 46, 4, 12, 91018) DEAR SIR STAFFORD, I got your touching letter yesterday when I was busy writing for Harijan.
('91', 46, 4, 13, 91111) Though I read it as soon as the visitors who had dropped in, had gone, I could not before now spare the time to write.
('91', 46, 4, 14, 91230) I am returning your letter, as it is marked “very confidential”.
('91', 46, 4, 15, 91295) However I see nothing in it which the world may not see, if it is curious.
('91', 46, 4, 16, 91370) I entirely agree with you [on] what the State Paper demands and commends 1 to is and yet it like everything coming from the British evokes nothing but distrust.
('91', 46, 4, 17, 91531) And I am sorry to confess that what has happened since the publication of the document has somewhat shaken my trust which the document by itself commanded and still commands.
('91', 46, 4, 18, 91706) The interpretations put upon it and the declarations since on independence, paramountcy, troops and the proposed disposal of the Baluchistan, election, the uncertainty about the European vote and above all, the waiting policy and the interminable delay about the Interim Government make me wonder whether a satisfactory Interim Government will ever be formed and whether the Constituent Assembly will ever meet.
('91', 46, 4, 19, 92118) Has even the cry of independence in action vanished into thin air?
('91', 46, 5, 20, 92185) 1 The source has “commands’
('91', 47, 0, 1, 92213) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 47, 1, 2, 92254) But I shall hope against hope and work for the success of the Mission even in spite of itself, though not hiding from them or the public honest doubt.
('91', 47, 1, 3, 92405) Trust put on is worse than useless.
('91', 47, 1, 4, 92441) Trust felt is the thing that counts.
('91', 47, 1, 5, 92478) Anyway, why worry about trust.
('91', 47, 1, 6, 92509) Trustworthy action will dispel all mistrust or distrust as the sun dispels morning mist.
('91', 47, 1, 7, 92598) This is not to disturb your test.
('91', 47, 1, 8, 92632) I would have refrained from writing to you, if your letter had not required a fairly full answer.

('91', 47, 1, 12, 92926) I leave for Mussoorie tomorrow morning.

('91', 55, 6, 10, 106012) If all nations were armed with the atom bomb they would refrain from using it as it would mean absolute destruction for all concerned.

('91', 55, 7, 14, 106348) 72. TALK WITH PRESS CORRESPONDENTS 3
('91', 55, 8, 15, 106385) [After May 28, 1946] 4
('91', 55, 9, 16, 106408) Your khadi, handicrafts and rural economy programme will have a great appeal for an agricultural country, as for instance, the Balkans.
('91', 55, 9, 17, 106544) .But to many of us, as indeed to many of your countrymen, it appears as a brake on progress.

('91', 55, 9, 19, 106719) How does my programme interfere with the progress of India?
('91', 55, 9, 20, 106779) India is mainly rural, consisting of 700,000 villages.
('91', 55, 10, 21, 106834) The visitor .
('91', 55, 10, 22, 106848) argued that this was unfair to the cities.
('91', 55, 10, 23, 106891) “What about the big cities like Bombay and Calcutta?” he asked.
('91', 55, 10, 24, 106955) On the contrary, the boot is on the other leg.
('91', 55, 10, 25, 107002) I regard the growth of cities as an evil thing, unfortunate for mankind and the world,
('91', 55, 11, 26, 107089) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “The Nightmare” 2 From the reference to Mussoorie where Gandhiji reached on May 28, 1946. 3 Reporting this in “Some Mussoorie Reminiscences”, Pyarelal says that during his ten days’ stay at Mussoorie a few foreign correspondents were able to have talks with Gandhiji during his morning walks.
