('91', 56, 0, 1, 107473) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 57
('91', 56, 1, 2, 107514) unfortunate for England and certainly unfortunate for India.
('91', 56, 1, 3, 107575) The British have exploited India through its cities.
('91', 56, 1, 4, 107628) The latter have exploited the villages.
('91', 56, 1, 5, 107668) The blood of the villages is the cement with which the edifice of the cities is built.
('91', 56, 1, 6, 107755) I want the blood that is today inflating the arteries of the run once again in the blood vessels of the villages.
('91', 56, 2, 7, 107869) The initial mistake having been made, you do not mean to suggest that all those steps should inexorably be retraced even though it might involve pulling down what has already been built.
('91', 56, 2, 8, 108056) Why not?
('91', 56, 2, 9, 108065) Once we discover that a mistake has been made, the only course open to us is to recognize our error, retrace our steps and begin anew.
('91', 56, 3, 10, 108200) Somehow, the belief prevails in the modern world that retracing one’s steps in this respect would be incompatible with progress.
('91', 56, 3, 11, 108329) What do you do when a ship loses her course on the sea?
('91', 56, 3, 12, 108385) She does not continue to follow the wrong course.
('91', 56, 3, 13, 108435) She at once retraces her course and then starts afresh.
('91', 56, 3, 14, 108491) How often must Columbus have done that or else he would have remained a derelict all the time.
('91', 56, 4, 15, 108586) Does that mean that you would depopulate the cities and send all the city folk back to the villages?
('91', 56, 4, 16, 108687) I would not do that.
('91', 56, 4, 17, 108708) All I want is that they should readjust their lives so as to cease to sponge upon the poor village folk and make to the latter what reparation is possible even at this late hour by helping to resuscitate their ruined economy.
('91', 56, 5, 18, 108934) What would you do if you were made a dictator of India for one day?
('91', 56, 5, 19, 109002) I would not accept it in the first place, but if I did become a dictator for one day I would spend it in cleaning the stables of the Viceroy’s House that the hovels of the Harijans in Delhi are.
('91', 56, 5, 20, 109197) It is disgraceful that under the very nose of the Viceroy such poverty and squalor should exist as there is in the Harijan quarters.
('91', 56, 5, 21, 109330) And why does the Viceroy need such a big house?
('91', 56, 5, 22, 109378) If I had my way I would turn it into a hospital.
('91', 56, 6, 23, 109427) And he gave the instance of President Kruger whose residence was not even as good as Birlaji’s ‘Hermitage’ in which he was staying.
('91', 56, 7, 24, 109559) “Well, sir, suppose they continue your dictatorship for the second day?” Gandhiji replied amidst laughter: The second day would be a prolongation of the first.
('91', 56, 8, 25, 109719) They next talked of several other things—the national language of India, the
('91', 57, 0, 1, 109796) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 57, 1, 2, 109837) place of English, the administrative problems that would face an independent India, the future of Indo British trade relations.
('91', 57, 1, 3, 109965) They then came to non violence.
('91', 57, 2, 4, 109997) “What will be the relations of India with Russia for instance?
('91', 57, 2, 5, 110060) What if Russia were to attack India?” Under my dictatorship Russia would find its occupation gone.
('91', 57, 2, 6, 110159) It will not find it profitable to stay on, even if it came.
('91', 57, 2, 7, 110219) But, of course, it is too rich a dream to be realized in a day.
('91', 57, 3, 8, 110283) The best men in the old generation had their education in England—you for instance.
('91', 57, 3, 9, 110367) Would you have India, when she becomes independent, send her sons there for study as before?
('91', 57, 3, 10, 110460) No, not just now.
('91', 57, 3, 11, 110478) I would advise her to send them there only after, say, 40 years.
('91', 57, 4, 12, 110543) It means depriving two generations of the benefits of contact with the West.
('91', 57, 4, 13, 110620) Why two generations?
('91', 57, 4, 14, 110641) 40 years or even 60 is not too much even in an individual’s life.
('91', 57, 4, 15, 110707) If there is right living we need not grow old at 60 as unfortunately many do in this country.
('91', 57, 4, 16, 110801) I repeat that they should go there only after they have reached maturity.
('91', 57, 4, 17, 110875) Because, it is only when they have learnt to understand the good that is in their own culture that they will be able to truly appreciate and assimilate the best that England or America has to give them.
('91', 57, 4, 18, 111078) Imagine a boy of seven teen, like myself, going to England—he will simply be submerged.
('91', 57, 5, 19, 111166) Then we may expect you in England some time, queried the friend.
('91', 57, 6, 20, 111231) Gandhiji replied amid general laughter: Oh, yes, you may.
('91', 57, 6, 21, 111289) Harijan, 23 6 1946
('91', 57, 7, 22, 111308) 73. TALK WITH A FRIEND 1
('91', 57, 8, 23, 111333) [After May 28, 1946] 2
('91', 57, 9, 24, 111356) “You have brought us to the threshold of independence, Gandhiji,” remarked another privileged friend who had a talk with him on an evening, “and we cannot feel too grateful for it.
('91', 57, 9, 25, 111537) You will, of course, give entire credit for it to ahimsa—that being your pet child.
('91', 57, 9, 26, 111621) But we feel that we have derived more strength from truth than from your ahimsa.” You are wrong in thinking that in my partiality for ahimsa I
('91', 57, 10, 27, 111764) 1Reproduced from Pyarelal’s report “Some Mussoorie Reminiscences”.
('91', 57, 10, 28, 111831) Gandhji reached Mussoorie on May 28, 1946. 2 Ibid
('91', 58, 0, 1, 111881) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 59
('91', 58, 1, 2, 111922) have given to truth the second place.
('91', 58, 1, 3, 111960) You are equally wrong in thinking that the country has derived more strength from truth than from ahimsa.
('91', 58, 1, 4, 112066) On the contrary, I am firmly convinced that whatever progress the country has made, is due to its adoption of ahimsa as its method of struggle.
('91', 58, 2, 5, 112210) I mean the country has not understood your ahimsa but it has understood truth and that has filled it with strength.
('91', 58, 2, 6, 112326) It is just the contrary.
('91', 58, 2, 7, 112351) There is so much of untruth in the country I feel suffocated sometimes.
('91', 58, 2, 8, 112423) I am convinced, therefore, that it must be the practice of ahimsa alone, however faulty, that has brought us so far.
('91', 58, 2, 9, 112540) Moreover, I have not given truth the second place as you seem to think.
('91', 58, 3, 10, 112612) He continued and described how at a meeting at Geneva 1 he had flabbergasted everybody by remarking that whereas he used to say that God is Truth, he had since come to hold that Truth is God.
('91', 58, 3, 11, 112804) “Nevertheless, your emphasis is always on ahimsa.
('91', 58, 3, 12, 112854) You have made propagation of non violence the mission of your life,” argued the friend.
('91', 58, 3, 13, 112942) There again you are wrong.
('91', 58, 3, 14, 112969) Ahimsa is not the goal.

('91', 58, 3, 17, 113114) A steadfast pursuit of ahimsa is inevitably bound to truth—not so violence.
('91', 58, 3, 18, 113190) That is why I swear by ahimsa.
('91', 58, 3, 19, 113221) Truth came naturally to me.

('91', 58, 3, 22, 113374) It is ahimsa, therefore, that our masses have to be educated in.
('91', 58, 3, 23, 113439) Education in truth follows from it as a natural end.

('91', 58, 4, 25, 113511) 74. MORE SUGGESTIONS
('91', 58, 5, 26, 113532) It is a good sign that food shortage is taxing many minds.
('91', 58, 5, 27, 113591) Suggestions for meeting it come in from all quarters.
('91', 58, 5, 28, 113645) A friend, who knows what he writes about, sends the following: 2
('91', 58, 6, 29, 113710) (1) A substantial saving in cereals should be possible by reducing the ration of cereals to non vegetarians to the extent that it is possible to supplement equal nutrition value by non vegetarian food.
('91', 58, 7, 30, 113912) 1 The meeting was held at Lausanne; vide “Statement to the Press”, 8 9 1931. 2 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('91', 59, 0, 1, 114042) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 59, 1, 2, 114083) (2) I expect that a large number of men do manual work find difficulty in satisfying hunger with the reduced rations.
('91', 59, 1, 3, 114201) It, therefore, follows that to the extent that cereals are reduced to non vegetarians, animal food, having equal nutrition value, should be substituted and that also for the same cost as that of the cereal reduced.
('91', 59, 1, 4, 114416) (3) There is a large damage to crops by deer, rabbit, boar, pig and pigeon .
('91', 59, 1, 5, 114493) Non vegetarians tell me that these can be used for food.
('91', 59, 1, 6, 114550) Incidentally, destruction on a large scale of these would be reflected in reduced destruction of field crops.
('91', 59, 1, 7, 114660) (4) To save food in order that it will be available for famine areas under the present system of ration appeals to very few.
('91', 59, 1, 8, 114785) There would be a good psychological appeal if the foodgrains saved are collected and guaranteed to be sent to the famine areas.
('91', 59, 1, 9, 114913) Whether the authorities act up to the first or not, it is one which those honest meat eaters who draw full vegetarian rations can.
('91', 59, 1, 10, 115044) They can easily part with a portion of their cereals for the benefit of those in need.
('91', 59, 1, 11, 115131) Mutual aid is the swiftest way of reaching relief to the needy in such cases.
('91', 59, 1, 12, 115209) The second follows from the first.
('91', 59, 1, 13, 115244) The third is contentious.
('91', 59, 1, 14, 115270) In a country where all life is largely held sacred and even when it is not, habit has made people reluctant to take any life, the suggestion may be difficult of adoption even by non vegetarians.
('91', 59, 1, 15, 115465) But a confirmed respecter of all life though I am, I have no difficulty in recommending for acceptance by meat eaters the suggestion that the correspondent’s wisdom has dictated.
('91', 59, 1, 16, 115644) I hope to examine an argument in Harijanbandhu advanced against the taking of even noxious life without any connection with food.
('91', 59, 2, 17, 115774) The fourth suggestion, though sound, is not likely to produce any tangible result because of the ruling corruption and the inefficiency and irresponsibility of the Government.
('91', 59, 2, 18, 115950) The difficulty will only be met when there is a national government which is responsible to the people and to which the people may look forward with confidence.
('91', 59, 2, 19, 116111) It has been long coming.
('91', 59, 2, 20, 116136) Will it ever come?
('91', 59, 2, 21, 116155) MUSSOORIE, May 29, 1946 Harijan, 9 6 1946
('91', 59, 3, 22, 116197) 1 Vide the following item.

('91', 60, 1, 2, 116265) 75. RELIGION V. NO RELIGION 1
('91', 60, 2, 3, 116295) A correspondent writes:
('91', 60, 3, 4, 116319) In the Harijanbandhu of the 5th May you have written that your non violence contemplates destruction of animals dangerous to mankind, such as leopards, wolves, snakes, scorpions, etc.
('91', 60, 4, 5, 116503) You do not believe in giving food to dogs, etc.
('91', 60, 4, 6, 116551) Several other people besides the Gujaratis look upon the feeding of dogs as a meritorious act.
('91', 60, 4, 7, 116646) Such a belief may not be justifiable in times of food shortage like the present.
('91', 60, 4, 8, 116727) Yet we must remember that these animals can be very useful to man.
('91', 60, 4, 9, 116794) One can feed them and take work out of them.
('91', 60, 4, 10, 116839) You had put 27 questions to Shri Raichandbhai from Durban.
('91', 60, 4, 11, 116898) One of these quesions was: “What should a seeker do when a sanke attacks him?” His answer was: “He should not kill the snake and, if it bites, he should let it do so.” 3 How is it that you speak differently now?
('91', 60, 4, 12, 117110) I have written a lot on this subject in the past.
('91', 60, 4, 13, 117160) At that time the topic was the killing of rabid dogs.
('91', 60, 4, 14, 117214) There was much discussion on the subject but all that seems to have been forgotten.
('91', 60, 4, 15, 117298) My non violence is not merely kindness to all living creatures.
('91', 60, 4, 16, 117362) The emphasis laid on the sacredness of subhuman life in Jainism is understandable.
('91', 60, 4, 17, 117445) But that can never mean that one is to be kind to this life in preference to human life.
('91', 60, 4, 18, 117534) While writing about the sacredness of such life, I take it that the sacredness of human life has been taken for granted.
('91', 60, 4, 19, 117655) The former has been over emphasized.
('91', 60, 4, 20, 117692) And, while putting it into practice, the idea has undergone distortion.
('91', 60, 4, 21, 117764) For instance, there are many who derive complete satisfaction in feeding ants.
('91', 60, 4, 22, 117843) It would appear that the theory has become a wooden, lifeless dogma.
('91', 60, 4, 23, 117912) Hypo crisy and distortion are passing current under the name of religion.
('91', 60, 4, 24, 117986) Ahimsa is the highest ideal.
('91', 60, 4, 25, 118015) It is meant of the brave, never for the cowardly.To benefit by others’ killing and delude oneself into the belief that one is being very religious and non violent, is sheer self deception.
('91', 60, 4, 26, 118204) A so called votary of non violence will not stay in a village, which is visited by a leopard every day, will run away and when someone has killed the leopard, will return to take charge of his hearth and home.
('91', 60, 4, 27, 118414) This is not non violence.
('91', 60, 4, 28, 118440) This is a coward’s violence.
('91', 60, 5, 29, 118469) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 9 6 1946. 2 Vide “The Monkey Nuisance”, 25 4 1946. 3 Vide “Questions on Religion”, before June 1894.
('91', 61, 0, 1, 118629) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 61, 1, 2, 118670) man who has killed the leopard has at least given proof of some bravery.
('91', 61, 1, 3, 118743) The man who takes advantage of the killing is a coward.
('91', 61, 1, 4, 118799) He can never expect to know true non violence.
('91', 61, 1, 5, 118846) In life it is impossible to eschew violence completely.
('91', 61, 1, 6, 118902) The question arises, where is one to draw the line?
('91', 61, 1, 7, 118954) The line cannot be the same for everyone.
('91', 61, 1, 8, 118996) Although essentially the principle is the same, yet every one applies it is his or her own way.
('91', 61, 1, 9, 119092) What is one man’s food can be another’s poison.
('91', 61, 1, 10, 119140) Meat eating is a sin for me.
('91', 61, 1, 11, 119169) Yet, for another person, who has always lived on meat and seen anything wrong in it, to give it up simply in order to copy me will be a sin.
('91', 61, 1, 12, 119310) If I wish to be an agriculturist and stay in the jungle, I will have to use the minimum unavoidable violence in order to protect my fields.
('91', 61, 1, 13, 119450) I will have to kill monkey, birds and insects which eat up my crops.
('91', 61, 1, 14, 119519) If I do not wish to do so myself, I will have to engage someone to do it for me.
('91', 61, 1, 15, 119600) There is not much difference between the two.
('91', 61, 1, 16, 119646) To allow crops to be eaten up by animals in the name of ahimsa while there is a famine in the land is certainly a sin.
('91', 61, 1, 17, 119765) Evil and good are relative terms.
('91', 61, 1, 18, 119799) What is good under certain conditions can become an evil or a sin under a different set of conditions.
('91', 61, 1, 19, 119902) Man is not to drown himself in the well of Shastras but he is to dive into their broad ocean and bring out pearls.
('91', 61, 1, 20, 120017) At every step he has to use discrimination as to what is ahimsa and what is himsa.
('91', 61, 1, 21, 120100) In this there is no room for shame or cowardice.
('91', 61, 1, 22, 120149) The poet has said that the road leading up to God is for the brave, never for the cowardly.
('91', 61, 1, 23, 120241) Finally, Raichandbhai’s advice to me was that if I had courage, if I wanted to see God face to face, I should let myself be bitten by a snake instead of killing it.
('91', 61, 1, 24, 120406) I have never killed a snake before or after receiving that letter.
('91', 61, 1, 25, 120473) That is no matter of credit for me.
('91', 61, 1, 26, 120509) My ideal is to be able to play with snakes and scorpions fearlessly.
('91', 61, 1, 27, 120578) But it is merely a wish so far.
('91', 61, 1, 28, 120610) Whether and when it will be realized I do not know.
('91', 61, 1, 29, 120662) Everywhere I have let my people kill both.
('91', 61, 1, 30, 120705) I could have prevented them if I had wished.
('91', 61, 1, 31, 120750) But how could I?
('91', 61, 1, 32, 120767) I did not have the courage to take them up with my own hands and teach my companions a lesson in fearlessness.
('91', 61, 1, 33, 120878) I am ashmed that I could not do so.
('91', 61, 1, 34, 120914) But my shame could not benefit them or me.
('91', 61, 1, 35, 120957) If Ramanama favours me I might attain that courage some day.
('91', 61, 1, 36, 121018) In the meantime.
('91', 61, 1, 37, 121035) I consider it my duty to act as I have stated above.
('91', 61, 1, 38, 121088) Religion is a thing to be lived.
('91', 61, 1, 39, 121121) It is not mere sophistry.
('91', 61, 1, 40, 121147) MUSSOORIE, May 29, 1946 Harijan, 9 6 1946

('91', 62, 3, 5, 121385) The circumstances are favourable.
('91', 62, 3, 6, 121419) What Bapa says is true.
('91', 62, 3, 7, 121443) By favourable circumstances.
('91', 62, 3, 8, 121472) Shri Thakkar Bapa probably means the establishment of a Congress Ministry.
('91', 62, 3, 9, 121547) That does not mean that henceforth reforms will be imposed upon the people.
('91', 62, 3, 10, 121623) There is the least room for the use of force in such things.
('91', 62, 3, 11, 121684) An evil like untouchability which ha found its way into the very marrow of the people’s bones, and that too in the name of religion, cannot be removed forcibly.
('91', 62, 3, 12, 121845) But an alien government uses its influence to further suppress the suppressed by force.
('91', 62, 3, 13, 121933) And when it tries to help them from a motive, pure or selfish, that too is done by the exercise of force.
('91', 62, 3, 14, 122039) The Congress has not estabilished its position through force.
('91', 62, 3, 15, 122101) It is a purely demorcatic organization.
('91', 62, 3, 16, 122141) Therefore, it is hoped that the Congress ministers will educate public measures.
('91', 62, 3, 17, 122222) This should result in an impetus to reforms like Harijan work in thier provinces and the forces standing in the way of such reforms would automatically disappear.
('91', 62, 3, 18, 122385) Moreover, intensive work in the limited area of the Bhusawal Taluka is likely to prove very fruitful.
('91', 62, 3, 19, 122487) We cannot reach the whole of India at one and the same time.
('91', 62, 3, 20, 122548) Wherever the workers have the requisite ability and influence, the work will proceed at a quicker pace.
('91', 62, 3, 21, 122652) Sound work in a small area is therefore likely to be copied by others and thus lead to an early success.
('91', 62, 3, 22, 122757) Let us hope that will be the result of the work which has been strarted in Bhusawal.

('91', 72, 5, 12, 142030) But, in order to avoid any misunderstanding, I expand my meaning.

('91', 73, 3, 9, 143741) IS LYING EVER JUSTIFLABLE?
('91', 73, 4, 10, 143768) Q. What do you say to the following from Bertrand Russell?
('91', 73, 4, 11, 143827) “I once in the course of a country walk saw a tired fox at the last stages of exhaustion still forcing himself to run.
('91', 73, 4, 12, 143946) A few minutes afterwards I saw the hunt.
('91', 73, 4, 13, 143987) They asked me if I had seen the fox, and I said I had.
('91', 73, 4, 14, 144042) They asked me which way he had gone, and I lied to them.
('91', 73, 4, 15, 144099) I do not think I should have been a better man if I had told the truth.” A. Bertrand Russell is a great writer and philosopher.
('91', 73, 4, 16, 144227) With all respect to him I must dissent from the view attributed to him.
('91', 73, 4, 17, 144299) He made the initial mistake of admitting that he had seen the fox.
('91', 73, 4, 18, 144366) He was not bound to answer the first question.
('91', 73, 4, 19, 144413) He could even refused to answer the second question unless he deliberately wanted to put the hunt off the track.
('91', 73, 4, 20, 144526) I have always maintained that nobody is bound always to answer quetions that may be put to him.
('91', 73, 4, 21, 144622) Truth telling admits of no exceptions.

('91', 77, 7, 11, 151153) Of course capitalists are among my friends and I take pride in the fact that they accept me as a friend.

('91', 77, 9, 15, 151461) 97. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('91', 77, 10, 16, 151492) MUSSOORIE, May 31, 1946
('91', 77, 11, 17, 151516) Speaking after prayers, Mahatma Gandhi expressed regret that yesterday due to inclement weather the audience had to be satisfied with Ramdhun only.
('91', 77, 11, 18, 151664) He was also sorry that some had to sit or stand on wet grass.
('91', 77, 11, 19, 151726) It would be good if there was a proper ground where everybody could go and pray in comfort.
('91', 77, 12, 20, 151818) He again suggested that Mussoorie should have a place where the poor could come and avail themeselves of the benefits of the hill climate whenever necessary.
('91', 77, 12, 21, 151976) I myself have become a Harijan by choice.
('91', 77, 12, 22, 152018) I would love to be in a place where Harijan too can come and dwell.
('91', 77, 12, 23, 152086) A Harijan by birth
('91', 77, 13, 24, 152105) 1 Of News Chronicle, London 2 The report in National Herald has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 78, 0, 1, 152242) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 79
('91', 78, 1, 2, 152283) may repudiate his varna but how can I who have become a Harijan by choice?
('91', 78, 1, 3, 152358) I have not hesitated to suggest to caste Hindus that today they have all to become atishudras, if the canker of caste feeling is to be eradicated from Hinduism and Hinduism is not to perish from the face of the earth.
('91', 78, 1, 4, 152576) If there were such a place in Mussoorie itself, where even Harijan would be welcome, he would rather stay there if ever he came to Mussoorie again.
('91', 78, 1, 5, 152724) In answer to a similar suggestion at Panchani, the people there were planning to have a place of that type.
('91', 78, 1, 6, 152832) He was glad to inform the gathering that there was some talk already of a com mittee of the citizens of Mussoorie being formed for that purpose.
('91', 78, 1, 7, 152977) What, however exercised his mind even more was the impending famine.
('91', 78, 1, 8, 153046) He reminded his fashionable audience of the coffin at their feast.
('91', 78, 1, 9, 153113) As a matter of fact the famine was already in the land.
('91', 78, 1, 10, 153169) Crores were not getting enough to eat.
('91', 78, 1, 11, 153208) Rich people were perhaps ready to give money, but no one could eat money.
('91', 78, 1, 12, 153282) There was not enough food in the country.
('91', 78, 1, 13, 153324) Whatever there was could not be transported quickly to the deficit areas.
('91', 78, 1, 14, 153398) Such was the bankruptcy of the Government.
('91', 78, 1, 15, 153441) Then again there were places where people went hungry in spite of the fact that the food was stored on the spot.
('91', 78, 1, 16, 153554) Then reason was all round corruption and the greed of our own people.
('91', 78, 1, 17, 153624) He appealed to those who were well off and could afford to get somehow whatever they wanted, to spare every grain of foodstuff that they could.
('91', 78, 1, 18, 153768) If the people co operated and there was no black marketing and corruption, possibly there was enough food in the land to enable them to tide over that crisis.
('91', 78, 1, 19, 153927) There were some who did not agree with him and main tained that if we did not get food from other countries we could not avoid starvation and death.
('91', 78, 1, 20, 154076) He was not of that opinion.
('91', 78, 1, 21, 154104) When other contries sent them supplies it would take time for the supplies to reach India in the first instance and even after they were landed in the ports, would take about six weeks to transport them to the needed areas.
('91', 78, 1, 22, 154328) The only real remedy was self help and co operation among all and disappearance of corruption.
('91', 78, 1, 23, 154423) He appealed to the well to do men and women of Mussoorie to save every grain they could for the famishing people.
('91', 78, 1, 24, 154537) If all voluntarily restricted themselves absolutely to what was needed for their health, they would be well able to tide over their difficulties.
('91', 78, 2, 25, 154683) National Herald, 2 6 1946, and Harijan, 9 6 1946

('91', 83, 6, 12, 162202) 105. INSTRUCTIVE CONVERSATION ON KHADI 2
('91', 83, 7, 13, 162243) A khadi worker writes:
('91', 83, 8, 14, 162266) I give below a recent conversation between the manager of a Khadi Bhandar and some customers.
('91', 83, 8, 15, 162360) Should khadi be sold to such persons?
('91', 83, 9, 16, 162398) Q. “is this yarn spun by you?”
('91', 83, 10, 17, 162429) A. “No I have bought eight hanks for Rs. 10.”
('91', 83, 11, 18, 162475) Q. To a second customer: “Are you able to spin all this yarn?”
('91', 83, 12, 19, 162538) A. “No.
('91', 83, 12, 20, 162546) This is spun by my daughter.
('91', 83, 12, 21, 162575) We shell yarn too at the rate of 12 annas per hank.”
('91', 83, 13, 22, 162628) Q. To a third: “You cannot buy khadi unless you produce the requisite quantity of yarn.”
('91', 83, 14, 23, 162717) A. “It does not matter.
('91', 83, 14, 24, 162741) So long as I cannot get the yarn, I will buy uncertified khadi.”
('91', 83, 15, 25, 162806) Q. To a fourth: “Why do you buy khadi?”
('91', 83, 16, 26, 162846) A. “Because it is easy to procure.”
('91', 83, 17, 27, 162882) Q. To a fifth: “You are not a regular wearer of khadi.
('91', 83, 17, 28, 162937) What will you do with what you have bought?”
('91', 83, 18, 29, 162982) A. “Today khadi is looked upon as being in the fashion.”
('91', 83, 19, 30, 163039) Q. To a sixth: “You do not spin yourself.
('91', 83, 19, 31, 163081) From where then comes this yarn?”
('91', 83, 20, 32, 163115) 1 Vide the preceding item 2 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 9 6 1946
('91', 84, 0, 1, 163206) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 85
('91', 84, 1, 2, 163247) A. “A good friend of mine provides me with yarn.”
('91', 84, 2, 3, 163297) Q. To a seventh: “Why do you always wear either silk or wool khadi?”
('91', 84, 3, 4, 163366) A. “Because I do not have to give yarn for these.”
('91', 84, 4, 5, 163417) Q. To an eighth: “You have bought a large quantity of khadi.
('91', 84, 4, 6, 163478) What will you do with it all?”
('91', 84, 5, 7, 163509) A. “This will last me two or three years.
('91', 84, 5, 8, 163551) After that it will be seen whether I can get any or not.” The above questions and answers are revealing.
('91', 84, 5, 9, 163656) If the new policy in regard to khadi is correct and khadi customers are of the above nature, it proves the necessity for the abolition of the khadi clause from the Congress Constitution.
('91', 84, 5, 10, 163843) It is worthy of note that the questions and answers concern eight persons.
('91', 84, 5, 11, 163918) The Charkha Sangh need not cater for the needs of a single one of them.
('91', 84, 5, 12, 163990) The Spinners’ Association exists only for the poor.
('91', 84, 5, 13, 164042) Those who wear khadi, do so either for the sake of the poor or for winning swaraj or both.
('91', 84, 5, 14, 164133) The eight customers mentioned above are concerned with neither.
('91', 84, 5, 15, 164197) If the Charkha Sangh is to prove the rightness of the ideal for which khadi stands, then its workers must be loyal enough to the new policy and not fear even the clossing down of the sales bhandars.
('91', 84, 5, 16, 164396) They must have the strength to bear any consequences in order to set right the mistakes of the past.
('91', 84, 5, 17, 164497) The above conversation also holds a warning to the managers of the bhandars to be wide awake.
('91', 84, 5, 18, 164591) They should become experts in the science of khadi and be prepared to teach customers the inner meaning of khadi with patience and humility.
('91', 84, 5, 19, 164732) This may take time but it is worth while.
('91', 84, 5, 20, 164774) If there is faith in the power of khadi I have no doubt that we shall remain steadfast and thereby inspire others the belief also.
('91', 84, 5, 21, 164905) But if workers themeselves lack faith then the claim for khadi will fall to the ground.
('91', 84, 5, 22, 164993) I have taken for granted that the conversation has been truly reported.
('91', 84, 6, 23, 165065) MUSSOORIE, June 1, 1946 Harijan, 9 6 1946

('91', 89, 4, 7, 172956) 111. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 89, 5, 8, 172988) MUSSOORIE, June 1, 1946 2
('91', 89, 6, 9, 173014) Addressing the meeting, Mahatma Gandhi said that it had given him much pleasure to come there for prayers.
('91', 89, 6, 10, 173121) He had been told the poor and labouring classes to which he himself belonged lived round about the place and it was difficult for them to come to where he was staying.
('91', 89, 6, 11, 173289) So he had agreed to hold the prayer meeting in the grounds of Silverton Hotel.
('91', 89, 6, 12, 173368) He would have loved to walk up to the place of prayer but that was not possible and much against his wish he had to motor down to the place.
('91', 89, 7, 13, 173509) The benefit one derived from community prayers had to be experienced rather than described, added Mahatma Gandhi.
('91', 89, 7, 14, 173623) He said that his experience of nearly 50 years had made him a confirmed advocate of community prayers.
('91', 89, 7, 15, 173726) The work done by two mean together was more than the sum of the output of each separately.
('91', 89, 7, 16, 173817) Similarly, the benefit derived from community prayers was incalculable.
('91', 89, 8, 17, 173889) Gandhiji reminded them about what he had said on the need for having a place for the poor people in Mussoorie.
('91', 89, 8, 18, 174000) He did not expect them to build palatial buildings, but they should be clean and well planned, so that even a man like him could come and stay there.
('91', 89, 8, 19, 174150) He could not stand dirty clothes, dirty houses and surroundings and dirty lavatories.
('91', 89, 8, 20, 174236) There was no reason why the poor should have to put up with dirt.
('91', 89, 9, 21, 174302) Their lavatories should be as clean as a bedroom or a library.
('91', 89, 9, 22, 174365) Defecation was not a dirty process.
('91', 89, 9, 23, 174401) It was a necessary physiological action of the body as was eating and they should have proper and clean places for it.
('91', 89, 9, 24, 174520) There should not be a trace of dirt or foul smell in it.
('91', 89, 9, 25, 174577) You might think that I am speaking with my tongue in my cheek.
('91', 89, 9, 26, 174640) The fact is that a meticulous sense of cleanliness, not only personal but also in regard to one’s surroundings is the alpha and omega of corporate life.
('91', 89, 9, 27, 174793) We in India have made a ritual of cleanliness.
('91', 89, 9, 28, 174840) But we have yet to make good our claim that we possess the sanitary instinct.
('91', 89, 9, 29, 174918) I have seen how we foul the banks of our holy rivers.
('91', 89, 9, 30, 174972) The Ganges water is regarded by us as
('91', 89, 10, 31, 175010) 1 The Hindustan Times report has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 89, 10, 32, 175116) 2 From Hindustan, 4 6 1946
('91', 90, 0, 1, 175143) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 91
('91', 90, 1, 2, 175184) holy, capable of washing off our sins.
('91', 90, 1, 3, 175223) The idea is symbolical.
('91', 90, 1, 4, 175247) Just as water washed the body clean, a devotee prays and hopes for the cleansing of the heart by the water of life.
('91', 90, 1, 5, 175363) But if we contaminate our holy rivers as we do, how can their water effect inner cleansing?
('91', 90, 2, 6, 175455) He had heard that the living conditions of the labourers in Mussoorie were deplorable.
('91', 90, 2, 7, 175542) They lived in small, overcrowded, dirty and evilsmelling rooms.
('91', 90, 2, 8, 175606) No one could afford to overlook that.
('91', 90, 2, 9, 175644) All life was one.
('91', 90, 2, 10, 175662) If they cleaned their own homes and neglected their neighbours’ they would have to pay the price in the form of epidemics and the like.
('91', 90, 2, 11, 175798) In the West they had been able to rid their countries of plague.
('91', 90, 2, 12, 175863) He himself had witnessed in South Africa how by prompt and energetic action the Johannesburg Municipality was able to arrest the outbreak of plague so effectively that it never came back.
('91', 90, 2, 13, 176051) But in India it returned again and again —it had become almost endemic.
('91', 90, 2, 14, 176123) The remedy lies in our own hands We must not only observe the rules of health and hygiene in our own persons but we must see that our poor neighbours do so too To neglect to do so is a sin for which we cannot escape the penalty.
('91', 90, 2, 15, 176352) I do not grudge the rich their riches provided that they do not forget the poor and share their riches with them and provided their riches are not gained at the expense of the impoverishment of others.
('91', 90, 3, 16, 176554) The Hindustan Times, 3 6 1946 and 4 6 1946, and Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 93, 1, 5, 181604) But for the person who has unquestioning faith in the power of Ramanama there is no other support but that, for when one has faith in its power Ramanama there is no other support but that, for when one has faith in its power Ramanama ceases to be a matter of reason and becomes solely a matter of the heart.
('91', 93, 1, 6, 181912) I feel every moment that for such a person Rama is the only King of his heart, and he who has Rama as his Lord cannot waste a single moment of his time.
('91', 93, 1, 7, 182065) And violation of brahmacharya even in thought means for that moment at least the man’s attention had wandered, and that, therefore, that moment was wasted.
('91', 93, 1, 8, 182221) I am not writing separately to Dhiru today.
('91', 93, 1, 9, 182265) This is to save time.

('91', 97, 9, 16, 187918) 124. TALK WITH AZAD HIND DAL VOLUNTEERS
('91', 97, 10, 17, 187958) MUSSOORIE, June 2, 1946
('91', 97, 11, 18, 187982) Seeing about 100 Azad Hind Dal volunteers in uniform who came to salute him .
('91', 97, 11, 19, 188060) Mahatma Gandhi expressed pleasure and said they looked very smart.
('91', 97, 12, 20, 188127) When apprised of the working of the Dal in the district the Mahatma asked the volunteers: Do you want to ask any questions?
('91', 97, 13, 21, 188251) A volunteer .
('91', 97, 13, 22, 188265) said, “Sir, .
('91', 97, 13, 23, 188279) please tell us when we are getting swaraj.” Mahatma Gandhi laughed heartily and replied: There is no doubt that we are getting swaraj but when, it is diffi cult to answer.
('91', 97, 13, 24, 188451) Anyway it would not be much longer, hence we are eager to establish swaraj as early as possible and trying to do it.
('91', 97, 14, 25, 188568) Another volunteer .
('91', 97, 14, 26, 188588) asked, “Do you still hold the same opinion which you expressed recently regarding the Cabinet Mission’s declaration?” Yes, because the Mission’s object is good, its members’ hearts are sincere and their is a sincere attempt to evolve a workable scheme of Indian independence out of the conflicting interestsand party aims.
('91', 97, 14, 27, 188911) This I say in spite of what the Delegation said.
('91', 97, 14, 28, 188960) I am primarily
('91', 98, 0, 1, 188975) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 99
('91', 98, 1, 2, 189016) concerned with their main plan.
('91', 98, 1, 3, 189048) We fail to appreciate the plan because we do not recognize our own weaknesses and failings.
('91', 98, 1, 4, 189140) We must be bold enough to confess our weaknesses and incompetences.
('91', 98, 2, 5, 189208) Another boy .
('91', 98, 2, 6, 189222) said, “If you think that we are still incompetent for swaraj on account of our shortcomings, then the British people will never give it and we will never have it, they being very clever and diplomatic.
('91', 98, 2, 7, 189424) What is the remedy in that case?” I do not say we are quite incompetent for independence but whatever I say about our own shortcomings is based on the reading of the mental working and behaviour of a few of our own people.
('91', 98, 2, 8, 189647) There are vast numbers, in fact crores, of our people of whom we know nothing.
('91', 98, 2, 9, 189726) We don’t know what they may say or do at a particular moment.
('91', 98, 2, 10, 189788) Freedom is not a matter of gift nor has the Delegation come here to give us freedom.
('91', 98, 2, 11, 189873) It would be too much to expect from them.
('91', 98, 2, 12, 189915) We have to evolve freedom from amongst ourselves rather out of our own divergences and differences and this is the crux of the matter.
('91', 98, 2, 13, 190050) They certainly have not come to deceive us this time.
('91', 98, 2, 14, 190104) This is how I take it.
('91', 98, 3, 15, 190127) What is the meaning of your “Do or Die” slogan of 1942 1?
('91', 98, 3, 16, 190185) It was taken out of the context.
('91', 98, 3, 17, 190218) I had also said that we should work for swaraj and die in the attempt for it.
('91', 98, 4, 18, 190296) The last question was regarding non violence.
('91', 98, 5, 19, 190342) Mahatma Gandhi said it was in 1920 that non violence was deliberately adopted as a method of obtaining swaraj but we could not translate it into practice nor could we stick to it steadfastly.
('91', 98, 5, 20, 190534) We only have the non violence of the coward and not of the brave.
('91', 98, 5, 21, 190600) We have not been non violent all through.
('91', 98, 5, 22, 190642) The discussion had finished when one of the volunteers fainted and fell down.
('91', 98, 6, 23, 190720) Mahatma Gandhi remarked: “You have asked too much and let us finish for today”, and left to see the boy.
('91', 98, 7, 24, 190825) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 6 1946
('91', 98, 8, 25, 190856) 1 Vide “Speech at A. I. C. C. Meeting”, 8 8 1942 and “Message to the Country”, 9 8 1942. 2 Ramprasad Gorkha, captain of the volunteers, requested Gandhiji to do something for the twelve Gorkhas who were court martialled and sentenced for mutiny in the Gorkha lines.

('91', 99, 1, 2, 191164) 125. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 99, 2, 3, 191196) MUSSOORIE, June 2, 1946
('91', 99, 3, 4, 191220) Gandhiji congratulated the audience on the exemplary behaviour at prayer time and thanked workers for excellent loudspeaker arrangments.
('91', 99, 3, 5, 191357) He reminded them of the debt the Hindu society owed to the Harijans.
('91', 99, 3, 6, 191426) A sin committed in the name of religion was doubly bad, he added.
('91', 99, 3, 7, 191492) The least that they could do for them was to subscribe money for their cause.
('91', 99, 3, 8, 191570) He also asked them to contribute liberally for building better quarters for the labourers and a Harijan dharmashala.
('91', 99, 3, 9, 191687) He, however, warned them against an enthusiastic beginning and a poor ending.
('91', 99, 3, 10, 191765) Ramanama is not for the few; it is for all.
('91', 99, 3, 11, 191809) He who takes His name lays by a rich store for himself, and it is inexhautible.
('91', 99, 3, 12, 191889) The more you draw upon it, the more it increases.
('91', 99, 3, 13, 191939) It is infinite.
('91', 99, 3, 14, 191955) As the Upanishad says, you take infinite out of infinite and infinite remains behind.
('91', 99, 3, 15, 192041) 2 It is the unfailing panacea for all the ills, physical, mental and spiritual to which man is subject.
('91', 99, 3, 16, 192145) Rama is only one of the numerous names of God.
('91', 99, 3, 17, 192192) In fact there are as many names of God as there are human beings in the world.
('91', 99, 3, 18, 192271) You may substitute Krishna for Rama or you can substitute for it any of His countless names and it will make no difference.
('91', 99, 4, 19, 192395) He himself had got the mantra of Ramanama, he said, from his nurse when he was a child.
('91', 99, 4, 20, 192483) I used to be frightened of ghosts and evil spirits in the dark.
('91', 99, 4, 21, 192547) My nurse told me, “If you repeat Ramanama all the ghosts and evil spirits will vanish.” I accepted her advice with all the unquestioning faith of a child.
('91', 99, 4, 22, 192702) That cured me of my cowardice.
('91', 99, 5, 23, 192733) If that was the experience of a child, how much more would the grown ups stand to gain by it if they repeated Ramanama with understanding and faith, he asked.
('91', 99, 6, 24, 192892) But the condition was that it must come from the heart.
('91', 99, 6, 25, 192948) Do evil thoughts possess you, or are you tormented by lust or
('91', 99, 7, 26, 193010) 1 The Hindustan Times report has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 99, 7, 27, 193116) 2 The invocatory mantra in Svetasvataropanisad reads : “That (the Brahman) is whole.
('91', 99, 7, 28, 193201) This (the Universe) is whole.
('91', 99, 7, 29, 193231) From the Whole has come out the Whole.
('91', 99, 7, 30, 193270) When whole is taken away from the Whole.
('91', 99, 7, 31, 193311) What is left is Whole.”
('91', 100, 0, 1, 193335) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 101
('91', 100, 1, 2, 193377) Then there is no charm against it like Ramanama.
('91', 100, 1, 3, 193426) Supposing you are tempted to amass a big fortune by some easy and dishonest means.
('91', 100, 1, 4, 193509) If you have faith in Ramanama you will say to yourself, ‘Why should I amass for my wife and children riches which they might squander away?
('91', 100, 1, 5, 193649) Why not leave them a legacy in the shape of sound character and sound education and training that will enable them to earn their living by honest industry and body labour?’ Ceaseless repetition of Ramanama will dispel your delusion and false attachment and the living realization will dawn on you that you were a fool to hanker after millions for the sake of your dear ones instead of offering them the priceless treasure of His name which frees one from all bondage and wanderings.
('91', 100, 1, 6, 194132) Filled with the joy of that realization such a person will tell his wife and children, ‘I have not brought for you the treasure I had set out for but something infinitely richer.’‘Where is it, show it to us?’ they will say incredulously.‘It is the Name which is richer than all treasures’ he will reply, ‘because it quenches the thirst for all riches.
('91', 100, 1, 7, 194484) It is enshrined in my heart.’

('91', 100, 3, 9, 194568) 126. ITS LANGUAGE 1
('91', 100, 4, 10, 194588) A correspondent writes: 2
('91', 100, 5, 11, 194614) It would be fitting if our constitution were to be drawn up in our national language.
('91', 100, 5, 12, 194700) But one difficulty will be that few, if any, of the judges of our High and Federal Courts know Hindustani.
('91', 100, 5, 13, 194807) They will, therefore, have to have an English translation for their use.
('91', 100, 6, 14, 194880) The other question that will arise is whether the members of the Constituent Assembly will know enough Hindustani to grasp its essentials.
('91', 100, 6, 15, 195019) This letter appeals to me.
('91', 100, 6, 16, 195046) Why should our constitution be in English?
('91', 100, 6, 17, 195089) It should certainly be in an Indian language and, in my opinion, that language can only be Hindustani which crores can easily understand.
('91', 100, 6, 18, 195227) In addition such an act will electrify the masses.
('91', 100, 6, 19, 195278) As circumstances are, it is right that the Constituent Assembly should make an English translation of the document and, indeed, there should be translations also in every one of the provincial languages.
('91', 100, 6, 20, 195482) The second point raised by the writer is also apt.
('91', 100, 6, 21, 195533) But since the

('91', 101, 1, 2, 195767) members of the Constituent Assembly will be chosen by the present legislative bodies, it will be open to the latter to elect, so far as possible, only those persons who are conversant with Hindustani and thus act on the correspondent’s letter.
('91', 101, 2, 3, 196011) MUSSOORIE, June 3, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 101, 3, 4, 196054) 127. URDU, THE LANGUAGE OF BOTH?
('91', 101, 4, 5, 196087) 1. You are making strenuous efforts to get every Indian, particularly Hindus with whom you naturally come most in daily contact, to learn Urdu.
('91', 101, 4, 6, 196231) Similarly, is any Mohammedan striving to induce Muslims to learn Hindi?
('91', 101, 4, 7, 196303) If not, will not the result of your labours be that Urdu will become the language of both and Hindi will remain the medium solely for Hindus?
('91', 101, 4, 8, 196445) Will not this be a disservice to Hindi?
('91', 101, 5, 9, 196485) 2. The Urdu equivalent of the Hindi word is invariably given in brackets in the Hindustani Prachar publications, but the converse is not done.
('91', 101, 5, 10, 196628) Does that not signify a desire to teach Urdu by force to Hindus?
('91', 101, 6, 11, 196693) 3. There are any number of Persian and Arabic words used in these publications.
('91', 101, 6, 12, 196773) Do you think they are understood by the general run of people?
('91', 101, 6, 13, 196836) For example adab 2, adab 3, etakad 4.
('91', 101, 7, 14, 196874) 4. If Hindustani is in fact a language, why in your educational readers is there such a difference in terminology in the Urdu and Hindi editions?
('91', 101, 8, 15, 197020) 5. My fear is that the lakhs of Southern Indians who have so far been trying to learn Hindi will be so scared of the Urdu script that they will learn neither and in the end the work hitherto done by the Hindustani Prachar Sabha will be completely wiped out.
('91', 101, 8, 16, 197278) 1. Effort are being made that those who are unacquainted with the Urdu form should learn it and vice versa with those who do not know the Hindi form.
('91', 101, 8, 17, 197428) It is true that my contacts are more with Hindi knowing Hindus.
('91', 101, 8, 18, 197492) But that does not worry me.
('91', 101, 8, 19, 197520) Hindus are not likely to forget their Hindi.
('91', 101, 8, 20, 197565) In fact I believe that their Hindi will be enriched by their knowledge of Urdu.
('91', 101, 8, 21, 197645) The majority of Indians whether Hindus or Mussalmans, generally know best the languages of their provinces
('91', 101, 9, 22, 197752) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 16 6 1946. 2 Politeness, literature 3 Respectful greetings 4 Faith
('91', 102, 0, 1, 197875) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 103
('91', 102, 1, 2, 197917) which contain a large number of Sanskrit words.
('91', 102, 1, 3, 197965) I myself have neither the fear nor the desire that everyone will, as a result of my efforts, learn the Urdu form to the exclusion of Hindi.
('91', 102, 1, 4, 198105) Desire or no desire, whatever is natural will happen.
('91', 102, 1, 5, 198159) The attempt to have a wise blending of the two forms for a national tongue is, in my opinion, a good venture in every way.
('91', 102, 1, 6, 198282) 2. I have not read all the publications of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('91', 102, 1, 7, 198355) It is commendable if the Urdu equivalents of some Hindi words are given in brackets.
('91', 102, 1, 8, 198440) This only means that in the opinion of the writers of the books these words are not commonly known.
('91', 102, 1, 9, 198540) That the Hindi equivalents are not given signifies that those Urdu works have become current coin in Hindi.
('91', 102, 1, 10, 198648) It is a pity that a learned person like the correspondent should have such suspicions.
('91', 102, 1, 11, 198735) Suspicion is not an attribute of learning.
('91', 102, 1, 12, 198778) 3. This does not seem to be a correct charge.
('91', 102, 1, 13, 198824) And even if it were true, what harm can there be?
('91', 102, 1, 14, 198874) The introduction of new words into any language enriches it.
('91', 102, 1, 15, 198935) The words of Latin origin that came into the English language after the Norman conquest added to its virility.
('91', 102, 1, 16, 199046) Whatever was not good or unnecessary or forced did not remain.
('91', 102, 1, 17, 199109) The words given by way of example by the correspondent are known to all Hindi lovers in the North and have taken their rightful place in Hindi.
('91', 102, 1, 18, 199253) It is true that they are new for Southern Indians and therefore their Sanskrit equivalents should be and are given.
('91', 102, 1, 19, 199369) The truth is that the Hindustani Prachar Sabha has neither antagonism towards one nor partiality towards the other.
('91', 102, 1, 20, 199485) Both forms are there and will remain and these should not present any difficulty.
('91', 102, 1, 21, 199567) But, of course, if there is jealoousy and antagonnism between the two, Hindustani will never come into being.
('91', 102, 1, 22, 199677) And such an eventuality will be a bad thing for India.
('91', 102, 1, 23, 199732) 4. Hindustani existed at one time.
('91', 102, 1, 24, 199767) The present effort is directed to revive it through a wise mixture of Hindi and Urdu and let it grow thereby.
('91', 102, 1, 25, 199877) Neither Hindi[ lovers] nor Urdu lovers should sorrow over this.
('91', 102, 1, 26, 199941) Hindi and Urdu are sisters.
('91', 102, 1, 27, 199969) What harm, therefore, if they mix with each other?
('91', 102, 1, 28, 200020) It cannot be a matter of surprise that in this transition stage there should be a difference of terminology in Hindi and Urdu books.
('91', 102, 1, 29, 200153) 5. My experience is quite contrary to that of the writer.
('91', 102, 1, 30, 200211) I have not known anyone who has given up learning either script because of the insistence on the Urdu script.
('91', 102, 1, 31, 200321) Nor do I fear that this will ever be
('91', 103, 0, 1, 200358) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 103, 1, 2, 200400) My appeal to the writer is to divest himself of his prejudices.
('91', 103, 1, 3, 200464) MUSSOORIE, June 3 1, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 103, 2, 4, 200509) 128. LANGUAGE AND THOUGHT
('91', 103, 3, 5, 200535) I quote the following letter 2 for the benefit of colleagues work ing in Harijanbandhu, after omitting the author’s name.
('91', 103, 3, 6, 200657) If I had the time, I would have given a detailed reply to this letter in Harijanbandhu itself.
('91', 103, 3, 7, 200752) But I have no time for that.
('91', 103, 3, 8, 200781) I am interested in language as such.
('91', 103, 3, 9, 200818) What I mean is that whatever language one may speak or write one’s pronunciation should be clear and the grammar perfect.
('91', 103, 3, 10, 200940) I have not been able to reach this ideal in the case of any language.
('91', 103, 3, 11, 201010) Gujarati being my mother tongue, naturally, I have love for it.
('91', 103, 3, 12, 201074) But everyone knows how imperfect my Gujarati is.
('91', 103, 3, 13, 201123) My grammar is weak, my spelling indifferent.
('91', 103, 3, 14, 201168) What need I say about my Hindi, Urdu and Hindustani?
('91', 103, 3, 15, 201221) Yet I have allowed myself to be the president of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('91', 103, 3, 16, 201300) I spent years running after English and lived for many years in the country of Englishmen.
('91', 103, 3, 17, 201391) The English language is glorious in its own place.
('91', 103, 3, 18, 201442) It is an international language.
('91', 103, 3, 19, 201475) I am also fond of it.
('91', 103, 3, 20, 201497) But I am conscious that my knowledge of it is also imperfect.
('91', 103, 3, 21, 201559) What could be the reason for such lack of organization?
('91', 103, 3, 22, 201615) It is obvious.
('91', 103, 3, 23, 201630) Language too has its own place like everything else.
('91', 103, 3, 24, 201683) Language is an adornment in its proper place.
('91', 103, 3, 25, 201729) It is a vehicle for thought; and not vice versa.
('91', 103, 3, 26, 201778) It is the thought contained in it that adorns the language.
('91', 103, 3, 27, 201838) Language does not have that power independently.
('91', 103, 3, 28, 201887) Realizing this I run after ideas and drag the language behind.
('91', 103, 3, 29, 201950) If the ideas are clear, grammar, spelling, etc., will come round automatically or may be the reader will generously put up with the looseness of language.
('91', 103, 3, 30, 202105) At present it is not possible for me to take up this dual responsibility.
('91', 103, 3, 31, 202179) I can be responsible for my ideas.
('91', 103, 3, 32, 202214) But if I wait.
('91', 103, 3, 33, 202229) to adorn my language, Harijan would suffer.
('91', 103, 3, 34, 202273) I manage with the existing
('91', 103, 4, 35, 202300) 1 From Harijan Sevak.
('91', 103, 4, 36, 202322) Harijan, however, has “4”.
('91', 103, 4, 37, 202349) 2 Not translated here.
('91', 103, 4, 38, 202372) The correspondent had complained of indifferent translation, incorrect transliteration into Gujarati and incompete rendering of Sanskrit quotations in Harijanbandhu.
('91', 104, 0, 1, 202538) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 105
('91', 104, 1, 2, 202580) If I were to examine [my work] from the point of view of the language I would envy so many journals.
('91', 104, 1, 3, 202681) Not one issue of Harijan would stand comparison with some other journals.
('91', 104, 1, 4, 202755) I should be happy if the language of all the issues of Harijan was chaste.
('91', 104, 1, 5, 202830) This is the reason why I have published the foregoing letter.
('91', 104, 1, 6, 202892) Writers and translators of Harijanbandhu should read and ponder over it to polish their language with due perseverence and render their versions and translations as perfect as possible.
('91', 104, 1, 7, 203078) The criticism made by the writer is friendly and the readers should take it in the same spirit and make whatever improvements they can.
('91', 104, 1, 8, 203214) A well wisher like this correspondent should not rest content with criticizing the work but should from time to time offer suggestions from which others can learn.
('91', 104, 1, 9, 203378) The late Sastriar had done it and I had published his article.
('91', 104, 2, 10, 203441) In the end I should like to say that an incorrect translation of a Sanskrit quotation must not go.
('91', 104, 2, 11, 203540) But sometimes though the original may be quoted the purpose is better served by including a Gujarati rendering at the same time.
('91', 104, 2, 12, 203669) I could not find time to examine whether it was so in the present case 2. The correspondent should be tolerant of the pronunciation of foreign languages.
('91', 104, 2, 13, 203823) Where the spelling does not correspond to the pronunciation, the translator would follow the spelling and this should be the normal practice.
('91', 104, 2, 14, 203965) If it were not so the translator would be overburdened.
('91', 104, 2, 15, 204021) As regards proper names, utter chaos prevails.
('91', 104, 2, 16, 204068) When they are transliterated either into Gujarati or into any other Indian language the safest way seems to be to conform the pronunciation to the spelling.
('91', 104, 2, 17, 204225) MUSSOORIE, June 3, 1946 Harijanbandhu, 16 6 1946
('91', 104, 3, 18, 204274) 1 Vide “The Schoolmaster Abroad”, 13 2 1933. 2 The correspondent had criticized the English rendering of the Saskrit quotations in Sushila Nayyar’s article “Meeting Sastriar” published in Harijan 28 4 1946.

('91', 107, 3, 4, 206862) I am glad to learn that the question of improving the living conditions of labourer and building a dharmashala for the poor is engaging the active attention of some of the prominent residents of Mussoorie.
('91', 107, 3, 5, 207068) But I am sorry to hear that even in a matter which should be common concern there is party feeling.

('91', 107, 4, 12, 207700) 134. MINDFULNESS THE REMEDY
('91', 107, 5, 13, 207728) The realization that the mere desire for truth and non violence is not sufficient to make people non violent made me think that.
('91', 107, 5, 14, 207857) a way must be taught, which would enable people to rebuild themselves fundmentally.
('91', 107, 6, 15, 207941) External observance like prayers, handicrafts, etc., are not the efficient means for truth and kindness.
('91', 107, 6, 16, 208046) Only by inner and well directed effort can a man rebuild himself.
('91', 107, 6, 17, 208112) I have in mind the way of mindfulness, recommended by Buddha.
('91', 107, 6, 18, 208174) .He has gone to the point of saying that this way can bring a man to prefection in seven days.
('91', 107, 7, 19, 208269) The way of mindfulness consists in being constantly observant, conscious, attentive, watchful, awake, uninterruptedly aware of the mental and emotional content of our consiousness and of its expressions through the body.
('91', 107, 8, 20, 208490) You can easily try it out on yourself.
('91', 107, 8, 21, 208529) Within a week you will be convinced that Buddha has left with us a toll of unparalelled efficacy for rebuilding ourselves truly and permanently.
('91', 107, 9, 22, 208674) 1 It being Gandhiji’s silence day his written message was read out after the prayers.
('91', 108, 0, 1, 208760) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 109
('91', 108, 1, 2, 208802) Thus writes Mr. Frydman 1, better known to the public as Bharatanand.
('91', 108, 1, 3, 208872) I reproduce it for what it is worth.
('91', 108, 1, 4, 208909) I have not fallen in love with it because this too has caught on.
('91', 108, 1, 5, 208975) If it was a seven days’ work, why is it that it has so few witnesses in the world today?
('91', 108, 1, 6, 209064) In so far as it is an aid, it is in general vogue and takes its place among the other remedies, whether it is called mindfulness vigilance or meditation.
('91', 108, 1, 7, 209218) It does not take the place of prayer or the mala, 2 or any other outward practice.
('91', 108, 1, 8, 209301) It is in addition to these outward observances so long as the latter are not for show.
('91', 108, 1, 9, 209388) Indeed, prayer is purely an inward act.
('91', 108, 1, 10, 209428) Those who found in Ramanama the talisman knew mindfulness and found by experience that Ramanama was the best of all the remedies adopted for the practice of Truth and Non violence.
('91', 108, 1, 11, 209609) MUSSOORIE, June 4, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 110, 2, 3, 211395) MUSSORIE, June 4, 1946
('91', 110, 3, 4, 211418) KANAM, I have your letter.
('91', 110, 3, 5, 211445) You are doing good work.
('91', 110, 3, 6, 211470) Why do you not do spinning?
('91', 110, 3, 7, 211498) You ask me to send you the list of books.
('91', 110, 3, 8, 211540) When you read the books available on the khadi science you will learn many new words, you will learn Gujarati and Hindi technical terms and you will also learn how much meaning is contained in khadi.
('91', 110, 3, 9, 211740) Show this letter to Vinoba and Bhansali and listen to what they say about khadi and ponder over it.
('91', 110, 3, 10, 211840) We should voluntarily and strictly follow the rules of an institution where we go, whether as guests or inmates.
('91', 110, 3, 11, 211953) That is what discipline means.
('91', 110, 3, 12, 211984) The term for displine in Gujarati and Hindi is shista, which however does not convey the full meaning of the English word.
('91', 110, 3, 13, 212107) Work done without discipline even if it is on a massive scale, is washed away.
('91', 110, 3, 14, 212186) The way the planets go round the sun is discipline.
('91', 110, 3, 15, 212238) If any planet, out of mischief, were to start going faster or rush too near to the sun, it would not only burn up but would destroy the whole solar system.
('91', 110, 3, 16, 212394) From this you may estimate the value of discipline.
('91', 110, 3, 17, 212446) It is certainly good that the Chimur people 1 have been released.
('91', 110, 3, 18, 212512) They deserved to be released.
('91', 110, 3, 19, 212542) But to command all that they did would amount to commending violence.
('91', 110, 3, 20, 212612) It would mean that we accepted it.
('91', 110, 3, 21, 212647) Now that they have all been released, uncle Bhansali should under stand this and make our Chimur friends understand.
('91', 110, 3, 22, 212764) I believe I shall be going to Panchgani after the 15th of this month.

('91', 112, 6, 20, 215802) 141. LETTER TO SARALABEHN A. SARABHAI
('91', 112, 7, 21, 215840) MUSSOORIE, June 4, 1946
('91', 112, 8, 22, 215864) DEAR SISTER, I have your letter.
('91', 112, 8, 23, 215897) The case of the late Manibehn indeed evokes sympathy.
('91', 112, 8, 24, 215951) As long as ignorance persists such cases are bound to happen in the world.
('91', 112, 8, 25, 216026) Our duty is only to remove the ignorance.
('91', 112, 8, 26, 216068) By this I don’t mean mere knowledge of the letters, but improvement of the mind.
('91', 112, 8, 27, 216149) I should welcome book knowledge to the extent it is incidental to such improvement.
('91', 112, 8, 28, 216233) I do not feel like writing anything in this regard in Harijan.

('91', 115, 1, 2, 219127) 145. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 115, 2, 3, 219159) MUSSOORIE, [June 4, 1946] 2
('91', 115, 3, 4, 219187) Gandhiji spoke of the poor rickshaw pullers and load carriers there.
('91', 115, 3, 5, 219256) They should be everyone’s concern.
('91', 115, 3, 6, 219291) They made life possible for the wealthy and yet the latter, while willing to take from them even the inhuman service of rickshaw pulling, did not care to see where and how they lived, what they ate and what they earned.
('91', 115, 3, 7, 219511) He had heard that these poor men lived in tiny rooms without adequate light and air; they did not want to reveal how many herded together into one room lest they should be evicted or fined.
('91', 115, 3, 8, 219701) They were dirtily clad as could be seen from the little crowd of them that had come to attend the prayers that evening.
('91', 115, 3, 9, 219821) But perhaps they had not the wherewithal to afford a change of clothes.
('91', 115, 3, 10, 219893) They might be like the woman in Bihar, when he first went there, who, when asked to wash herself and her clothes, said to Ba: “How can I bathe when I have not another sari to put on?“ It was the benden duty of those to whom God had given more than their needs to spend the extra money on those who were in want.
('91', 115, 3, 11, 220205) He had been told that the Congress Goverment was now in power and would see to it that labour quarters everywhere were rebuilt.
('91', 115, 3, 12, 220333) If they did so it would be a good thing.
('91', 115, 3, 13, 220374) It would be no more than their bare duty.
('91', 115, 3, 14, 220416) That would not, however, exonerate rickshaw riders from their duty.
('91', 115, 3, 15, 220484) Doctros had told him that these poor people pulled these vehicles for four years or so and the work was so hard they died soon after of lung and heart trouble.
('91', 115, 3, 16, 220644) How could the users be so callous as not to see that rickshaw pullers were properly housed and sufficiently paid and clothed and not overworked.
('91', 115, 4, 17, 220789) Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 115, 5, 18, 220808) 146. HINDUSTANI CRITICIZED
('91', 115, 6, 19, 220835) Shri Jivaji Desai has sent me samples of some criticisms of the edition in Urdu script of Harijan Sevak from both Hindi and Urdu newspapers.
('91', 115, 6, 20, 220976) They have made fun of its Hindustani.
('91', 115, 6, 21, 221014) Hindi critics opine that the articles are deliberately filled with unneccesary Urdu words and Urdu critics complain of the use of Sanskrit words which Muslims cannot understand.
('91', 115, 6, 22, 221192) I am glad of these criticisms.
('91', 115, 6, 23, 221223) Thus, why should the paper be called Harijan Sevak instead of Harijan Khidmatgar?Why Sampadak and not ‘Editor’ or Mudir and so on?
('91', 115, 6, 24, 221354) Lovers of Urdu believe that
('91', 115, 7, 25, 221382) 1 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 2 The source reports this after the speech of June 2 and before that of June 5.
('91', 116, 0, 1, 221507) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 117
('91', 116, 1, 2, 221549) Hindustani and Urdu are synonymous.
('91', 116, 1, 3, 221585) Lovers of Hindi feel the same conversely even when it is written in the Urdu script.
('91', 116, 1, 4, 221670) Presumably they hope that this criticism will go home and make me give up the Urdu script in sheer despair.
('91', 116, 1, 5, 221778) But the hope is not likely to be fulfilled.
('91', 116, 1, 6, 221822) In fact neither Urdu or Hindi is to be termed Hindustani.
('91', 116, 1, 7, 221880) Though not in vogue today Hindustani is a wise mixture of the two.
('91', 116, 1, 8, 221947) If newspaper and other critics will exercise a little forbearance they will presently see that it is not difficult to understand what is Hindustani as distiguished from Hindi and Urdu.
('91', 116, 1, 9, 222132) I admit that those who write for Harijan Sevak are still struggling but they are determined to reach the desired goal.
('91', 116, 1, 10, 222251) Readers must bear kindly with what may today seem a hotch potch of the two forms.
('91', 116, 1, 11, 222333) If God spares my life I hope to prove to the readers of Harijan Sevak that Hindustani can be as sweet as either Urdu or Hindustani can be a sweet as either Urdu or Hindi.
('91', 116, 1, 12, 222504) The seeming quarrel of today will shortly disappear when it is realized that the two forms are sister and that through their joint effort will come into being a stately language which will serve the crores of India.
('91', 116, 1, 13, 222720) In the interim, I hope, critics will point out what to them may appear as mistakes.
('91', 116, 1, 14, 222804) Taken in a friendly spirit such criticism will help to improve the languae of Harijan Sevak.
('91', 116, 1, 15, 222897) MUSSOORIE, June 5, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 116, 2, 16, 222940) 147. TRUE BUT NOT NEW 1
('91', 116, 3, 17, 222964) Maulvi Hamidullah Sahib of Lucknow came to see me in Mussoorie and handed two of his pamphlets.
('91', 116, 3, 18, 223060) They are an attempt to prove the necessity of making obligatory up to the high school standard a knowlede of both Hindi and Urdu and the Nagari and Persian scripts, whether for boys or girls.
('91', 116, 3, 19, 223252) The idea appeals forcibly to me.
('91', 116, 3, 20, 223285) My effort has always been directed to this end.
('91', 116, 3, 21, 223333) Time was when Maulana Hasrat Mohani and Babu Purushottamdas Tandon were working for the same objective but alas!
('91', 116, 3, 22, 223446) we did not meet with sucess.
('91', 116, 3, 23, 223475) Nevertheless, I neither abandoned hope nor effort and the result was the creation of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha.
('91', 116, 3, 24, 223590) The Maulvi Sahib’s request, therefore, is nothing new for me.
('91', 116, 3, 25, 223652) If the U. P. Government is able, with the general consent, to
('91', 116, 4, 26, 223714) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('91', 116, 4, 27, 223745) The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 16 6 1946, under the date June 6, 1946.
('91', 117, 0, 1, 223839) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 118
('91', 117, 1, 2, 223881) make the attempt, they will have rendered a great service.
('91', 117, 1, 3, 223940) I am of the opinion that in all the provinces where Hindi or Urdu is the mother tongue, a knowledge of the other should be made compulsory.
('91', 117, 1, 4, 224080) I have no doubt that the natural outcome of such a step will be the easy birth of Hindustani, in which the two will blend into one.
('91', 117, 1, 5, 224212) The present controversy between the two sisters will then cease.
('91', 117, 1, 6, 224277) Another advantage that will accrue is that tuition up to the high school will be in the national language instead of English.

('91', 121, 8, 10, 230451) 156. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('91', 121, 9, 11, 230483) MUSSOORIE, June 5, 1946 3
('91', 121, 10, 12, 230509) His remarks 4 were taken to heart by one of the workers who has in charge of the meeting.
('91', 121, 10, 13, 230599) On Subsequent inquiry Gandhiji learnt that the information which he had received was of doubtful authenticity.
('91', 121, 10, 14, 230710) As a satyagrahi he felt he had fallen from grace in accepting a statement made to him without full scrutiny and by basing his public remarks thereon.
('91', 121, 10, 15, 230860) Making a public confession of his mistake in his address after the prayers on the following day, he stressed the importance of speaking only when necessary and uttering every word after the most careful thought.
('91', 121, 10, 16, 231072) A satyagrahi cannot afford to be credulous or to be careless in his speech.
('91', 121, 10, 17, 231148) There is a Sanskrit verse saying that not to begin is the first sign of wisdom, but once you begin a thing you should do it well.
('91', 121, 10, 18, 231278) It would have been best not to have made use of the unsifted information.
('91', 121, 10, 19, 231352) But having done so I should end it well by making the admission that on inquiry I found that the accusation could not be
('91', 121, 11, 20, 231473) 1 S. M. Iyengar had come, with a letter of recommendation from B. C, Roy to show Gandhiji “his new method of spinning and the wheel he had devised”.
('91', 121, 11, 21, 231622) 2 Reproduced from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 3 The source reports this before the speech of June 7, 1946. 4 Made during the previous day’s speech when it was reported to Gandhiji that some rickshaw pullers were turned out of the prayer gathering because of their dirty clothes.
('91', 122, 0, 1, 231900) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 123
('91', 122, 1, 2, 231942) supported.
('91', 122, 1, 3, 231953) There is a great piece of sculpture in Japan depicting three monkeys.
('91', 122, 1, 4, 232023) One of them is shutting his mouth with his hands, the second is shutting his ears and the third is shutting his eyes.
('91', 122, 1, 5, 232141) The lesson of the first one is not to speak unless absolutely necessary and then too, to weigh every word before speaking.
('91', 122, 1, 6, 232264) The message of the second is not hear evil things, of the third not to let one’s eyes wander here, there and everywhere.
('91', 122, 2, 7, 232385) Therefore, when going along the road, one should either contemplate the beauty of nature or else fix [one’s] gaze on the ground before one.
('91', 122, 2, 8, 232525) He carried about the three gurus with him wherever he went and he advised them all to bear their instructions in mind.
('91', 122, 2, 9, 232644) Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 123, 7, 8, 233542) 159. LETTER TO MANU GANDHI
('91', 123, 8, 9, 233569) MUSSOORIE, June 6, 1946
('91', 123, 9, 10, 233593) MANUDI, I shall be glad if Jaisukhlal and you come.
('91', 123, 9, 11, 233645) If both of you can live happily away from me and you get educated and become wise there is nothing special to be gained by coming to me.
('91', 123, 9, 12, 233782) If there has been any misunderstanding the fire of time will melt it away provided we let it do so.
('91', 123, 9, 13, 233882) From your doings 3 there which you describe it seems that you are spending your time well.
('91', 123, 9, 14, 233973) By goondas you seem to mean the bad boys you have to come across.
('91', 123, 9, 15, 234039) Your way of dealing with them may be said to resemble partly of Draupadi.
('91', 123, 9, 16, 234113) The method worth emulating is that of Sita.
('91', 123, 9, 17, 234157) Though, of course, both have been counted among the [five] satis.
('91', 123, 9, 18, 234223) 4 It is worth thinking over why Draupadi, though she had five husbands, was and is regarded as a sati.
('91', 123, 9, 19, 234326) But I leave that question aside.
('91', 123, 9, 20, 234359) If your answer to the goonda meant nothing more than what you did, if your heart was full of anger, then you may be said to have replied to the goonda with the violence on your part.
('91', 123, 9, 21, 234542) If you think over the meaning of whipping out the sandal from your
('91', 123, 10, 22, 234609) 1 Dr. Suresh Chandra, who was interned in Germany 2 In a letter dated July 27, 1946, C.W. B. Rankin replied that the internee, released in the middle of May, had been asked whether he wished to be repatriated to India and a reply from him was awaited.
('91', 123, 10, 23, 234861) 3 The addressee had punished a boy who was teasing girls.
('91', 123, 10, 24, 234919) 4 Ideal wives; the most well known in tradition are Anasuya, Parvati, Savitri, Sita and Draupadi.
('91', 124, 0, 1, 235017) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 125
('91', 124, 1, 2, 235059) foot and throwing it at him or striking him a few times with the sandal in your hand and the goonda becoming cowed down, you will realize what you did.
('91', 124, 1, 3, 235211) Since you resorted to physical force in a crowded square the other people also would take courage andthe goonda being a coward at heart, would be cowed down and run away.
('91', 124, 1, 4, 235382) If taking off the sandal was a sign of compassion on your part then I would regard even your hitting the man with it as an act of ahimsa.
('91', 124, 1, 5, 235520) Ahimsa has its roots in the heart.
('91', 124, 1, 6, 235555) And its result should be that the other person submits, not to physical force, but to soul force because he is overwhelmed by the power of compassion behind the physical punishment.
('91', 124, 1, 7, 235737) I will give you an instance of this from my own life.
('91', 124, 1, 8, 235791) Miss Schlesin 1 in her folly started smoking a cigarette in my presence.
('91', 124, 1, 9, 235864) I slapped her and threw away the cigarette.
('91', 124, 1, 10, 235908) For the first time she cried before me and apologized and wrote to me afterwards saying that she would never do such a thing again and that she had recognized my love I have narrated this incident in my autobiography.
('91', 124, 1, 11, 236126) 2 There have been many other similar incidents in my life.
('91', 124, 1, 12, 236185) Others also may have similar experience about which we do not know.
('91', 124, 1, 13, 236253) Did the goonda recognize the love in your heart?
('91', 124, 1, 14, 236302) Do not be decided whether your action was inspired by violence or non violence.
('91', 124, 1, 15, 236382) Ordinarily whipping out sandals is no sign of culture or ahimsa.
('91', 124, 1, 16, 236447) It is a sign of impulsiveness, that is, of lack of culture.
('91', 124, 1, 17, 236507) But in your case, the action may have been a sign of ahimsa.
('91', 124, 1, 18, 236568) Still you alone can testify which is the truth; or, may be God.
('91', 124, 1, 19, 236632) However, after analysing your action in such detail, I only wish to compliment you.
('91', 124, 1, 20, 236716) For I do not mind even if your action was violent.
('91', 124, 1, 21, 236767) It is enough for me that you were not cowed down.
('91', 124, 1, 22, 236817) I assume that you wish to cultivate ahimsa, and therefore, even if it was an act of violence, you will try and learn ahimsa from it.
('91', 124, 1, 23, 236950) I, therefore, gladly gave your letter to every body to read.
('91', 124, 1, 24, 237011) Akha Bhagat 3
('91', 124, 2, 25, 237025) has said: “Live as you like but realize Hari anyhow.” Accordingly, if you learn to parctise pure truth and pure ahimsa even while living there I will believe that you have learnt more than what you would have by staying with me and learning them under my guidence.
('91', 124, 2, 26, 237290) Blessings to you both from BAPU From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M. M. U./XXIV
('91', 124, 3, 27, 237370) 1 Sonja Schlesin Gandhiji’s assistant in South Africa 2 The incident, however, is not reported in the Autobiography.
('91', 124, 3, 28, 237487) 3 Saint poet of Gujarat

('91', 125, 1, 2, 237553) 160. LETTER TO LAKSHMI M. SHARMA
('91', 125, 2, 3, 237586) MUSSOORIE, June 6, 1946
('91', 125, 3, 4, 237610) LAKSHMI 1, You are now a widow.
('91', 125, 3, 5, 237642) If you have learnt anything from me, there is no difference between a wife and a widow, truly understood, for sooner or later everyone has to die.
('91', 125, 3, 6, 237789) The soul does not die.
('91', 125, 3, 7, 237812) Marriage is not of bodies, and if it is [regarded as such] it is wrong.
('91', 125, 3, 8, 237884) If one could marry a body, why don’t we marry a dead body or, say, a stone?
('91', 125, 3, 9, 237960) A marriage takes place between two souls and the soul never dies.
('91', 125, 3, 10, 238026) Moreover, you have your children.
('91', 125, 3, 11, 238060) You should bring them up with care and lead an absolutely chaste life.
('91', 125, 3, 12, 238131) If you conduct your life with restraint you will not feel any loss.
('91', 125, 3, 13, 238199) In fact you will have gained something through the loss.
('91', 125, 3, 14, 238256) Laksmidasdada 2 has asked you to go and live in the Harijan Ashram.
('91', 125, 3, 15, 238324) Do as he says.
('91', 125, 3, 16, 238339) In it lies your highest good.
('91', 125, 3, 17, 238369) If you live in the Ashram it will be like being among your ow family.
('91', 125, 3, 18, 238439) Sorrounded by them you will always be protected.
('91', 125, 3, 19, 238488) You are a good girl, so if you will wisely devote yourself to the work of service that you have taken up you will shine and do good to many others.
('91', 125, 3, 20, 238636) You yourself once wrote to me, didn’t you, that with the Sardar’s help you had acquired a house of your own.
('91', 125, 3, 21, 238745) If so, make all arrangements about it as Lakshmidasdada advises, so that you will have nothing to worry about.
('91', 125, 3, 22, 238856) What are your liabilities?
('91', 125, 3, 23, 238883) What has Maruti 3 left you?
('91', 125, 3, 24, 238911) Who are your friends, men as well as women?
('91', 125, 3, 25, 238955) You did write something about your sister Mani, but I have forgotten it.
('91', 125, 3, 26, 239028) Let me have all the information in detail.
('91', 125, 3, 27, 239071) I take it that you are calm.
('91', 125, 3, 28, 239100) Don’t give yourself up to grief.
('91', 125, 3, 29, 239133) Be cheerful at heart.
('91', 125, 4, 30, 239155) Blessings from BAPU HARIJAN ASHRAM SABARMATI
('91', 125, 5, 31, 239200) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
