('91', 126, 6, 14, 239952) 162. LETTER TO CHAMPA R. MEHTA
('91', 126, 7, 15, 239983) MUSSOORIE, June 6, 1946
('91', 126, 8, 16, 240007) CHAMPA, I have your letter.
('91', 126, 8, 17, 240035) The handwriting does not look like yours.
('91', 126, 8, 18, 240077) If it is I will say you have improved it a lot.
('91', 126, 8, 19, 240125) I don’t remember anything about any freedom I might have given you in regard to your mode of life there.
('91', 126, 8, 20, 240230) If I did, you should have asked me to give it in writing.
('91', 126, 8, 21, 240288) Human memory has ever been infirm.
('91', 126, 8, 22, 240323) And [mine] has now become quite weak.
('91', 126, 8, 23, 240361) I do remember, however, that whatever I might have said I qualified it with the condition that whatever you did should be with the consent of Chimanlal or Krishnachandra.
('91', 126, 8, 24, 240532) That is because I do not have, nor do I want to have, any exclusive right.
('91', 126, 8, 25, 240607) How could I then make any concession independently?
('91', 126, 8, 26, 240659) Whatever I might have said earlier, make a note of what I am now writing and conduct yourself accordingly.
('91', 126, 8, 27, 240766) I only wish your good.
('91', 126, 8, 28, 240789) Now indeed you have realized that your upbringing had not been perfect.
('91', 126, 8, 29, 240861) Whatever might have become aware of things.
('91', 126, 8, 30, 240905) You cannot therefore behave irresponsibly on the strength of your wealth.
('91', 126, 8, 31, 240979) Besides, the money that you have should be regarded as a sacred trust and spent accordingly.
('91', 126, 8, 32, 241072) At the Ashram it would become you to live in poverty as the others do; only then can you be
('91', 127, 0, 1, 241164) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 128
('91', 127, 1, 2, 241206) accommodated.
('91', 127, 1, 3, 241220) You cannot spend your money in such a way that it corrupts others.
('91', 127, 1, 4, 241287) I cannot tolerate it, nor should the Ashram.
('91', 127, 1, 5, 241332) You should therefore sit down with Chimanlal and Krishnachandra and organize your life as they advise and make yourself one with the Ashram as sugar dissolves in milk.
('91', 127, 1, 6, 241500) Only then will you be happy, and make your children happy too.
('91', 127, 1, 7, 241563) It would not befit you to behave in any other way.
('91', 127, 1, 8, 241614) Although Ratilal is alive, I am sure you never let yourself forget that you are as good as a widow.
('91', 127, 1, 9, 241714) If you cannot act in this way, if you are made of an altogether different stuff, you had better leave promptly; go and live where it suits you.
('91', 127, 1, 10, 241858) As I don’t know when I shall be reaching there, I have written at length.
('91', 127, 1, 11, 241932) I know yours is a difficult task.

('91', 132, 1, 11, 249183) It is our duty to offer things according to a man’s needs.
('91', 132, 1, 12, 249242) I have often said that the Ashram should be like a hotel.
('91', 132, 1, 13, 249300) The difference is that the boarders in a hotel can ask for anything they like and on payment they get it.
('91', 132, 1, 14, 249406) Whatever we would give a person taking into consideration his bodily needs should be in the nature of a medicine.
('91', 132, 1, 15, 249520) If we give quinine to one man, can everone ask for it?
('91', 132, 1, 16, 249575) We must not regard quinine and coffee from different angles.
('91', 132, 1, 17, 249636) We have to offer rice to a South Indian, bread to a Punjabi, fish to a Bengali, beer and beef to an Englishman.
('91', 132, 1, 18, 249748) It is another thing that we may not give meat and fish even as medicine, generally not even rice.
('91', 132, 1, 19, 249846) But if we admit such persons then it becomes our dharma to let them have [what they need.] But we may offer all the four things to all four of them at the same time.
('91', 132, 1, 20, 250012) Now meat and fish are out of the question, but how can we refuse to give wheat, rice, coffee, tea, etc., which we have once given?
('91', 132, 1, 21, 250143) Think over all this and do as you deem proper.
('91', 132, 1, 22, 250190) As for prayers, everywhere I am sticking to the old order, but if you think it right to have some change at the Ashram you may not make it.
('91', 132, 1, 23, 250330) For that consult the old collegues like Chimanlal, Balvantsinha, etc., or postpone it till I reach there.
('91', 132, 1, 24, 250436) I have written to Champabehn 2. I understand what you say about mango seeds, and also about dogs and mice.
('91', 132, 1, 25, 250543) Do what is proper about wood.
('91', 132, 1, 26, 250573) I propose to reach there in the beginning of August.
('91', 132, 1, 27, 250626) If Lilavati is there tell her that if she wants to abide by my word she has my permission.
('91', 132, 1, 28, 250717) If she wants to act within the limits imposed by time, she hasdn’t much time, has she?
('91', 132, 1, 29, 250804) She will have to think over all this herself.
('91', 132, 2, 30, 250850) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Hindi: G. N. 4559

('91', 133, 6, 10, 251472) 173. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 133, 7, 11, 251504) MUSSOORIE, June 7, 1946
('91', 133, 8, 12, 251528) Apologizing for the delay in his address at the end of the prayers, Gandhiji told the audience how pleased he was that Kanu Gandhi had started the prayers without waiting for him.
('91', 133, 8, 13, 251708) It should be the rule that prayers must not be delayed for anybody on earth.
('91', 133, 8, 14, 251785) God’s time never stops.
('91', 133, 8, 15, 251809) From the very beginning wheel of His time has gone ceaselessly on.
('91', 133, 8, 16, 251876) As a matter of fact there is no beginning for Him or His time.
('91', 133, 8, 17, 251939) God is not person.
('91', 133, 8, 18, 251958) No one knows what His watch is like.
('91', 133, 8, 19, 251995) No one can describe Him as no one has seen Him.
('91', 133, 8, 20, 252043) He is the Law and the Law giver combined into one.
('91', 133, 8, 21, 252094) The author of the Vedas, after the profoundest search has described Him as neti, neti (not this, not this).
('91', 133, 8, 22, 252202) He moves all and yet no one can move Him.
('91', 133, 8, 23, 252244) Not a blade of grass moves without His will.
('91', 133, 8, 24, 252289) For Him there is no begnning and no end.
('91', 133, 8, 25, 252330) Everything that has a beginning must end.
('91', 133, 8, 26, 252372) The sun, the moon and the earth must all perish one day even though it might be aftter an incalculable number of years.
('91', 133, 8, 27, 252492) God alone is immortal, imperishable.
('91', 133, 8, 28, 252529) How can man find words to describe Him?
('91', 133, 8, 29, 252569) How can anyone afford to miss the time of offering prayers to Him whose watch never stops?
('91', 133, 9, 30, 252660) 1 The report in National Herald has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 134, 0, 1, 252769) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 135
('91', 134, 1, 2, 252811) Kanu Gandhi knew all that and knew that any waiting for him would hurt.
('91', 134, 1, 3, 252883) So he had started the prayers on time.
('91', 134, 1, 4, 252922) Gandhiji had felt ashamed of disturbing the meeting by walking up to the dais when the prayer was going on.
('91', 134, 1, 5, 253030) If others came late during the prayers he inwardly fretted: why did they not stand at the far end of the gathering instead of walking in and disturbing the meeting?
('91', 134, 1, 6, 253195) He would have liked to wait outside but he knew that people were waiting for him.
('91', 134, 1, 7, 253277) They might feel worried over his absence.
('91', 134, 1, 8, 253319) Therefore, he had dared to walk to the dais and take his seat there though not without trembling.
('91', 134, 1, 9, 253417) His car had not failed him.
('91', 134, 1, 10, 253445) But he could not rudely tear himself away from his visitors.
('91', 134, 2, 11, 253506) He wanted them all to learn a lesson from the incident.
('91', 134, 2, 12, 253562) If they kept the time for the prayers the habit would be reflected in all that they did.
('91', 134, 2, 13, 253651) A man who works regularly in a systematic fashion never feels overworked or tired.
('91', 134, 2, 14, 253734) He knows his limits and is able to do in fair time, all that he undertakes.
('91', 134, 2, 15, 253810) It is not hard work that kills a man, but irregularity or lack of system.
('91', 134, 3, 16, 253884) National Herald, 8 6 1946, and Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 134, 4, 17, 253934) 174. DURING MUSSOORIE SOJOURN
('91', 134, 5, 18, 253964) During the prayer meeting in Mussoorie I suggested that the gay people of the place might well think of the poor among them, and make their living comfortable, clean and hygienic as also enable the poorest of all classes to find an abode where it would be possible for them to receive the benefit of the hill climate.
('91', 134, 5, 19, 254282) Both the suggestions have been taken up with ethusiasm.
('91', 134, 5, 20, 254338) An influential committee has been formed to carry out the idea of a dharmashala or musafarkhana.
('91', 134, 5, 21, 254435) I write this note to suggest that much the most important things would be to have a committee of workers or even one worker who would make it his business to run the guest house in a becomig manner.
('91', 134, 5, 22, 254634) Seeing that the place will be free of rent it will be no small task to choose the guests who may occupy the premises.
('91', 134, 5, 23, 254752) Care will have to be taken to exclude those who are at all able to pay a reasonable rent.
('91', 134, 5, 24, 254842) The visitors must be those who have nothing wherewith to pay.
('91', 134, 5, 25, 254904) If the place is to be kept absolutely clean, there will have to be rules to be rigidly enforced in the interests of the visitors themselves.
('91', 134, 5, 26, 255045) And yet the occupants will have to be treated with perfect courtesy.
('91', 134, 5, 27, 255114) They must never be allowed to feel that poverty is a crime.
('91', 134, 5, 28, 255174) Every third class traveller knows that the poor receive rough treatment in the railway carriages and at railway stations.
('91', 134, 5, 29, 255296) It is a sad commentary that in this
('91', 135, 0, 1, 255332) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 136
('91', 135, 1, 2, 255374) poor country where according to books poverty carries with it a certain dignity, in public places the poor are treated almost with contempt and they are made to pay for receiving it.
('91', 135, 1, 3, 255557) It is in this unfortunate atmosphere that this guest house is to be built.
('91', 135, 1, 4, 255632) Let the committee seek out from now an ideal caretaker who will answer the requirements of the office which are undoubtedly onerous.
('91', 135, 1, 5, 255765) If such a person is found, the project is bound to be a pattern for all such places on hill stations.
('91', 135, 1, 6, 255867) MUSSOORIE, June 8, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946
('91', 135, 2, 7, 255910) 175. TAKE CARE OF PENNIES
('91', 135, 3, 8, 255936) I have discovered honourable members of Assemblies using most expensive embossed note paper even for private use.
('91', 135, 3, 9, 256050) So far as I know, office stationery cannot be used for private purposes such as writing to friends or relatives or for letters from members of Assemblies to constituents outside matters of public business.
('91', 135, 3, 10, 256256) So far as I know, this a universal objection in every part of the world.
('91', 135, 3, 11, 256329) But for this poor country my objection goes deeper.
('91', 135, 3, 12, 256381) The stationery I refer to is too expensive of us.
('91', 135, 3, 13, 256431) Englishmen belonging to the most expensive country in the world and who had to flourish on the awe they could inspire in us introduced expensive and massive buildings for offices and bungalows requiring for their upkeep an army of servants and hangers on.
('91', 135, 3, 14, 256687) If we copy their style and habits we will be ruined ourselves and carry the country in this ruin.
('91', 135, 3, 15, 256785) And what was tolerated in the case of the conquerors will not be tolerated in ours.
('91', 135, 3, 16, 256869) There is, too, paper shortage.
('91', 135, 3, 17, 256900) I am of opinion, therefore, that all these expensive habits sohuld be given up.Hand made paper with ordinarily printed letter heads in Nagari and Urdu should be used.The embossed stationery already printed can easily be cut up and put to better use, and should not be used up under cover of economy.
('91', 135, 3, 18, 257200) Surely village products cannot be made to wait till the expensive and possible foreign stuff is used up.
('91', 135, 3, 19, 257305) Popular Governments should signalize their advent by adopting popular measures and inexpensive habits.
('91', 135, 4, 20, 257408) MUSSOORIE, June 8, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 136, 6, 18, 258240) 177. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 136, 7, 19, 258270) MUSSOORIE, June 8, 1946 2
('91', 136, 8, 20, 258296) Mahatma Gandhi held his last prayer meeting in Mussoorie this evening.
('91', 136, 8, 21, 258367) He told the audience about the work that has been done in connection with two points raised by him, namely, erecting a dharmashala for the poor and building better quarter for the coolies.
('91', 136, 9, 22, 258556) As regards the latter, it had beeen decided that the project was too big for individual effort and that the U. P. Government should be approached.
('91', 136, 9, 23, 258703) There were plenty of rich people lin Mussoorie; it was their duty to see that the coolies had better quarters.
('91', 136, 9, 24, 258814) As for the dharmashala, a committee had been formed and money collected.
('91', 136, 9, 25, 258887) When the dharmashala would materialize rested with them, Gandhiji added.
('91', 136, 9, 26, 258960) He had suggested that the dharmashala should be such that a person like him could stay there without any hesitation.
('91', 136, 9, 27, 259077) All that was required was a clean well ventilated building.
('91', 136, 9, 28, 259137) He would much rather stay in a place built for the poor.
('91', 136, 9, 29, 259194) Such a building would be an
('91', 136, 10, 30, 259222) 1 Vide “Letter to Prabhudayal Vidyarthi”, 31 5 1946. 2 From The Hindustan Times, 10 6 1946
('91', 137, 0, 1, 259313) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138
('91', 137, 1, 2, 259355) inducement for him to come to Mussoorie again.
('91', 137, 1, 3, 259402) Someone had taken exception to the word dharmashala.
('91', 137, 1, 4, 259455) The critic said it meant a place for the Hindus only.
('91', 137, 1, 5, 259509) That was not his conception.
('91', 137, 1, 6, 259538) Hindus, Muslims Sikhs, Christians, Parsis, Jews—all should be able to come and stay there provided they were poor.
('91', 137, 1, 7, 259653) They would have to cook thier own food.
('91', 137, 1, 8, 259693) And so for Harijans, for him everybody was a Harijan.
('91', 137, 1, 9, 259747) He had said that a religion which made distinctions of high and low was no religion.
('91', 137, 1, 10, 259832) He had suggested that all of them should become Harijans voluntarily and among Harijans too, Bhangis.
('91', 137, 1, 11, 259934) Lord Shiva was called Bhangi 1 because he had the intoxication of the good of the creation.
('91', 137, 1, 12, 260026) Therefore by becoming Bhangis, they would become servants and lovers of humanity.
('91', 137, 1, 13, 260108) The service rendered by the Bhangis was the most useful for humanity.
('91', 137, 1, 14, 260178) So there could be no discrimination against Harijans in the dharmshala that was contemplated.
('91', 137, 1, 15, 260272) Another friend had written to him that there were already several dharmashalas in Mussoorie, one for Arya Samajists, one for Sikhs and so on.
('91', 137, 1, 16, 260414) Why add another when even those in existence lay vacant for most of the time because they were meant for one sect or another?
('91', 137, 1, 17, 260540) The dharmashala of his conception would be open to all without any discrimination of caste, colour or creed.
('91', 137, 1, 18, 260649) If they were not prepare for that he would advise them to dissolve the committee and return to their respective donors the money that had been collected .
('91', 137, 2, 19, 260804) Friends had warned him against coming to Mussoorie, the seat of fashion and frivolity, Gandhiji contined.
('91', 137, 2, 20, 260910) He did not grudge the amusement provided it was innocent.
('91', 137, 2, 21, 260968) If their enjoyment was tainted, they would never be able to build the kind of place that he had suggested and keep it up.
('91', 137, 2, 22, 261090) As such, they would have no time to think of the poor.
('91', 137, 2, 23, 261145) The management of such a dharmashala would be even more difficult than building it.
('91', 137, 2, 24, 261229) They would have to be ever watchful so that it served the purpose for which it was built.
('91', 137, 2, 25, 261319) Otherwise, he would feel sorry for the money wasted.
('91', 137, 2, 26, 261372) They had attended the prayers for several days.
('91', 137, 2, 27, 261420) If they had really come to hear Ramanama in their hearts, they could certainly do what he had asked in the name of Rama and His creation.
('91', 137, 2, 28, 261558) He also expected them to offer prayers in their own homes regularly, morning and evening.
('91', 137, 2, 29, 261648) There was no need for them to learn the Sanskrit Shlokas if they did not wish to; Ramdhun was enough.
('91', 137, 2, 30, 261750) The essence of all prayers was to establish God in their hearts.
('91', 137, 2, 31, 261815) If they succeeded in doing that, all would be well with them, with the society and the world.
('91', 137, 3, 32, 261909) The Hindu, 10 6 1946
('91', 137, 4, 33, 261930) 1 One who partakes of bhang, an intoxicant

('91', 138, 1, 2, 262015) 178. NOTES
('91', 138, 2, 3, 262026) NO PUBLICITY REQUIRED 1
('91', 138, 3, 4, 262050) A Brahmin correspondent asks me to publish the fact that he has become a Harijan and wants to eliminate his name as a caste Hindu from the census too.
('91', 138, 3, 5, 262201) This is a sequence to my having asked all caste Hindus to look upon themselves as Harijans of the so called lowest stratum.
('91', 138, 3, 6, 262325) But what is the point in giving publicity to an inner change?
('91', 138, 3, 7, 262387) The real proof is for the convert to practise the change in his daily life.
('91', 138, 3, 8, 262463) He will, therefore, mix freely with Bhangis and take an active part in their life.
('91', 138, 3, 9, 262546) If possible, he will live with them or get a Bhangi to live with him.
('91', 138, 3, 10, 262616) He will give his children in marriage to Harijans and on being questioned he will say that he has become a Harijan of his own free will and will register his name either as a Harijan or Bhangi in the census when he has to classify himself.
('91', 138, 3, 11, 262856) But having done so he will on no account arrogate to himself any of the rights of Harijans as, for example, he will not enter his name as a voter on their list.
('91', 138, 3, 12, 263017) In other words, he will undertake to fulfil all the duties of a Harijan without seeking any of the rights that pertain to them.
('91', 138, 3, 13, 263145) So long As separate voting lists are maintained he will cease to be a voter.

('91', 138, 4, 15, 263276) A correspondent writes as follows:
('91', 138, 5, 16, 263311) Owing to lack of time it is not always possible to do all the necessary touring by rail.
('91', 138, 5, 17, 263400) Workers have, therefore, to travel long dis tances by car.
('91', 138, 5, 18, 263459) As petrol is rationed and the required quantity is not available recourse is had to the black market.
('91', 138, 5, 19, 263561) It is either bought through someone or the taxi driver is commissioned to obtain it from the black market and payment per mile is given to him according to the price paid for the petrol.
('91', 138, 6, 20, 263748) Is it right for workers to use a car under these circumstances?
('91', 138, 7, 21, 263812) It is possible that if they do not, they will have to cut down their touring which will seemingly be harmful to the work.
('91', 138, 7, 22, 263934) Am I right in believing that there is no alternative?
('91', 138, 7, 23, 263988) I am of opinion that the worker who believes in truth should not use a car under these conditions.
('91', 138, 7, 24, 264087) Even if he is not a believer but tries to render services thoughtfully he should not do so.
('91', 138, 7, 25, 264179) If he does he

('91', 139, 1, 4, 264541) NEW DELHI, June 9 1 , 1946
('91', 139, 2, 5, 264568) DECIMAL COINAGE It seems that I inadvertently allowed to be printed in the last paragraph of Shri K. Mashruwala’s article 2 on this subject the statement that a second instalment would follow showing how, if at all, decimal coinage without loss to the poor could be promulgated.
('91', 139, 2, 6, 264847) As a matter of fact I do not think the time has come for a serious consideration of the contemplated reform.
('91', 139, 2, 7, 264956) I am quite clear that however attractive any scheme of decimal coinage may be, it should not be considered before there is an independent national government.
('91', 139, 2, 8, 265115) Therefore the publication of any such scheme is wholly premature.There are many more pressing, urgent problems occupying the best minds of the country.
('91', 139, 2, 9, 265267) Surely the country can easily wait for a more fortunate moment for a proper understanding of a scheme before legislation on the subject is undertaken.
('91', 139, 2, 10, 265418) If England has waited for years and is still waiting, why should poor famishing India have a radical reform in courage sprung upon it without the man in the street being instructed in the pros and cons of the subject?
('91', 139, 2, 11, 265636) It is not a matter which has nothing to be said against it.
('91', 139, 2, 12, 265696) It will certainly not add one grain of corn to the existing stocks.
('91', 139, 2, 13, 265764) Whether a rupee is to contain 100 cents or 64 pice is a problem that can await solution for a happier day.
('91', 139, 2, 14, 265871) Democracy demands patient instruction on it before legislation.
('91', 139, 2, 15, 265935) Hence I intended to erase the announcement of the second article in order to avoid raising a hope I had no desire to satisfy.
('91', 139, 2, 16, 266061) NEW DELHI, June 9, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 141, 4, 9, 268414) 181. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 141, 5, 10, 268446) NEW DELHI, June 9, 1946
('91', 141, 6, 11, 268470) I have been in your midst for several weeks with short breaks.
('91', 141, 6, 12, 268533) It hurts me that you have not yet learnt to observe perfect silence without being requested.
('91', 141, 6, 13, 268626) It is an indication that Ramanama has not gone to your hearts.
('91', 141, 6, 14, 268689) There is no power greater than God in the world.
('91', 141, 6, 15, 268738) You would expect me to say something.
('91', 141, 6, 16, 268776) I too wish to tell you something, but just as a cook never puts half cooked dishes before guests, I too would not place before you things that are still half cooked.
('91', 141, 6, 17, 268942) This, however, I may tell you, that you must not give up hope till the last.
('91', 141, 6, 18, 269019) We must realize that if we achieve nothing ultimately is because of our of own shortcomings.
('91', 141, 6, 19, 269112) Nobody can prove himself right by pointing to others’ faults.
('91', 141, 6, 20, 269174) We can improve ourselves by acknowledging our own faults.
('91', 141, 6, 21, 269232) If I realize that I am crooked, I shall become straight.
('91', 141, 6, 22, 269289) It will only be false pride if I fency that I am straight and the entire world is crooked.
('91', 141, 6, 23, 269380) That is why I say that, if we achieve nothing, it will be because we do not deserve it.
('91', 141, 6, 24, 269468) We have been carrying on this fight through non violent means, but we could not generate enough power to induce others to play straight with us.
('91', 141, 6, 25, 269613) We—Hindus and Muslims—I must say have been quarrelling amongst ourselves and if we look to the British to unite us it will be a great blot on our civilization.
('91', 141, 6, 26, 269773) Who is a Hindu?
('91', 141, 6, 27, 269789) Who is a Muslim?
('91', 141, 6, 28, 269806) Why this distinction?
('91', 141, 6, 29, 269828) Let us all pray to God that wisdom may dawn on us so that we may be united.
('91', 141, 6, 30, 269904) If this happens we shall easily arrive at some settlement with the British.
('91', 141, 6, 31, 269980) You must remember that this is being said
('91', 141, 7, 32, 270022) 1 The report in Hindustan has been collated with the version in Harijan Sevak.
('91', 142, 0, 1, 270101) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 143
('91', 142, 1, 2, 270143) today by the same man who had told you that, so long as the British remained, unity between the two of us would be difficult to achieve.
('91', 142, 1, 3, 270280) But that was only a proclamation of ours weakness.
('91', 142, 1, 4, 270331) I fail to see why we have become so mad, why we have become so uncivilized.
('91', 142, 1, 5, 270407) But let us not despair.
('91', 142, 1, 6, 270431) Leave it to God.
('91', 142, 1, 7, 270448) Let destiny take its course.
('91', 142, 1, 8, 270477) All will be well if God helps us.

('91', 142, 3, 11, 270575) 182. THE UNKNOWN
('91', 142, 4, 12, 270592) Some learned men describe Him as Unknowable, some others as Unknown, yet others as ‘Not This’.
('91', 142, 4, 13, 270687) ‘The Unknown’ is good for the present purpose.
('91', 142, 4, 14, 270734) When yesterday (9th June) I said a few words to the prayer audience, I could say nothing more than that they should pray for and rely upon the strength and the guidance that this big X could give.
('91', 142, 4, 15, 270931) There were difficulties to be overcome by all parties in the great Indian drama that was being enacted before them.
('91', 142, 4, 16, 271047) They were all to rely upon the Unknown who had often confounded man’s wisdom and in the twinkling of an eye upset his tin pot plans.
('91', 142, 4, 17, 271180) The British party claimed to believe in God, the Unknown.
('91', 142, 4, 18, 271238) The Muslim League did likewise.
('91', 142, 4, 19, 271270) They delighted is saying Allah o Akbar 1 .
('91', 142, 4, 20, 271313) The Congress naturally had no single equivalent cry.
('91', 142, 4, 21, 271366) Nevertheless, if it sought to represent the whole of India, it represented the millions of believers, no matter to what compartment in the House of God they belonged.
('91', 142, 4, 22, 271533) At the time of writing, in spite of my irrepressible optimism, I am unable to say decisively that at least in political parlance, the thing is safe.
('91', 142, 4, 23, 271682) All I can say, therefore, is that if, with the best efforts of all the parties, the unsafe happens, I would invite them to join with me in saying that it was as well and that safety lay in unsafety.
('91', 142, 4, 24, 271881) If we are all children of God, as we are, whether we know it or not, we will take in good part whatever happens and work with zest and confidence for the next step whatever it may be.
('91', 142, 4, 25, 272065) The only condition for that zest is that each party does its honest best for the good of the whole of India.
('91', 142, 4, 26, 272174) For that is the stake and no other.
('91', 142, 5, 27, 272210) NEW DELHI, June 10, 1946 Harijan, 16 6 1946

('91', 145, 1, 2, 275182) 187. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 145, 2, 3, 275214) NEW DELHI, June 11, 1946
('91', 145, 3, 4, 275239) Expressing his regret for the delay in attending the prayers Gandhiji said: Unfortunately owing to Maulana Saheb’s illness the Congress Working Committee meeting which was to be held here was held at his place.
('91', 145, 3, 5, 275450) On momentous occasions like this it is necessary that as many members as possible should attend the meeting.
('91', 145, 3, 6, 275559) Maulana Saheb’s presence, he being the President of the Congress, was absolutely essential.
('91', 145, 3, 7, 275651) In order that we may not be deprived of his advice the meet ing was held at his residence.
('91', 145, 3, 8, 275742) I could not, in spite of all efforts, disengage myself in time and was ten minutes late.
('91', 145, 3, 9, 275831) Since the Divine Clock stops for no one’s sake, I am glad that the prayers were begun according to schedule without waiting for me.
('91', 145, 3, 10, 275963) I am sorry that even on the third day I cannot give you any definite news whether the talks 2 on the British proposals have broken down or not.
('91', 145, 3, 11, 276107) All I can say is that the Congress Working Committee 3 is striving its utmost to prevent a breakdown.
('91', 145, 3, 12, 276209) As long as there is life there is hope too.
('91', 145, 3, 13, 276253) It is easy to destroy but to build is a slow and labourious process.
('91', 145, 3, 14, 276322) Besides, the prestige of the Cabinet Mission is at stake.
('91', 145, 3, 15, 276380) They cannot afford a breakdown.
('91', 145, 3, 16, 276412) If the aim of all the three parties, the Congress, the Muslim League and the Mission is the same, viz., the independence of India, the present dialogue should not end in failure.
('91', 145, 3, 17, 276591) But we must be patient.
('91', 145, 3, 18, 276615) The independence of 400 millions is no conjurer’s trick.
('91', 145, 3, 19, 276672) The fact that the Congress Working Committee even at this stage is giving it the most serious consideration shows how anxious it is to avoid a breakdown, if it is humanly possible without sacrificing honour or the interests of India’s dumb millions.
('91', 145, 3, 20, 276922) If, however, in spite of our efforts to avoid it the talks in the end do break down, we should not despair.
('91', 145, 3, 21, 277030) Those who have faith in God will leave the result to Him.
('91', 145, 3, 22, 277088) In the event of a breakdown I shall report it to you without reservation and in the plainest of words.
('91', 145, 3, 23, 277191) [From Hindi] Hindustan, 12 6 1946
('91', 145, 4, 24, 277225) 1 The meeting was attended among others by Sir Stafford Cripps and Lady Cripps.
('91', 145, 4, 25, 277305) 2 For an official version of the interview as recorded by Lord Wavell, vide “Interview with Lord Wavell”, 11 6 1946. 3 The Hindustan Times report here has “the three parties concerned”.

('91', 147, 1, 2, 278434) 190. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('91', 147, 2, 3, 278461) VALMIKI MANDIR, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, June 12, 1946
('91', 147, 3, 4, 278516) DEAR FRIEND, From you, almost straight away, I went to the Working Committee which, owing to his illness, was held at Maulana Saheb’s quarters.
('91', 147, 3, 5, 278660) I gave them the gist of our conversation, told them that I gladly endorsed your suggestion about the parties meeting to fix up names subject to the provison that no party should talk of parity, 1 you should invite them simply to submit to you a joint list of the Cabinet of the Provisional Interim Government which you would approve or, if you did not, you would invite them to submit a revised list bearing in mind your amendments, that the list should represent a coalition Government composed of persons of proved ability and incorruptibility.
('91', 147, 3, 6, 279207) I suggested too that in the place of parity there should be active enforcement of the long term provision in your joint Statement 2 that in all major communal issues there should be communal voting to decide them.
('91', 147, 3, 7, 279421) I suggested also that in the event of absence of agreement between the parties in spite of all effort, you should examine the merits of the respective lists of the two parties and accept either the one or the other (not an amalgam) and announce the names of the Interim Government but that before that final step was taken you should closet yourselves until a joint list was prepared.
('91', 147, 3, 8, 279806) I told the Working Committee that you had seemed to endorse my suggestions.
('91', 147, 3, 9, 279882) I told them further that, so far as I knew, it was a point of
('91', 147, 4, 10, 279944) 1 In his letter to Lord Wavell dated June 8, M. A. Jinnah had claimed that the Viceroy had given him “the assurance that there will be only twelve portfolios, five on behalf of the League, five Congress, one Sikh and one Christian or Anglo Indian”.
('91', 147, 4, 11, 280193) During the meeting with the Cabinet Delegation on June 8, the Viceroy said that “he had given no assurance to Mr. Jinnah” but he thought that “the 5 : 5 : 2 ratio as the most hopeful basis of settlement” and that he was working on that basis.
('91', 147, 4, 12, 280436) He told them that M. A. Jinnah “had taken a very strong line about the Interim Government and had said that the Muslim League would not be prepared to come in except on the basis of 5 : 5 : 2 distribution of portfolios, between the Muslim League, the Congress, and the minorities”.
('91', 147, 4, 13, 280718) This parity between the Congress and the Muslim League was wholly unacceptable to the Congress.
('91', 147, 4, 14, 280814) 2 Of May 16, vide Appendix “Statement of Cabinet Delegation and Viceroy”, 16 5 1946.
('91', 148, 0, 1, 280899) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 149
('91', 148, 1, 2, 280941) honour with Congressmen that there could be no joint consultation in which Maulana Saheb was not associated with the talks.
('91', 148, 1, 3, 281065) You said it was a sore point with Quaid e Azam Jinnah and I replied that the soreness was wholly unwarranted and that the Congress could not be expected to sacrifice its faithful servant of twenty five years’ standing whose self sacrifice and devotion to the national cause had never been in question.
('91', 148, 1, 4, 281367) But I told you that your great experience and ability to handle delicate matters would show you the way out of the difficulty.
('91', 148, 1, 5, 281494) Finally, I told the Committee that I drew your attention to the fact that the European vote which was being talked of was unthinkable, in connection with the Constituent Assembly and nothing but a public declaration by the European residents of India or one by you on their behalf could make possible the formation of the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 148, 1, 6, 281838) I gathered from you that the question was already engaging your attention and that it should be satisfactorily solved.
('91', 148, 1, 7, 281957) Probably you have already moved in the matter of the joint talk.
('91', 148, 1, 8, 282022) Nevertheless, I thought that I owed it to you and the Working Committee to put on record what I had reported about our talks.
('91', 148, 1, 9, 282148) If I have in any way misunderstood you, will you please correct me?
('91', 148, 1, 10, 282216) I may say that the Working Committee had its draft letter ready but at my suggestion it postponed consideration of it pending the final result of your effort adumbrated in this letter.
('91', 148, 1, 11, 282401) The draft letter takes the same view that I placed before you yesterday on parity and the European vote and their election as members of the contemplated Constituent Assembly.
('91', 148, 1, 12, 282577) I close with the hope that your effort will bear the fruit to which all are looking forward.
('91', 148, 2, 13, 282670) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('91', 150, 3, 4, 284702) DEAR FRIEND, I promised to send you a copy of Rev.
('91', 150, 3, 5, 284753) J. J. M. Nichols Roy’s address 2. I do so herewith.

('91', 150, 3, 10, 285130) 5 I spoke last evening at the prayer meeting without knowing anything of the latter which I hold to be a dangerous statement.
('91', 150, 3, 11, 285256) It fills me with distrust of the future well being through the proposed Constituent Assembly.
('91', 150, 3, 12, 285350) I suppose the Statesman’s leading article today represents the general British attitude in India.
('91', 150, 3, 13, 285448) The article is headed“Slow Motion”.
('91', 150, 3, 14, 285484) “Deliberation, wariness, sobriety in an approach to great decisions are proper; but not swither and loquacity or delays due to mere tactical manoeuvring.” All this is a prelude to what I consider an unwarranted attack on the Congress.
('91', 150, 3, 15, 285719) If you of the Mission and the Viceroy share the view, you should really have no dealings with the Congress, however powerful or representative it may be.
('91', 150, 3, 16, 285873) Naturally you should be the sole judges of what the Congress has appeared to you to be like.

('91', 151, 0, 1, 286847) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 151, 1, 2, 286889) For my part, as a detached observer, as I hold myself to be, I think that the Congress has not been procrastinating.
('91', 151, 1, 3, 287006) It has been extraordinarily prompt in its dealings in connection with the work of the high mission which you are shouldering.
('91', 151, 1, 4, 287132) But my purpose in writing this letter is to tell you that it will be wrong on my part if I advise the Congress to wait indefinitely until the Viceroy has formed the Interim Government or throws up the sponge in despair.
('91', 151, 1, 5, 287352) Despair he must, if he expects to bring into being a coalition Government between two incompatibles.
('91', 151, 1, 6, 287453) The safest, bravest and the straightest course is to invite that party to form a government which, in the Vice roy’s estimation, inspires greater confidence.
('91', 151, 1, 7, 287611) Then there is a possi bility within 24 hours of forming a National Government.
('91', 151, 1, 8, 287690) If, how ever, no party inspires confidence such a declaration should be made and the Viceroy should run the Government in the best way he knows.
('91', 151, 1, 9, 287835) But the Congress Working Committee should not be delayed indefinitely.
('91', 151, 1, 10, 287906) As for me, I would gladly stay behind if you want me to.
('91', 151, 1, 11, 287963) But I feel that I shall be a useless adviser.
('91', 151, 1, 12, 288009) I can only advise out of the fulness of trust.
('91', 151, 1, 13, 288056) I become paralysed when distrust chokes me.
('91', 151, 1, 14, 288100) I am sorry to send you this letter.
('91', 151, 1, 15, 288136) But I would be an unworthy friend if I disguised my feelings.
('91', 151, 1, 16, 288198) You should know me as I am.
('91', 151, 1, 17, 288226) Hence these tears.
('91', 151, 2, 18, 288245) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('91', 151, 5, 21, 288367) NEW DELHI, June 12, 1946
('91', 151, 6, 22, 288392) Gandhiji began his after prayer address by introducing Khwaja Abdul Majid to the audience as an old and dear friend of his.
('91', 151, 6, 23, 288516) He recalled how during the Khilafat days he had once stayed at Khwaja Saheb’s house.
('91', 151, 6, 24, 288601) Swami Satyadevji was with him.
('91', 151, 6, 25, 288632) He was an orthodox Hindu and would not eat or drink from a Mussalman’s hands.
('91', 151, 6, 26, 288710) Khwaja Saheb had employed a Brahmin to render all those services to him.
('91', 151, 6, 27, 288783) It had affected Swamiji deeply.
('91', 151, 6, 28, 288815) Khwaja Saheb was one of the earliest to join the nationalist

('91', 152, 1, 3, 289207) There were many such great men in the various communities.
('91', 152, 1, 4, 289266) This treasure of goodness did not lessen by exercising goodness in all walks of life.
('91', 152, 2, 5, 289352) Referring to the political situation he said he was still not ready to say anything.
('91', 152, 2, 6, 289437) There was, however, one thing to which he was free to draw their attention.
('91', 152, 2, 7, 289513) He had called the Cabinet plan good and he still held to his opinion with the interpretation he put upon it.
('91', 152, 2, 8, 289622) The Constituent Assembly has to be formed by the elected members of the Provincial Legislatures.
('91', 152, 2, 9, 289719) The Government of India Act of 1935 has given a number of seats in the Legislatures to the Europeans.
('91', 152, 2, 10, 289821) For instance, in Bengal alone there is a solid block of 25 Europeans.
('91', 152, 2, 11, 289891) In Assam there are 9. Quite a number of them are multi millionaires or their representatives.
('91', 152, 2, 12, 289985) They are foreigners, members of the ruling race.
('91', 152, 2, 13, 290034) As such they can have no place in the Constituent Assembly as candidates, nor can they as voters return members.
('91', 152, 2, 14, 290147) The Cabinet plan has said clearly that Indians are to form India’s constitution.
('91', 152, 3, 15, 290228) Lawyer friends had told Gandhiji that if the matter were taken to a law court the verdict would surely be against the Europeans.
('91', 152, 3, 16, 290357) But from the papers he had gathered that they intended to exercise the right, which they thought they had.
('91', 152, 3, 17, 290464) 1 Till now they had used their vote to uphold the British power and acted as a wedge between the Hindus and the Mussalmans.
('91', 152, 3, 18, 290588) He appealed to them, therefore, apart from the question of legalities, to abstain from interference.
('91', 152, 3, 19, 290689) No Congressman would wish to drag them to the law court.
('91', 152, 3, 20, 290746) They should recognize the signs of the time and make a voluntary declaration that the newspaper report was wrong and that they had no wish to interfere in the affairs of Indians which ought to be settled by Indians themselves and that they would not exercise their votes for the selection of candidates for the Constituent Assembly, nor would they stand as candidates.
('91', 152, 3, 21, 291115) They should no longer impose themselves upon India.
('91', 152, 3, 22, 291167) Whatever they might have done in the past, they should alleviate communal bitterness, not accentuate it.
('91', 152, 3, 23, 291272) They should wish India to win her freedom as early as possible.
('91', 152, 3, 24, 291336) Such a statement would be graceful for the Europeans.
('91', 152, 4, 25, 291390) It was up to the Cabinet Mission and the Viceroy, concluded Gandhiji, to see that this foreign element was not used to affect the elections in any way whatsoever.

('91', 153, 0, 1, 291922) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 153, 1, 2, 291964) 194. MUCH IN LITTLE
('91', 153, 2, 3, 291984) In Mr. Mahadev Desai’s book on the Travancore Temple Entry Proclamation, I find your speeches made in several places in Travancore.
('91', 153, 2, 4, 292116) You have spoken of the Ishopanishad and said that if the first verse alone survived and all the rest of the Hindu scriptures were destroyed, it would alone save religion from extinction.
('91', 153, 2, 5, 292303) Perhaps you know that that verse was a turning point in the life of Devendranath Tagore, the Poet’s father.
('91', 153, 2, 6, 292411) Young Devendranath was in a mood of great depression when his father died leaving the family estate highly encumbered.
('91', 153, 2, 7, 292530) One day while in this mood a piece of printed paper was wafted by a passing breeze to where he was sitting, he picked it up.
('91', 153, 2, 8, 292655) It was in Sanskrit which he had not learnt then.
('91', 153, 2, 9, 292704) He took it to the family pundit who read it out.
('91', 153, 2, 10, 292753) It was the first verse of the Ishopanishad.
('91', 153, 2, 11, 292797) “Nectar poured into my soul,” says the Maharshi in his autobiography.
('91', 153, 3, 12, 292867) The phrase about enjoying by renunciation puzzled me for long.
('91', 153, 3, 13, 292930) One day (or night to be correct) it flashed on me that the phrase but expressed a daily experience.
('91', 153, 3, 14, 293030) What greater enjoyment is there than renouncing something one values to one— person or cause—which one hods dear.
('91', 153, 3, 15, 293144) The above letter from Shri K. Natarajan was received by me about three months ago.
('91', 153, 3, 16, 293227) I had hoped to deal with it in these columns much earlier but could not.
('91', 153, 3, 17, 293300) Nothing, however, is lost, for the subject matter of the letter is an evergreen.
('91', 153, 3, 18, 293381) I try to the utmost of my ability to live the meaning that, in my ungrammatical way, I have ascribed to the shloka.
('91', 153, 3, 19, 293497) Not being a reader of books, I never knew the instance that Shri Natarajan quotes from Maharshi Devendra’s life.
('91', 153, 3, 20, 293610) It fortifies my belief that the first mantra of Ishopanishad is all that undiluted Hinduism—in other words, for me, religion—can have to give.
('91', 153, 3, 21, 293753) The recitation of the 18 chapters of the Gita is finished in one week at the morning prayer and so it has gone on now for some years from week to week.
('91', 153, 3, 22, 293905) The Gita is a commentary on the first verse of the Ishopanishad.
('91', 153, 3, 23, 293970) And I feel, not without diffidence, that the interpretation that flashed on Shri Natarajan’s mind reveals but the partial truth.
('91', 153, 3, 24, 294099) As I understand it, his interpretation is only the well worn doctrine of self sacrifice which is undoubtedly a common enough experience.
('91', 153, 3, 25, 294236) Take only one instance.
('91', 153, 3, 26, 294260) Many a mother sacrifices all for her children.
('91', 153, 3, 27, 294307) But the mantra referred to here was not revealed to confirm the truth of that practice, well known even during the remote times when it is said to have been given.
('91', 153, 3, 28, 294471) To live up to that verse means the new birth enunciated in the New Testament, or Brahmasamarpana (dedication to God) as taught in Hinduism.
('91', 153, 3, 29, 294611) The verse, therefore, seems to me to mean only one thing.
('91', 153, 3, 30, 294669) Recognize that everything you fancy
('91', 154, 0, 1, 294705) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 155
('91', 154, 1, 2, 294747) everything you fancy you have is God’s and from God and take only what you really need for life.
('91', 154, 1, 3, 294844) In other words, in the language of the Gita it teaches the doctrine of uttermost detachment.
('91', 154, 1, 4, 294937) Then only is life worth living.
('91', 154, 1, 5, 294969) NEW DELHI, June 13, 1946 Harijan, 23 6 1946
('91', 154, 2, 6, 295013) 195. QUESTION BOX
('91', 154, 3, 7, 295031) A correspondent writes:
('91', 154, 4, 8, 295055) Supposing that in a Government or private godown foodgrains are being allowed to rot while people are starving because none are available in the market, what are workers to do?
('91', 154, 4, 9, 295232) Would it be permissible to resort to something in the nature of your Dharasana salt raid in order to save the people?
('91', 154, 4, 10, 295350) Otherwise, what alternative is there to either looting or dying like dumb cattle, of both of which you disapprove?
('91', 154, 5, 11, 295465) A. It should be common cause that looting in itself can never do any good.
('91', 154, 5, 12, 295540) Wherever it is claimed to have done so, the good consisted only in drawing the attention of the authority to a crying want.
('91', 154, 5, 13, 295664) The way of voluntary fasting that I have suggested 1 is the most efficient because it is good in itself and good also as an effective demonstration.
('91', 154, 5, 14, 295813) It is good in itself because the people who voluntarily fast exhibit strength of will which saves them from the pangs of hunger and wakes up public conscience as also that of the authority, assuming that the latter can have any conscience at all.
('91', 154, 5, 15, 296060) So far as the Dharasana salt raid 2 is concerned, apart from the fact that there were, according to my conception of it, several mistakes made, it was a perfect thing of its kind and a heroic struggle in which the sufferings undergone were bravely borne.
('91', 154, 5, 16, 296315) But the distinction between it and loot should be clearly borne in mind.
('91', 154, 5, 17, 296388) The Dharasana Salt Works were conceived to be national property.The intention there was not to seize the property by force.
('91', 154, 5, 18, 296512) The fight was to assert the right of the nation to the possession of all salt yielded by land or sea in India.
('91', 154, 5, 19, 296623) If the raid had succeeded, that is to say, if the Government had yielded, they would have done so to the nation’s sufferings which the raid and the like involved.
('91', 154, 5, 20, 296786) And, as a matter of fact, the sum total of the sufferings undergone by the people on a nation wide scale did result
('91', 154, 6, 21, 296902) 1 Vide “Question Box”, 29 5 1946. 2 The reference is to the Salt Satyagraha of 1930.
('91', 155, 0, 1, 296987) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 155, 1, 2, 297029) in what is known as the Irwin Gandhi Pact 1. Thus it will be seen that between the loot that the correspondent has in mind and the Dharasana raid there is no analogy whatsoever.

('91', 155, 2, 4, 297240) 196. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('91', 155, 3, 5, 297267) BHANGI COLONY, READING ROAD, NEW DELHI, June 13, 1946
('91', 155, 4, 6, 297321) DEAR FRIEND, Lord Lawrence conveyed your thanks to me last night when he invited me to see him.
('91', 155, 5, 7, 297417) Please believe me when I say that I have never been guilty consciously of doing anything for thanks.“Duty will be merit when debt becomes donation’ and why thank at all when my advice is not followed out?
('91', 155, 5, 8, 297622) You are a great soldier—a daring soldier.
('91', 155, 5, 9, 297664) Dare to do the right.
('91', 155, 5, 10, 297686) You must make your choice of one horse or the other.
('91', 155, 5, 11, 297739) So far as I can see you will never succeed in riding two at the same time.
('91', 155, 5, 12, 297814) Choose the names submitted either by the Congress or the League.
('91', 155, 5, 13, 297879) For God’s sake do not make an incompatible mixture and in trying to do so produce a fearful explosion.
('91', 155, 5, 14, 297982) Anyway, fix your time limit and tell us all to leave when that limit is over.
('91', 155, 5, 15, 298060) I hope I have made my meaning clear.
('91', 155, 6, 16, 298097) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('91', 156, 1, 2, 298402) 197. LETTER TO LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE
('91', 156, 2, 3, 298439) NEW DELHI, June 13, 1946
('91', 156, 3, 4, 298464) DEAR FRIEND, I wrote to you a long letter yesterday 1, partly in fulfilment of my promise to send you a copy of the Rev.
('91', 156, 3, 5, 298585) Nichols Roy’s address and, if I could trace it, Quaid e Azam Jinnah’s address.
('91', 156, 3, 6, 298664) I have not been able yet to lay hands on the reference I told you I had heard read to me.
('91', 156, 3, 7, 298754) But I got the Muslim League Council’s resolution 2 which speaks volumes, at any rate, for me.
('91', 156, 3, 8, 298848) Both these things, without my letter, I handed to Sudhir Ghosh to be given to you.
('91', 156, 3, 9, 298931) The letter I withheld at the instance of Agatha Harrison, Horace Alexander and Sudhir Ghosh who thought that it was likely to pro duce an effect contrary to what I had expected.
('91', 156, 3, 10, 299109) I did not share their view because we have known each other for so many years.
('91', 156, 3, 11, 299188) I lay no stress upon the fact that we have known each other for such a long time for we have had no contact for years after our meeting during the stirring days of the Suffragette Movement.
('91', 156, 3, 12, 299378) 3 The bond that was then created could not, I felt, be easily snapped and so I presumed to write frankly to lay bare my mind to you.
('91', 156, 3, 13, 299511) That I felt was due to you if I was to be a friendly adviser to the Mission which you are leading.
('91', 156, 3, 14, 299610) Nevertheless I yielded to the advice of the three friends.
('91', 156, 3, 15, 299669) I have told them that they are at liberty to describe to you the whole of the conversation between them and me.
('91', 156, 4, 16, 299781) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('91', 156, 5, 17, 299811) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, pp.

('91', 157, 1, 2, 300232) 198. LETTER TO SIR STAFFORD CRIPPS
('91', 157, 2, 3, 300267) NEW DELHI, June 13, 1946
('91', 157, 3, 4, 300292) DEAR SIR STAFFORD, Sudhir told me something of the storm that is brewing within you.
('91', 157, 3, 5, 300377) I met your good wife the day before.
('91', 157, 3, 6, 300414) I would ask you not to worry.
('91', 157, 3, 7, 300444) You are handling the most diffi cult task of your life.
('91', 157, 3, 8, 300500) As I see it the Mission is playing with fire.
('91', 157, 3, 9, 300546) If you have courage you will do what I suggested from the very begin ning.
('91', 157, 3, 10, 300621) Even when the Parliamentary Delegation came 1 before you I said then, “You will not be able to have your cake and eat it.
('91', 157, 3, 11, 300743) You will have to choose between the two—the Muslim League and the Con gress, both your creations.” Every day you pass here coquetting now with the Congress, now with the League and again with the Congress, wearing yourself away.
('91', 157, 3, 12, 300972) [This] will not do.
('91', 157, 3, 13, 300992) Either you swear by what is right or by what the exigencies of British policy may dictate In either case bravery is required.
('91', 157, 3, 14, 301118) Only stick to the programme.
('91', 157, 3, 15, 301147) Stick to your dates even though the heavens may fall.
('91', 157, 3, 16, 301201) Leave by the 16th whether you allow the Congress to form a coalition or the League.
('91', 157, 3, 17, 301285) If you think that the accumulated British wisdom must know better than these two creations of yours I have nothing to add.
('91', 157, 3, 18, 301408) But I have fancied that you are not cast in the mould.
('91', 157, 3, 19, 301463) If so, keep to your passage for the 16th and take your poor wife with you to England and bury yourselves in private life unless the brave British announcement made is fulfilled to the Indian hope.
('91', 157, 3, 20, 301660) A word to the wise.
('91', 157, 4, 21, 301680) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('91', 157, 5, 22, 301710) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, p.
('91', 157, 6, 23, 301769) 1 The British Praliamentary Delegation, consisting of Prof.
('91', 157, 6, 24, 301829) Richards, Lord Charley and Reginald Sorenson had arrived in India on December 5, 1945 and met Gandhiji on January 23 and 24, 1946 at Madras.
('91', 157, 6, 25, 301970) Vide “Discussion with Members of Parliamentary Delegation”, 24 1 1946. 2 In reply the addressee wrote the same day : “I am afraid you, like some others of us, are feeling somewhat impatient!
('91', 157, 6, 26, 302161) But I always remember you advised me to show ‘infinite patience’ in dealing with these difficult matters.
('91', 157, 6, 27, 302267) Certainly I shall never put my desire to return home and rest before my determination to leave nothing undone which may help a solution of the difficult problems here.
('91', 157, 6, 28, 302435) I can assure you neither I nor my colleagues lack courage to act but we want to temper that courage with prudence.
('91', 157, 6, 29, 302550) I still have great hopes that before we leave India, we may have helped towards a settlement of the problem.”

('91', 158, 1, 2, 302702) 199. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 158, 2, 3, 302734) NEW DELHI, June 13, 1946
('91', 158, 3, 4, 302759) Remarking on the size of the prayer gathering on Thursday evening, which was large than usual, Mahatma Gandhi in the course of his speech asked whether it was due to the fact that he had spoken on a political topic on Wednesday and they had come in the expectation of satisfying their curiosity as regards the political situa tion.
('91', 158, 3, 5, 303091) If that was so, it was wrong.
('91', 158, 3, 6, 303121) The only urge which should prompt people to come to the prayer gathering was the desire to know the Maker and attune themselves with Him.
('91', 158, 4, 7, 303259) On Wednesday, Gandhiji said, he had criticized the conduct of the European Group for wanting to exercise a right which did not legitimately belong to them, but today he proposed to say something in criticism of “our own conduct and behaviour”.
('91', 158, 4, 8, 303503) He had been telling his audiences what their duty was in this hour.
('91', 158, 4, 9, 303571) As a firm believer in the utility of community prayer, he had been making them sing Ramdhun in the mass.
('91', 158, 4, 10, 303676) But were they following it in their daily lives?
('91', 158, 4, 11, 303725) To repeat Ramanama and to follow the way of Ravana in actual practice was worse than useless.
('91', 158, 4, 12, 303819) It was sheer hypo crisy.
('91', 158, 4, 13, 303844) One might deceive oneself or the world but one could not deceive the Almighty.
('91', 158, 4, 14, 303923) Today, in the West people talk of Christ, but it is really Anti Christ that rules their lives.
('91', 158, 4, 15, 304018) Similarly, there are people who talk of Islam but they really follow the way of Satan.
('91', 158, 4, 16, 304105) It is a deplorable state of affairs.
('91', 158, 4, 17, 304142) We are afraid of people professing religions other than our own.
('91', 158, 4, 18, 304207) We think that they will crush us, forgetting that no one can crush us if we have made God our refuge.
('91', 158, 4, 19, 304309) The hymn that has just been sung describes how God has redeemed sinners.
('91', 158, 4, 20, 304382) How much more, then, would He do for His devotees?
('91', 158, 4, 21, 304433) But they must be devotees of God in the true sense of the term.
('91', 158, 5, 22, 304497) If people followed the way of God, continued Gandhiji, there would not be the corruption and profiteering that were seen in the world today.
('91', 158, 5, 23, 304638) As it was, the rich were becoming richer and the poor poorer.
('91', 158, 5, 24, 304700) Hunger, nakedness and death stared one in the face.
('91', 158, 5, 25, 304752) These were not the marks of the Kingdom of God but that of Satan, Ravana or Anti Christ.
('91', 158, 5, 26, 304841) They could not expect to bring the reign of God on earth by merely repeating His name with the lips.
('91', 158, 5, 27, 304942) Their conduct must conform to His ways instead of Satan’s.
('91', 158, 6, 28, 305001) The Hindustan Times, 14 6 1946, and Harijan, 23 6 1946
('91', 158, 7, 29, 305056) 1 The Hindustan Times report has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.

('91', 159, 3, 4, 305261) Mahatma Gandhiji said that he still could not tell them what was taking place behind the scenes.
('91', 159, 3, 5, 305358) But he wanted to say that the Cabinet Mission and the Viceroy were working away at it from morning till night.
('91', 159, 3, 6, 305469) They were attempting what could well be considered impossible.
('91', 159, 3, 7, 305532) I have often written that true Hindu Muslim unity cannot be expected while the third party is there.
('91', 159, 3, 8, 305633) The slaves and their master are both in an unnatural state.
('91', 159, 3, 9, 305693) They cannot act and think naturally.
('91', 159, 3, 10, 305730) But suppose a mother sees that her child is dying, still she does not give up hope.
('91', 159, 3, 11, 305814) She keeps on trying the prescriptions of vaidyas or hakims till the last moment.
('91', 159, 3, 12, 305895) Similarly the Mission does not wish to give up striving.
('91', 159, 3, 13, 305952) They are trying to bring the Congress and the League togetjer.
('91', 159, 3, 14, 306015) They are striving with the Europeans to do the right thing.
('91', 159, 3, 15, 306075) The Europeans have said they are going to exercise their right, which is not theirs at all.
('91', 159, 3, 16, 306167) But if the Congress and the League appealed to them they might consider their request.
('91', 159, 3, 17, 306254) There is no question of going to them with the beggar’s bowl.
('91', 159, 3, 18, 306316) They have no place in the Constituent Assembly according to the legal interpretation of the Cabinet Mission’s paper.
('91', 159, 3, 19, 306433) To enslave another country is unnatural.
('91', 159, 3, 20, 306474) Merely by making up a pious resolve they will not get off India’s back.
('91', 159, 3, 21, 306546) The British cannot succeed in doing so.
('91', 159, 3, 22, 306586) Corresponding action is required.
('91', 159, 3, 23, 306620) They are striving and there is no reason for India to doubt their bona fides.
('91', 159, 3, 24, 306698) Their task is difficult.
('91', 159, 3, 25, 306723) The Congress, the League and the British are all labouring under unnatural conditions.

('91', 160, 2, 11, 308547) 202. WHAT HAS THE CONGRESS DONE?
('91', 160, 3, 12, 308580) A Harijan from Gujarat writes:
('91', 160, 4, 13, 308611) The elections have made it clear that only two parties count in India today, the Muslim League and the Congress.
('91', 160, 4, 14, 308724) The elections have also shown that most of the Harijans are with the Congress.
('91', 160, 4, 15, 308803) The Ambedkarites have won very few seats.
('91', 160, 4, 16, 308845) What is the place of Congress Harijans in the Congress?

('91', 162, 2, 3, 311570) A correspondent writes: 2
('91', 162, 3, 4, 311596) If what the writer says is true, it is indeed, in one sense, a matter of shame for every Hindu.
('91', 162, 3, 5, 311692) But no sin can be wiped out by mere condemnation by word of mouth.
('91', 162, 3, 6, 311759) Nor does the guilt of the whole body absolve the individual from his duty.
('91', 162, 3, 7, 311834) Therefore, in my opinion, the responsibility of working for the reform rests, in the first instance, on the correspondent, secondly on the people of the place where the animal sacrifices are held, then on the Ruler of the State and his people and after them in turn on Karnataka, Madras Presidency and the whole of India.
('91', 162, 3, 8, 312156) Only if all, in their respective places, take up the work systematically—and systematic work can only succeed if run on the basis of non violence—can the evil that has been handed down through the ages be wiped out of existence.
('91', 162, 3, 9, 312385) Therefore, it is the correspondent who must make the beginning.
('91', 162, 3, 10, 312449) I have written enough previously as to how the work of reform should be undertaken.

('91', 162, 7, 15, 312757) He indignantly asks:
('91', 162, 8, 16, 312778) Is the Bhangi to continue his service on starvation wages, living in dirt and squalor?
('91', 162, 9, 17, 312865) A. The question is appropriate.
('91', 162, 9, 18, 312897) I claim that in such cases the proper remedy is not a strike but a notice to the public in general and the employing corporation in particular that the Bhangis must give up the sweeping service which consigns those reserved for that service to
('91', 162, 10, 19, 313141) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 23 6 1946. 2 The letter, not reproduced here, informed Gandhiji about the animal sacrifices in Mysore by Harijans as well as priests who also indulged in drinking and beef eating on such occasions.

('91', 163, 0, 1, 313429) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 163, 1, 2, 313471) a life of starvation and all it means.
('91', 163, 1, 3, 313510) There is a wide distinction between a strike and an entire discontinuation (not suspension) of service.
('91', 163, 1, 4, 313614) A strike is a temporary measure in expectation of relief.
('91', 163, 1, 5, 313672) Discontinuance is giving up of a particular job because their is no expectation of relief.
('91', 163, 1, 6, 313763) Proper discontinuance presupposes fair notice on the one hand and prospect of better wages and freedom from squalor and dirt on the other.
('91', 163, 1, 7, 313902) This will wake up society from its disgraceful slumber resul ting in a proper scavenging of the over growth that has smothered public conscience.
('91', 163, 1, 8, 314048) At a stroke the Bhangis will raise scavenging to a fine art and give it the status it should have had long ago.

('91', 171, 6, 16, 331084) 216. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 171, 7, 17, 331114) NEW DELHI, June 18, 1946
('91', 171, 8, 18, 331139) The expectant crowd that attended Mahatma Gandhi’s evening prayer today was again sorely disappointed when he told them that he had nothing decisive to tell them as to the result of the talks Maulana Azad had with the Cabinet Mission.
('91', 171, 8, 19, 331374) A man of prayer must, however, know no disappointment because he knows that the times are in His hands who is the Arch planner and does everything in His good time.
('91', 171, 8, 20, 331539) A man of prayer,
('91', 172, 0, 1, 331556) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 173
('91', 172, 1, 2, 331598) therefore, waits in faith and patience always.
('91', 172, 2, 3, 331645) Making the theme of his after prayer discourse the song that had been sung at the prayers, he explained how that song gave the allegorical story of the struggle between the elephant king (Gajendra) and the Graha (the alligator).
('91', 172, 2, 4, 331874) It is taken from the classical episode of “Gajendra Moksha” from the Bhagavata.
('91', 172, 2, 5, 331954) The original is a piece of rare poetical merit, combining as it does the melodious music of verse with loftiness of the sentiment which it embodies.
('91', 172, 2, 6, 332103) That is the test of all great pieces of art.
('91', 172, 2, 7, 332148) I must combine beauty with use.
('91', 172, 2, 8, 332180) Cattle might be satisfied with filling their bellies with fooder but man likes his food to please the eye as well as provide nourishment.
('91', 172, 2, 9, 332318) In the allegory of Gajendra and Graha the elephant king is seized unawares by the crocodile as he goes to have a drink of water in the river and is dragged down.
('91', 172, 2, 10, 332480) The more he struggles the deeper he sinks.
('91', 172, 2, 11, 332523) A stage is, however, reached when despairing of his physical prowess he throws himself on God’s grace entirely and invokes his aid and the Lord of Dwarka comes in the twinkling of an eye and rescues him.
('91', 172, 2, 12, 332727) The moral of the story is that God never fails His devotees in the hour of trial.
('91', 172, 2, 13, 332809) The condition is that there must be a living faith and the uttermost reliance on Him.
('91', 172, 2, 14, 332895) The test of faith is that having done our duty we must be prepared to welcome whatever He may send—joy as well as sorrow, good luck as well as bad luck.
('91', 172, 2, 15, 333048) We will be like King Janaka who, when informed that his capital was ablaze, only remarked that it was no concern of his.
('91', 172, 2, 16, 333169) 1 The secret of his resignation and equa nimity was that he was ever awake, never remiss in the performance of his duty.
('91', 172, 2, 17, 333290) Having done his duty, he could leave the rest to God.
('91', 172, 2, 18, 333344) And so a man of prayer will in the first place be spared mishaps by the ever merficul Providence, but if mishaps do come he will not bewail his fate nor lay the blame on God but bear it with an undistrubed peace of mind and joyous resignation to His will.
('91', 172, 2, 19, 333600) The Hindustan Times, 19 6 1946
('91', 172, 3, 20, 333631) 1 — Mahabharata, Shantiparva, Ch. 178, 2
('91', 173, 0, 1, 333672) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('91', 173, 5, 6, 334119) 218. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 173, 6, 7, 334151) NEW DELHI, June 19, 1946 If I were appointed dictator for a day in the place of the Vice roy, I would stop all newspapers.
('91', 173, 7, 8, 334274) He added with a smile and a wink: With the exception of Harijan of course.
('91', 173, 8, 9, 334349) Incidentally he remarked that if he had to rename his weekly he would call it not Harijan but “Bhangi” i.
('91', 173, 8, 10, 334455) e., sweeper, that being more in tune with his present temper and the need of the hour as he understood it.
('91', 173, 8, 11, 334562) Deprecating these reports 2 as irresponsible and mischievous, he reminded the fraternity of the Press of Cardinal Newman’s hymn: “Lead Kindly Light”, the Gujarati rendering of which was sung at the prayers.
('91', 173, 8, 12, 334769) Contrary to the teaching of that hymn they always hankered after the “distant scene”, letting their fertile imagination supply what was beyond their ken of knowledge.
('91', 173, 8, 13, 334936) As an illustration of the infinite harm that might result from such irresponsible journalism, he remarked that, if the people were to believe what had been appearing in the Press about his part in the deliberations of the Working Committee, Hindus would be right to execrate him as the enemy of their interests.
('91', 173, 8, 14, 335248) It was further being made to appear, he observed, that his was the only intransigent voice in the Working Committee.
('91', 173, 8, 15, 335365) He wanted them to dismiss all that as pure imagination.
('91', 173, 8, 16, 335421) He appealed to newspapermen to put a curb on their pen.
('91', 173, 8, 17, 335477) Failing that it was up to the public to shed their craving for ‘potted’ news and to cease to patronize papers that purveyed it or at least cease to be misled by what might appear in them.
('91', 173, 9, 18, 335665) 1 The Hindustan Times report has been collated with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 173, 10, 19, 335771) 2 In the Press about what was supposed to be taking place in the Congress Working Committee
('91', 174, 0, 1, 335863) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 175
('91', 174, 1, 2, 335905) Gandhiji remarked that it was wholly untrue that the delay in arriving at a final decision was due to divisions in the Working Committee.
('91', 174, 1, 3, 336043) Differences of opinion were inevitable in a living organization.
('91', 174, 1, 4, 336108) He himself did not know what the final decision of the Working Committee was going to be.
('91', 174, 1, 5, 336198) It was but natural that there should be more Hindus on the Congress register than Muslims, as the Hindu population preponderated in India.
('91', 174, 1, 6, 336337) But the Congress could not by any stretch of imagination be called a Hindu organization.
('91', 174, 1, 7, 336426) Its President Maulana Azad had occupied the Presidential chair for a longer period than any other in the Congress history.
('91', 174, 1, 8, 336549) He was held in equal respect by all those who claim to be of the Congress.
('91', 174, 1, 9, 336624) The Congress had constituted itself into a trustee, not of any particular community, but of India as a whole.
('91', 174, 1, 10, 336734) In an organization like that it always became the duty of the majority to make sacrifices for the minorities and backward sections, not in a spirit of patronizing favour, but in a dignified manner and as a duty.
('91', 174, 1, 11, 336946) In the eyes of the Congress, Hindus and Mussalmans, Parsis, Christians and Sikhs are all Indians and therfore equally entitled to its care.
('91', 174, 1, 12, 337086) The Congress has no sanction except that of non violence.
('91', 174, 1, 13, 337144) Unlike the Viceroy, who has the entire armed force of the British Empire at his back, the Congress President can rely only on the united and whole hearted co operation of all the communities and classes to give effect to India’s will to independence.
('91', 174, 1, 14, 337395) The Working Committee is, therefore, anxious that we should accept responsibility at the Centre only with the unanimous goodwill of all the communities.
('91', 174, 1, 15, 337548) That is why they were giving such anxious thought to all the various interests which they claim to represent.
('91', 174, 1, 16, 337658) They have to adjust conflicting claims and interests and that is a ticklish job.
('91', 174, 1, 17, 337739) They do not want to make the Interim Government an arena of unseemly quarrels among themselves or with members of the Muslim League.
('91', 174, 2, 18, 337872) The Hindustan Times, 20 6 1946, and Harijan, 30 6 1946

('91', 175, 5, 9, 338892) 221. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 175, 6, 10, 338922) NEW DELHI, [June 20, 1946] 2
('91', 175, 7, 11, 338951) Much as he would have liked to share with them all that was taking place in the Working Committee and in the course of his talks with the Cabinet Mission, he was not free to do so, said Gandhiji.
('91', 175, 7, 12, 339147) When there was anything worth knowing he would tell them.
('91', 175, 7, 13, 339205) They should not run after ‘potted’ news served by the commercialized daily Press.
('91', 175, 7, 14, 339287) There were two kinds of curiosity, he remarked—healthy and unhealthy.
('91', 175, 7, 15, 339357) One should always be curious to know one’s duty at every step.
('91', 175, 7, 16, 339420) But the itch for news was a kind of mental dissipation debilitating to the mind and spirit, unless it was properly curbed.
('91', 175, 8, 17, 339543) Commenting upon Mira’s song which was sung at the prayer he said that in that song the devotee asks the should to drink deep of the nectar of God’s name.
('91', 175, 8, 18, 339697) Physical food and drink result in satiety and if over indulged in illness.
('91', 175, 8, 19, 339772) But the ambrosia of God’s name knows no such limit.
('91', 175, 8, 20, 339824) The deeper one drinks of it the more the thirst for it grows.
('91', 175, 9, 21, 339886) But it must sink deep into the heart.
('91', 175, 9, 22, 339924) When that happens all delusion and attachment, lust and envy, fall off from us.
('91', 175, 9, 23, 340004) Only one must persevere and have patience.
('91', 175, 9, 24, 340047) Success is the inevitable result of such effort.
('91', 175, 9, 25, 340096) The Hindustan Times, 21 6 1946

('91', 176, 2, 3, 340669) IMITATION
('91', 176, 3, 4, 340679) Q. You have averred that a person who gives up eating meat in mere imitation of you cannot be said to be doing the right thing.
('91', 176, 3, 5, 340807) Are you not wrong in holding this view?
('91', 176, 4, 6, 340847) A. I see nothing wrong in what I said.
('91', 176, 4, 7, 340886) 2 If a person may change his practice in imitation, it is equally possible for him to revert to the original practice in imitation.
('91', 176, 4, 8, 341018) 3 The gist of what I said was that nothing should be done without being well weighed and thought out and without deep conviction.
('91', 176, 4, 9, 341148) Thoughtless imitation is the sport of little minds and may lead a man into a ditch with disastrous results.
('91', 176, 5, 10, 341256) HARIJAN COLLECTIONS
('91', 176, 6, 11, 341276) Q. You collect funds for Harijans wherever you go.
('91', 176, 6, 12, 341327) According to Press reports, you sometimes receive large sums for that purpose.
('91', 176, 6, 13, 341406) What is the total amount that you have collected?
('91', 176, 6, 14, 341456) How is it spent?
('91', 176, 6, 15, 341473) Are the accounts inspected or audited by anyone?
('91', 176, 6, 16, 341522) I do not mean to suggest that the funds are being misused, but it ill becomes you to keep the people in the dark about these things.
('91', 176, 7, 17, 341655) A. The question hardly calls for a reply.
('91', 176, 7, 18, 341697) But there must be many uninformed people like the correspondent.
('91', 176, 7, 19, 341762) By itself the question is legitimate.
('91', 176, 7, 20, 341800) The answer is simple.
('91', 176, 7, 21, 341822) All Harijan collections made by me are handed over to the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('91', 176, 7, 22, 341901) Shri Thakkar Bapa is the guardian of the fund.
('91', 176, 7, 23, 341948) It is spent according to the direction and with the sanction of the Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('91', 176, 7, 24, 342037) Some of it is spent according to my instructions, but it has to be for the service of the Harijans only.
('91', 176, 7, 25, 342142) Similarly for other funds, donations are sent to be spent at my discretion.
('91', 176, 7, 26, 342218) Strict account is kept of every pie and the income and expenditure accounts are duly audited and certified from time to time.

('91', 183, 7, 17, 356525) The passive resisters were not criminals but respectable citizens.
('91', 183, 7, 18, 356592) They were fighting for the vindication of their rights.
('91', 183, 7, 19, 356648) As self respecting people they preferred imprisonment to segregation in ghettos.

('91', 185, 3, 4, 359340) In the Working Committee meeting in the afternoon Bapu put forth his emphatic view that the Congress should keep out of the Interim Government but go into the Constituent Assembly as it was purely an elective body whose representative character was admitted even by the British Government.
('91', 185, 3, 5, 359630) The Viceroy could not interfere with its working—he could not even sit in it as a matter of right.
('91', 185, 3, 6, 359729) If the worst came to the worst, it could be turned into a rebel body.
('91', 185, 3, 7, 359799) In the alternative, he saw no possiblity of giving a fight, as the requisite atmosphere of non violence was not forth coming.
('91', 185, 3, 8, 359925) Personally, he could not even think of launching civil disobedience, etc.

('91', 186, 2, 6, 362044) But as an old maxim says, the corruption of the best is the worst.
('91', 186, 2, 7, 362111) A single drop of poison can convert a pot of nectar into a fatal draught.
('91', 186, 3, 8, 362185) He had commended the State document because of its voluntary character.
('91', 186, 3, 9, 362257) But he had only an hour ago made a discovery which had come to him and the members of the Working Committee as a rude shock.
('91', 186, 3, 10, 362382) A telegram from Assam had drawn attention to the fact that under Rules of Procedure for the election of members to the Constituent Assembly that had been issued from the Viceroy’s office to the Speakers of the various Provincial Assemblies, no one could stand as a candidate unless he signed a declaration that he would abide by clause 19 of the State Paper of May 16. As they all knew, clause 19 referred, among other things, to grouping.
('91', 186, 3, 11, 362822) It was true that there was no legal sanction behind the document and therefore if anyone signed that declaration and afterwards did not abide by it he did not incur the penalty of law.
('91', 186, 3, 12, 363007) Nevertheless, the undertaking would be morally binding and its breach would amount to bad faith, and those who were prepared to sacrifice honesty would make sorry architects of India’s future.
('91', 186, 4, 13, 363200) It grieved him to see that the Constituent Assembly was being killed by the underlings of the very people who had given it birth.
('91', 186, 4, 14, 363330) He exculpated the authors of the State Paper unless he found that they had known that such instructions were issued.
('91', 186, 5, 15, 363447) No one, not even the framers, had any right to interpret the State Paper in their own way, said Gandhiji.
('91', 186, 5, 16, 363553) It could only be interpreted by a properly constituted court of law.
('91', 186, 5, 17, 363622) The document had to be interpreted and applied as a whole.
('91', 186, 5, 18, 363681) He still clung to the hope that it was only an error, and would soon be rectified.
('91', 186, 5, 19, 363764) Then and then alone would it be possible to decide whether the Constituent Assembly was worthy of the name.
('91', 186, 5, 20, 363872) If they participated in it, it would be for the sake of gaining India’s independence.
('91', 186, 5, 21, 363958) If they decided against it, it would still be in the same cause.
