('91', 195, 2, 3, 380183) NEW DELHI, June 25, 1946 2
('91', 195, 3, 4, 380210) Gandhiji drew attention to the demi official statement 3 that had appeared in the Press that the instructions issued for the election of candidates for the Constituent Assembly did not bind them to anything in clause 19 of the Statement.
('91', 195, 3, 5, 380448) This was clear in the declaration quoted in the papers.
('91', 195, 3, 6, 380504) He was sorry, said Gandhiji, that he had not seen it before he made his Sunday’s speech.
('91', 195, 3, 7, 380593) 4 He was glad to say that his fears on that score had proved groundless.
('91', 195, 3, 8, 380666) He felt he owed it to the Delegation to own his mistake, however bona fide it was.
('91', 195, 4, 9, 380749) He referred to the report of the deliberations of the Working Committee that had appeared in the newspapers.
('91', 195, 4, 10, 380858) It was true that the Working Committee had decided to reject the proposals put before them for the formation of a provisional government for the interim period.
('91', 195, 4, 11, 381019) But they had decided to go into the proposed Constituent Assembly.
('91', 195, 4, 12, 381086) There were several flaws in the proposal for the Constituent Assembly, he said, but the Working Committee had reasoned that after all, it would consist of the elected representatives of the people.
('91', 195, 4, 13, 381284) So, after considering every aspect of the question, they had decided that it should not be rejected.
('91', 195, 5, 14, 381385) The papers had also reported, proceeded Gandhiji, that the Working Committee’s decision had been taken in the teeth of his opposition.
('91', 195, 5, 15, 381520) That was a misleading statement to make.
('91', 195, 5, 16, 381561) The fact was that for the last four or five days his mind had been filled with a vague misgiving.
('91', 195, 5, 17, 381659) He saw darkness where he had seen light before.
('91', 195, 5, 18, 381707) He knew that darkness indicated lack of faith in God.
('91', 195, 5, 19, 381761) One whose being is filled with God, should never experience darkness.
('91', 195, 6, 20, 381831) Be that as it may, said Gandhiji, the fact remained that he did not see the light just then.
('91', 195, 6, 21, 381924) What was more, he could not explain or give re asons for his fear.
('91', 195, 6, 22, 381991) He had, therefore, simply placed his misgiving before the Working Committee and told them that they should come to a decision independently of him.
('91', 195, 6, 23, 382139) Those whose function was to give a lead to the country could not afford to be guided by another’s unreasoned instinct.
('91', 195, 6, 24, 382258) They could not guide the destiny of the country unless they had the capacity to think for themselves and convince others by reason.
('91', 195, 6, 25, 382390) The members of the Working Committee, he concluded, were the servants of the nation.
('91', 195, 6, 26, 382475) They had no other sanction except the willing consent of the people whom they tried to serve.
('91', 195, 6, 27, 382569) The latter would remove them whenever they liked.
('91', 195, 6, 28, 382619) His advice to the people, therefore, was to follow

('91', 196, 0, 1, 382858) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 197
('91', 196, 1, 2, 382900) the lead given by the Working Committee.
('91', 196, 1, 3, 382941) He would tell them when he saw the light.
('91', 196, 1, 4, 382983) But so long as darkness surrounded him in anything, nobody should follow him in it.

('91', 196, 2, 6, 383086) 250. WHITE MAN’S BURDEN
('91', 196, 3, 7, 383110) According to Reuter picked Indians, men and women, headed by Dr. Naicker, commenced satyagraha (in South Africa popularly known as passive resistance) on June 14th in respect of the Segregation Law of the Union Parliament of South Africa.
('91', 196, 3, 8, 383349) The same agency further reports that neither the Government nor the Municipality had taken any action against the passive resisters but that some ‘whites’ of Durban had taken the execution of the law into their own hands by raiding the camp at night, cutting down tents swiftly and carrying them away.“A band of 100 young white men broke through the cordon of 50 Indian passive resisters, pulled down the tents and dragged them away torn.
('91', 196, 3, 9, 383788) Some camp stretchers were smashed and blankets and pillows removed.
('91', 196, 3, 10, 383856) Two women resisters were involved in the melee.
('91', 196, 3, 11, 383904) They are stated to have been kicked but not injured.
('91', 196, 3, 12, 383957) The papers report that after three days of hooliganism the Borough police had posted themselves near the scene of passive resistance and warned the hooligans against molesting the resisters and terrorizing them into submission.
('91', 196, 3, 13, 384185) This is heartening news.
('91', 196, 3, 14, 384210) Let us hope that it can be taken at its full value and that the protection means fullest protection against lawlessness, sporadic or organized.
('91', 196, 3, 15, 384354) Organized popular lawlessness is known as lynching, so shamelessly frequent in America.
('91', 196, 3, 16, 384442) Before the Segregation Law was passed, white men, known to be respectable, had carried anti Asiatic agitation to the point of frenzy.
('91', 196, 3, 17, 384576) Not satisfied with their triumph in having legislation compelling segregation passed probably beyond expectation, the more advanced section among the agitators have become the executioners of their own laws.
('91', 196, 3, 18, 384784) They do not know that they are thereby defaming the white man’s name!
('91', 196, 3, 19, 384854) My appeal to the white men and women who have regard for laws for which they have voted is that they should create public opinion against hooliganism and lynch law.
('91', 196, 3, 20, 385019) Passive resistance is aimed at removal in a most approved
('91', 197, 0, 1, 385077) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 197, 1, 2, 385119) manner of bad laws, customs or other evils and is designed to be a complete and effective substitute for forcible methods including hooliganism and lynch law.
('91', 197, 1, 3, 385278) It is an appeal to the heart of man.
('91', 197, 1, 4, 385315) Often reason fails.
('91', 197, 1, 5, 385335) It is dwarfed by self.
('91', 197, 1, 6, 385358) The theory is that an adequate appeal to the heart never fails.
('91', 197, 1, 7, 385422) Seeming failure is not of the law of satyagraha but of incompetence of the satyagrahi by whatever cause induced.
('91', 197, 1, 8, 385535) It may not be possible to give a complete historical instance.
('91', 197, 1, 9, 385598) The name of Jesus at once comes to the lips.
('91', 197, 1, 10, 385643) It is an instance of brilliant failure.
('91', 197, 1, 11, 385683) And he has been acclaimed in the West as Prince of passive resisters.
('91', 197, 1, 12, 385753) I showed years ago in South Africa that the adjective “passive” was a misnomer, at least as applied to Jesus.
('91', 197, 1, 13, 385863) He was the most active resister known perhaps to history.
('91', 197, 1, 14, 385921) His was non violence par excellence.
('91', 197, 1, 15, 385958) But I must no longer stray from my main subject.
('91', 197, 1, 16, 386007) It is the resistance of the Jesus type that the white hooligans are seeking to thwart.
('91', 197, 1, 17, 386094) Let us hope that our countrymen’s heroic resistance will not only shame the hooligans into silence but prove the precursor of the repeal of the Law that disfigures the statute book of South Africa.
('91', 197, 1, 18, 386292) In concrete form, what pure suffering, wholly one sided, does is to stir public opinion against a wrong.
('91', 197, 1, 19, 386397) Legislators are, after all, representatives of the public.
('91', 197, 1, 20, 386456) In obedience to it they have enacted a wrong.
('91', 197, 1, 21, 386502) They have to reverse the process when the same public, awakened to the wrong, demands its removal.
('91', 197, 1, 22, 386601) The real ‘white man’s burden’ is not insolently to dominate coloured or black people under the guise of protection; it is to desist from the hypocrisy which is eating into them.
('91', 197, 1, 23, 386779) It is time white men learnt to treat every human being as their equal.
('91', 197, 1, 24, 386850) There is no mystery about whiteness of the skin.
('91', 197, 1, 25, 386899) It has repeatedly been proved that given equal opportunity a man, be he of any colour or country, is fully equal to any other.
('91', 197, 1, 26, 387026) Therefore, white men throughout the world and especially of India should act upon their fellow men in South Africa and call upon them not to molest Indian resisters who are bravely struggling to preserve the self respect of Indians in the Union and the honour of their motherland.
('91', 197, 1, 27, 387307) “Do unto others as you would that they should do unto you.” Or, do they take in vain the name of Him who said this?
('91', 197, 1, 28, 387423) Have they bani shed from their hearts the great coloured Asiatic who gave to the world the above message?
('91', 197, 1, 29, 387529) Do they forget that the greatest of the teachers of mankind were all Asiatics and did not possess a white face?
('91', 197, 1, 30, 387641) These, if they descended on earth and went to South Africa, would all have to live in the segregated areas and be classed as
('91', 198, 0, 1, 387766) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 199
('91', 198, 1, 2, 387808) Asiatics and coloured people unfit by law to be equals of whites.
('91', 198, 1, 3, 387874) Is a civilization worth the name which requires for its existence the very doubtful prop of racial legislation and lynch law?
('91', 198, 1, 4, 388000) The silver lining to the cloud that hangs over the devoted heads of our countrymen lies in the plucky action of Rev.
('91', 198, 1, 5, 388117) Scott 1, a white clergyman, and his equally white fellow workers, who have undertaken to share the sufferings of the Indian resisters.
('91', 198, 2, 6, 388252) NEW DELHI, June 26, 1946 Harijan, 30 6 1946
('91', 198, 3, 7, 388296) 251. DR.
('91', 198, 3, 8, 388305) LOHIA’S CHALLENGE
('91', 198, 4, 9, 388323) It would appear from newspaper reports that Dr. Lohia 3 went to Goa at the invitation of Goans and was served with an order to refrain from making speeches.
('91', 198, 4, 10, 388480) According to Dr. Lohia’s statement, for 188 years now, the people of Goa have been robbed of the right to hold meetings and form organizations.
('91', 198, 4, 11, 388624) Naturally he defied the order.
('91', 198, 4, 12, 388655) He has thereby rendered a service to the cause of civil liberty and especially to the Goans.
('91', 198, 4, 13, 388748) The little Portuguese settlement which merely exists on the sufferance of the British Government can ill afford to ape its bad manners.
('91', 198, 4, 14, 388884) In free India Goa cannot be allowed to exist as a separate entity in opposition to the laws of the free State.
('91', 198, 4, 15, 388995) Without a shot being fired, the people of Goa will be able to claim and receive the rights of citizenship of the free State.
('91', 198, 4, 16, 389120) The present Portuguese Government will no longer be able to rely upon the protection of British arms to isolate and keep under subjection the inhabitants of Goa against their will.
('91', 198, 4, 17, 389301) I would venture to advise the Portuguese Government of Goa to recognize the signs of the times and come to honourable terms with its inhabitants rather than function on any treaty that might exist between them and the British Government.
('91', 198, 4, 18, 389539) To the inhabitants of Goa I will say that they should shed fear of the Portuguese Government as the people of other parts of India have shed fear of the mighty British Government and assert their fundamental right of civil liberty and all it means.
('91', 198, 4, 19, 389788) The differences of religion among the inhabitants of Goa should be no bar to common civil life.
('91', 198, 4, 20, 389884) Religion is for each individual, himself or herself, to live.
('91', 198, 5, 21, 389946) Michael Scott 2 An advance copy of this was sent to Lord Wavell.

('91', 200, 6, 12, 392439) MANUDI, I got your letter of the 15th three days ago.
('91', 200, 6, 13, 392493) But I am able to reply to it only today.
('91', 200, 6, 14, 392534) After discussing the courage that you had displayed you asked me whether I would call it violence or non violence.
('91', 200, 6, 15, 392649) I should advise you not to bother about that question.
('91', 200, 6, 16, 392704) If we go on reflecting over the meaning of ahimsa, we shall but act non violently when the occasion arises.
('91', 200, 6, 17, 392812) We should not mind whether other people regarded it as non violent or not.
('91', 200, 6, 18, 392887) The effect of such action depends not on what others think about it but on what is in our minds.
('91', 200, 6, 19, 392984) We do not know our minds ourselves, but, assuming that we do, if the mind says that in abusing or slapping a person we acted non violently, it would be for us a non violent action.
('91', 200, 6, 20, 393165) Whether in fact it was non violent God alone can know.
('91', 200, 6, 21, 393220) The other party and the spectators also can judge it from the effect of the action on the former.

('91', 202, 2, 3, 395703) NEW DELHI, June 26, 1946

('91', 202, 4, 14, 396183) A mere Asiatic.

('91', 206, 6, 12, 401800) 265. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 206, 7, 13, 401832) NEW DELHI, June 27, 1946
('91', 206, 8, 14, 401857) The South African satyagraha was again the theme of Gandhiji’s talk after the prayers today.
('91', 206, 8, 15, 401950) The whites there were becoming more and more frenzied in their hooliganism and seemed to be determined to cow down the satyagrahis who were behaving in a calm and diginified manner.
('91', 206, 8, 16, 402132) The Indians in South Africa were a little over two lakhs only.
('91', 206, 8, 17, 402195) They were a mere handful in the midst of the overwhelming mojority of white men and Negroes.
('91', 206, 8, 18, 402288) Imagine what it must mean for men like Doctors Naicker and Dadoo to be required to live in special locations.
('91', 206, 8, 19, 402398) I want you all to continue your prayers to God to enable our brethren to remain steadfast till the end and to vouchsafe wisdom to the whites.
('91', 206, 8, 20, 402540) Let me repeat that prayer from the heart can achieve what nothing else can in the world.
('91', 206, 8, 21, 402629) Two months’ mountain air 2 seems to be necessary to keep me going for the rest of the year.
('91', 206, 8, 22, 402721) It is surprising, the difference it makes.
('91', 206, 8, 23, 402764) But I am not altogether sure whether it is not Ramanama really that is responsible for the marvellous result.
('91', 206, 9, 24, 402874) The Bombay Chronicle, 28 6 1946, and Harijan, 7 7 1946
('91', 206, 10, 25, 402929) 1 The report in The Bombay Chronicle has been collected with Pyarelal’s version in his “Weekly Letter” in Harijan.
('91', 206, 10, 26, 403044) 2 Gandhiji was to leave the following evening for Panchgani.
('91', 207, 0, 1, 403105) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 207, 1, 2, 403147) 266. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 207, 2, 3, 403177) NEW DELHI, June 28, 1946
('91', 207, 3, 4, 403202) Gandhiji paid tribute to the courage and suffering of the passive resisters with out retaliation in the midst of the hooliganism which was daily increasing.
('91', 207, 3, 5, 403359) He was born in India but was made in South Africa of which he knew practically every province.
('91', 207, 3, 6, 403454) He had passed there twenty years of his life at its meridian.
('91', 207, 3, 7, 403516) He knew the white men of South Africa.
('91', 207, 3, 8, 403555) He loved them as well as his countrymen.
('91', 207, 3, 9, 403596) He felt ashmed, he said, of the hooliganism of some of them.
('91', 207, 3, 10, 403657) He had the fear that this hooliganism had the sympathy of the mass of the white men of the Union.
('91', 207, 3, 11, 403755) Hooliganism would not flourish without such silent sympathy.
('91', 207, 3, 12, 403816) He fondly hoped that as the white men realized the deep strength and sincerity of satyagrahis, they would begin to respect them and transfer their sympathy to the suffering passive resisters.
('91', 207, 3, 13, 404008) He asked the gathering to offer their heartfelt prayers for God’s mercy on the hooligans.
('91', 207, 3, 14, 404098) He did not want to send money to their contrymen.
('91', 207, 3, 15, 404148) Money could not give them victory.
('91', 207, 3, 16, 404183) They had money enough.
('91', 207, 3, 17, 404206) But a time might come when it would be their duty in India to offer non violent resistance of the purest type for the sake of their brethren.
('91', 207, 3, 18, 404348) He could not tell how.
('91', 207, 3, 19, 404371) India was fast becoming the storehouse of the honour and dignity of the human race.
('91', 207, 3, 20, 404455) It would be in the fitness of things if it fell to their lot to help the struggle of gallant resisters of South Africa.
('91', 207, 3, 21, 404575) But for that the way must be clear before them.
('91', 207, 3, 22, 404623) He felt that he would know when it was clear.
('91', 207, 3, 23, 404669) Meantime he invoked the sympathy of the Viceroy and the white men and women of India to do their portion of duty.
('91', 207, 4, 24, 404783) Taking stock of his nearly three months’ communion with them (with only two breaks) he asked them to preserve and enlarge the most precious part of what he was leaving behind,viz., the practice of common prayer.
('91', 207, 4, 25, 404995) He did not mind whether they recited the prayer verse or not.
('91', 207, 4, 26, 405057) What was absolutely necessary was that all the members of their families should daily assemble at a convenient time and observe at the most five minutes silence with concentration on God within.
('91', 207, 5, 27, 405252) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 6 1946, and Harijan 7 7 1946
('91', 208, 0, 1, 405306) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 209
('91', 208, 1, 2, 405348) 267. KHADI MAD 1
('91', 208, 2, 3, 405365) The Rajkot Rashtriyashala appeal about the Charkha Jayanti of this year is as follows 2: Narandas Gandhi is khadi mad.
('91', 208, 2, 4, 405484) There are two ideas governing my conception of a yarn bank.
('91', 208, 2, 5, 405544) First, that all yarn in whatever quantity, of whatever quality and from wheresoever it comes should be colleced in one place.
('91', 208, 2, 6, 405670) From there it should be sent to the weaver in such a condition as will enable him to weave it with the same speed as he weaves mill yarn.
('91', 208, 2, 7, 405808) For this purpose all yarn has to be doubled and twisted.
('91', 208, 2, 8, 405865) Yarn that has not been subjected to this process should not really be reckoned as yarn.
('91', 208, 2, 9, 405953) There will thus be two kinds of yarn, one doubled and twisted and one single.
('91', 208, 2, 10, 406031) The former will have a higher value.
('91', 208, 2, 11, 406068) It will, of course, take time to achieve this desideratum.
('91', 208, 2, 12, 406127) In the meantime, yarn will have to be separated and the single thread doubled and twisted and then woven into cloth at the yarn depot or wherever it may be suitable.
('91', 208, 2, 13, 406293) The second thing to remember is that just as gold and silver emerge as coins from a mint, so khadi alone should emerge from a yarn bank.
('91', 208, 2, 14, 406430) Not until such time as this happens will the defects in hand spun yarn be removed and the quality of khadi improved beyond expectation.
('91', 208, 2, 15, 406566) This work cannot be accomplished by compul sion.
('91', 208, 2, 16, 406615) Khadi must be selfless, true and of a scientific mind for the easy, quick and voluntary achievement of this noble end.
('91', 208, 3, 17, 406734) To acheive it is the real goal of the Charkha Sangh.
('91', 208, 3, 18, 406787) It will not matter if, in working up to this end, all the sales bhandars have to be closed and khadi wearers reduced to a handful.
('91', 208, 3, 19, 406918) Even so, there will be no shame attaching to the endeavour.
('91', 208, 3, 20, 406978) On the other hand, if khadi is sold as a symbol of hypocrisy and untruth it will drag the names of both the Charkha Sangh and the Congress in the mud and khadi will no longer be able either to deliver swaraj or be the mainstay of the poor.
('91', 208, 3, 21, 407218) Unbelievers will ask: ‘Then why take so much trouble over khadi?
('91', 208, 3, 22, 407283) Why not let it remain as one of the many occupations of village India, instead of being fad of non violence?’ Those who are khadi mad must learn the secret of the science of khadi and be

('91', 215, 4, 5, 421030) A friend from Patidar Ashram, Surat, writes to Shri Narahari Parikh: 2
('91', 215, 5, 6, 421101) If Harijan girls are to marry caste Hindus it should be on condition that the couple will devote their lives to the service of the Harijans.

('91', 215, 5, 8, 421354) If an educated Harijan girl marries a caste Hindu, the couple ought to devote themselves to the service of Harijans.
('91', 215, 5, 9, 421471) Self indul gence can never be the object of such a marriage.
('91', 215, 5, 10, 421532) That will be im proper.
('91', 215, 5, 11, 421556) I can never encourage it.
('91', 215, 5, 12, 421582) It is possible that a marriage entered into with the best of intentions turns out to be a failure.
('91', 215, 5, 13, 421681) No one can prevent such mishaps.
('91', 215, 5, 14, 421714) Even if one Harijan girl marries a caste Hindu with a high character it will do good to both the Hari jans and caste Hindus.
('91', 215, 5, 15, 421839) They will set up a good precedent and if the Harijan girl is really worthy, she will spread her fragrance far and wide and encourage others to copy her example.
('91', 215, 5, 16, 422000) Society will cease to be scared by such marriages.
('91', 215, 5, 17, 422051) They will see for themselves that there is nothing wrong in them.
('91', 215, 5, 18, 422117) If children born of such a union turn out to be good, they will further help to remove untouchability.

('91', 215, 5, 20, 422271) To be dissatisfied with this slowness of progress betrays ignorance of the way in which reform works.
('91', 215, 5, 21, 422373) It is certainly desirable that caste Hindu girls should select Harijan husbands.
('91', 215, 5, 22, 422454) I hesitate to say that it is better.
('91', 215, 5, 23, 422491) That would imply that women are inferior to men.
('91', 215, 5, 24, 422540) I know that such inferiority complex is there today.
('91', 215, 5, 25, 422593) For this reason I would agree that at present the marriage of a caste Hindu girl to a Harijan is better than that of a Harijan girl to a caste Hindu.
('91', 215, 5, 26, 422743) If I had my way I would persuade all caste Hindu girls coming under my influence to select Harijan husbands.

('91', 218, 1, 2, 428008) 273. WHY KILL?
('91', 218, 2, 3, 428023) The following suggestion has been received from Aligarh: 2
('91', 218, 3, 4, 428082) You write: “We have to kill monkeys, birds and animals which ruin the crops, or else keep someone who will kill them for us.” My uncle has been able to keep monkeys off his field by using strong electric light at night.
('91', 218, 3, 5, 428302) Why cannot this method be given a wider trial?
('91', 218, 3, 6, 428349) At first sight the suggestion seems attractive but on deeper thought one finds that it won’t work.
('91', 218, 3, 7, 428448) I might be able to protect my own field in this manner, but what of those round about?
('91', 218, 3, 8, 428535) It will not be right for me selfishly to save my crops at the cost of others.
('91', 218, 3, 9, 428613) That will be violence in the name of non violence.
('91', 218, 3, 10, 428664) For instance, we will throw a snake or rubbish from our own yard into that of our neighbour without compunction.
('91', 218, 3, 11, 428777) True ahimsa demands that if we must save the society as well as ourselves from the mischief of mon keys and the like, we have to kill them.
('91', 218, 3, 12, 428917) The general rule is that we must avoid violence to the utmost extent possible.
('91', 218, 3, 13, 428996) Non violence for the society is necessarily different from that for the individual.
('91', 218, 3, 14, 429080) One living apart from society may defy all precaution, not so society as such.
('91', 218, 4, 15, 429159) June 30, 1946 Harijan, 7 7 1946

('91', 227, 4, 11, 445143) 286. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 227, 5, 12, 445173) POONA, July 2, 1946
('91', 227, 6, 13, 445193) God is not a person.
('91', 227, 6, 14, 445214) He is the all pervading, all powerful spirit.
('91', 227, 6, 15, 445260) Anyone who bears Him in his or her heart has access to a marvellous force or energy as effective in its results as, say, electricity, but much subtler.
('91', 227, 7, 16, 445412) In explaining the significance of Ramanama was he propagating a species of superstition, he asked.
('91', 227, 7, 17, 445511) “No” was his reply.
('91', 227, 7, 18, 445531) Mere repetition of Ramanama possessed no mysterious virtue as such.
('91', 227, 7, 19, 445599) Ramanama was not like black magic.
('91', 227, 7, 20, 445634) It had to be taken with all that it symbolized.
('91', 227, 7, 21, 445682) Rather, it was like a mathematical formula which summed up in brief the result of endless research.
('91', 227, 7, 22, 445782) Mere mechanical repetition of Ramanama could not give strength.
('91', 227, 7, 23, 445846) For that one had to understand and live up to the conditions attaching to its recitation.
('91', 227, 7, 24, 445936) To take God’s name one had to live a godly life.
('91', 227, 8, 25, 445985) Mathatma Gandhi said that the outbreak of communal riots in Ahemedabad had pained him deeply and he had told Mr. Morarji Desai, Bombay’s Home Minister, who had come to see him before his departure for Ahmedabad, that he (Mr. Desai) must go to meet the flames under the sole protection of God, not that of the police and military.
('91', 227, 8, 26, 446315) If need be, he must perish in the flames in the attempt to quell them as the late Mr. Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi had done.
('91', 227, 9, 27, 446436) 1 In March, 1931. Vide “Speech on Kanpur Riots, Subjects Committee Meeting, Karachi”, 27 3 1931, “Telegram to Balkrishna Sharma”, 1 4 1931 and “Notes”, 9 4 1931. The Following paragraph is translated from Pyarelal’s Gujarati article “Three Pure Sacrifices” Harijanbandhu.
('91', 228, 0, 1, 446708) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 229
('91', 228, 1, 2, 446750) Two Hindu workers and a Muslim worker set out to quell the riots and died in the effort.
('91', 228, 1, 3, 446839) I am not unhappy at their death.
('91', 228, 1, 4, 446872) I do not weep for them.
('91', 228, 1, 5, 446896) Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi laid down his life similarly in the Kanpur riots.
('91', 228, 1, 6, 446971) Friends had warned him: “Do not go in to the riot affected area.
('91', 228, 1, 7, 447036) The people there have gone mad.
('91', 228, 1, 8, 447068) They will kill you.” But Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi was not to be daunted.
('91', 228, 1, 9, 447141) He was confident that his going would stop the riots.
('91', 228, 1, 10, 447195) He went there and died at the hands of those who had gone mad.
('91', 228, 1, 11, 447258) I was happy at his death.
('91', 228, 1, 12, 447284) I do not say all this to excite you.
('91', 228, 1, 13, 447321) I want to make you understand that if you but learn how to die all will be well.
('91', 228, 1, 14, 447402) If enough young men like Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi, Vasantrao 1 and Rajab Ali 2 came out, riots could be banished for ever.
('91', 228, 2, 15, 447525) Gandhiji also stated that the Congress Ministry in the Province was there to serve all the communities, but the Ministers could not serve them unless they had the willing co operation of the people.
('91', 228, 3, 16, 447724) In Ahmedabad, went on Gandhiji, the pride of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, where he had rendered yeoman’s service to the Municipality, Hindus and Muslims had always lived together in peace.
('91', 228, 3, 17, 447910) But of late, they seemed to be dehumanized.
('91', 228, 3, 18, 447954) Today Hindus and Muslims have gone mad and are stabbing each other.
('91', 228, 3, 19, 448022) How shameful and tragic it is!
('91', 228, 3, 20, 448053) If one of the communities gives up the madness the conflict will cease immediately.
('91', 228, 4, 21, 448137) All the deaths in Ahmedabad were not the result of firing.
('91', 228, 4, 22, 448196) Many were the results of stabbing and the like.
('91', 228, 4, 23, 448244) It was a shame that they had to call for the help of the police and the military to prevent them from flying at each other’s throats.
('91', 228, 5, 24, 448378) But you must realize that by seeking the help of the police and the army we become their slaves If we want to have true independence, we should stop relying on them and relying solely on God should learn how to die.
('91', 228, 5, 25, 448594) That is all we have to do.
('91', 228, 5, 26, 448621) Many people know how to die after killing others but we have to die without killing anyone.
('91', 228, 6, 27, 448713) If one side ceased to retaliate, the riots could not go on.
('91', 228, 6, 28, 448773) What did it matter if even a few lakhs were killed in the right manner out of the 40 crores of Indians?
('91', 228, 6, 29, 448877) If they could learn the lesson of dying without killing, India which was celebrated in legend history as Karmabhoomi—the land of duty—would become a virtual Eden, the image of the Kingdom of Heaven on earth.
('91', 228, 7, 30, 449085) The Hindu, 4 7 1946, and Harijanbandhu, 14 7 1946

('91', 229, 0, 1, 449319) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 229, 1, 2, 449361) 287. DISTINCTION BETWEEN HINDI AND URDU
('91', 229, 2, 3, 449401) Shri Ram Naresh Tripathi is well known to me.
('91', 229, 2, 4, 449447) One day he came to see me at Mussoorie.
('91', 229, 2, 5, 449487) I had feared that he would reproach me for my propagation of Hindustani.
('91', 229, 2, 6, 449560) But when I talked to him I found the reverse.
('91', 229, 2, 7, 449606) He told me that if I cherished the hope that Hindustani would emerge from a blending of Hindi and Urdu, Urdu would be of more help.
('91', 229, 2, 8, 449738) Only I should become as fully aware of the attempts to distort Urdu by giving it a new look as I am of the attempts to distort Hindi.
('91', 229, 2, 9, 449872) Hindustani would then come of itself.
('91', 229, 2, 10, 449910) I asked him to give me illustrations to help me understand what he meant.
('91', 229, 2, 11, 449984) When he tried to think he found some difficulty in doing so.
('91', 229, 2, 12, 450045) I then asked him to explain in writing.
('91', 229, 2, 13, 450085) The result was the following letter which he wrote to me:
('91', 229, 3, 14, 450143) Pujya Bapu,
('91', 229, 4, 15, 450155) You had asked me to explain to you the structural difference between Hindi and Urdu.
('91', 229, 4, 16, 450240) But it seems to me a matter of experience.
('91', 229, 4, 17, 450283) I cannot clearly define it.
('91', 229, 4, 18, 450311) I can venture a suggestion though.
('91', 229, 4, 19, 450346) Get a paragraph from Harijan translated into Hindi and Urdu by two competent writers.
('91', 229, 4, 20, 450432) You will know the difference between the structure of the two languages.
('91', 229, 5, 21, 450505) I had told you that da ythat Urdu was more refined than Hindi.
('91', 229, 5, 22, 450568) I will give you an example.
('91', 229, 5, 23, 450596) Here is a sentence from a well known Hindi writer:
('91', 229, 6, 24, 450647) In Urdu cannot be used.
('91', 229, 6, 25, 450671) It is either or .
('91', 229, 6, 26, 450689) No good Urdu
('91', 229, 7, 27, 450702) writer will ever use an incorrect idiom.
('91', 229, 7, 28, 450743) If he does so he had to be prepared to engage in a stiff battle.
('91', 229, 7, 29, 450808) There is no movement for refining Hindi.
('91', 229, 7, 30, 450849) But rather than such a movement being started it would do Hindi much more good if Urdu books and writings were published in the Devanagari script.
('91', 229, 7, 31, 450996) In this way Hindi would be benefited by the struggles of the Urdu writers and poets over the last several centuries to improve and polish Urdu.
('91', 229, 7, 32, 451140) This would automatically transform it into Hindustani.
('91', 229, 7, 33, 451195) This letter deserves consideration.
('91', 229, 7, 34, 451231) I am a lover of languages but I am not a linguist.
('91', 229, 7, 35, 451282) My knowledge of Hindi is barely satisfactory.
('91', 229, 7, 36, 451328) I did not learn Hindi from any books.
('91', 229, 7, 37, 451366) I did not have the time for that.
('91', 229, 7, 38, 451400) My son Devdas who, with my encouragement and my blessings, went to Madras to learn Hindi, knows it far better than I do.
('91', 229, 7, 39, 451521) There are many others also whom I can name.
('91', 229, 7, 40, 451565) My knowledge of Urdu is even less than my knowledge of Hindi.
('91', 229, 7, 41, 451627) I have known the Nagari script
('91', 230, 0, 1, 451658) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 231
('91', 230, 1, 2, 451700) from my childhood.
('91', 230, 1, 3, 451719) I have learnt the Persian script with considerable effort.
('91', 230, 1, 4, 451778) As I have not had the practice, I am able to read it only with some difficulty.
('91', 230, 1, 5, 451858) I manage somehow to write it.
('91', 230, 1, 6, 451888) Thus my knowledge of Urdu is very rudimentary.
('91', 230, 1, 7, 451935) What I do have is love and an impartial attitude.
('91', 230, 1, 8, 451985) Therefore, if God wills it and if I get help from scholars of the two languages, my venture will succeed.
('91', 230, 1, 9, 452091) I published Tripathiji’s letter only with the idea that he and other would help me in this effort.
('91', 230, 1, 10, 452190) Another lover of Hindi also tells me that hardly has there been such work done for Hindi as there has been for Urdu.
('91', 230, 1, 11, 452307) If only people would not indulge in a tug of war but would realize that the two languages have a common root in the speech of the millions of our villagers and that it is for this that our scholars and poets have to work, we could quickly march forward.
('91', 230, 2, 12, 452561) POONA, July 3, 1946 [From Hindi]

('91', 234, 4, 8, 458153) 294. INTERVIEW TO JOACHIM DIAS AND CHANDRAKANT KAKODKAR 1
('91', 234, 5, 9, 458211) POONA, July 3, 1946 Do not bow before the Portuguese Government.
('91', 234, 5, 10, 458276) Remember that 40 crores of Indians are behind you.
('91', 234, 6, 11, 458327) Q. Our fight against the Portuguese imperialism is for the present to obtain civil liberties.
('91', 234, 6, 12, 458421) Hence, what is the type of satyagraha that we should offer?
('91', 234, 7, 13, 458481) A. You have to resist through civil disobedience every attack on civil liberties.
('91', 234, 7, 14, 458563) But you should define beforehand what the civil libert ies are for which you are fighting.
('91', 234, 7, 15, 458654) You cannot ask for anything to which you have no moral right.
('91', 234, 7, 16, 458716) Moreover, your movement should be strictly non violent.
('91', 234, 8, 17, 458772) Q. The Colonial Administration of the Portuguese Government demands previous permission for meetings; but we want the right of calling meetings even without serving notice.
('91', 234, 9, 18, 458945) A. You should have every right to call meetings without notice.
('91', 234, 9, 19, 459009) No self respecting person can tolerate any hindrance to his doing what is morally just.
('91', 234, 9, 20, 459097) We are free men and we want to hold meetings peacefully.
('91', 234, 9, 21, 459154) For this we cannot give any previous notice.
('91', 234, 9, 22, 459199) Hence you should hold meetings without giving any notice.
('91', 234, 10, 23, 459257) Q. In case we call a meeting and address the people and are arrested, and police allow us to go away saying we should come back on any fixed day, are we to agree to it?
('91', 234, 10, 24, 459426) Or should we refuse to quit the police premises, or should we come out and defy their bans again?
('91', 234, 11, 25, 459524) A. The police who have the right to arrest you also have the
('91', 234, 12, 26, 459585) 1 President and Member of the Executive Committee of the Goan Youth League 2 This Paragraph is from The Hindu.
('91', 235, 0, 1, 459696) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 235, 1, 2, 459738) right to let you go.
('91', 235, 1, 3, 459759) Hence you should go out if you are allowed to do so.
('91', 235, 1, 4, 459812) You should not insist on being kept under arrest.
('91', 235, 1, 5, 459862) But once you go out you can defy the ban again.
('91', 235, 1, 6, 459910) In case any day is fixed for your reappearance before the police, you are bound as gentlemen to do so.
('91', 235, 2, 7, 460013) Q. How should people act when a satyagrahi is arrested?
('91', 235, 3, 8, 460069) A. There should be no demonstration or disturbance of any kind if a satyagrahi is arrested.
('91', 235, 3, 9, 460161) The people should be peaceful and offer themselves either individually or collectively to be arrested.
('91', 235, 3, 10, 460264) I am not for hartal and such other things if anyone is arrested.
('91', 235, 3, 11, 460329) After all you should know that a satyagrahi courts arrest of his own accord, and if the people wish to do anything at all, it should be to follow his example.
('91', 235, 3, 12, 460488) As for demonstrations, etc., they will come at a later stage.
('91', 235, 4, 13, 460550) Q. How to defy the pre censorship of Press?
('91', 235, 5, 14, 460594) A. This is really difficult but there are two solutions which I can offer.
('91', 235, 5, 15, 460669) The first one is the one followed by me in South Africa.
('91', 235, 5, 16, 460726) It is to issue handwritten bulletins which volunteers should sell openly.
('91', 235, 5, 17, 460800) These bulletins should contain defiant news exposing the Government.
('91', 235, 5, 18, 460869) It is better if the people who write out, sign their full names at the bottom of each bulletin.
('91', 235, 5, 19, 460965) If many of you join together it won’t be difficult to take out several copies.
('91', 235, 5, 20, 461044) Let the Government arrest the people con cerned, others can continue the work.
('91', 235, 5, 21, 461123) The other way open to you is to get printed matter from outside and distribute it openly.
('91', 235, 6, 22, 461213) Q. How to defy the ban on organizations?
('91', 235, 7, 23, 461254) A. Start as many organizations as you like and begin working in their name.
('91', 235, 8, 24, 461330) Q. How should people react in case the Government takes recourse to shooting, etc.?
('91', 235, 9, 25, 461414) A. It is better to die bravely than exist under such repugnant conditions.
('91', 235, 9, 26, 461489) Let the people say: ‘All right, shoot us!’
('91', 235, 10, 27, 461532) Q. How should a satyagrahi keep up his morale when subjected to torture?
('91', 235, 11, 28, 461605) A. The satyagrahi must not wince.
('91', 235, 11, 29, 461639) He should submit to every form of torture.
('91', 235, 12, 30, 461682) Q. What should be the attitude of a satyagrahi towards the Catholic Church in Goa when it becomes an active agency of oppression in the hands of the Portuguese rulers?
('91', 235, 13, 31, 461850) A. It is better to leave religion alone.
('91', 235, 13, 32, 461891) But if it really plays into the hands of oppressors, then it is your duty to oppose it in the same way as you would oppose any oppressive regime.
('91', 235, 13, 33, 462037) But be against it
('91', 236, 0, 1, 462055) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 237
('91', 236, 1, 2, 462097) only to the extent to which it hinders your cause.
('91', 236, 1, 3, 462148) Now I have answered all your questions, and I want that you should show your courage and should not allow the movement to fizzle out.
('91', 236, 1, 4, 462282) Even if no one is prepared for sacrifice it is the duty of anyone who feels the wrong to oppose it without waiting for others to follow.
('91', 236, 1, 5, 462419) [If] you rot in prison, the eyes of the others will be opened some time or other.
('91', 236, 1, 6, 462501) As for myself I would not have remained for a moment in Goa without breaking such inhuman laws.
('91', 236, 1, 7, 462597) You have all my blessings and I promise you I will exert all my influence to see that the Indian National Congress is interested in Goa and that Goa comes on the map of India.
('91', 236, 1, 8, 462773) Only show courage; I admire it.
('91', 236, 2, 9, 462805) The Hindu, 5 7 1946, and C. W. 11018. Courtesy: U. R. Rao
('91', 236, 3, 10, 462863) 295. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 236, 4, 11, 462895) POONA, July 3, 1946
('91', 236, 5, 12, 462915) Addressing the prayer gathering today, Gandhiji referred to the situation in Ahmedabad, and stated that the latest report was that the situation was well in hand.
('91', 236, 5, 13, 463078) Shri Morarji Desai had invited the representatives of Muslims, Hindus and others to a joint conference at Ahmedabad and had told them that he was prepared to withdraw the police and military if they so desired.
('91', 236, 5, 14, 463289) But the latter, he heard, had unanimously replied that they were not prepared to take the risk.
('91', 236, 5, 15, 463385) The result was the police and military were there.
('91', 236, 5, 16, 463436) The authorities had promulgated a curfew order for three days to be enforced day and night.
('91', 236, 5, 17, 463528) Therefore although as a result, the disturbances had been arrested, the peace that was seen in Ahmedabad today was the peace of the grave.
('91', 236, 6, 18, 463667) It was something, he added, of which no one could be proud.
('91', 236, 6, 19, 463727) How he wished that both the Hindus and Muslims would combine and dispense with the help of the police and military for purposes of keeping them from mutual fight.
('91', 236, 6, 20, 463890) The State could not suddenly disband them, but they could certainly reserve them for purposes of regulating the traffic, municipal sanitation and growing more food to combat the famine.
('91', 236, 6, 21, 464076) He reminded them that so long as they depended upon the help of the police and military for maintaining law and order, real independence must remain a mere idle talk.
('91', 236, 6, 22, 464243) They daily joined him in prayers.
('91', 236, 6, 23, 464277) The essence of prayer was reliance on God and utter fearlessness.
('91', 236, 7, 24, 464343) Gandhiji said that he would not say that the situation in South Africa was

('91', 237, 1, 2, 464566) deteriorating.
('91', 237, 1, 3, 464581) But it was certainly becoming graver.
('91', 237, 1, 4, 464619) The Government repression was becoming worse.

('91', 239, 8, 17, 469350) Untouchability has found refuge more in custom than in law.
('91', 239, 8, 18, 469410) In fact, as far as I know, there is absolutely no basis for untouch ability in law but under the present judicial system, however evil it may be, custom acquires the strength of law.
('91', 239, 8, 19, 469593) Take, for instance, the “age of consent” 2. Now a days the Government has even stopped enforcing it because people no longer abide by it.
('91', 239, 8, 20, 469731) It means that a law which is ahead of public opinion ceases to be observed.
('91', 239, 8, 21, 469807) Nevertheless a Bill has to be brought up.
('91', 239, 8, 22, 469849) Its implementation will depend largely upon the courage of caste Hindus and Harijans.
('91', 239, 8, 23, 469935) Your law pundits will have to be careful of the word ‘Harijan’.
('91', 239, 8, 24, 469999) It is an apt expression, sweet but now embittered by many people.

('91', 241, 1, 2, 472153) I now wish to reveal my interrogatory heart in order to be well nigh to your feelings towards us and to be definite about our position in the muddled and complicated Indian political field.
('91', 241, 2, 3, 472343) By the time you will receive this letter it will be the last date of filling in nomination forms for the candidateships for the Constituent Assembly, which has, it is learnt, to be completed by the end of this month.
('91', 241, 2, 4, 472560) Congress is proposing particular M. L. As and non M. L. As for the same.
('91', 241, 2, 5, 472633) It is believed that Scheduled Castes are also to be represented (adequately?).
('91', 241, 2, 6, 472712) But is there any proposal from you or from Congress to elect adequate or at least some members from the Mehtar Community who, I am sure, will discharge their duty of citizenship and pick up their legitimate share in the future constituion of Free India?
('91', 241, 2, 7, 472966) 2. Generous as you are towards us, may I assure myself and my community that Mehtar seats in the Constituent Assembly will not escape your notice?
('91', 241, 2, 8, 473113) 3. Who will be the components of the Advisory Board?
('91', 241, 2, 9, 473166) Caste Hindus or Minorities including (?) the Scheduled Castes?
('91', 241, 2, 10, 473229) 4. Will the advice or proposals of the Advisory Board be binding to the Constituent Assembly?
('91', 241, 2, 11, 473323) I think they will not.
('91', 241, 2, 12, 473346) If so, what sense is there in appointing such a Board, which will be nonentity if the Constituent Assembly were not to pay heed to its advice?
('91', 241, 2, 13, 473489) Is it not merely for the appeasement of the weak minorities?
('91', 241, 2, 14, 473550) You might say you have been [doing] and will do everything for us, but I wish to say ‘let us be with you when everything for us is to be done.
('91', 241, 2, 15, 473693) Let us be represented democratically.’ I strongly hope that my questions will be fully and satisfactorily answered by you with an obligation of immediate reply to me.
('91', 241, 2, 16, 473860) I further humbly request you to be good enough to publish your answers in your weekly Harijan.
('91', 241, 2, 17, 473955) Hope to be excused for troubles.
('91', 241, 2, 18, 473988) I have reproduced the foregoing in order to show what havoc dangerous knowledge of English has produced in our society.
('91', 241, 2, 19, 474108) This is a specimen not of English nor yet of Indian English.
('91', 241, 2, 20, 474169) It is bookish English which the writer probably half understands.
('91', 241, 2, 21, 474235) I suggest to him that if he had written to me in the national language Hindustani or in his provincial language, it would not have evoked an unfavourable response from me.
('91', 241, 2, 22, 474407) The writer has paid me a left handed compliment and that perhaps in order to teach me how to express my love for the Bhangi, otherwise known as Mehtar.
('91', 241, 2, 23, 474559) The writer is a discontented graduate,
('91', 242, 0, 1, 474598) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 243
('91', 242, 1, 2, 474640) setting no example or a bad example to Bhangis.
('91', 242, 1, 3, 474688) He has isolated himself from them, though he professes to represent them.
('91', 242, 1, 4, 474762) He will certainly become my teacher if he will be a graduate in the art of being a good Bhangi.
('91', 242, 1, 5, 474858) I very much fear that he does no scavenging himself; he does not know what scientific scavenging is.
('91', 242, 1, 6, 474959) If he became an expert in the art, his services would be wanted by all the cities of India.
('91', 242, 1, 7, 475051) When Bhangis really rise from the slumber of ages, they will successfully sweep the Augean stables everywhere and India will be a pattern of cleanliness and there will be in India no plague and other diseases which are the descendants of filth and dirt.
('91', 242, 1, 8, 475305) In the place where I am living in Bombay, my room and the ad joining lavatory are fairly clean, but I am in the midst of suffocating dirt.
('91', 242, 1, 9, 475444) I have had no time to examine the tenements in front of me.
('91', 242, 1, 10, 475504) They are as crowded and as dirty as the ones in the quarters where I was living in New Delhi.
('91', 242, 1, 11, 475598) Had my graduate fellow Bhangi been an expert in the art, I would, without doubt, have requisitioned his services as my guide and helper.
('91', 242, 1, 12, 475735) As it is, not only have I no use for him, I have to risk his dis pleasure by telling him that he should not think of the Constituent Assembly or other assemblies.
('91', 242, 1, 13, 475898) Let those go to them who are wanted there.
('91', 242, 1, 14, 475941) Instead of getting rid of the wretched caste mentality, he argues that any Harijan is not good enough for the purpose but preference should be given to the Mehtar caste.
('91', 242, 1, 15, 476111) I suggest to him that it is a harmful method, doing no good to anybody.
('91', 242, 1, 16, 476183) Anyway, he has expected the impossible from me.
('91', 242, 1, 17, 476231) I am not made for these big institutions.
('91', 242, 1, 18, 476273) I have never interested myself in the periodical assembly elections.
('91', 242, 1, 19, 476342) I have not attended Working Committee meetings where they make these selections.
('91', 242, 1, 20, 476423) What I know of the present selections is from the newspapers.
('91', 242, 1, 21, 476485) I have become a Bhangi because I think that that is the vocation of every Hindu, that the hoary institution of untouchability as we know it today in its ugly shape will die a decent death only when the Hindus will be casteless by becoming Bhangis from the bottom of their hearts.
('91', 242, 1, 22, 476765) That cannot be done by aspiring after the membership my correspondent has in view.

('91', 243, 1, 2, 476930) 303. ‘ALL ABOUT BHANDARS’ 1
('91', 243, 2, 3, 476958) An article under the above caption appeared in the Khadi Patrika of 3rd June.
('91', 243, 2, 4, 477036) As it is important I give it in full below:
('91', 243, 3, 5, 477080) It is our intention to make rapid changes in the running of our bhandars.
('91', 243, 3, 6, 477154) In spite of the condition of yarn currency attaching to the sales of khadi, Bombay people have not yet taken to spinning.
('91', 243, 3, 7, 477276) Most of the yarn given in exchange for cloth is bought.
('91', 243, 3, 8, 477332) From the 1st of July, we shall give only Rs. 2 worth of khadi for one hank and, as a result, the sales of khadi will go down.
('91', 243, 3, 9, 477458) One of the main reasons for khadi sales is that mill cloth is rationed.
('91', 243, 3, 10, 477530) Many persons who ordinarily wear mill cloth are almost forced, as it were, to buy khadi.
('91', 243, 3, 11, 477619) We take a statement from every customer as to whether the yarn given in is self spun or spun by a member of the family or staff.
('91', 243, 3, 12, 477748) But we have regretfully to admit that many customers do not appreciate their responsibility in the matter of making accurate statements.
('91', 243, 3, 13, 477885) This irresponsible attitude is not in the best interests of khadi.
('91', 243, 3, 14, 477952) Khadi production aims at self sufficiency of village India.
('91', 243, 3, 15, 478012) Other provinces will, therefore, now provide less and less cloth to our bhandars.
('91', 243, 3, 16, 478094) The use of the words ‘sale of khadi’ is really inconsistent with the ideal.
('91', 243, 3, 17, 478170) In the circumstances it is imperative for us to make timely changes in the running of bhandars.
('91', 243, 3, 18, 478266) From July 1st we are closing two branches in Matunga and Dadar.
('91', 243, 3, 19, 478330) For the last three months we have been giving training in Matunga in all the processes of khadi.
('91', 243, 3, 20, 478427) In Dadar, there was some sale of khadi too, but these activities must now come to an end.
('91', 243, 3, 21, 478517) In Girgaum, in the Khadi Printing Shop, the A. I. S. A. was running a training centre too.
('91', 243, 3, 22, 478608) This shop will now be handed back to the trustees of the Khadi Printing Shop who will continue to give instruction in all the processes of khadi as well as arrange for some sales.
('91', 243, 4, 23, 478788) The reduction of work involves dispensing with the services of fifteen workers.
('91', 243, 5, 24, 478868) Ever since the new policy came into vogue, Gandhiji has been saying that the make up of the bhandars must be changed.
('91', 243, 5, 25, 478986) In order to fall into line we arranged facilities for teaching and weaving in some places but such outward changes have not connoted the real change.
('91', 243, 5, 26, 479136) We felt that a change in our mental outlook is what was most needed.
('91', 243, 5, 27, 479205) Therefore, examination of workers and such other reforms came into force.
('91', 243, 6, 28, 479279) Nevertheless all the changes mentioned above have not enabled us to gain our object.
('91', 243, 6, 29, 479364) At the time when customers looked upon khadi as being in the fashion, bhandars were purely commercial depots.
('91', 243, 6, 30, 479474) Today the bhandar desires
('91', 243, 7, 31, 479500) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 14 7 1946.
('91', 244, 0, 1, 479570) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 245
('91', 244, 1, 2, 479612) to bring about a change in the mentality of the khadi wearer.
('91', 244, 1, 3, 479674) It no longer desires to remain a sales depot.
('91', 244, 1, 4, 479720) It desires to become a centre for imparting knowledge in all the processes of khadi manufacture.
('91', 244, 1, 5, 479817) It desires to become a centre of attraction for weavers and other craftsmen.

('91', 244, 1, 8, 480075) We expect the customers of Bombay to remain loyal to us in our endeavour.

('91', 245, 4, 16, 482110) 306. RESOLUTION ON SOUTH AFRICAN STRUGGLE 1
('91', 245, 5, 17, 482154) BOMBAY, July 6, 1946 This meeting of the A.I.C.C., while it is grieved that it has become imperative for the Indian settlers in South Africa once more to offer Satyagraha in the land of its birth against a law imposing on them a colour bar far more sinister than the one against which they had put up a brave fight between 1907 and 1914, congratulates the handful of satyagrahis on their brave but unequal action against heavy odds.
('91', 245, 5, 18, 482587) This meeting is pleased to find that doctors and such other men and women are at the head of the gallant struggle and that among them are represented Parsis, Christians, Muslims and Hindus.
('91', 245, 5, 19, 482777) This meeting is also pleased to find that a few white men like the Rev.
('91', 245, 5, 20, 482849) Scott 2 have thrown in their lot with the satyagrahis.
('91', 245, 5, 21, 482904) This meeting condemns the action of some white men in resorting to the barbarous method known as lynch law to terrorize the satyagrahis into submission to the humiliating legislation.
('91', 245, 5, 22, 483088) It is worthy
('91', 245, 6, 23, 483101) 1 For Gandhiji’s speech on the resolution, vide “Speech at A. I. C. C.”, 7 7 1946. 2 Rev.
('91', 245, 6, 24, 483191) Michael Scott, a white clergyman who had stood up against the inequality of the segregation laws and the ill treatment of Indian settlers in South Africa.
('91', 246, 0, 1, 483346) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 247
('91', 246, 1, 2, 483388) of note that a large part of the Indians are born and bred in South Africa, to whom India exists only in their imagination.
('91', 246, 1, 3, 483512) These colonial born Indians have adopted European manners and customs and English has become like their mother tongue.
('91', 246, 1, 4, 483631) This meeting notes with great satisfaction that the Indian resis ters are keeping their struggle free from violence in any shape or form and conducting it with dignity and without rancour and that they are thus suffering not only for their self respect but for the honour of India, and by their heroic resistance setting a noble example to all the exploited people of the earth.
('91', 246, 1, 5, 484010) This meeting assures the Indian settlers of South Africa of India’s full support in this unequal struggle and is firmly of opinion that persistence in it is bound to crown their effort with success.
('91', 246, 1, 6, 484209) This meeting appeals to His Excellency the Viceory to use all his endeavours and ensure that of the British Government in aid of this struggle and invites the European residents of India to raise their voice in protest against white hooliganism and the anti Asiatic and anti colour legislation of South Africa.
('91', 246, 2, 7, 484520) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('91', 255, 5, 25, 506498) 314. THE REAL DANGER
('91', 255, 6, 26, 506519) As during the two days of the session of the A. I. C. C. in Bombay I listened to some of the spirited speeches against the Working Committee’s resolution submitted the A. I. C. C. for ratifi cation, I could not subscribe to the dangers portrayed by the opposi tion.
('91', 255, 6, 27, 506785) No confirmed satyagrahi is dismayed by the dangers, seen or unseen, from his opponent’s side.
('91', 255, 6, 28, 506879) What he must fear, as every army must, is the danger from within.
('91', 255, 6, 29, 506945) Opposition, however eloquent it may be, will defeat its purpose if it is not well informed, balanced and well based and does not promise action and result more attractive than what is opposed.
('91', 255, 6, 30, 507138) Let the opposition at the late meeting answer.
('91', 256, 0, 1, 507185) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 257
('91', 256, 1, 2, 507227) My purpose here is merely to point out the danger from within.
('91', 256, 1, 3, 507290) The first in importance is laziness of mind and body.
('91', 256, 1, 4, 507344) This comes out of the smug satisfaction that Congressmen having suffered imprison ment have nothing more to do to win freedom and that a grateful organization should reward their service by giving them first preference in the matter of elections and offices.
('91', 256, 1, 5, 507603) And so, there is an unseemly and vulgar competition for gaining what are described as prize posts.
('91', 256, 1, 6, 507702) Here there is a double fallacy.
('91', 256, 1, 7, 507734) Nothing should be considering a prize in the Congress dictionary and imprisonment is its own reward.
('91', 256, 1, 8, 507835) It is the preliminary examination of a satyagrahi.
('91', 256, 1, 9, 507886) Its goal is the slaughter house even as that of the spotless lamb.
('91', 256, 1, 10, 507953) Jail going is, instead, being used as a passport to every office accessible to the Congress.
('91', 256, 1, 11, 508046) Hence there is every prospect of a satyagrahi’s imprisonment becoming a degrading occupation like that of pro fessional thieves and robbers.
('91', 256, 1, 12, 508187) No wonder my friends of the under ground variety avoid imprisonment as being comparatively a bed of roses.
('91', 256, 1, 13, 508294) This is a pointer to the pass the Congress is coming to.
('91', 256, 1, 14, 508351) The friends who opposed the resolution on the British Cabinet Delegation’s proposals do not seem to know what they are aiming at.
('91', 256, 1, 15, 508481) Is independence to be bought at the price of a bloody revolution as was, say, the French, the Soviet or even the English?
('91', 256, 1, 16, 508603) Then frank and honest work has yet to begin.
('91', 256, 1, 17, 508648) They have to tread a very dangerous path in openly making the Congress such an institution.
('91', 256, 1, 18, 508740) My argument has no force if subterranean activity is a doctrine of univer sal application and is now being employed against the Congress.
('91', 256, 1, 19, 508878) The very thought repels me.
('91', 256, 1, 20, 508906) I should hope for the sake of my own sanity that the thought is devoid of any foundation.
('91', 256, 1, 21, 508996) Then it is clearly their duty to say to the Congressmen that now that there is Congress Raj or Representative Raj, whether of the Congress variety or the Muslim League, they must set about reforming it in detail and not condemn it in toto.
('91', 256, 1, 22, 509236) Total non violent non co operation has no place in popular Raj, whatever its level may be.
('91', 256, 1, 23, 509327) Who is responsible for the mad orgy in Madura and, coming nearer, in Ahmedabad?
('91', 256, 1, 24, 509407) It will be folly to attribute everything evil to British machinations.This senseless theory will perpetuate foreign domination, not necessarily British.
('91', 256, 1, 25, 509560) The British will go in any case.
('91', 256, 1, 26, 509593) They want to go in an orderly manner as is evident to me from the State Paper or they will go and leave India to her own fate assuming that India has forsaken the path of non violence with the certain result of a combined intervention of an assortment of armed powers.
('91', 256, 1, 27, 509862) Let the
('91', 257, 0, 1, 509870) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('91', 257, 1, 3, 509983) Congressmen in general certainly do not know the kind of independence they want.

('91', 260, 0, 1, 516182) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 261
('91', 260, 1, 2, 516224) The whites in South Africa are becoming like brutes.

('91', 260, 1, 12, 516817) But, said the Field Marshal, in spite of the absence of prejudice, he was bound to protect Western culture in South Africa and he hoped that an understanding man that I was, I would appreciate it.
('91', 260, 2, 13, 517014) Gandhiji failed to understand how a culture or civilization worth the name could require legal protection.
('91', 260, 2, 14, 517121) The Indians were resisting the ghetto law in a civil, i.
('91', 260, 2, 15, 517178) e., non violent and therefore civilized, way.
('91', 260, 2, 16, 517224) They welcomed the penalty for the breach of law which could not be morally defended.
('91', 260, 2, 17, 517309) But the white hooligans too were breaking their own laws.
('91', 260, 2, 18, 517367) Theirs was crminal disobedience.
('91', 260, 2, 19, 517400) It was a matter of pride for India that the children of indentured labourers and traders—many of them descendants of Harijans—were proving themselves such brave satyagrahis.
('91', 260, 2, 20, 517574) As against this the whites were resorting to lynch law.
('91', 260, 2, 21, 517630) He remarked: After all civil resistance had its birth in Asia.
('91', 260, 2, 22, 517693) Jesus was an Asiatic.
('91', 260, 2, 23, 517715) If he was reborn and went to South Africa today and lived there, he would have to live in a ghetto.
('91', 260, 3, 24, 517815) He hoped that as in 1914, Field Marshal Smuts would at long last realize that he could not persecute the Indians in South Africa for ever and come to an honourable settlement with them when he had tried them through and through.
('91', 260, 3, 25, 518044) A committee of white men had been formed in South Africa to express sympathy with identify themselves with the cause of the Indian passive resisters there.
('91', 260, 3, 26, 518200) There was something of that kind in his time also.
('91', 260, 3, 27, 518251) But this time it seemed to be on a bigger scale.
('91', 260, 3, 28, 518300) If this becomes extensive and the hooliganism is stopped and anti Asiatic laws are repealed, there is hope of a blending of Eastern and Western cultures.
('91', 260, 3, 29, 518454) Otherwise South Africa may prove to be the grave of Western civilization.
('91', 260, 4, 30, 518528) Harijan, 21 7 1946

('91', 263, 9, 26, 523124) 324. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 263, 10, 27, 523154) POONA, July 11, 1946
('91', 263, 11, 28, 523175) Giving the latest news from South Africa to the prayer gathering, Mahatma Gandhi said that men and women from Johannesburg had gone to Durban to offer satyagraha.
('91', 263, 11, 29, 523338) It was good news.
('91', 263, 11, 30, 523356) Victory was sure if they kept up that spirit.
('91', 264, 0, 1, 523402) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 265
('91', 264, 1, 2, 523444) Referring next to the meetings of the A. I. S. A. and the Kasturba Trust which he had attended in the afternoon, Gandhiji mentioned that the A. I. S. A. had distributed five crores of rupees on an average of Rs. 25 lakhs per year among the poor spinners and weavers.
('91', 264, 1, 3, 523711) It had done a lot, but compared to the task before it, its achievement appeared insignificant.
('91', 264, 1, 4, 523806) It had to clothe the whole of India with khadi as was the case once upon a time.
('91', 264, 1, 5, 523887) Not only did India produce enough cloth for herself, she was also able to export it.
('91', 264, 1, 6, 523972) There were no mills in India then.
('91', 264, 1, 7, 524007) He said: I might say that every woman had her own mill in the charkha and the takli.
('91', 264, 2, 8, 524092) Modern mills were evolved from the charkha.
('91', 264, 2, 9, 524136) Man was a mixture of divine and devilish forces.
('91', 264, 2, 10, 524185) The force behind the spinning wheel was divine, devoid of any trace of exploitation.
('91', 264, 2, 11, 524270) The foreigner saw the hidden possibilities that were in it and, by the application of steam and electricity, created mills and used them as instruments of exploitation of the simple races of the earth.
('91', 264, 3, 12, 524472) This represented the power of the devil.
('91', 264, 3, 13, 524513) There were so many cloth mills in India and yet India went about almost naked.
('91', 264, 3, 14, 524592) There was scarcity of cloth all over the world.
('91', 264, 3, 15, 524640) The Prime Minister of the Indonesian Republic Dr. Sultan Sjahrir, had informed Pandit Nehru that they had surplus rice which they would gladly send to India to help meet the threat of famine.
('91', 264, 3, 16, 524832) In return, they wanted no money, but would be glad to have cloth as they were suffering from cloth shortage themselves.
('91', 264, 3, 17, 524952) They had neithter cloth mills nor had they taken to the wheel.
('91', 264, 3, 18, 525015) Pandit Nehru had broached the matter to some mill owners who gladly gave quantities of cloth for despatch to Java.
('91', 264, 3, 19, 525130) If out of the 40 crores of India, even 20 crores in her seven lakh villages took to spinning for one or two hours a day, they could not only clothe the population of the villages but even supply cloth for the cities.
('91', 264, 3, 20, 525347) The conviction had dawned upon him even before he came to India that the revival of hand spinning alone could restore India to its pristine glory.
('91', 264, 3, 21, 525494) He had since compared the spinning wheel to the central sun round which the solar system of village economy revolved.
('91', 264, 3, 22, 525612) It provided the golden bridge between the rich and the poor.
('91', 264, 4, 23, 525673) To meet the crisis theat faced them, said Gandhiji, he suggested tha the popular Ministries should make a declaration that the villagers must produce their own cloth.
('91', 264, 4, 24, 525840) They would be supplied with cotton, which they must spin and make into cloth.
('91', 264, 4, 25, 525918) This would enable them to have cloth almost free of cost as it were.
('91', 264, 4, 26, 525987) The All India Spinners’ Association is likely to draw up a scheme for the expansion of the khadi industry in the country and place it before the popular Ministries.
('91', 264, 4, 27, 526152) If the Ministers realize that there is no other way to clothe the naked in India, the scheme will go ahead without any difficulty.
('91', 264, 5, 28, 526283) Today, the city dwellers complained that they could not get khadi at khadi bhandars, that they were asked to make partial payment in yarn spun by themselves.
('91', 264, 5, 29, 526441) If they understood the new spirit behind the khadi drive, these complaints would
('91', 265, 0, 1, 526522) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 265, 1, 2, 526564) disappear.
('91', 265, 1, 3, 526575) There was nothing to prevent the city dwellers from producing their own khadi in the same way as the villagers were expected to do.
('91', 265, 2, 4, 526707) As for the Kasturba Trust its work was still more difficult than that of the A.I.S.A. They had collected one and a quarter crores of rupees, but the money had to be spent on the welfare of women and children in the villages.
('91', 265, 2, 5, 526932) Take for instance maternity work in the villages.
('91', 265, 2, 6, 526982) The village midwives were ignorant and dirty.
('91', 265, 2, 7, 527028) The village women were more hardy than city women.
('91', 265, 2, 8, 527079) Still the laws of Nature could not be defied.
('91', 265, 2, 9, 527125) To teach clean methods to the village midwife was not an easy job.
('91', 265, 2, 10, 527192) It was a matter of adult education and everyone knew that adult education was a much harder task than the education of the children.
('91', 265, 2, 11, 527325) He could spend away the one and a quarter crores today by raising one or two big hospitals of the city type.
('91', 265, 2, 12, 527434) But that would not be rendering real service to women and children in the villages.
('91', 265, 2, 13, 527518) The money was collected in the name of woman who had become a villager and who died with her heart in the villages.
('91', 265, 2, 14, 527634) He was not prepared to squander away that money anyhow.
('91', 265, 2, 15, 527690) He knew that the public were becoming impatient.
('91', 265, 2, 16, 527739) They felt that the work was progresing too slowly.
('91', 265, 2, 17, 527790) But he wished to tell them not to lose patience.
('91', 265, 2, 18, 527839) The work was going on slowly but surely.
('91', 265, 2, 19, 527880) They were moving in unchartered waters.
('91', 265, 2, 20, 527920) They must proceed with caution.
('91', 265, 2, 21, 527952) The Hindu, 13 7 1946

('91', 268, 4, 15, 533649) 329. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 268, 5, 16, 533681) PANCHGANI, July 13, 1946 In the song that has just been sung, 2 the world has been aptly described as the valley of sorrow and suffering.
('91', 268, 5, 17, 533819) God alone enables us to brave it all.
('91', 268, 5, 18, 533857) The poet, however has proceeded to call the world an illusion and a dream.
('91', 268, 5, 19, 533932) Joy or what men call happiness may be, or really is, a dream in a fleeting and transitory world, where everything is like a dissolving phantasmagoria.
('91', 268, 5, 20, 534083) But we cannot dismiss the suffer ing of our fellow creatures as unreal and thereby provide a moral alibi for ourselves.
('91', 268, 5, 21, 534203) Even dreams are true while they last and to the sufferer, his suffering is a grim reality.
('91', 268, 5, 22, 534294) Anyway, whether the world be real or unreal, we have certain duties in life which must be faced, understood and duly performed while we are in this world.
('91', 268, 6, 23, 534449) Mahatma Gandhi said he was grateful to God for being able to come to Panchgani again this year although he was not able to come earlier because of his stay in Delhi on account of the Cabinet Mission.
('91', 268, 6, 24, 534649) This annual short stay at the hill station enabled him, he added, to store up enough energy for carrying on his heavy work during the remaining months.
('91', 268, 6, 25, 534801) From his experience of the last three years he found it beneficial to plan staying about six months on the side of Poona from

('91', 269, 4, 5, 535520) 330. KHADI IN TOWNS
('91', 269, 5, 6, 535540) Your scheme for making village India self sufficient in the matter of clothing has hit town lovers of khadi pretty hard.
('91', 269, 5, 7, 535661) You have gone so far as to say that sales bhandars may close as such and that townsfolk may even revert to the use of mill cloth.
('91', 269, 6, 8, 535791) While there is no quarrel with the new ideology and the consequent basic change in the running of bhandars nor with the introduction of a certain quota of yarn currency for purchasing khadi, I would like you to solve the difficulty of town buyers who must use only khadi.
('91', 269, 6, 9, 536063) Let the readers fully understand the so called new plan for khadi.
('91', 269, 6, 10, 536130) I call it so called, because what is being done is the logical step, if khadi is to clothe the villagers, as from the very start it was intended to do.
('91', 269, 6, 11, 536282) Khadi was never meant merely for the townspeople, it was never meant to bleed the villagers as they are being bled so that the townspeople can live.
('91', 269, 6, 12, 536431) Khadi was from its inception conceived for the sake of reversing the order though never to bleed the townspeople.
('91', 269, 6, 13, 536545) To reverse the order was to restore the natural relation.
('91', 269, 6, 14, 536603) Towns there were before the British arrival.
('91', 269, 6, 15, 536648) Things were bad enough then.
('91', 269, 6, 16, 536677) Now they are much worse.
('91', 269, 6, 17, 536702) Towns became cities.
('91', 269, 6, 18, 536723) The latter, in spite of their Indian millionaires, lived mainly for the British masters.
('91', 269, 6, 19, 536812) Khadi was to undo the grave mischief.
('91', 269, 6, 20, 536850) Mill cloth is the symbol of the slavery of village India as khadi is or should be the symbol of its freedom, both economic and political.
('91', 269, 6, 21, 536988) If it cannot be that, it is meaningless.
('91', 269, 6, 22, 537029) Therefore, any healthy change undergone in the process of khadi development is to be welcomed.
('91', 269, 6, 23, 537124) The defect in the existing development, good though it ap peared, was not good enough for the villagers who spun yarn and wove khadi but did not use it themselves.
('91', 269, 6, 24, 537288) They neither understood nor appreciated the dignity and value that its use carried.
('91', 269, 6, 25, 537372) The fault was not theirs.
('91', 269, 6, 26, 537398) The workers themselves did not.
('91', 269, 6, 27, 537430) The town dwellers had to wear khadi and do the penance.
('91', 269, 6, 28, 537486) They were

('91', 270, 1, 2, 537538) willing to buy penance for a few extra rupees which they could easily spare and be called patriots into the bargain.
('91', 270, 1, 3, 537655) But how could the Charkha Sangh (called in English All India Spinners’ Association) belie its faith by ignoring the very foundation of khadi?
('91', 270, 1, 4, 537797) And so it is employing its resources to making the villagers khadi clad.

('91', 274, 1, 2, 546669) 334. KASTURBA MEMORIAL TRUST 1
('91', 274, 2, 3, 546700) Some people complain that the funds of this Trust are not being spent fast enough and that no one knows how they are being spent.
('91', 274, 2, 4, 546830) The complaint is baseless on both counts.
('91', 274, 2, 5, 546872) The thing is that even though the donations to the Trust came largely from the cities, the aim has throughout been for the money to be spent in the villages, and in the interest of village women and children.
('91', 274, 2, 6, 547081) Therefore, those who do not see the Trust accounts would not know how the money is spent in villages.
('91', 274, 2, 7, 547183) The critics are all city dwellers.Villagers neither read the newspapers nor care about how the money is spent.
('91', 274, 2, 8, 547294) If any work is done in their own village they can see it for themselves.
('91', 274, 2, 9, 547367) Anything done for the city dwellers is widely publicised.
('91', 274, 2, 10, 547425) If a building or a statue is being made, there is a discussion in the papers about how it is being made.
('91', 274, 2, 11, 547530) Then when it is completed its opening or unveiling ceremony is performed with much fanfare so that people would know that the purpose for which the money was collected had been accomplished.
('91', 274, 2, 12, 547721) There cannot be any such advertisement of the work which is being done for women in villages.
('91', 274, 2, 13, 547815) Therefore, for the time being the newspaper readrs will have to be content with just knowing through whom the work is being carried on.
('91', 274, 2, 14, 547951) When some work has been done in a few thousand out of the seven lakhs of our villages and the women and children of these villages have been prepared everyone will come to know of it.
('91', 274, 2, 15, 548135) Take just one example.
('91', 274, 2, 16, 548158) Training is being given to village women as midwives.
('91', 274, 2, 17, 548212) Nurses are being trained to work in villages.
('91', 274, 2, 18, 548258) If this information is not enough, what more can one say?
('91', 274, 2, 19, 548316) At the last meeting of the Executive Committee of the Kasturba Trust held recently at Poona, budgets were passed for the holding of training camps in several of the twenty one provinces.
('91', 274, 2, 20, 548503) But the women trained in this way have to go to villages.
('91', 274, 2, 21, 548561) City dwellers can know about them only if they are paraded in the cities.
('91', 274, 2, 22, 548635) But this is not intended, nor would it be proper.
('91', 274, 2, 23, 548685) There is another thing.
('91', 274, 2, 24, 548709) The work to be undertaken in the villages is of a new kind and has to be taken up from the beginning.
('91', 274, 2, 25, 548811) Therefore, the progress would perforce be slow as it has been in the case of khadi and other village industries.
('91', 274, 2, 26, 548924) We paid very little attention to the villages.
('91', 274, 2, 27, 548971) It is so even today.
('91', 274, 2, 28, 548992) When city dwellers turn their attention to the villages, things will be diffe rent.

('91', 275, 1, 2, 549179) long as this does not happen neither the newspapers will notice the work of organizations of this kind nor city dwellers will take much interest in it.
('91', 275, 1, 3, 549331) There are occasions when it is not wise to spend the money as soon as it is collected, when wisdom in fact lies in spending it slowly and with care, as it has been in the case of the Kasturba Trust.
