('91', 278, 3, 9, 555971) PANCHGANI, [July 14, 1946] 2
('91', 278, 4, 10, 556000) Poverty, remarked Gandhiji, had a dignity in our country.
('91', 278, 4, 11, 556058) The poor man was not ashamed of his poverty.
('91', 278, 4, 12, 556103) He preferred his hut to the rich man’s palace.
('91', 278, 4, 13, 556150) He even took pride in it.
('91', 278, 4, 14, 556176) Though poor in material goods, he was not poor in spirit.
('91', 278, 4, 15, 556234) Contentment was his treasure.
('91', 278, 4, 16, 556264) He might as well say to himself, ‘Since we cannot all become rich and own palaces, let us at least pull down the palaces of the rich and bring them down to our level.’ That could bring no happiness or peace either to themselves or anyone else, and God would certainly be not the friend and helper of the poor of such description.
('91', 278, 4, 17, 556594) Poverty, in the sense of inequality of material possessions was there in every part of the world.
('91', 278, 4, 18, 556692) That was perhaps in a certain measure inevitable, for all men are not equal either in their talents or the measure of their needs.
('91', 278, 4, 19, 556823) Even in America which was fabulously rich and where Mammon had taken the place of God, there were many poor.
('91', 278, 4, 20, 556932) Poet Malabari had come across some relatives of Shah Alam 3
('91', 278, 5, 21, 556992) begging in the streets of Rangoon.
('91', 278, 5, 22, 557027) He had written a beautiful poem about it which had sunk into Gandhiji’s heart.
('91', 278, 5, 23, 557106) The substance of it was that he alone is rich who has God for his friend and helper.
('91', 278, 5, 24, 557191) In India there was a particular type of man who delighted in having as few needs as possible.
('91', 278, 5, 25, 557285) He carried with him only a little flour and a pinch of salt and chillies tied in his napkin.
('91', 278, 5, 26, 557378) He had a lota and a string to draw water with from the well.
('91', 278, 5, 27, 557439) He needed nothing else.
('91', 278, 5, 28, 557463) He walked on foot covering 10 12 miles a day.
('91', 278, 5, 29, 557509) He made the dough on his napkin, collected a few twigs to make a fire and baked his dough on the embers.
('91', 278, 5, 30, 557614) It was called bati.
('91', 278, 5, 31, 557634) He tasted it an found it most delicious.
('91', 278, 5, 32, 557675) The relish did not lie in the food but in the appetite that honest toil and the contentment

('91', 279, 2, 10, 558601) 338. LETTER TO KHURSHEDBEHN NAOROJI
('91', 279, 3, 11, 558637) PANCHGANI, July 15, 1946
('91', 279, 4, 12, 558662) DEAR KHURSHEDBEHN, Though you have said your last letter does not need any reply, in my opinion it demands one.
('91', 279, 4, 13, 558774) I see that your ahimsa and mine are poles asunder.
('91', 279, 4, 14, 558825) I have great regard for Jaiprakash but not for his views.
('91', 279, 4, 15, 558883) Aruna allows herself to be my daughter.
('91', 279, 4, 16, 558923) She is a brave woman.
('91', 279, 4, 17, 558945) But views like hers would take the paupers to future starvation and death.
('91', 279, 4, 18, 559020) That I commended their names and others to J.’s 1 attention was not because of their views but in spite of them in the hope that responsibility under J. would show them the error of their ways.
('91', 279, 4, 19, 559214) But they chose the opposite course.
('91', 279, 4, 20, 559250) I shall now watch their course.
('91', 279, 4, 21, 559282) They are all a power.
('91', 279, 4, 22, 559304) I shall hug my darkness, not their light.
('91', 279, 4, 23, 559346) There is, therefore, hardly any chance of my following them.
('91', 279, 4, 24, 559407) I wish you well.
('91', 279, 4, 25, 559424) May God be your protection and guidance.
('91', 279, 4, 26, 559465) I write this to make my position clear.
('91', 279, 4, 27, 559505) I love you too well to keep you in the dark about it.
('91', 279, 4, 28, 559559) How I wish I have misunderstood you.
('91', 279, 4, 29, 559596) You had made your position clear the other day when you met me for half a minutue.
('91', 279, 4, 30, 559679) Your letter under reply clinches the matter.
('91', 279, 4, 31, 559724) Of course you are at liberty to show this to our Socialist friends.
('91', 279, 5, 32, 559792) Blessings from BAPU

('91', 280, 1, 2, 559989) 339. LETTER TO VALJI G. DESAI
('91', 280, 2, 3, 560019) PANCHGANI, July 15, 1946
('91', 280, 3, 4, 560044) VALJI, I have gone through your draft.
('91', 280, 3, 5, 560083) It is a good summary.
('91', 280, 3, 6, 560105) You have given better treatment to the vows than to the constructive programme.
('91', 280, 3, 7, 560185) The latter lacks life.
('91', 280, 3, 8, 560208) Maybe the original itself lacks it.
('91', 280, 3, 9, 560244) It would be quite wrong to give to this writing the title “Mohan Samhita”.
('91', 280, 3, 10, 560319) I do not see the quality of a Samhita 1 in it.
('91', 280, 3, 11, 560366) A simpler title would be more becoming.
('91', 280, 3, 12, 560406) Truly speaking what Manu Subedar wants is something much better.
('91', 280, 3, 13, 560471) It has to be something original.
('91', 280, 3, 14, 560504) He is not likely to want a mere summary.
('91', 280, 3, 15, 560545) Probably what he has in mind is a booklet or two based on all my writings.
('91', 280, 3, 16, 560620) You should show him your draft and find out.
('91', 280, 3, 17, 560665) It is the title that I strongly object to.
('91', 280, 3, 18, 560708) ‘Mangal prabhat’ and ‘A Summary of Constructive Programme’ would be a better description of what you have written.
('91', 280, 3, 19, 560823) I hope you are well.
('91', 280, 3, 20, 560844) It would be morally wrong to neglect your health.
('91', 280, 4, 21, 560894) Blessings from BAPU

('91', 291, 1, 2, 572570) 346. LETTER TO SARAT CHANDRA BOSE
('91', 291, 2, 3, 572604) CAMP: PANCHGANI, July 16, 1946
('91', 291, 3, 4, 572635) BROTHER SARAT BABU, I write this in English so as to cause you less strain and be better understood.
('91', 291, 3, 5, 572736) I had long chats with Bela and Arvind.
('91', 291, 3, 6, 572775) They feel deeply aggrieved by your treatment of them.
('91', 291, 3, 7, 572829) It is not, as I could see, so much a question of money as of ill treatment.
('91', 291, 3, 8, 572905) They feel too that Amiya is the evil genius.
('91', 291, 3, 9, 572950) As often happens among cousins they fight for no reason whatsoever.
('91', 291, 3, 10, 573018) I wonder if this is such a case.
('91', 291, 3, 11, 573051) Anyway, both Bela and Arvind are certainly disconcerted.
('91', 291, 3, 12, 573108) They seem to have discussed the matter with Jawaharlal and Sardar.
('91', 291, 3, 13, 573175) They appear to have said they can do nothing.
('91', 291, 3, 14, 573221) I have advised them to put themselves at your disposal without any expectation of favour which they do not want.
('91', 291, 3, 15, 573334) They say they want justice, they want to be treated as members of the family who have done no wrong to any of the members.
('91', 291, 3, 16, 573457) They say they have been discredited without cause.
('91', 291, 3, 17, 573508) This they resent bitterly.
('91', 291, 3, 18, 573535) The issue is purely moral.
('91', 291, 3, 19, 573562) This you should be able to fix up without any difficulty.
('91', 291, 3, 20, 573620) They ought not to be cut off from the family, if they have been.
('91', 291, 3, 21, 573685) I have given you an idea of what, as I see it, they feel.
('91', 291, 3, 22, 573743) I am sending them a copy of this letter.
('91', 291, 4, 23, 573784) Blessings from BAPU

('91', 295, 2, 3, 578668) PANCHGANI, July 17, 1946
('91', 295, 3, 4, 578693) SATYADEVI, Jayantilal brought me your letter giving me the news of Krishnamaiya’s passing away.
('91', 295, 3, 5, 578789) Later, on inquiring I came across Mahavir’s telegram.
('91', 295, 3, 6, 578843) It had been received by Pyarelal two days ago and was lying with him.
('91', 295, 3, 7, 578913) He assumed that I must have been informed and so kept it for filing.
('91', 295, 3, 8, 578982) Thus I could get the news only last evening.
('91', 295, 3, 9, 579027) I believe that Krishnamaiya has found relief in death.
('91', 295, 3, 10, 579082) I know from the death of Kashi, wife of Jaisukhlal, that cancer is painful disease.
('91', 295, 3, 11, 579166) X ray [sic], etc., is the right treatment for it.
('91', 295, 3, 12, 579216) Your account also tells me that Mother passed away peacefully.
('91', 295, 3, 13, 579279) We should all,therefore, be but happy about it.
('91', 295, 3, 14, 579327) She has departed after seeing you all well settled.
('91', 295, 3, 15, 579379) You should all now prove yourselves worthy of her name as well as your father’s and also of the Ashram’s where you were brought up.
('91', 295, 3, 16, 579511) Mahavir is properly settled, so is Durga.
('91', 295, 3, 17, 579553) You are study ing.
('91', 295, 3, 18, 579572) Once you recover your health, you are intelligent enough to be able to take care of yourself.
('91', 295, 3, 19, 579666) Dharmakumar cannot be said to be doing too well.
('91', 295, 3, 20, 579715) Maitri however has grown quite mature.
('91', 295, 3, 21, 579754) She is the eldest among you.
('91', 295, 3, 22, 579783) I am sure you will all regard her as your mother and conduct yourselves accordingly.
('91', 295, 3, 23, 579868) Krishnamaiya’s advice is right, i.
('91', 295, 3, 24, 579903) e., you should all take care of her and she will look after you all.
('91', 295, 3, 25, 579972) Thus the whole family will be protected.
('91', 295, 3, 26, 580013) I am not writing separately either to Mahavir or to Dharma kumar.
('91', 295, 3, 27, 580079) All of you brothers and sisters should read this.
('91', 295, 3, 28, 580129) I had only one letter from Dharmakumar regarding your operation.Under pressure of work I could not spare any time before this.

('91', 297, 5, 14, 582864) 356. INTERVIEW TO LOUIS FISCHER 1
('91', 297, 6, 15, 582898) PANCHGANI, [July 17, 1926]2
('91', 297, 7, 16, 582926) LOUIS FISCHER: I would go into the Constituent Assembly and use it for a different purpose—as a battle field—and declare it to be a sovereign body.
('91', 297, 7, 17, 583074) What do you say to this?
('91', 297, 8, 18, 583099) GANDHIJI: It is no use declaring somebody else’s creation a sovereign body.
('91', 297, 8, 19, 583175) After all, it is a British creation.
('91', 297, 8, 20, 583212) A body does not become a sovereign body by merely asserting it.To become sovereign, you have to behave in a sovereign way.
('91', 297, 8, 21, 583335) Three tailors of Tooley Street in Johannesburg declared that they were a sovereign body.
('91', 297, 8, 22, 583424) In ended in nothing.
('91', 297, 8, 23, 583445) It was just a farce.
('91', 297, 8, 24, 583466) I do not consider the proposed Constituent Assembly to be non revolutionary.
('91', 297, 8, 25, 583543) I have said, and I mean it cent per cent, that the proposed Constituent Assembly is an effective substitute for civil dis obedience of the constructive type.
('91', 297, 8, 26, 583701) Whilst I have the greatest admi ration for the self denial and spirit of sacrifice of our Socialist friends,
('91', 297, 9, 27, 583810) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “After Four Years”.
('91', 297, 9, 28, 583858) Louis Fischer met Gandhiji twice on the 17th and then again on the 18th.
('91', 297, 9, 29, 583931) The report here reproduced covers the two interviews on the 17th.
('91', 297, 9, 30, 583997) For the interview of the 18th,vide “Interview to Louis Fischer”, 18 7 1946. For extracts from Fischer’s report of the interviews, vide Appendix “Extracts from Louis Fischer’s Report of Interview with Gandhiji”, 17 7 1946.
('91', 298, 0, 1, 584219) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 299
('91', 298, 1, 2, 584261) I have never concealed the sharp difference between their method and mine.
('91', 298, 1, 3, 584336) They frankly believe in violence and all that is in its bosom.
('91', 298, 1, 4, 584399) I believe in non violence through and through.
('91', 298, 2, 5, 584446) L. F. You are a socialist and so are they.
('91', 298, 3, 6, 584489) G. I am, they are not.
('91', 298, 3, 7, 584512) I was a socialist before many of them were born.
('91', 298, 3, 8, 584561) I carried conviction to a rabid socialist in Johannesburg, but that is neither here nor there.
('91', 298, 3, 9, 584656) My claim will live when their socialism is dead.
('91', 298, 4, 10, 584705) L. F. What do you mean by your socialism?
('91', 298, 5, 11, 584747) G. My socialism means ‘even unto this last’.
('91', 298, 5, 12, 584792) I do not want to rise on the ashes of the blind, the deaf and the dumb.
('91', 298, 5, 13, 584864) In their socia lism, probably these have no place.
('91', 298, 5, 14, 584915) Their one aim is material progress.
('91', 298, 5, 15, 584951) For instance, America aims at having a car for every citizen.
('91', 298, 5, 16, 585013) I do not.
('91', 298, 5, 17, 585023) I want freedom for full expression of my personality.
('91', 298, 5, 18, 585077) I must be free to build a staircase to Sirius if I want to.
('91', 298, 5, 19, 585137) That does not mean that I want to do any such thing.
('91', 298, 5, 20, 585190) Under the other socialism, there is no individual freedom.
('91', 298, 5, 21, 585249) You own nothing, not even your body.
('91', 298, 6, 22, 585286) L. F. Yes, but there are variations.
('91', 298, 6, 23, 585323) My socialism in its modified form means that the State does not own everything.
('91', 298, 6, 24, 585403) It does in Russia.
('91', 298, 6, 25, 585422) There you certainly do not own your body even.
('91', 298, 6, 26, 585469) You may be arrested at any time, though you may have committed no crime.
('91', 298, 6, 27, 585542) They may send you wherever they like.
('91', 298, 7, 28, 585580) Does not, under your socialism, the State own your children and educate them in any way it likes?
('91', 298, 8, 29, 585678) G. All States do that.
('91', 298, 8, 30, 585701) America does it.
('91', 298, 9, 31, 585718) L. F. Then America is not very different from Russia.
('91', 298, 10, 32, 585772) G. But socialism is dictatorship or else arm chair philosophy.
('91', 298, 10, 33, 585835) I call myself a communist also.

('91', 302, 1, 2, 593067) 357. QUESTION BOX
('91', 302, 2, 3, 593085) Q. I am a young businessman of 21 years and have 11 dependents.
('91', 302, 2, 4, 593149) I believe in truth and non violence but find I cannot strictly follow it in business.
('91', 302, 2, 5, 593235) What should I do?
('91', 302, 2, 6, 593253) Abandoning the business means suffering for my relations.
('91', 302, 3, 7, 593311) A. This begs the question.
('91', 302, 3, 8, 593338) It is difficult but not impossible to conduct strictly honest business.The fact is that the honester a business the more successful it is.
('91', 302, 3, 9, 593477) Hence the proverb coined by businessmen “Honesty is the best policy”.What the correspondent lacks is appli cation and an accurate knowledge of honest business methods.
('91', 302, 3, 10, 593645) What is true is that honesty is incompatible with the amassing of a large fortune.
('91', 302, 3, 11, 593728) “Verily, verily, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the Kingdom of God.” Nor therefore should an honest businessman, however capable he may be, support idlers whether eleven or more or fewer.
('91', 302, 3, 12, 593978) The eleven depen dents cannot all be infants or incapables.
('91', 302, 3, 13, 594038) Honesty makes no impossi ble demands upon the resources of a businessman.
('91', 302, 3, 14, 594112) An honest man cannot have dishonest kinsmen.
('91', 302, 3, 15, 594157) The questioner will find on intros pection that there is nothing wrong with honest business but that there is something wrong with him.
('91', 302, 3, 16, 594293) Let him find out what it is that is wrong with him.
('91', 302, 4, 17, 594345) Q. Are the time, place and manner of death predestined by the Almighty for each individual?
('91', 302, 4, 18, 594437) If so, why worry even if we are ill?
('91', 302, 5, 19, 594474) A. I do not know whether time, place and the manner of death are predestined.
('91', 302, 5, 20, 594552) All I do know is that ‘not a blade of grass moves but by His will’.
('91', 302, 5, 21, 594620) This too I know hazily.
('91', 302, 5, 22, 594644) What is hazy today will be clear tomorrow or the day after by prayerful waiting.
('91', 302, 5, 23, 594725) Let this however be quite clear.
('91', 302, 5, 24, 594758) The Almighty is not a person like us.
('91', 302, 5, 25, 594796) He or It is the greatest living Force or Law in the world.
('91', 302, 5, 26, 594855) Accordingly He does not act by caprice, nor does that Law admit of any amendment or improvement.His will is fixed and changeless, everything else changes every second.
('91', 302, 5, 27, 595023) Surely, it does not follow from the doctrine of predesti nation that we may not ‘worry’ in the care of ourselves even if we are ill.
('91', 302, 5, 28, 595156) Indifference to illness is a crime greater than that of falling ill.
('91', 302, 5, 29, 595225) There is no end to the effort to do better today than yesterday.
('91', 302, 5, 30, 595290) We have to ‘worry’ and find out why we are or have become ill.
('91', 302, 5, 31, 595353) Health, not ‘illth’, is the law of nature.
('91', 302, 5, 32, 595396) Let us investigate the law of nature and obey it, if we will not be ill or, if having fallen ill, will be restored.

('91', 303, 1, 2, 595598) 358. A TRAGIC PHENOMENON
('91', 303, 2, 3, 595623) My post contains so many letters from persons who want to be in the Constituent Assembly that it frightens me into the suspicion that, if these letters are an indication of the general feeling, the intelligentsia is more anxious about personal aggrandizement than about India’s independence.
('91', 303, 2, 4, 595915) And if I, though I have no connection with the applications of candidates for elections, receive so many letters, how many must the members of the Working Committee be receiving?
('91', 303, 2, 5, 596094) These correspondents should know that I take no interest in these elections, I do not attend meetings at which these applications are considered and that I often only know from newspapers who have been elected.
('91', 303, 2, 6, 596305) It is on rare occasions that my advice is sought as to the choice to be made.
('91', 303, 2, 7, 596383) But I write this more to draw attention to the disease of which these applications are a sign than to warn my correspondents against building any expectation of my intervention.
('91', 303, 2, 8, 596561) It is wrong to think communally in such elections, it is wrong to think that anyone is good enough for the Constituent Assembly, it is altogether wrong to think that the election carries any honour with it, it is a post of service if one is fitted for the labours and, lastly, it is wrong to regard the post as one for making a few rupees while the Assembly lasts.
('91', 303, 2, 9, 596926) The Constituent Assembly should have such members only who know something about constitutions all the world over, above, all, about the constitution that India’s genius demands.
('91', 303, 2, 10, 597104) It is debasing to think that true service consists in getting a seat in the Assembly.
('91', 303, 2, 11, 597190) True service lies outside.
('91', 303, 2, 12, 597217) The field of service outside is limitless.
('91', 303, 2, 13, 597260) In the fight for independence, the Assembly, like the one in course of formation, has a place.
('91', 303, 2, 14, 597355) Nevertheless it is a very small place and that too if we use it wisely and well; certainly not, if there is a scramble for a seat in it.
('91', 303, 2, 15, 597492) The scramble warrants the fear that it may become a hunting ground for place seekers.
('91', 303, 2, 16, 597578) I am free to confess that a Constituent Assembly is the logical outcome of parliamentary activity.
('91', 303, 2, 17, 597677) The labour of the late Deshbandhu Chittaranjan Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru opened my eyes to the fact that the parliamen tary programme had a place in the national activity for independence.
('91', 303, 2, 18, 597869) I strove hard against it.
('91', 303, 2, 19, 597895) It is certainly inconsistent with pure non co operation.
('91', 303, 2, 20, 597952) But pure non co operation never held the field.
('91', 303, 2, 21, 598000) What came into being also waned.
('91', 303, 2, 22, 598033) Had there been universal non co opera tion of the non violent type in the Congress ranks, there would have been no parliamentary programme.
('91', 303, 2, 23, 598173) Non violent non co operation with evil
('91', 304, 0, 1, 598212) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 305
('91', 304, 1, 2, 598254) means co operation with all that is good.
('91', 304, 1, 3, 598296) There fore, non violent non co operation with a foreign government necessarily means an indigenous government based on non violence.
('91', 304, 1, 4, 598429) Had there been such complete non co operation, there would be swaraj today based on non violence.
('91', 304, 1, 5, 598527) But this never happened.
('91', 304, 1, 6, 598552) In the circumstances it would have been vain to struggle against what the nation had been familiar with and from which it could not be completely weaned.
('91', 304, 1, 7, 598706) The parliamentary step having been taken, it would have been improper to boycott the present effort.
('91', 304, 1, 8, 598807) But that does not, can never, mean that there should be indecent competition for filling the seats in it.

('91', 306, 4, 6, 602518) 362. INTERVIEW TO LOUIS FISCHER
('91', 306, 5, 7, 602550) PANCHGANI, [July 18, 1946] 1
('91', 306, 6, 8, 602579) L. F. If the Working Committee had reacted to your ‘groping in the dark’ or as you have called it your instinct about the long term proposals, they would have rejected them?
('91', 306, 7, 9, 602753) G. Yes, but I did not let them.
('91', 306, 8, 10, 602785) L. F. You mean you did not insist?
('91', 306, 9, 11, 602820) G. More than that.
('91', 306, 9, 12, 602839) I prevented them from following my instinct unless they also felt likewise.
('91', 306, 9, 13, 602915) It is no use conjecturing what would have happened.
('91', 306, 9, 14, 602967) The fact however remains that Dr. Rajendra Prasad asked me: ‘Does your instinct go so far that you would prevent us from accepting the long term proposals, whether we understand you or not?’ I said, ‘No.
('91', 306, 9, 15, 603171) Follow your reason since my own reason does not support my instinct.
('91', 306, 9, 16, 603240) My instinct rebels against my reason.
('91', 306, 9, 17, 603278) I have placed my misgivings before you as I want to be faithful to you.
('91', 306, 9, 18, 603350) I myself have not followed my instinct unless my reason backed it.’
('91', 306, 10, 19, 603418) L. F. But you have said that you follow your instinct when it speaks to you on occasions as, for instance, you did before certain fasts that you undertook.
('91', 306, 11, 20, 603574) G. Yes, but even in these cases, before the fast began, my reason was able to back my instinct.
('91', 306, 11, 21, 603670) My reason failed my instinct on the long term proposals.
('91', 306, 12, 22, 603727) L. F. Them, why did you inject your ‘instinct’ into the political situation?
('91', 306, 13, 23, 603804) G. Because I was loyal to my friends.
('91', 306, 13, 24, 603842) I wanted to retain my faith in the bona fides of the Cabinet Mission.
('91', 306, 13, 25, 603912) So I told the Cabinet Mission also about my misgivings.
('91', 306, 13, 26, 603968) I said to myself, ‘Supposing they meant ill, they would feel ashamed.’
('91', 306, 14, 27, 604039) 1Vide 1st footnote of “Interview to Louis Fischer”, 17 7 1946.
('91', 307, 0, 1, 604102) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 307, 1, 2, 604144) L. F. You are strongly constitutionalist now.
('91', 307, 1, 3, 604190) Is it for fear of the alternative— violence?
('91', 307, 2, 4, 604235) If India is destined to go through a blood bath, it will do so.
('91', 307, 2, 5, 604299) The thing I would fear is my own cowardice or dishonesty.
('91', 307, 2, 6, 604357) I have neither.
('91', 307, 2, 7, 604373) So I say, we must go in and work it out.
('91', 307, 2, 8, 604414) If they are dishonest, they will be found out.
('91', 307, 2, 9, 604461) The loss will not be ours but theirs.
('91', 307, 3, 10, 604499) L. F. I think you are afraid of the spirit of violence.
('91', 307, 3, 11, 604555) It is widespread.
('91', 307, 3, 12, 604573) I wonder whether it has not captured the mood of the youth and you are aware of it and you fear that mood.
('91', 307, 4, 13, 604680) G. It has not captured the imagination of the country.
('91', 307, 4, 14, 604735) I admit that it has captured the imagination of a section of the youth.
('91', 307, 5, 15, 604807) L. F. It is a mood that has got to be combated.
('91', 307, 6, 16, 604855) G. Yes.
('91', 307, 6, 17, 604863) I am doing it in my own way.
('91', 307, 6, 18, 604892) It is my implicit faith that it is a survival which will kill itself in time.
('91', 307, 6, 19, 604970) It cannot live.
('91', 307, 6, 20, 604986) It is so contrary to the spirit of India.
('91', 307, 6, 21, 605028) But what is the use of talking?
('91', 307, 6, 22, 605060) I believe in an inscrutable Providence which preside over our desti nies—call it God or by any other name you like.
('91', 307, 6, 23, 605176) All I contend is that it is not the fear of violence that makes me advise the country to go to the Cons tituent Assembly.
('91', 307, 6, 24, 605298) It is repugnant in a non violent attitude not to accept an honourable substitute for civil revolt.
('91', 307, 6, 25, 605397) Harijan, 4 8 1946
('91', 307, 7, 26, 605415) 363. “SCHEDULED CASTES”
('91', 307, 8, 27, 605439) A copy of a printed leaflet was thrown into my car on 6th July as I was driving to the A. I. C. C. meeting in Bombay.
('91', 307, 8, 28, 605557) It was again handed to me by Shri Rajbhoj on the 12th instant.
('91', 307, 8, 29, 605620) It is addressed to the members of the A. I. C. C. I promised to deal with the questions in these pages.
('91', 307, 8, 30, 605724) I do so now.
('91', 307, 8, 31, 605737) The questions are such as not to need an answer from the members.
('91', 307, 8, 32, 605803) I should not wonder if no member has answered them.
('91', 307, 8, 33, 605855) They betray gross ignorance of Congress history.
('91', 307, 8, 34, 605904) It is hardly the province of men gathered together for a particular purpose to deal with extraneous matters.
('91', 307, 8, 35, 606013) But it is the province of newspapers to dispel ignorance.
('91', 307, 8, 36, 606071) It is doubly mine, being conductor of a weekly and a Harijan by choice.
('91', 307, 9, 37, 606143) Q. What is going to be the place of the untouchables in your swaraj?
('91', 307, 9, 38, 606212) The Congress has talked a lot about protecting the minorities.
('91', 307, 9, 39, 606275) Why has the Congress
('91', 308, 0, 1, 606296) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 309
('91', 308, 1, 2, 606338) failed to produce its blue print of plan for protecting the minorities?
('91', 308, 1, 3, 606410) Is this silence not calculated to create want of confidence in the bona fides of the Congress?
('91', 308, 2, 4, 606505) A. The place of untouchables in the swaraj of my conception will be the same in every respect as that of the so called caste Hindus.
('91', 308, 2, 5, 606638) Such is also the position of the Congress.
('91', 308, 2, 6, 606681) It has talked less and done more for minorities than any other cosmopolitan body known to me.
('91', 308, 2, 7, 606775) There is no blue print necessary when work speaks.
('91', 308, 3, 8, 606826) Q. Does the Congress regard the untouchables as a minority?
('91', 308, 3, 9, 606886) Mr. Gandhi in an article in the Harijan in 1939 admitted that the only real minority in India were the untouchables.
('91', 308, 3, 10, 607003) Why did Maulana Azad in his last letter 1 to the Viceroy say that the Congress was not prepared to recognize the untouchables as a minority?
('91', 308, 4, 11, 607144) A. The Congress should not regard the untouchables as a minority for the simple reason that they are not a minority in the sense in which Parsis, Jews, Christians and others can call themselves minorities.
('91', 308, 4, 12, 607350) Harijans are a minority, if Brahmins, Kashatriyas and Vaishyas are minorities and Shudras are a majority.
('91', 308, 4, 13, 607456) These are not minorities and majorities in the sense we are used to.We have fortu nately not come to that pass.
('91', 308, 4, 14, 607568) When we do, it will be good bye to any kind of swaraj.
('91', 308, 4, 15, 607623) The English may go today, they will some day, but if we become savages cutting one another’s throats we will have the freedom that savages have.
('91', 308, 4, 16, 607768) The President of the Bombay Provincial Scheduled Castes Fede ration should have given the quotation referred to by him from the article in the Harijan of 1939. He has not taken the trouble of giving even the number and page of the Harijan in question.
('91', 308, 4, 17, 608020) I have no recollection of ever having made the statement attributed to me.
('91', 308, 4, 18, 608095) What the Maulana Saheb is reported to have said was undoubtedly right, irrespective of what I wrote in 1939 or did not write.
('91', 308, 5, 19, 608221) Q. What is the significance of the statement that the Congress does not regard the untouchables as a minority?
('91', 308, 5, 20, 608332) Does it mean that the Congress will take away even those political safeguards which have been secured by the untouchables under the present Government of India Act?'
('91', 308, 6, 21, 608498) A. The significance is that untouchables are an integral part of Hindus.
('91', 308, 6, 22, 608571) They are, therefore, better than minorities and worse if they claim to be and become a distinct community.
('91', 308, 6, 23, 608678) A few educated untou chables may keep themselves as a class apart but the mass of them must sink or swim with the Hindus who, if they continue their
('91', 308, 7, 24, 608827) 1 Of June 25, 1946
('91', 309, 0, 1, 608846) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 309, 1, 2, 608888) misbehaviour towards Harijans—the so called untouchables—must become extinct as a separate branch of the human family.
('91', 309, 1, 3, 609007) What ‘political safeguards’ the questioner has in view I do not know.
('91', 309, 1, 4, 609077) If they refer to ‘separate’ electorates they must go even to the extent they exist today.They are a device of Satan named Imperialism It was never meant for the protection of the untouchables.
('91', 309, 1, 5, 609270) It was a prop of Imperialism.
('91', 309, 1, 6, 609300) Every statutory separation has been in furthe rance of the policy of ‘divide and rule’.
('91', 309, 1, 7, 609388) It is inherent in the life of Imperialism even if it were to the called by a sweeter name.
('91', 309, 2, 8, 609479) Q. Does the Congress admit or does it not admit that the candidates of the Scheduled Castes who have been elected to the Provincial Legislatures came to the bottom in the primary elections and the candidates put up by the Scheduled Castes Federation came to the top?
('91', 309, 2, 9, 609746) Does the Congress admit or does it not admit that if in the final election the failed candidates were elected, it was entirely due to the Hindu votes?
('91', 309, 2, 10, 609897) Can the Congress deny that candidates elected by Hindu votes cannot be regarded as the real representatives of the Scheduled Castes?
('91', 309, 3, 11, 610030) A. I have not the statistics to verify the statement.
('91', 309, 3, 12, 610084) My impre ssion is to the contrary except in some cases.
('91', 309, 3, 13, 610140) Who were the ‘failed’ candidates?
('91', 309, 3, 14, 610174) They could not offer them selves for the joint vote.
('91', 309, 3, 15, 610227) The first four in the primary elections are the successful candidates, i.
('91', 309, 3, 16, 610301) e., eligible for the joint vote.
('91', 309, 3, 17, 610334) Surely it is a thing to be proud of, if the last successful candidate in the primary list won because of the caste Hindu vote at the joint election.
('91', 309, 3, 18, 610483) The Congress must deny that the top man of the primary elec tion who failed to secure enough or any caste Hindu votes was the real representative of the Scheduled Castes.
('91', 309, 3, 19, 610654) Can Sjt.
('91', 309, 3, 20, 610663) Gaekwad and others like him, so long as they Hindus, be indifferent to the vote of their fellow Hindus, even though the latter are caste men?
('91', 309, 3, 21, 610805) They must not cut the branch on which they are sitting.
('91', 309, 3, 22, 610861) Separation must mean either change or religion or setting up a new religion—confusion added to confusion.
('91', 309, 4, 23, 610967) Q. At the time of the Poona Pact, Mr. Gandhi gave a pledge that the Hindus will not interfere in the election of the Scheduled Castes to the seats reserved for them.
('91', 309, 4, 24, 611133) Why did the Congress violate the pledge and commit breach of faith?
('91', 309, 5, 25, 611201) A. I gave no such pledge as is imputed to me.
('91', 309, 5, 26, 611247) The joint vote for the sake of which I fasted was interference, if it can be so called.
('91', 309, 5, 27, 611335) If any other interference is meant, the questioner must explain and quote my writing in support of the contention.
('91', 309, 6, 28, 611450) Q. In the Simla Conference called by Lord Wavell in 1945, the Congress raised no objection to two representatives of the Scheduled Castes being included in
('91', 310, 0, 1, 611606) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 311
('91', 310, 1, 2, 611648) the Executive Council.
('91', 310, 1, 3, 611671) Why did the Congress reduce the representation of the Scheduled Castes this time to one?
('91', 310, 1, 4, 611760) Does it not prove that the Congress cannot be trusted to keep its word and that as soon as the Congress obtains the right to decide, it will break all its promises and withdraw all the political safeguards secured by the Scheduled Castes?
('91', 310, 2, 5, 611999) A. I do not understand this charge at all.
('91', 310, 2, 6, 612042) The Congress, so far as I know, has committed no breach of faith.
('91', 310, 3, 7, 612108) Q. It has been admitted by all the workers of the Harijan Sevak Sangh and also by Mr. Gandhi that the removal of untouchability has made no headway at all.
('91', 310, 3, 8, 612264) On the contrary, the tyranny and oppression of the untouchables by the caste Hindus which has been going on for ages, has increased in its rigour and has taken manifold forms.
('91', 310, 3, 9, 612440) It is necessary to ventilate these grievances on the floor of the legislatures if any redress is to be obtained.
('91', 310, 3, 10, 612553) No sensible man will deny that this work of ventilating the grievances cannot be done except by the representatives of the Scheduled Castes who are returned through separate electorates.
('91', 310, 3, 11, 612740) Why does the Congress alone oppose the demand of the Scheduled Castes for separate electorates?
('91', 310, 4, 12, 612836) A. I have made no statement, and I do not know that the Harijan Sevak Sangh has, to the effect that the removal of untou chability has made ‘no headway at all’.
('91', 310, 4, 13, 612997) What all of us have admitted is that removal, so far as the caste Hindus are concerned, has made no satisfactory headway.
('91', 310, 4, 14, 613119) That is not a new complaint.
('91', 310, 4, 15, 613148) It is of long standing.
('91', 310, 4, 16, 613172) Woe to the reformer who is easily satisfied with the progress of the reform, on which his mind is set.
('91', 310, 4, 17, 613275) The reform is two sided.
('91', 310, 4, 18, 613300) So far as work among the Harijans is concerned, the Sangh has made fair strides.
('91', 310, 4, 19, 613381) That in itself is no small contribution to the cause of removal of untouchability.
('91', 310, 4, 20, 613464) The work among the touchables has gone on at a snail’s pace.
('91', 310, 4, 21, 613525) It is an uphill task.
('91', 310, 4, 22, 613547) Yet I assert that it is making sure progress, though undoubtedly slow.
('91', 310, 4, 23, 613618) The charge that the tyranny and oppression by caste Hindus have“increased and have become intensified in rigour” is wholly wrong and cannot be sustained.
('91', 310, 4, 24, 613772) What is true, and it is a healthy sign, is that there is a growing consciousness of the wrong among the Harijans, thanks largely to the efforts and the increase in the number of reformers and their impatience of the wrong.
('91', 310, 4, 25, 613995) But they dare not be satisfied with the results so far achieved.
('91', 310, 4, 26, 614060) They have to go much farther than they have done.
('91', 310, 4, 27, 614110) I am sure that will never be through the legis latures or legislation, necessary as both are, though to very limited extent.
('91', 310, 4, 28, 614235) As I have said in a previous issue, it is the hoary custom and not law, that is responsible for the mischief.
('91', 310, 4, 29, 614345) Custom is any day
('91', 311, 0, 1, 614363) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 311, 1, 2, 614405) tougher than law.
('91', 311, 1, 3, 614423) It can be removed only by enlightened public opinion.
('91', 311, 1, 4, 614477) Progress will be totally blocked by separation.
('91', 311, 1, 5, 614525) It is a night mare which must be given up, unless the goal of separation is extinction of Hindus including the so called Scheduled Classes.
('91', 311, 1, 6, 614665) They can only be misrepresented by separate electorates.
('91', 311, 1, 7, 614722) How can others who are not interested in Scheduled Classes oppose separation?
('91', 311, 2, 8, 614800) Q. There is no connection between the religion of a community and its demand for separate electorates.
('91', 311, 2, 9, 614903) Even communities professing one religion have claimed separate electorates.
('91', 311, 2, 10, 614979) Europeans, Anglo Indians and Indian Christians profess one common religion.
('91', 311, 2, 11, 615055) Yet all of them have separate electorates.
('91', 311, 2, 12, 615098) Nobody has raised any objection to their separate electorates, not even the Congress.
('91', 311, 2, 13, 615184) Why does the Congress oppose the demand of the Scheduled Castes for separate electorates on the ground of common religion which it does not rely upon in other cases?
('91', 311, 3, 14, 615350) A. This question can only arise in the minds of those who support separate electorates as good in themselves.
('91', 311, 3, 15, 615460) Not so the Congress.
('91', 311, 3, 16, 615481) The parallel of Anglo Indians, Europeans and Indian Chris tians is inapplicable and fatal.
('91', 311, 3, 17, 615572) That separation is a glaring example of the mischief that separate electorates are, as also of Imperialism gone mad.
('91', 311, 3, 18, 615689) Arrogance cannot go farther.
('91', 311, 3, 19, 615718) Europeans have been separated as the ruling race, Anglo Indians being a cross breed have been kept distinct from Indian Christians.
('91', 311, 4, 20, 615850) Q. There is no social separation between the Hindus and the Sikhs.
('91', 311, 4, 21, 615917) In one family one member is a Sikh and the other a Hindu.
('91', 311, 4, 22, 615975) The Hindus and the Sikhs intermarry and interdine.
('91', 311, 4, 23, 616026) Yet the Sikhs have separate electorates to which the Congress has never raised any objection.
('91', 311, 4, 24, 616120) The untouchables in the matter of social intercourse are far more separated from the Hindus than all the Sikhs and Muslims.
('91', 311, 4, 25, 616244) If the Sikhs and Muslims can have separate electorates, why not the untouchables?
('91', 311, 5, 26, 616326) A. The Congress would do away today with these separate electorates if it had the power—not the power that the sword gives but that of persuasion.
('91', 311, 5, 27, 616473) It is perfectly true that more is common between Hindus and Sikhs than between caste Hindus and untouchables.
('91', 311, 5, 28, 616583) That is a blot upon caste Hindus and Hinduism.
('91', 311, 5, 29, 616630) But the remedy is not to add evil to evil but to reform Hinduism, so that the demand for separation on the part of untouchables dies a natural death.
('91', 311, 5, 30, 616780) Meantime Hindus cannot be expected to commit suicide which separation of Harijans from caste Hindus must mean.
('91', 311, 5, 31, 616891) PANCHGANI, July 19, 1946 Harijan, 28 7 1946

('91', 315, 6, 15, 621941) 371. LETTER TO R. K. RAMLINGA REDDY
('91', 315, 7, 16, 621977) PANCHGANI, July 20, 1946
('91', 315, 8, 17, 622002) RAMLINGA REDDY, I have your postcard redirected from Poona.
('91', 315, 8, 18, 622062) After all everyone has to lose his father someday or other.
('91', 315, 8, 19, 622122) We too have to go.
('91', 315, 8, 20, 622141) Why grieve over it?
('91', 315, 8, 21, 622161) The thing to do is to emulate the good qualities of our fathers and forget their faults.
('91', 315, 8, 22, 622250) Only then do we gain something.
('91', 315, 8, 23, 622282) Go on doing your work with zeal and you will have perfect peace.
('91', 315, 8, 24, 622347) I shall be reaching Sevagram in August.
('91', 315, 8, 25, 622387) You may come then, if you want to.
('91', 315, 8, 26, 622422) Blessings from BAPU
('91', 315, 9, 27, 622442) From a photostat of the Hindi: C. W. 10416
('91', 315, 10, 28, 622485) 1 Prime Minister of Kashmir
('91', 316, 0, 1, 622513) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 317
('91', 316, 1, 2, 622555) 372. TALK WITH MEMBERS OF HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH 1
('91', 316, 2, 3, 622603) PANCHGANI, [July 20, 1946] 2
('91', 316, 3, 4, 622632) Q. The Communist Party has successfully organized sweepers’ unions and helped them to secure their rights through hartals, etc.
('91', 316, 3, 5, 622760) But the Harijan Sevak Sangh’s activities are confined mostly to welfare work.
('91', 316, 3, 6, 622838) It cannot therefore successfully compete with the Communists for popularity among the Harijans.
('91', 316, 3, 7, 622934) Don’t you think that in view of this, the Harijan Sevak Sangh ought to alter its policy and method of work?
('91', 316, 4, 8, 623042) A. We must be guided in our policy by our sense of right, not by the lure of winning cheap popularity.
('91', 316, 4, 9, 623145) If the Harijan Sevak Sangh is convinced that it is working on the right lines, it will keep on to them, regardless of what others might or might not do.
('91', 316, 4, 10, 623298) Thus we may organize unions or even induce hartals, not from political motives or for such purposes but for bettering the social or economic position of Harijans.
('91', 316, 5, 11, 623461) Q. The feeling is gaining ground among the Harijans that the Congress is showing more solicitude for Muslim demands than for the just rights of the Harijans.
('91', 316, 5, 12, 623619) What have you to say to it?
('91', 316, 6, 13, 623647) A. The Congress being a political organization is likely to be more susceptible to political pressure, which the Muslims are in a far stronger position to exert than the Harijans.
('91', 316, 6, 14, 623827) If it succumbs to that pressure, it will pay the price for it.The Harijan Sevak Sangh, however, being a non political organization, should never put expediency before its primary duty towards the Harijans.
('91', 316, 7, 15, 624033) Q. In your recent correspondence with Shri Shyamlal you have said that caste ought to go root and branch if untouchability is to be completely eradicated.
('91', 316, 7, 16, 624188) Then, why do you not make anti untouchability work part of a wider crusade against the caste system itself?
('91', 316, 7, 17, 624296) If you dig out the root, the branches will wither by themselves.
('91', 316, 8, 18, 624361) A. It is one thing for me to hold certain views and quite another to make my views acceptable in their entirety to society at large.
('91', 316, 8, 19, 624494) My mind, I hope, is ever growing, ever moving forward.
('91', 316, 8, 20, 624549) All may not keep pace with it.
('91', 316, 8, 21, 624580) I have therefore to exercise utmost patience and be satis fied with hastening slowly.
('91', 316, 8, 22, 624666) As you must have seen from my preface to a recent Navajivan publication of my writings on Varnavyavastha, 3 I
('91', 316, 9, 23, 624776) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s report “Harijan Sevak Sangh Under Fire” 2 From Gandhi—1915 1948 3 Vide “Foreword to Varnavyavastha”, 31 5 1945.
('91', 317, 0, 1, 624916) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 317, 1, 2, 624958) am wholly in agreement with you in principle.
('91', 317, 1, 3, 625004) If I live up to 125 years, I do expect to convert the entire Hindu society to my view.
('91', 317, 2, 4, 625091) Q. Would you advise the so called savarna Hindus to start, even under the pre sent circumstances, an agitation in selected places for securing elementary civic and social rights for the Harijans?
('91', 317, 2, 5, 625287) Would you for this purpose advise the Harijan Sevak Sangh to organize satyagraha against the savarna Hindus if necessary?
('91', 317, 3, 6, 625409) A. I would not advise the Sangh as an organization to offer satyagraha against the savarna Hindus, but I would certainly not only advise but expect members of the Sangh in their individual capacity to organize such satyagraha in their respective places.
('91', 317, 3, 7, 625663) I shall certainly support any such move on their part if it is undertaken in the proper spirit.
('91', 317, 3, 8, 625759) It is their duty.
('91', 317, 4, 9, 625777) Q. Would you, in the absence of popular government in the provinces, advise the Sangh to carry on a vigorous and energetic programme of temple entry for Harijans?
('91', 317, 5, 10, 625940) A. I could.
('91', 317, 5, 11, 625952) I understand it is being done even at present but at a rather slow pace.
('91', 317, 5, 12, 626025) I would certainly like its tempo to be stepped up.
('91', 317, 6, 13, 626076) Q. Can the members of the Sangh refuse to interdine with the untouchables?
('91', 317, 6, 14, 626151) Have your views on this question undergone any change?
('91', 317, 7, 15, 626206) A. At one time I did say that interdining was not an essential part of the campaign for the removal of untouchability.
('91', 317, 7, 16, 626325) Personally, I was for it.
('91', 317, 7, 17, 626351) Today I encourage it.
('91', 317, 7, 18, 626373) In fact, today I even go further, as a perusal of my recent preface to which I have already referred would show.
('91', 317, 8, 19, 626486) Q. Should not the Harijan Sevak Sangh try to secure for the Harijans political power by demanding due representation for them on gram panchayats, municipalities and legislatures?
('91', 317, 9, 20, 626665) A. Certainly it ought to.
('91', 317, 9, 21, 626691) No effort can be too great for it.
('91', 317, 10, 22, 626726) Q. Should not the Sangh give instructions in the essentials of Hindu religion in the Harijan hostels and in Harijan gatherings of adults?
('91', 317, 11, 23, 626864) A. It ought to be the primary duty of the Sangh to give to Harijan children and adults a grounding in the essentials of Hindu religion.
('91', 317, 11, 24, 627000) If they were brought up in ignorance of these, they would not continue to remain in the Hindu fold, and the responsibility for it would rest on those who had failed to give them the necessary instruc tion.
('91', 317, 12, 25, 627206) Shri Sitaram Shastri of Vinaya Ashram, Guntur, asked whether the Sangh ought not to specially train a body of missionaries to carry on propaganda work
('91', 318, 0, 1, 627357) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 319
('91', 318, 1, 2, 627399) among the savarna Hindus.
('91', 318, 1, 3, 627425) He was prepared to start a training centre for that purpose in his Ashram if he were given adequate help.
('91', 318, 2, 4, 627531) Gandhiji however had grave doubts as to the practicability of the suggestion.
('91', 318, 2, 5, 627609) In fact, the question had actually been raised by Shri Ghanshyamdas Birla several years ago and dropped after full discussion.
('91', 318, 2, 6, 627736) He would be quite satisfied, if at least the members of the Sangh would fully come up to the ideal.
('91', 318, 3, 7, 627836) Q. Ought not we to set up a precedent for having Harijan representatives in the Sangh or at least one Harijan member in the Executive Committee of the Sangh?
('91', 318, 4, 8, 627994) In reply he referred to the history of the birth of the Harijan Sevak Sangh at the conclusion of the Poona Pact, which resulted in the modification of the decision of the MacDonald Government on the question of the representation of the minorities.
('91', 318, 4, 9, 628243) It was felt that if the rot was to be effectively stopped, Hinduism ought to be completely rid of the curse of untouchability.
('91', 318, 4, 10, 628370) This called for a real change of heart and repentance for its past sins on the part of Hindu society.
('91', 318, 4, 11, 628472) It was to that end that the Harijan Sevak Sangh was formed.
('91', 318, 4, 12, 628532) I am therefore opposed to both the propositions.
('91', 318, 4, 13, 628581) I know that under the present arrangement some Harijans are included in the Board of the Sangh.
('91', 318, 4, 14, 628677) But this was a concession to Thakkar Bapa’s weakness.
('91', 318, 4, 15, 628731) I have described the Harijan Sevak Sangh as an organi zation of penitent sinners.
('91', 318, 4, 16, 628813) Its object is to call upon so called savarna Hindus to do expiation for having harboured untouchability.
('91', 318, 4, 17, 628918) The inclusion of a Harijan in the Sangh would be mere eye wash and make believe, as his would be a mere voice in the wilderness.
('91', 318, 4, 18, 629047) Before long, he would himself heartily wish to be out of it.
('91', 318, 4, 19, 629108) I say this from my personal experience of the way in which committees function.
('91', 318, 4, 20, 629188) I know the Sangh cannot always keep up to the mark.
('91', 318, 4, 21, 629240) It is of course open to the Sangh to alter its scope and give Harijans a majority in its Executive Committee or appoint a competent body of representative Harijans to act as a board of advisers and supervisors and keep the Sangh on the alert and on the right track.
('91', 318, 5, 22, 629506) Gandhiji was next asked to give his opinion on the recent work in the Gwalior State to enlist the services of the Sadhu community in the cause of Harijan uplift.
('91', 318, 5, 23, 629668) Gandhiji replying said he had grave doubts as to the correctness or advisability of the step.
('91', 318, 5, 24, 629762) It seemed to him to smack of politics.
('91', 318, 5, 25, 629801) He would welcome the assistance of true sadhus, if it was available.
('91', 318, 5, 26, 629870) But he confessed he looked in vain in the country for sadhus of his conception.
('91', 318, 5, 27, 629950) Such sadhus as he saw disappointed him.
('91', 318, 5, 28, 629990) There might be here and there honourable exceptions and their help would be welcome.
('91', 318, 5, 29, 630075) But he was frankly sceptical of the possibility of utilizing sadhus as a body for their work.
('91', 318, 5, 30, 630169) Even if they tried the experiment, he was afraid they would come to the parting of the ways
('91', 319, 0, 1, 630261) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 319, 1, 2, 630303) before long.
('91', 319, 2, 3, 630316) Another friend asked whether a portion of the Kasturba Memorial Trust Fund ought not to be earmarked for Harijan sisters.
('91', 319, 2, 4, 630438) Gandhiji’s reply was that they could have the whole of it if they could show the capacity to utilize it.
('91', 319, 2, 5, 630543) No special earmarking of a part was therefore necessary.
('91', 319, 2, 6, 630600) I am responsible for the policy of conducting Harijan uplift work through the agency of the savarna Hindus.
('91', 319, 2, 7, 630708) They had to do expiation.
('91', 319, 2, 8, 630734) All of them, I argued to myself, could help with money even if they could not, owing to lack of necessary qualifications, render direct service.
('91', 319, 2, 9, 630879) For instance, they might not be able themselves to do teaching work, but they could engage a competent teacher to give education to Harijan children.
('91', 319, 2, 10, 631029) That would be one way of doing expiation.
('91', 319, 2, 11, 631071) They would be able to penetrate Harijan society and help in its progress.
('91', 319, 3, 12, 631145) He knew there were sceptical critics, who questioned whether this kind of work could lead to the eradication of untouchability.
('91', 319, 3, 13, 631273) He himself was at one time among the doubters.
('91', 319, 3, 14, 631320) But he had since realized his mistake.
('91', 319, 3, 15, 631359) He owed a debt of gratitude in this respect to the late Shri Devdhar, at whose activity he had at one time looked askance and which he had even criticized.
('91', 319, 3, 16, 631515) A year’s experience, however, had cured him of his conceit and taught him humility.
('91', 319, 3, 17, 631599) He realized that if he confined himself exclusively to doing propaganda among the savarna Hindus with a view to their conversion, he might have to wait till the Greek Kalends and in the meantime the actual uplift work among the Harijans would remain hopelessly bogged.
('91', 319, 3, 18, 631868) His own experience had since convinced him that if they could only have sufficient workers with the requisite purity and devotion and spirit of sacrifice to work among Harijans, untouchability would become a thing of the past, even if the savarna Hindus were left severely alone.
('91', 319, 3, 19, 632148) But that would mean that they must first become Harijans at heart and live and labour among the Harijans as Harijans.
('91', 319, 3, 20, 632266) But can the members of the Harijan Sevak Sangh truthfully claim to have eradicated the last trace of untouchability from their own hearts?
('91', 319, 3, 21, 632405) Are their professions altogether on a par with their practice?
('91', 319, 4, 22, 632468) A member asked as to what his criterion was in that respect.
('91', 319, 4, 23, 632529) Are you married?
('91', 319, 5, 24, 632546) THE MEMBER: I happen to be.
('91', 319, 6, 25, 632574) G. The have you an unmarried daughter?
('91', 319, 6, 26, 632613) If you have, get for her a Harijan bridegroom, not to satisfy her lust but in a purely religious spirit and I shall send you a wire of congratulations at my expense.
('91', 320, 0, 1, 632779) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 321
('91', 320, 1, 2, 632821) You will now realize why the Harijan sevaks are unable to move the hearts of the savarna Hindus.
('91', 320, 1, 3, 632918) The reason is that they have not that fire of faith in their hearts, that impatient hunger for service which is the first essential for an effective appeal.
('91', 320, 1, 4, 633075) Let but a handful of savarna Hindus go forth in that true missionary spirit and they will leaven the entire Hindu mass.
('91', 320, 1, 5, 633195) But not even a whole army of missionaries so called will produce any effect upon them.
('91', 320, 2, 6, 633282) It needed a Malaviyaji to make such a missionary.
('91', 320, 2, 7, 633332) He (Gandhiji) could not convert his own sister.
('91', 320, 2, 8, 633380) And if he could not, how could he blame others.
('91', 320, 2, 9, 633428) That would show how hard and thorny was that path.
('91', 320, 2, 10, 633479) It was however open to them, if they felt that they had the necessary qualification, to try the experiment for themselves in their locality.
('91', 320, 3, 11, 633620) The reason for this partial failure, Gandhiji proceeded to explain, was also that the approach of most of the members of the Harijan Sevak Sangh to their mission was not unmixed with political motives.
('91', 320, 3, 12, 633822) If they really wanted to penetrate the hearts of savarna Hindus, they ought to be filled with a purely religious spirit.
('91', 320, 3, 13, 633943) Mere dialectics was a poor weapon for this kind of work.
('91', 320, 3, 14, 634000) As it was, they were too much weighed down by inertia, heedlessness and woodenness of mind.
('91', 320, 3, 15, 634092) The other method is more fierce and not altogether free from danger.
('91', 320, 3, 16, 634161) It is the method of fasting.
('91', 320, 4, 17, 634190) He himself had before condemned fasting when it seemed to him to be wrong or morally unjustified.
('91', 320, 4, 18, 634288) But to shirk a fast when there was a clear moral indica tion was a dereliction of duty.
('91', 320, 4, 19, 634376) Such a fast had to be based on unadulterated truth and ahimsa.
('91', 320, 5, 20, 634439) In passing he hinted at the possibility of his having to go through one more fast in his life, possibly even more than one.
('91', 320, 5, 21, 634563) He warned them however that he had no present thought of any.
('91', 320, 5, 22, 634625) It was only a vague premonition.
('91', 320, 5, 23, 634658) Harijan, 28 7 1946

('91', 320, 8, 28, 634875) Let us all imbibe his good qualities and by doing so bear testimony to his immortality.
('91', 320, 8, 29, 634963) Do not grieve for him but carry on his work even as

('91', 321, 11, 21, 635772) It is good that 128 people have taken the pledge to do spinning as yajna.

('91', 322, 0, 1, 636050) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 323
('91', 322, 1, 2, 636092) 376. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('91', 322, 2, 3, 636124) PANCHGANI, July 20, 1946 The verse from the gatha sung today says: ‘Let me remember Thee by making my heart pure by righteous thought, by performing good and wise deeds and by right speech.’ Unless all these conditions are fulfilled, one cannot expect to come near God.
('91', 322, 2, 4, 636394) Then the poet says: ‘We bow to Thee and thank Thee for all that Thou hast done for us.
('91', 322, 2, 5, 636481) We will always remain Thy debtors.’ What is this debt towards God and how can one repay it?
('91', 322, 2, 6, 636573) The answer is, by discharging one’s duty completely.
('91', 322, 2, 7, 636626) And since no mortal can completely discharge his duty in life, he must for ever remain a debtor to God.
('91', 322, 2, 8, 636730) Harijan, 28 7 1946
('91', 322, 3, 9, 636749) 377. EXTRACTS FROM SPEECHES AT PRAYER MEETINGS 2
('91', 322, 4, 10, 636798) PANCHGANI, [Before July 21, 1946] 3
('91', 322, 5, 11, 636834) In the song that has been sung today, the devotee says: ‘Keep my heart pure—guide me on the path of truth.Give me true happiness which springs from holding on to truth.
('91', 322, 5, 12, 637003) Destroy the misery which results from relinquishing truth.’ Believe me when I tell you after 60 years of personal experience that the only real misfortune is to abandon the path of truth.
('91', 322, 5, 13, 637191) If you but realize this, your one prayer to God will always be to enable you to put up without flinching with any number of trials and hardships that may fall to your lot in the pursuit of truth.
('91', 322, 5, 14, 637387) The verse from the Zend Avesta describes five kinds of physi cians, but the fifth is the true physician, who depends on nothing but the name of God for healing.
('91', 322, 5, 15, 637548) That is just what I have been saying in connection with nature cure.
('91', 322, 5, 16, 637617) Ramanama is the sovereign remedy.
('91', 322, 5, 17, 637651) It is an agreeable surprise to me to find an authority for it in the gatha.
('91', 322, 5, 18, 637727) In the song that has been sung, the poet says that God is hidden
('91', 322, 6, 19, 637792) 1Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 21 7 1946 2 Ibid 3 Ibid
('91', 323, 0, 1, 637860) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 323, 1, 2, 637902) and yet present everywhere.
('91', 323, 1, 3, 637930) That is true.
('91', 323, 1, 4, 637944) He knows our innermost thoughts better than we ourselves can do.
('91', 323, 1, 5, 638009) One who depends on God will never be afraid of anybody, not even of the most despotic government on earth or its officers.
('91', 323, 1, 6, 638132) For he will have as his protector the King of kings from whose eye nothing is hid.
('91', 323, 1, 7, 638215) Just as a tree has many branches but one root, similarly the various religions are the leaves and branches of the same tree.
('91', 323, 1, 8, 638340) Islam, Christianity, Hinduism and Zoroastrianism are the main branches but as for varieties of religion, they are as numerous as mankind.
('91', 323, 1, 9, 638478) If you take the name of God in the prayer gathering and forget all about it on going out, it is not prayer but blasphemy.
('91', 323, 1, 10, 638600) Religion has to be lived every moment of one’s life.
('91', 323, 1, 11, 638653) The girls have sung, ‘With folded hands, O Mazda!
('91', 323, 1, 12, 638703) I beg of Thee to give me true knowledge and enable me to devote every moment of my life to the service of Thy creation.’ It is a great prayer.
('91', 323, 1, 13, 638846) The devotee begs of God to fill him or her with the thirst for service, so that service will become a pleasure and not a task.
('91', 323, 1, 14, 638973) But what is the meaning of service?
('91', 323, 1, 15, 639009) Is killing fellow human beings in war, for instance, also service?
('91', 323, 1, 16, 639076) Therefore the devotee says, ‘Whatever I do, whether in order to serve others or myself, let all my deeds be pure and noble.
('91', 323, 1, 17, 639200) Let them fill me with Thy joy.’ A man who lives up to this prayer would always be filled with His joy.
('91', 323, 2, 18, 639303) Referring to the riots in Ahmedabad he said that the Hindus and Muslims in Ahmedabad had not yet got over their insanity.
('91', 323, 2, 19, 639425) Islam meant peace, Hindus claimed to follow the path of ahimsa.
('91', 323, 2, 20, 639489) They both swore by God but in practice they followed Satan.
('91', 323, 2, 21, 639549) The Muslim stabbed the innocent Hindu and the Hindu stabbed the innocent Muslim.
('91', 323, 2, 22, 639630) Of the three workers who were killed in Ahmedabad some days ago one was a Muslim 1. It was a Muslim’s dagger that killed him.
('91', 323, 2, 23, 639756) He was in the company of Hindus.
('91', 323, 2, 24, 639789) No one even knew that he was a Muslim.
('91', 323, 2, 25, 639828) One of his companions Vasantrao was well known and commanded the respect of both Hindus and Muslims.
('91', 323, 2, 26, 639929) While in jail one of his Muslim companions went on a fast.There was an overwhelming majority of Hindus amongst the satyagrahi prisoners.
('91', 323, 2, 27, 640066) Vasantrao felt that he ought to give his moral support to the Muslim brother and went on a sympathetic fast.
('91', 323, 2, 28, 640175) His senior companions in jail, tried to dissuade him.
('91', 323, 2, 29, 640229) ‘Are you wiser than all of us?
('91', 323, 2, 30, 640260) You know the Muslim friend’s fast is not justified.
('91', 323, 2, 31, 640312) If it was, we would all have fasted
('91', 323, 3, 32, 640348) 1 Rajabali Lakhani; vide “Letter to Ghulam Rasool Qureshi”, 17 7 1946.
('91', 324, 0, 1, 640419) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 325
('91', 324, 1, 2, 640461) with him.’ His reply was:‘I do not claim to be wise.
('91', 324, 1, 3, 640514) I prefer to be a fool.
('91', 324, 1, 4, 640537) I seek your blessings.
('91', 324, 1, 5, 640560) If this Muslim friend dies in jail in the midst of all of us Hindus, with what face shall I return to my Muslim friends outside?
('91', 324, 1, 6, 640689) Therefore, I would far rather die with him, whatever the issue of his fast.’ Neither died in the end, but Vasantrao proved by his action that he was a true Hindu and a true Muslim combined into one.
('91', 324, 2, 7, 640888) Gandhiji concluded by exhorting the audience to cultivate that mentality.
('91', 324, 2, 8, 640962) He was sure that if they prayed to God to restore to sanity the Hindus and Muslims of Ahmedabad, their prayer would not go unheeded, but leap across space and melt the hearts of the deluded rioters in Ahmedabad.
('91', 324, 3, 9, 641174) Harijan, 28 7 1946
('91', 324, 4, 10, 641193) 378. INDEPENDENCE
('91', 324, 5, 11, 641211) Q. You have said in your article in the Harijan of July 15, under the caption “The Real Danger”, 1 that Congressmen in general certainly do not know the kind of independence they want.
('91', 324, 5, 12, 641396) Would you kindly give them a broad but com prehensive picture of the Independent India of your own conception?
('91', 324, 6, 13, 641507) A. I do not know that I have not, from time to time, given my idea of Indian independence.
('91', 324, 6, 14, 641598) Since, however, this question is part of a series, it is better to answer it even at the risk of repetition.
('91', 324, 6, 15, 641707) Independence of India should mean independence of the whole of India, including what is called India of the States and the other foreign powers, French and Portuguese, who are there, I presume, by British sufferance.
('91', 324, 6, 16, 641924) Independence must mean that of the people of India, not of those who are today ruling over them.
('91', 324, 6, 17, 642021) The rulers should depend on the will of those who are under their heels.
('91', 324, 6, 18, 642094) Thus, they have to be servants of the people, ready to do their will.
('91', 324, 6, 19, 642164) Independence must begin at the bottom.
('91', 324, 6, 20, 642203) Thus, every village will be a republic or panchayat having full powers.
('91', 324, 6, 21, 642275) It follows, therefore, that every village has to be self sustained and capable of managing its affairs even to the extent of defending itself against the whole world.
('91', 324, 6, 22, 642442) It will be trained and prepared to perish in the attempt to defend itself against any onslaught from without.
('91', 324, 6, 23, 642552) Thus, ultimately, it is the indivi dual who is the unit.
('91', 324, 6, 24, 642609) This does not exclude dependence on and willing help from neighbours or from the world.
('91', 324, 6, 25, 642697) It will be free and voluntary
('91', 324, 7, 26, 642727) 1 Vide “The Real Danger”, 9 7 1946.
('91', 325, 0, 1, 642763) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 325, 1, 2, 642805) play of mutual forces.
('91', 325, 1, 3, 642828) Such a society is necessarily highly cultured in which every man and woman knows what he or she wants and, what is more, knows that no one should want anything that others cannot have with equal labour.
('91', 325, 1, 4, 643031) This society must naturally be based on truth and non violence which, in my opinion, are not possible without a living belief in God, meaning a self existent, all knowing living Force which inheres every other force known to the world and which depends on none and which will live when all other forces may conceivably perish or cease to act.
('91', 325, 1, 5, 643374) I am unable to account for my life without belief in this all embracing living Light.
('91', 325, 1, 6, 643460) In this structure composed of innumerable villages, there will be ever widening, never ascending circles.
('91', 325, 1, 7, 643566) Life will not be a pyramid with the apex sustained by the bottom.
('91', 325, 1, 8, 643632) But it will be an oceanic circle whose centre will be the individual always ready to perish for the village, the latter ready to perish for the circle of villages, till at last the whole becomes one life composed of individuals, never aggressive in their arrogance but ever humble, sharing the majesty of the oceanic circle of which they are integral units.
('91', 325, 1, 9, 643990) Therefore the outermost circumference will not wield power to crush the inner circle but will give strength to all within and derive its own strength from it.
('91', 325, 1, 10, 644149) I may be taunted with the retort that this is all Utopian and, therefore, not worth a single thought.
('91', 325, 1, 11, 644251) If Euclid’s point, though incapable of being drawn by human agency, has an imperi shable value, my picture has its own for mankind to live.
('91', 325, 1, 12, 644391) Let India live for this true picture, though never realizable in its completeness.
('91', 325, 1, 13, 644474) We must have a proper picture of what we want, before we can have something approaching it.
('91', 325, 1, 14, 644566) If there ever is to be a republic of every village in India, then I claim verity for my picture in which the last is equal to the first or, in other words, no one is to be the first and none the last.
('91', 325, 1, 15, 644767) In this picture every religion has its full and equal place.
('91', 325, 1, 16, 644828) We are all leaves of a majestic tree whose trunk cannot be shaken off its roots which are deep down in the bowels of the earth.
('91', 325, 1, 17, 644956) The mightiest wind cannot move it.
('91', 325, 1, 18, 644991) In this there is no room for machines that would displace human labour and that would concentrate power in a few hands.
('91', 325, 1, 19, 645111) Labour has its unique in a cultured human family.
('91', 325, 1, 20, 645161) Every machine that helps every individual has a place.
('91', 325, 1, 21, 645216) But I must confess that I have never sat down to think out what that machine can be.
('91', 325, 1, 22, 645301) I have thought of Singer’s sewing
('91', 326, 0, 1, 645335) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 327
('91', 326, 1, 2, 645377) machine.
('91', 326, 1, 3, 645386) But even that is perfunctory.
('91', 326, 1, 4, 645416) I do not need it to fill in my picture.
('91', 326, 2, 5, 645456) Q. Do you believe that the proposed Constituent Assembly could be used for the realization of your picture?
('91', 326, 3, 6, 645564) A. The Constituent Assembly has all the possibilities for the realization of my picture.
('91', 326, 3, 7, 645653) Yet I cannot hope for much, not because the State Paper holds no such possibilities but because the document, being wholly of a voluntary nature, requires the common consent of the many parties to it.
('91', 326, 3, 8, 645854) These have no common goal.
('91', 326, 3, 9, 645881) Congressmen themselves are not of one mind even on the contents of Indepen dence.I do not know how many swear by non violence or the charkha or, believing in decentralization, regard the village as the nucleus.
('91', 326, 3, 10, 646092) I know on the contrary that many would have India become a first class military power and wish for India to have a strong centre and build the whole structure round it.
('91', 326, 3, 11, 646261) In the medley of these conflicts I know that if India is to be leader in clean action based on clean thought, God will confound the wisdom of these big men and will provide the villages with the power to express themselves as they should.
('91', 326, 4, 12, 646500) Q. If the Constituent Assembly fizzles out because of the “danger from within”, as you have remarked in the above mentioned article, would you advise the Congress to accept the alternative of general country wide strike and capture of power, either non violently or with the use of necessary force?
('91', 326, 4, 13, 646799) What is your alternative in that eventuality if the above is not approved by you?
('91', 326, 5, 14, 646881) A. I must not contemplate darkness before it stares me in the face.
('91', 326, 5, 15, 646949) And in no case can I be party, irrespective of non violence, to a universal strike and capture of power.
('91', 326, 5, 16, 647054) Though, therefore, I do not know what I should do in the case of a breakdown, I know that the actuality will find me ready with an alternative.
('91', 326, 5, 17, 647198) My sole reliance being on the living Power which we call God, He will put the alternative in my hands when the time has come, not a minute sooner.
('91', 326, 6, 18, 647345) PANCHGANI, July 21, 1946 Harijan, 28 7 1946
