('91', 330, 10, 22, 652259) 386. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('91', 330, 11, 23, 652291) PANCHGANI, July 21, 1946
('91', 330, 12, 24, 652316) Gandhiji said that when he came to Panchgani under medical advice in 1944, after his release from detention, he found that there was no place where the poor and the destitute could put up, in order to take advantage of the beautiful climate.
('91', 330, 12, 25, 652558) And what about the Harijans?
('91', 330, 12, 26, 652587) He had received a long letter from one of them describing their woes.
('91', 330, 13, 27, 652657) 1 The letter bears the remark : “To be sent with Brijkrishna.” 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 30 7 1946
('91', 331, 0, 1, 652775) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 331, 1, 2, 652817) “It is all right so long as his identity is unknown.
('91', 331, 1, 3, 652870) But the moment it is discovered that he is a Harijan, he suddenly becomes a pariah.
('91', 331, 1, 4, 652954) He is unwelcome everywhere.
('91', 331, 1, 5, 652982) All doors are shut against him.
('91', 331, 1, 6, 653014) The shopkeeper receives his money but sells him the rottenest stuff and cheats him into the bargain by giving him less than the full measure.
('91', 331, 1, 7, 653156) Should the poor unfortunate object, he is insulted and told to be gone.
('91', 331, 1, 8, 653228) The landlord won’t have him and asks him to quit.
('91', 331, 1, 9, 653278) Where is the poor man to go?” It was heart rending.
('91', 331, 1, 10, 653330) He felt he could not come and stay in Panchgani unless there was a place where the Harijans would be welcome like all others.
('91', 331, 1, 11, 653456) It had therefore given him great pleasure that Panchgani was at last going to hare such a place.
('91', 331, 1, 12, 653553) Sheth Shantilal of Ahmedabad had purchased the ‘Satish Kunj’ property for Rs. 45,000 and had agreed to get it reconditioned and bear the running expenses of the institution for ten years.
('91', 331, 1, 13, 653741) In the dharma shala which was going to be built, the poor of all communities including the Harijans would be able to come and stay without any distinction of caste or religion.
('91', 331, 1, 14, 653918) They would be provided free accommodation but would have to make their own arrangements as regards food, etc.
('91', 331, 1, 15, 654028) A Trust had been formed to look after the dharmashala, consisting of Sheth Shantilal of Ahmedabad, Sheth Mohanlal, Shri Bachharaj, Dr. Dinshaw Mehta and Gandhiji.
('91', 331, 1, 16, 654191) He would have liked the dharmashala, said Gandhiji, to be built out of funds provided by the inhabitants of Panchgani itself.
('91', 331, 1, 17, 654317) But finance was not everything.
('91', 331, 1, 18, 654349) Although they had not contributed the money, they should give their blessings and co operation.
('91', 331, 1, 19, 654445) The institution would fail unless the people took active and genuine interest in it.
('91', 331, 1, 20, 654530) He suggested that sisters from well to do families should visit the sick or the convalescent who might come to the dharmashala for a change of climate, soothe them by singing beautiful hymns and render them whatever service they could or was necessary.
('91', 331, 2, 21, 654783) The sanitary conditions in Panchgani were awful.
('91', 331, 2, 22, 654832) In a climate like theirs there should never be any epidemics.
('91', 331, 2, 23, 654894) Yet they had the plague only the year before and had to vacate the bazaar which was indescribably dirty.
('91', 331, 2, 24, 654999) There was water shortage in spite of a plentiful rainfall.
('91', 331, 2, 25, 655058) Why could not the rain water be captured and utilized for water supply?
('91', 331, 2, 26, 655130) In South Africa, where rainfall was scarce and there was a dearth of underground water supply, they had a reservoir in every house for storing rain water.
('91', 331, 2, 27, 655285) It was the duty of all of them, most of all the Municipality and the Public Health Department to remedy these defects.
('91', 331, 2, 28, 655404) The Prime Minister Shri Balasaheb Kher 1 was there and was prepared to render them whatever help was necessary.
('91', 331, 2, 29, 655516) If he were the Health Officer or the Chairman of the Panchgani Municipality, said Gandhiji, he would make the place so clean and neat that anybody might be able to lie down and sleep on the hill side in the open without any compunction.
('91', 331, 2, 30, 655753) Today that was not
('91', 331, 3, 31, 655772) 1 Kher, Bal Gangadhar (1888 1957); Premier of the Bombay State from 1937 to 1939 and again from 1946 to 1952. He along with Patil and Tapase had come from Poona for the ceremony of dedication of ‘Satish Kunj’
('91', 332, 0, 1, 655981) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 333
('91', 332, 1, 2, 656023) possible, because of the Municipal insanitation.
('91', 332, 1, 3, 656072) People spat and made nuisance here, there and everywhere indiscriminately.
('91', 332, 1, 4, 656147) He spoke from knowledge, he said.
('91', 332, 1, 5, 656181) Before he came under the Mahatmaic handicap and was free to go into dharmashalas and other places of public utility without attracting crowds, he had occasion to study the conditions prevailing in those places.
('91', 332, 1, 6, 656392) The insanitation, the filth and the stench of the public latrines and urinals of the railway stations and in the dharmashalas were simply awful.
('91', 332, 1, 7, 656537) They could make Panchgani into a jewel among hill stations, if only they did their duty.
('91', 332, 2, 8, 656626) He then proceeded to make some concrete suggestions.
('91', 332, 2, 9, 656679) The first and foremost of course was sanitation and night soil disposal.
('91', 332, 2, 10, 656752) Having become a Bhangi himself, he thought of it first.
('91', 332, 2, 11, 656808) He had done a Bhangi’s job right from South Africa.
('91', 332, 2, 12, 656860) He knew how to do it without becoming filthy himself.
('91', 332, 2, 13, 656914) The sight of a Bhangi carrying the night soil basket on his head made him sick.
('91', 332, 2, 14, 656994) Scavenging was a fine art.
('91', 332, 2, 15, 657021) Not only must the cleaning be perfect, but the manner of doing it and the instruments used, must be clean and not revolting to one’s sanitary sense.
('91', 332, 2, 16, 657170) You have only to see the privy I use.
('91', 332, 2, 17, 657208) It is spotlessly clean without a trace of smell.
('91', 332, 2, 18, 657257) That is so because I clean it myself.
('91', 332, 2, 19, 657295) The municipal Bhangi pours out the contents of the night soil waggons over a cliff converting a beauty spot into a plague spot.
('91', 332, 2, 20, 657423) If you become your own Bhangis, not only will you ensure perfect sanitation for yourself, but you will make your surroundings clean and relieve the Bhangis of the weight of oppression which today crushes them.
('91', 332, 2, 21, 657633) Do not imagine that thereby you would deprive them of their living.
('91', 332, 2, 22, 657701) Today we have reduced them to the level of the beast.
('91', 332, 2, 23, 657755) They earn a few coppers but only at the expense of their human dignity.
('91', 332, 2, 24, 657827) The same Bhangi serves in the municipality as well as in your bungalow, with the result that he can do justice to neither.
('91', 332, 2, 25, 657950) Look at him as he eats his food, cowering under the shadow of the latrine wall, surrounded by filth.
('91', 332, 2, 26, 658051) It is enough to break one’s heart.
('91', 332, 2, 27, 658086) It should not be difficult for you to find a more decent avocation for him to follow.
('91', 332, 3, 28, 658172) The Nawab Saheb of Wai who had seen him earlier in the day had told him that they knew what to do, but that the municipality was too poor and the necessary finances were lacking.
('91', 332, 3, 29, 658351) He had asked the Nawab Saheb, said Gandhiji, to send him a small note setting forth their handicap.
('91', 332, 3, 30, 658451) He hoped to be able to show him that what they wanted to do and what needed to be done, need not be held up for lack of funds.
('91', 332, 3, 31, 658578) After all the various improvements which he had suggested would not require more than ten lakhs of rupees.
('91', 332, 3, 32, 658685) He wanted to tell the rich folk who frequented Panchgani that it was up to them to provide that amount.
('91', 332, 3, 33, 658789) In free and progressive countries, the gentry considered it their special privilege and duty to shoulder the burden of providing municipal amenities and improvements.
('91', 332, 3, 34, 658956) It was only in India that people looked for every little thing to the Government.
('91', 332, 3, 35, 659038) They must learn to shed that mendicant habit if
('91', 333, 0, 1, 659086) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 333, 1, 2, 659128) they aspired to become a free and self respecting nation.
('91', 333, 2, 3, 659186) Then they should do something to improve the drainage.
('91', 333, 2, 4, 659241) For that, a suitable scheme would have to be prepared by an engineer.
('91', 333, 2, 5, 659311) He hoped that the work would be taken up without delay.
('91', 333, 3, 6, 659367) Lastly, he hoped that something would be done immediately about the disposal of the night soil.
('91', 333, 3, 7, 659463) The present practice was a sin against man and God and its continuation even for a single day should be a matter of utter shame to them.
('91', 333, 3, 8, 659600) He was sorry to tell them that Dr. Dinshaw had reported that even after nearly a fortnight, things were as bad as they were on their arrival in Panchgani.
('91', 333, 4, 9, 659755) He hoped that when he came to Panchgani next year, God willing, he would find things different.
('91', 333, 4, 10, 659851) The gulf that separated the rich and the poor today was appalling.
('91', 333, 4, 11, 659918) It had to be bridged.
('91', 333, 4, 12, 659940) The rich must share all their amenities with the poor in the fullest measure.
('91', 333, 4, 13, 660018) Their joining in the prayer gathering would have gone in vain if it did not help them to realize and do their duty.
('91', 333, 4, 14, 660134) Such prayer would be vain repetition which could do no good to them, to him or to anybody.
('91', 333, 4, 15, 660225) Harijan, 11 8 1946
('91', 333, 5, 16, 660244) 387. BLOODSHED IN AHMEDABAD 1
('91', 333, 6, 17, 660274) Bloodshed had been going on in Ahmedabad for several days now.
('91', 333, 6, 18, 660337) It is difficult to say who is at fault.
('91', 333, 6, 19, 660377) The policy of the Govern ment has been not to let anyone know who has stabbed whom.
('91', 333, 6, 20, 660461) The Congress Government has adhered to this policy, so we should assume that there is some reason behind it.
('91', 333, 6, 21, 660570) It could be in the manner of a thief’s mother feigning grief over her son’s doings, because in Ahmedabad everyone must know who is the aggressor or who is more to blame.
('91', 333, 6, 22, 660740) My job is not to deliberate upon it; it is comparatively easier.
('91', 333, 6, 23, 660805) The best way is for one of the parties to desist.
('91', 333, 6, 24, 660855) Then alone can true peace be established and the madness come to an end.
('91', 333, 6, 25, 660928) In my childhood a cousin of mine and I took bhang and laughed and laughed at each other like two mad men.
('91', 333, 6, 26, 661034) When morning came and we were sober, we were both ashamed of ourselves and could not face each other.
('91', 333, 6, 27, 661136) That intoxication was comparatively harmless but this is frightful.
('91', 333, 6, 28, 661204) Is it not enough that three young men 2 have died in the attempt to stop the holocaust?
('91', 333, 6, 29, 661292) I spoke about it at the prayer meeting at Poona.
('91', 333, 6, 30, 661341) 3 Several friends have written to me about the martyrdom.
('91', 333, 7, 31, 661399) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 28 7 1946. 2 Two of them were Rajabali Lakhani and Vasantrao Hegishte.
('91', 333, 7, 32, 661525) 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 2 7 1946.
('91', 334, 0, 1, 661570) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 335
('91', 334, 1, 2, 661612) had sense that sacrifice would have quenched the fire.
('91', 334, 1, 3, 661667) That has not happened.
('91', 334, 1, 4, 661690) However, that does not mean that the sacrifice was in vain.
('91', 334, 1, 5, 661750) It only means that many more such sacrifices must be offered before the fire can be quelled.
('91', 334, 1, 6, 661843) Or both sides must tire themselves out.
('91', 334, 1, 7, 661883) Some must face police bullets, some go to jail and some hang before the flames are extinguished.
('91', 334, 1, 8, 661980) This is the wrong way; because the fire thus put out has every possibility of erupting again.
('91', 334, 1, 9, 662074) It will not reduce the poison, only suppress it, which will then spread in the body politic and cause immense mischief.
('91', 334, 1, 10, 662194) Moreover, if the riots are suppressed with the help of the police and its elder brother the military, it will strengthen the grip of the foreigner and emasculate us still further Poet Iqbal has said: “Reli gion does not teach us to bear enmity towards each other.” Can there be greater cowardice than to fight amongst ourselves.
('91', 334, 1, 11, 662523) There are ways even of fighting.
('91', 334, 1, 12, 662556) If we must fight, why should we seek the help of the police and the military?
('91', 334, 1, 13, 662634) The Government too should clearly say that the military, whilst it is in India, will only be used for the work of sanitation, for cultivating unused land and the like.
('91', 334, 1, 14, 662802) And the police similarly will be used for catching thieves and dacoits, but never to put down communal riots.
('91', 334, 1, 15, 662912) Let the people of Ahmedabad be brave enough to say that they will not seek the help of the police and the military, and they will not flee in panic.
('91', 334, 1, 16, 663061) Rioters are mostly goondas.
('91', 334, 1, 17, 663089) Even the white collared goondas murder by stealth.
('91', 334, 1, 18, 663140) I am told that nearly all the stabbings have been in the back, none or very few in the chest or the face.
('91', 334, 1, 19, 663246) Why should one be frightened of such people?
('91', 334, 1, 20, 663291) One should either die at their hands in the hope that they will in the end give up their madness and goondaism, or if one does not have that much courage one should fight to defend oneself.
('91', 334, 1, 21, 663481) The question may rightly be asked how can one fight against a person who strikes from behind.
('91', 334, 1, 22, 663575) It may not be possible to prevent such a person from stabbing people in the back but if the onlookers are not in collusion with him and are brave enough, they can catch hold of the culprit and hand him over to the police or to the community to which he belongs, or bring him before the panch.
('91', 334, 1, 23, 663868) Only, they may not become judges.

('91', 335, 1, 2, 664010) 388. A DHARMASHALA FOR PANCHGANI
('91', 335, 2, 3, 664043) When I first visited Panchgani after my release from jail, at a prayer meeting I mentioned the absence, in a beautiful place like Panchgani, of facilities for the poor, especially Harijans.
('91', 335, 2, 4, 664233) In the event, for a person like me it becomes difficult even to stay at Panchgani.
('91', 335, 2, 5, 664316) As far as I was concerned there were many who would put me up but where could the Harijans go?
('91', 335, 2, 6, 664411) My host would accommodate the Harijans accompanying me but what about the rest?
('91', 335, 2, 7, 664491) How could we put up with such a pitiable state of affairs?
('91', 335, 2, 8, 664550) I told this to the audience assembled at the prayer meeting.
('91', 335, 2, 9, 664611) This created some stir.
('91', 335, 2, 10, 664635) However, the result came only after two years.
('91', 335, 2, 11, 664682) Sheth Shantilal bought a house and handed it on to me for lodging the poor.
('91', 335, 2, 12, 664758) Such poor include myself and others I recommend.
('91', 335, 2, 13, 664807) Of course they include poor Harijans and poor persons belonging to other religions who have nowhere to stay.
('91', 335, 2, 14, 664916) There won’t be any arrangement for their meals.
('91', 335, 2, 15, 664964) Even poor people do eat at home, so they will have to do their own cooking or make whatever other arrangement is possible.
('91', 335, 2, 16, 665087) Besides, the poor will have to keep the place given to them clean, deposit their trash in the municipal cans and observe all the rules of sanitation.
('91', 335, 2, 17, 665237) Free supply to them of water and electricity will be arranged.
('91', 335, 2, 18, 665300) No one will be allowed to stay for ever.
('91', 335, 2, 19, 665341) Those who are not suffering from infectious diseases, are not invalid, and do not require looking after will be given free accommodation for a certain specified period.
('91', 335, 2, 20, 665510) They will not be provided with bedding, etc.
('91', 335, 2, 21, 665555) This is not to be a home for the crippled.
('91', 335, 2, 22, 665598) Idlers will have no place here.
('91', 335, 2, 23, 665630) There are many places in Panchgani and the neighbouring hills for the middle class people who observe caste distinctions.
('91', 335, 2, 24, 665752) However, there is none for those who have broken away from the circle of castes or are outside that circle.
('91', 335, 2, 25, 665860) Here accommodation will be provided to the poor and industrious.
('91', 335, 2, 26, 665925) This activity can be pursued only if some local public worker is available.
('91', 335, 2, 27, 666001) Shri Bachharaj Tribhovandas Doshi is such a worker.
('91', 335, 2, 28, 666053) It was through his encouragement, as also of Gadhada’s Sheth Mohanlal Motichand and of his won grandfather Jeshangbhai, that Sheth Shanti lal bought the above mentioned house.
('91', 335, 2, 29, 666229) Bhai Bachharaj stays in Panchgani most of the time.
('91', 335, 2, 30, 666281) He has a flair and also love for this kind of work, so he will keep an eye on it.
('91', 335, 2, 31, 666363) Sheth Shantilal has undertaken to bear the cost of repairs for ten
('91', 336, 0, 1, 666430) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 337
('91', 336, 1, 2, 666472) Five trustees have already been appointed.
('91', 336, 1, 3, 666515) I am considering the names of the remaining two.
('91', 336, 1, 4, 666564) Among the five trustees are the above mentioned three gentlemen, Dr. Dinshaw and myself.
('91', 336, 1, 5, 666653) At the moment the building is not fit for residence.
('91', 336, 1, 6, 666706) It is in need of repairs and the water supply is incomplete.
('91', 336, 1, 7, 666767) It may be ready for use only in October.
('91', 336, 1, 8, 666808) Thus a beginning has been made.
('91', 336, 1, 9, 666840) Prime Minister Shri Kher along with two other Ministers Shri Tapase and Shri Patil, were present when this was announced after the prayer meeting in the hall of the Parsi Girls School on Sunday.
('91', 336, 1, 10, 667035) 1 We should pray and wish that the work which has begun so well may really prove beneficial to the poor.

('91', 342, 3, 8, 675088) 400. NOTE TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('91', 342, 4, 9, 675118) July 24, 1946 I have gone through everything carefully.
('91', 342, 4, 10, 675174) You seem to forget that I had offered to give you work only after you had decided what you wished to do regarding Kanchan.
('91', 342, 4, 11, 675297) This time you have come to some decision, but it is incomplete.
('91', 342, 4, 12, 675361) I had also told you what you should do in the meanwhile and I had explained, too, that if you finally decided to stay with me you would be welcome.
('91', 342, 4, 13, 675509) But you can live and work with me only if you abide by my advice.
('91', 342, 4, 14, 675575) Personally, I would welcome your staying with me; but if you experience any difficulty in doing so, is it not for you yourself to overcome it?
('91', 342, 4, 15, 675718) You may ask for my help in that.
('91', 342, 4, 16, 675751) Your work for each hour should be defined.
('91', 342, 4, 17, 675794) Don’t you observe complete silence?
('91', 342, 4, 18, 675830) Never enter into an argument with anybody.
('91', 342, 4, 19, 675873) If other people speak untruth or behave indecorously, how are you concerned with that?
('91', 342, 4, 20, 675960) We may feel ashamed if we ourselves do so.
('91', 342, 4, 21, 676003) It is true I have collected a mixed crowd round me.
('91', 342, 4, 22, 676055) But is that a new story?
('91', 342, 4, 23, 676080) This answers all your questions.
('91', 342, 4, 24, 676113) How ever, if any point is left out you may ask me.
('91', 342, 4, 25, 676164) Do not reduce your exercise.
('91', 342, 4, 26, 676193) Physical labour is necessary.
('91', 342, 4, 27, 676223) Improve your proficiency in the languages.
('91', 342, 4, 28, 676266) As soon as you have come to some decision I shall immediately be able to make arrangements for your work.
('91', 342, 4, 29, 676372) In short you should know that I have given my word to Kanchan that as long as she is firm in her desire to live separately with you I will support her in her desire.
('91', 342, 4, 30, 676538) Blessings from BAPU

('91', 343, 0, 1, 676632) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 343, 1, 2, 676674) 401. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('91', 343, 2, 3, 676702) PANCHGANI, July 24, 1946
('91', 343, 3, 4, 676727) Doctor A. G. Tendulkar, President, Goa Congress Committee is the last one from Goa who has come to me with the latest news from the place.
('91', 343, 3, 5, 676866) 1 He tells me that there are several parties there, working not necessarily for its inhabitants but for power.
('91', 343, 3, 6, 676977) Yet at bottom the fight is good.
('91', 343, 3, 7, 677010) He has produced voluminous papers in support of the statement that confusion reigns supreme in the minds of Goans, correctly described as Gomantakas.
('91', 343, 3, 8, 677160) This confusion is bad in that the inhabitants of these Portuguese possessions are novices in the art of real politics.
('91', 343, 3, 9, 677279) Its separate existence, it is clear, can only depend on the goodwill of the mighty British Government and the impotence of its Indian residents.
('91', 343, 3, 10, 677424) It is therefore most essential for the success of the movement that it should be conducted by the Gomantakas on the clearest possible issue, i.
('91', 343, 3, 11, 677568) e., civil liberty.
('91', 343, 3, 12, 677587) The larger question of swaraj should await its attainment by the whole of India unless of course the Portuguese Government wisely come to terms with the inhabitants of the settlement through friendly negotiations.
('91', 343, 3, 13, 677801) It cannot be attained by any direct action of the citizens, whether violent or non violent.
('91', 343, 3, 14, 677893) In non violent action success is assured where every inhabitant is a hero ready to lay down his or her life.
('91', 343, 3, 15, 678002) It is less to be thought of in Goa than in the more numerous and better seasoned and awakened British India.
('91', 343, 3, 16, 678111) Therefore the clearest possible issue of civil liberty must be kept steadily in view.
('91', 343, 3, 17, 678197) The second condition of success is that the fight must be through non violent and therefore also entirely open means.
('91', 343, 3, 18, 678315) Thirdly, there should be no parties struggling for power and position.
('91', 343, 3, 19, 678386) Where the goal and the means are common, different parties have no meaning.
('91', 343, 3, 20, 678462) On reading the literature I find two persons called loyalists who have already made lavish declarations saying that nothing is wrong in
('91', 343, 4, 21, 678598) 1 Tendulkar saw Gandhiji in the afternoon of July 23; vide “Letter to Indumati Tendulkar”, 23 7 1946.
('91', 344, 0, 1, 678700) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 345
('91', 344, 1, 2, 678742) Goa and that a false agitation is being carried on by some mischievous persons.
('91', 344, 1, 3, 678822) Let not the circle of these loyalists grow larger.
('91', 344, 1, 4, 678873) The best way to avoid this growth is for all parties to become one.
('91', 344, 2, 5, 678941) PANCHGANI, July 24, 1946 Harijan, 28 7 1946
('91', 344, 3, 6, 678985) 402. QUESTION BOX 1
('91', 344, 4, 7, 679005) Q. I have been repeating Ramanama according to your advice and I am gett ing better.
('91', 344, 4, 8, 679090) I must add that the medical treatment for tuberculosis is also being followed.
('91', 344, 4, 9, 679169) You have said that eating little and eating the right food enables a man to be healthy and promotes longevity.
('91', 344, 4, 10, 679280) I have observed the rule about eating sparely for the last twenty five years.
('91', 344, 4, 11, 679358) Why should I have fallen a prey to tuberculosis?
('91', 344, 4, 12, 679407) Would you say I should attribute this ill luck to some evil deed in this life or in the previous one?
('91', 344, 4, 13, 679509) You say a man can live up to 125 years.
('91', 344, 4, 14, 679549) Then why should God have carried away Mahadevbhai, who was so useful to you?
('91', 344, 4, 15, 679626) He observed the rule of eating mode rately and having a balanced diet and he served you as his God.
('91', 344, 4, 16, 679726) Why did he fall a prey to high blood pressure?
('91', 344, 4, 17, 679773) Why did Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, who is looked upon as an incarnation of God, fall a prey to cancer, as deadly a disease as tuberculosis?
('91', 344, 4, 18, 679911) Why was he not able to fight it successfully?
('91', 344, 5, 19, 679957) A. I have been expounding the rules of maintaining health as I know them.
('91', 344, 5, 20, 680031) Spare and balanced diet may not be the same for everybody.
('91', 344, 5, 21, 680090) It can be best worked out by the individual for himself through proper reading and careful thought.
('91', 344, 5, 22, 680190) But that does not mean that the individual cannot make mistakes or that his or her knowledge is complete.
('91', 344, 5, 23, 680296) That is why life has been called a laboratory.
('91', 344, 5, 24, 680343) One should learn from the experience of others and go forward and if he is not successful, he should not blame others or even himself.
('91', 344, 5, 25, 680478) One should not be too ready to find fault with the rule, but if after careful thought, one comes to the conclusion that a certain rule is wrong, he should be able to tell the right one and declare it.
('91', 344, 5, 26, 680679) So far as your own case is concerned, there may be several causes leading to your illness.
('91', 344, 5, 27, 680770) Who can say whether you have made the right use of the five ‘powers’ in your own case?
('91', 344, 5, 28, 680857) So long as I believe in the laws of nature as I know them, I have to say that you must have erred somewhere.
('91', 344, 5, 29, 680966) As for Mahadev and Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, to feel that even they must have erred somehow is fitter
('91', 344, 6, 30, 681067) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 4 8 1946
('91', 345, 0, 1, 681140) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 345, 1, 2, 681182) than to say that the laws are wrong.
('91', 345, 1, 3, 681219) These rules are not my creation.
('91', 345, 1, 4, 681252) They are the laws of nature according to experienced men.
('91', 345, 1, 5, 681310) I believe them and try to live up to my belief.
('91', 345, 1, 6, 681358) Man is after all an imperfect creature.
('91', 345, 1, 7, 681398) How can he know the whole truth?
('91', 345, 1, 8, 681431) That the doctors do not believe in them or, if they do, they do so in a different sense, does not impress me.
('91', 345, 1, 9, 681541) What I have said does not and should not in any way detract from the greatness of the individuals mentioned.
('91', 345, 2, 10, 681650) Q. In Harijanbandhu of 14 4 ’46, you have said, “God is the Law and the Law giver.” I do not understand it.
('91', 345, 2, 11, 681758) Laws are made by man and they keep on changing with time.
('91', 345, 2, 12, 681816) For instance, Draupadi had five husbands and yet she was considered a sati.
('91', 345, 2, 13, 681892) A woman who does that today will be considered immoral.
('91', 345, 3, 14, 681948) A. Law here means the law of God.
('91', 345, 3, 15, 681982) Man interprets that law according to his understanding.
('91', 345, 3, 16, 682038) We can therefore say that with the gaining of more knowledge he finds the previous assumption wrong.
('91', 345, 4, 17, 682139) For instance, the rotation of the earth is a law of nature.
('91', 345, 4, 18, 682199) We are convinced of its correctness today.
('91', 345, 4, 19, 682242) Yet before Galileo, astronomers believed differently.
('91', 345, 4, 20, 682296) As for Draupadi, the Mahabharata in my opinion is an allegory and not history.
('91', 345, 4, 21, 682375) Draupadi means the soul wedded to the five senses.
('91', 345, 5, 22, 682426) Q. God cannot be realized through reason.
('91', 345, 5, 23, 682468) He has to be understood through faith.
('91', 345, 5, 24, 682507) Do you believe in rebirth or is it that the Hindu seers 2 propounded it in order to enable people to appreciate the significance of good and evil deeds and derive some satisfaction from the belief?
('91', 345, 6, 25, 682705) A. God cannot be realized through the intellect.
('91', 345, 6, 26, 682754) Intellect can lead one to a certain extent and no further.
('91', 345, 6, 27, 682813) It is a matter of faith and experience derived from that faith.
('91', 345, 6, 28, 682877) One might rely on the experience of one’s betters 3 or else be satisfied with nothing less than personal experience.
('91', 345, 6, 29, 682994) Full faith does not feel the want of experience.
('91', 345, 6, 30, 683043) The distinction between good and evil is not meant to act as a consolation.
('91', 345, 6, 31, 683119) Nor is faith in God meant for that purpose.
('91', 345, 6, 32, 683163) The seers have held that there is good and evil and there is rebirth.
('91', 345, 6, 33, 683233) I think this theory of reincarnation is capable of being understood by the intellect.
('91', 345, 7, 34, 683319) Q. The Congress has been fighting the British Government non violently.
('91', 345, 7, 35, 683391) When Congressmen come into power, they shoot their own brothers who have gone astray and are causing trouble.
('91', 345, 7, 36, 683501) Is it right?
('91', 345, 7, 37, 683514) If the Congressmen in power have not the courage to lay down their lives while attempting to put down the riots non violently,
('91', 345, 8, 38, 683641) 1 This is taken from the Gujarati version.
('91', 345, 8, 39, 683684) 2The Gujarati original has “Hindu dharma”.
('91', 345, 8, 40, 683727) 3 The Gujarati original has “predecessors”.
('91', 346, 0, 1, 683771) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 347
('91', 346, 1, 2, 683813) does it not show with the exception of a few individuals like Ravishankar Maharaj and Sane Guruji, the non violence of Congressmen in general is the non violence of the weak?
('91', 346, 2, 3, 683988) A. The question of violence and non violence raised by you is an old question.
('91', 346, 2, 4, 684067) I have said a lot in this connection.
('91', 346, 2, 5, 684105) If like many others, non violence does not appeal to your heart, you should discard it.
('91', 346, 2, 6, 684193) I shall not find fault with you for that, and, if others do, you should not care.
('91', 346, 2, 7, 684275) The principle is this: “That which has been propounded by the rishis, practised by the sages and appeals to one’s heart should be followed and put into practice.” The question might arise as to what one is to do when the thing that appeals to one’s heart is contrary to what has been propounded by the rishis and practised by the sages.
('91', 346, 2, 8, 684612) The answer is, that in such a case the individual can follow his bent at his own risk.
('91', 346, 2, 9, 684699) Many reforms and new discoveries have been made in this way.
('91', 346, 2, 10, 684760) Our Shankaracharyas have supported the institution of untouchability but both our head and heart consider it a blot on Hinduism.
('91', 346, 2, 11, 684889) We do not care if others consider our belief to be wrong.
('91', 346, 3, 12, 684947) Q. From 1920 you have described the British Government’s officials as the arms of Ravana.
('91', 346, 3, 13, 685037) Congress Governments use these arms.
('91', 346, 3, 14, 685074) Again, the laws made by the British Government say that it is an offence to beat a prisoner arrested on suspicion or for an alleged offence, in order to extort a confession or to frighten him.
('91', 346, 3, 15, 685267) During the 1942 revolution, many like me were severely beaten after arrest.
('91', 346, 3, 16, 685343) Should not the Congress Governments hold an inquiry into the police excesses thus committed?
('91', 346, 4, 17, 685436) A. I have severely criticized the British Government and do so still.
('91', 346, 4, 18, 685506) But that does not mean that all police officials under the British Government must necessarily be devil’s disciples even when they come under Congress Governments.
('91', 346, 4, 19, 685670) No one has questioned Congress Govern ment’s right to inquire into the police excesses in 1942 or even before.
('91', 346, 4, 20, 685781) But such rights are not always exercised.
('91', 346, 4, 21, 685823) We all know that there are times when wisdom lies in not exercising certain rights.
('91', 346, 4, 22, 685907) The Congress has in general followed the policy of not inquiring into the kind of excesses mentioned by you.
('91', 346, 4, 23, 686016) You should know that often such offences are difficult to prove.
('91', 346, 4, 24, 686081) I believe the right of inquiry has been exercised in cases where the offence was beyond doubt.
('91', 346, 4, 25, 686176) But my advice is let us not sit in judgment on the Congress ministries.
('91', 346, 4, 26, 686248) The belief that Congress has acted wisely in accepting power should suffice.
('91', 346, 5, 27, 686325) PANCHGANI, July 25, 1946 Harijan, 4 8 1946
('91', 347, 0, 1, 686368) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 347, 1, 2, 686410) 403. HEAL THYSELF 1
('91', 347, 2, 3, 686430) A correspondent has written to me about the butchery that is going on in Ahmedabad.
('91', 347, 2, 4, 686514) I give below the relevant portions from his letter.
('91', 347, 3, 5, 686566) I wish to write to you about the means to be employed for putting down riots.
('91', 347, 3, 6, 686644) About two months ago you wrote an article on Ahimsak Seva Dal—non violent volunteer corps.
('91', 347, 3, 7, 686735) 2 But looking to the situation in the country, the suggestion will not do.
('91', 347, 3, 8, 686810) Just as you have taught us how to fight against the British Government non violently, you should go to some place of riot and show us the way of quelling riots in a non violent manner by personal example.
('91', 347, 3, 9, 687015) Supposing you were in Ahmedabad today and went out to quell the riots, any number of volunteers will join you.
('91', 347, 3, 10, 687126) Two of our Congress workers, Shri Vasantrao and Shri Rajabali, went out in such a quest and fell a prey to the goonda’s knife.
('91', 347, 3, 11, 687253) They laid down their lives in the pursuit of an ideal and they deserve all praise.
('91', 347, 3, 12, 687336) But no one else had the courage to follow in their footsteps.
('91', 347, 3, 13, 687398) They have not the same self confidence.
('91', 347, 3, 14, 687438) If they had it, there would be no riots and, even if riots broke out, they would never assume the proportions and the form that the present day riots do.
('91', 347, 3, 15, 687592) But the fact remains that such a state is merely an imaginary thing today.
('91', 347, 4, 16, 687667) Your guidance and example can inspire many like me with courage and self confidence.
('91', 347, 4, 17, 687752) Once you have shown the way, the local workers will be able to follow it whenever occasion demands it.
('91', 347, 4, 18, 687855) I feel that unless you set an example in action, your writings and utterances will not be of any use to the ordinary people, and even Congressmen, in organizing non violent protec tion of society.
('91', 347, 4, 19, 688052) I like the suggestion mentioned above.
('91', 347, 4, 20, 688091) People followed my advice and took to non violent resistance against the British Govern ment because they wanted to offer some sort of resistance.
('91', 347, 4, 21, 688238) But their non violence, I must confess, was born of their helplessness.
('91', 347, 4, 22, 688310) There fore, it was the weapon of the weak.
('91', 347, 4, 23, 688353) That is why today we worship Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose and his Azad Hind Fauj.
('91', 347, 4, 24, 688433) We forget that Netaji himself had told his soldiers that on going to India, they must follow the way of non violence.
('91', 347, 4, 25, 688551) This I have from the leaders of the I. N. A. But we have lost all sense of discrimination.
('91', 347, 4, 26, 688642) To restore it, the I. N. A. men will have to live up to the ideal placed before them by Netaji.
('91', 347, 4, 27, 688738) The work of those who believe in non violence is very difficult
('91', 347, 5, 28, 688802) 1 The Hindi original of this was also published in Harijan Sevak, 4 8 1946. 2 Vide “Non Violent Volunteer Corps”, 26 4 1946.
('91', 348, 0, 1, 688927) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 349
('91', 348, 1, 2, 688969) in this atmosphere which is full of violence.
('91', 348, 1, 3, 689015) But the path of true non violence requires much more courage than violence.
('91', 348, 1, 4, 689091) We have not been able to give proof of such non violence.
('91', 348, 1, 5, 689149) We might look upon the action of Shri Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi, Shri Vasantrao and Shri Rajabali as examples of the non violence of the brave.
('91', 348, 1, 6, 689292) But when communal feelings run high, we are unable to demonstrate any effect of the sacrifices mentioned above.
('91', 348, 1, 7, 689404) For that, many like Shri Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi will have to lay down their lives.
('91', 348, 1, 8, 689489) The fact that no one else in Ahmedabad has followed the example set by Shri Vasantrao and Shri Rajabali shows that we have not yet developed the spirit of sacrifice to the extent of laying down our lives in non violent action.
('91', 348, 1, 9, 689716) The correspondent has rightly said that under these circum stances, I should act myself whether others join me or not.
('91', 348, 1, 10, 689835) It will be disgraceful on my part to sit at home and tell others to go and lay down their lives.
('91', 348, 1, 11, 689932) Such a thing cannot be an indication of non violence.
('91', 348, 1, 12, 689986) I have never had the chance to test my non violence in the face of communal riots.
('91', 348, 1, 13, 690069) It might be argued that it was my cowardice which prevented me from seeking such a chance.
('91', 348, 1, 14, 690160) Be that as it may, God willing, the chance will still come to me, and by throwing me in the fire, He will purify me and make the path of non violence clear.
('91', 348, 1, 15, 690317) No one should take it to mean that sacrifice of my life will arrest all violence.
('91', 348, 1, 16, 690399) Several lives like mine will have to be given if the terrible violence that has spread all over, is to stop and non violence is to reign supreme in its place.
('91', 348, 1, 17, 690558) The poet 1 has sung:
('91', 348, 2, 18, 690579) “The path of Truth is for the brave, never for the coward.” The path of Truth is the path of non violence.
('91', 348, 3, 19, 690686) PANCHGANI, July 25, 1946 Harijan, 4 8 1946
('91', 348, 4, 20, 690729) 1 The Hindi original has ‘Pritam’.

('91', 351, 5, 11, 693991) 409. ENTRY IN DIARY OF MUNNALAL SHAH
('91', 351, 6, 12, 694028) PANCHGANI, July 26, 1946 4 5 Five minutes for toilet .
('91', 351, 6, 13, 694083) 1 Comments Prayer 50 minutes.
('91', 351, 6, 14, 694113) Lack complete concentration.
('91', 351, 6, 15, 694142) Liked the Bhajan
('91', 351, 7, 16, 694159) 5 6 The light did not come on.
('91', 351, 7, 17, 694190) Enjoy ed reading with the kerosene lamp.
('91', 351, 7, 18, 694231) Read Urdu.
('91', 351, 9, 19, 694242) 6 7 Walk and exercise.

('91', 357, 8, 13, 703866) 418. CLOTH SHORTAGE Shri Manu Subedar who takes interest in khadi and other village industries, sent me the following note some time ago.
('91', 357, 8, 14, 704004) But I delayed publication in order that I might make some more effective use of it than giving it in Harijan.
('91', 357, 8, 15, 704114) I could not think of any.
('91', 357, 8, 16, 704140) Hence this publication for the use, not only of all provincial governments but also of private individuals or organizations, in however limited a field it may be.
('91', 357, 8, 17, 704303) Here is Shri Subedar’s scheme:
('91', 357, 9, 18, 704334) One bale of cotton should be given to every village collectively.
('91', 357, 9, 19, 704400) The people of the village could spin this yarn.
('91', 357, 9, 20, 704448) The yarn will be used either for doubling or as weft and cloth could be made.
('91', 357, 10, 21, 704526) One bale would yield approximately 2,400 yards of cloth (or 1,800 according to count).
('91', 357, 11, 22, 704613) If charkhas and taklis are wanted, they should be supplied by the State.
('91', 357, 11, 23, 704686) (Manufacture should be organized in jails.)
('91', 357, 12, 24, 704730) 1 The rest of the letter has been omitted in the source.
('91', 357, 12, 25, 704787) 2German ecclesiastic and writer.
('91', 357, 12, 26, 704820) The book referred to was presumably Imitation of Christ.
('91', 358, 0, 1, 704877) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 359
('91', 358, 1, 2, 704919) The cloth, when ready, should be made available to the people of the villages on a per head ration basis.
('91', 358, 2, 3, 705025) If and when it is important to collect grain in those villages where there is supposed to be a grain surplus in the hands of the farmers, the cloth should be substituted only for grain.
('91', 358, 2, 4, 705211) In other cases, the people of the village should collect enough to pay for the value of the bale of cotton.
('91', 358, 2, 5, 705319) In other words, for the price of cotton (which is in the first instance advanced by Government) they would get cloth.
('91', 358, 3, 6, 705437) While cloth shortage would be eased, cotton surplus would also be taken away and it will help the grower of cotton.
('91', 358, 4, 7, 705553) As the village Panch would have to take over the cotton bale and deal with the whole thing, the beginning would be made of:
('91', 358, 5, 8, 705677) (i) village industry,
('91', 358, 6, 9, 705699) (ii) joint and collective effort,
('91', 358, 7, 10, 705733) (iii) participation and labour contribution by the small and the big ones, and
('91', 358, 8, 11, 705812) (iv) elimination of the middleman.
('91', 358, 9, 12, 705847) If the experiment were made in the first instance with twenty thousand villages of the Bombay Presidency or even two thousand of them, the results would be seen in the course of the next six weeks.
('91', 358, 10, 13, 706045) Government will have to lock up funds for the cotton at the rate of Rs. 225 per bale.
('91', 358, 10, 14, 706131) Much of this money will return either in the form of grain or in the form of cash.
('91', 358, 10, 15, 706214) But it will have incidentally marked the beginning of something which the villages can do for themselves.
('91', 358, 11, 16, 706320) Assistance may have to be given where looms are not available, or where the yarn produced is not capable of being used both as warp and as weft.
('91', 358, 11, 17, 706465) But these are details in organization which could be attended to by someone at the headquarters of every district.
('91', 358, 12, 18, 706580) On return of price of bale by a village, a fresh bale should be sent to them by Government as an advance.
('91', 358, 12, 19, 706686) I may add that this is a variation upon the one suggested by me.
('91', 358, 12, 20, 706751) In my opinion, the original is probably better, but I attach greater value to Shri Subedar’s note because he has worked out the figures, suggested a beginning with a bale of cotton and more specially because he as an economist has thought out his scheme independently of me.
('91', 358, 12, 21, 707026) It will be easy enough to find flaws in every human scheme.
('91', 358, 12, 22, 707086) Our business is to remove flaws if we know how or to make a beginning in spite of the flaws which we know but cannot mend.
('91', 358, 12, 23, 707209) No reform is possible if we wait for perfection.
('91', 358, 13, 24, 707258) PANCHGANI, July 27, 1946 Harijan, 4 8 1946

('91', 359, 1, 2, 707343) 419. NINTH AUGUST
('91', 359, 2, 3, 707361) Ninth August, like 6th April, 13th April and 26th January, is a red letter day in the battle of India’s freedom.
('91', 359, 2, 4, 707474) They are days for universal hartal in terms of satyagraha, i.e., truth and non violence.
('91', 359, 2, 5, 707563) But today, considered in terms of satyagraha, hartals are generally taboo and more specially so on the coming 9th of August.
('91', 359, 2, 6, 707688) They would be fitting if hartals are designed to signalize violence.
('91', 359, 2, 7, 707757) Two powerful voices have spoken: one of the President of the Congress, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and the other of the President of the Socialist Group, Shri Jaiprakash Narayan.
('91', 359, 2, 8, 707932) It is delicate for me to give my opinion when these two ardent lovers of their country speak in opposition.
('91', 359, 2, 9, 708040) But as a satyagrahi I must overcome the delicacy.
('91', 359, 2, 10, 708090) Jaiprakash Narayan is a Congressman.
('91', 359, 2, 11, 708127) It is an open secret that he was offered a seat on the Working Committee by Panditji, naturally under the belief that, whatever views he entertained, he was too honest to be disloyal to the Congress in action.
('91', 359, 2, 12, 708337) If, now, in spite of knowing the Congress President’s views to the contrary, he adheres to his own opinion given to the contrary, it would appear to be an act of disloyalty to the Congress.
('91', 359, 2, 13, 708527) If, therefore, he has not withdrawn from the false position, I hope, recognizing the aptness of my remarks, he will see the wisdom of retracing his steps.
('91', 359, 2, 14, 708682) The Working Committee, rightly or wrongly, has taken a step.
('91', 359, 2, 15, 708743) It has been endorsed by the A. I. C. C. 1 It is up to every Congressman to support the Congress going to the Constituent Assembly, by creating the atmosphere suitable for work in that Assembly.
('91', 359, 2, 16, 708937) This I say even to those who distrust good faith in everything the British do.
('91', 359, 2, 17, 709016) They may warn the Congress of the dangers they sense.
('91', 359, 2, 18, 709070) This they were allowed by the President to have the fullest latitude to do at the recent A. I. C. C. meeting.
('91', 359, 2, 19, 709180) Anything in excess of that opposition is surely harmful for the country.
('91', 359, 2, 20, 709253) I would consider as such the hartal on the 9th August.
('91', 359, 2, 21, 709308) The Congress cannot have the cake and eat it too.
('91', 359, 2, 22, 709358) It must be left free, it must be helped, to develop freedom through the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 359, 2, 23, 709452) It will not be a waste of effort to honestly work the Assembly for the purpose.
('91', 359, 2, 24, 709532) The Congress must not kill the hen before
('91', 359, 3, 25, 709574) 1 The resolution signifying acceptance by the Congress of the proposal regar ding the Constituent Assembly contained in the Cabinet Mission’s announce ment of May 16, was passed by the Working Committee on June 26 and ratified by the A. I. C. C. on July 6.
('91', 360, 0, 1, 709831) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 361
('91', 360, 1, 2, 709873) it has laid.
('91', 360, 1, 3, 709886) Then mark the atmosphere in the country.
('91', 360, 1, 4, 709927) There is senseless disorder as in Ahmedabad and elsewhere.
('91', 360, 1, 5, 709986) There is a parody of satyagraha in the show staged by Dr. Ambedkar.
('91', 360, 1, 6, 710054) In satyagraha the cause has to be just and clear as well as the means.
('91', 360, 1, 7, 710125) The cause is certainly vague, even if the means are non violent.
('91', 360, 1, 8, 710190) I doubt the wisdom of the sympathetic paralysis of all business in Bombay and elsewhere, assuming the postal strike to be good on merits.
('91', 360, 1, 9, 710328) Many would seem to have left off all thinking.
('91', 360, 1, 10, 710375) They seem to take up any nostrum without caring to examine its merits.
('91', 360, 1, 11, 710446) To call for hartal in this atmosphere is to invite disorder.
('91', 360, 1, 12, 710507) No disorder is conducive to the growth of indepen dence.
('91', 360, 1, 13, 710564) Considered from every point of view, I hope that 9th August next will see no hartal in India, but a peaceful and dignified, orderly celebration of the day as advised by the President of the Congress.
('91', 360, 1, 14, 710764) PANCHGANI, July 27, 1946 [PS.] Before the despatch of this to Harijan I saw to my joy the withdrawal by Shri Jaiprakash of his proposal for hartal on 9th August.
('91', 360, 1, 15, 710926) I am glad that the spirit of discipline has dictated this with drawal.
('91', 360, 1, 16, 710997) I might have cancelled the foregoing but for the important incidental observations in it.

('91', 365, 2, 5, 718806) 427. ANSWER TO QUESTION 1
('91', 365, 3, 6, 718832) PANCHGANI, [On or before July 28, 1946] 2
('91', 365, 4, 7, 718874) Q. The English people have for years oppressed the coloured people in India, Ceylon and South Africa.
('91', 365, 4, 8, 718976) Would their conduct not make an impression on their civilization?
('91', 365, 4, 9, 719042) Can any one nation attain progress or preserve its existence through oppression?
('91', 365, 5, 10, 719123) A. An oppressor must perish in the end.
('91', 365, 5, 11, 719163) But I wonder if that term can be strictly applied to the English people.
('91', 365, 5, 12, 719236) Surely, they are not the worst.
('91', 365, 5, 13, 719268) I have simply stated the divine law with regard to the oppressor.
('91', 365, 5, 14, 719334) It is attested to by all religions.
('91', 365, 5, 15, 719370) Irrespective of whether the conquest and exploitation by the English of other nations can be called oppression in the technical sense, their power cannot last for ever.
('91', 365, 5, 16, 719539) Oppression is sin but submission to oppression is no less sin.
('91', 365, 5, 17, 719602) History teaches us that neither the power of the oppressor nor the suffering of the oppressed can last for ever.
('91', 365, 5, 18, 719715) Both must come to an end.
('91', 365, 5, 19, 719741) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 7 1946
('91', 365, 6, 20, 719773) 428. QUESTION BOX
('91', 365, 7, 21, 719791) Q. Whilst the food policy was in the hands of the Advisors to the Provinicial Governors, there was no effective method of checking them.
('91', 365, 7, 22, 719928) Things under the responsible Provincial Governments are different.
('91', 365, 7, 23, 719995) Should it not be a matter of conscience with Congress ministers to get their rations from common rationing depots and take not a grain more from any other source?
('91', 365, 7, 24, 720158) This will immediately have a far reaching effect.
('91', 365, 7, 25, 720208) Today all controlling centres for food grains or cloth have public dens for thieving and corruption.
('91', 365, 7, 26, 720309) Equipped with the moral force that the ministers will gain by acting as suggested, they will be able to fight out the evil with success.

('91', 366, 2, 10, 721435) 429. KHADI WORKERS 1
('91', 366, 3, 11, 721456) I have two questions about Khadi workers before me.
('91', 366, 3, 12, 721508) One of these is in connection with village workers.
('91', 366, 3, 13, 721560) It is their duty to spend their time mainly in spinning and making others spin.
('91', 366, 3, 14, 721640) The new conception of khadi work includes all the processes from the cultivation of cotton to the preparation of cloth.
('91', 366, 3, 15, 721760) A worker who does all these intelligently and can mend the spinning wheel or the spindle, will never have any difficulty in earning his livelihood and teaching others to do so.
('91', 366, 3, 16, 721937) Along with it, and without letting khadi work suffer, the worker might treat simple ailments and attend to the sanitation of the village.
('91', 366, 3, 17, 722075) Education has to be imparted through a craft.
('91', 366, 3, 18, 722121) Therefore I do not consider it apart from khadi work.
('91', 366, 3, 19, 722175) Those who come for education must wear khadi and get education through khadi.
('91', 366, 3, 20, 722253) The second question is how long should a khadi worker work as a paid worker.
('91', 366, 3, 21, 722330) In my view he should be self supporting from the beginning.
('91', 366, 3, 22, 722390) If that is not possible, he should fix a time limit for himself.
('91', 366, 3, 23, 722455) Five years is the utmost limit in my opinion.
('91', 366, 3, 24, 722501) A worker who is to become self supporting at the end of five years, should reduce his allowance progressively from year to year.
('91', 366, 3, 25, 722630) He cannot expect to become self supporting all of a sudden at the end of five years.
('91', 366, 3, 26, 722715) It is an art which requires careful thought and management.
('91', 366, 3, 27, 722775) He who really teaches others should certainly become self supporting himself.
('91', 366, 4, 28, 722853) PANCHGANI, July 28, 1946 Harijan, 4 8 1946

('91', 368, 6, 14, 725347) 433. SPEECH AT MEETING OF DECCAN PRINCES 1
('91', 368, 7, 15, 725390) POONA, July 28, 1946
('91', 368, 8, 16, 725411) Gandhiji said that it was a great pleasure to him to be able to meet the Deccan Princes.
('91', 368, 8, 17, 725500) He had read the papers and the note prepared for his edification by the Raja Saheb of Phaltan.
('91', 368, 8, 18, 725595) He did not wish to speak on the papers.
('91', 368, 8, 19, 725635) It was a good thing that the Princes were seriously thinking in terms of the whole of India, rather than of themselves and of the protection they had all these years thought they were getting from the Paramountcy of the British Power.
('91', 368, 8, 20, 725870) Only a few years ago the Princes felt that they could not be safe except under the Paramountcy of the British Crown.
('91', 368, 8, 21, 725987) It seemed to have dawned on most of them that that was not the correct attitude.
('91', 368, 8, 22, 726068) This was but natural, for they were after all sons of the soil.
('91', 368, 8, 23, 726132) He had said openly on another
('91', 368, 9, 24, 726162) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Deccan Chiefs in Conference”.
('91', 368, 9, 25, 726221) The meeting was held in the Servants of India Society’s Library Hall.
('91', 368, 9, 26, 726291) Among those present were the Rajas of Aundh, Phaltan, Bhor, Miraj (Senior), Jamkhandi and Kurundwad (Senior), Appasaheb Pant and Satawalekar from Aundh, Kore, Sathe and Thomre from Sangli, the Dewan of Bhor and representatives from Budhgaon and Ramdrug.
('91', 368, 9, 27, 726545) N. C. Kelkar and Shankerrao Deo were also present on the occasion by special invitation.
('91', 369, 0, 1, 726634) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 369, 1, 2, 726676) occasion that the people of the States were slaves of slaves which the Princes were.
('91', 369, 1, 3, 726761) They exercised their authority within their own principalities, so long as they were in the good books of the British Government.
('91', 369, 1, 4, 726891) They were made or unmade at the pleasure of the British Crown.
('91', 369, 1, 5, 726954) The Princes who had eyes opened to that vital fact were desirous of India’s independence equally with the people of India.
('91', 369, 1, 6, 727077) If then they felt that need, they did not want a union of the States but each State had first to form a union with its own people.
('91', 369, 1, 7, 727208) Their people were the real power on whom they were to depend for their status.
('91', 369, 1, 8, 727287) It became trusteeship if they became servants of their own people.
('91', 369, 1, 9, 727354) If they took that attitude, they needed no terms with the Congress or with any other organization.
('91', 369, 1, 10, 727453) The immediate need was an understanding with their own people.
('91', 369, 2, 11, 727516) He made bold to take up that attitude, though his might be a lonely voice.
('91', 369, 2, 12, 727591) In his opinion, the Princes, as servants and trustees of their people, were worthy of their hire.
('91', 369, 2, 13, 727689) It would then (but not before) be time to consider whether they and their people wanted a union among themselves.
('91', 369, 2, 14, 727803) Such a union would be of a wholly different type from what they had conceived.
('91', 369, 3, 15, 727882) The speaker had a serious suspicion that the present proposal 1 was a creation of the British Rulers, meaning the Political Agents.
('91', 369, 3, 16, 728014) No blame need be imputed to them if they advised such a union.
('91', 369, 3, 17, 728077) They were brought up in no better tradition.
('91', 369, 3, 18, 728122) They thought that when the British power was not in India, the Princes would fight amongst themselves.
('91', 369, 3, 19, 728225) That fear was wholly unjustifiable.
('91', 369, 3, 20, 728261) They honestly believed that before they retired, as they must within perhaps a few months, owing to force of circumstances, they should enable the Princes to consolidate their power by organizing them into a union.
('91', 369, 4, 21, 728476) It was his belief that if India was not merely to be independent of British control, but was to enjoy real freedom, which their country, by virtue of its ancient culture and tradition was entitled to, it should grow from the bottom upwards, not be imposed from above.
('91', 369, 4, 22, 728744) Otherwise, it would be a question of change of masters only.
('91', 369, 4, 23, 728805) Instead of the English, there might be the Allied Powers or whosoever could impose himself on them.
('91', 369, 4, 24, 728905) He did not look forward to that time.
('91', 369, 4, 25, 728943) He looked forward to a time when India would come into her own because of her intrinsic merit.
('91', 369, 4, 26, 729038) To that consummation the Princes could make a most handsome contribution.
('91', 369, 5, 27, 729112) If the Deccan Princes played their part and set a solid example, they would follow.

('91', 376, 1, 2, 741793) 441. SPEECH AT EDUCATION MINISTERS’ CONFERENCE 1
('91', 376, 2, 3, 741842) POONA, July 29, 1946
('91', 376, 3, 4, 741863) He knew clearly enough, said Gandhiji, what was to be done but he did not quite know how it could be done.
('91', 376, 3, 5, 741970) So far they had their course mapped out for them, but now they had to sail on uncharted waters.
('91', 376, 3, 6, 742066) He knew their difficulties.
('91', 376, 3, 7, 742094) It was not easy for those who had been brought up in the old tradition to break away from it at a stroke.
('91', 376, 3, 8, 742200) If he were in the Ministerial chair, he would issue broad instructions that hereafter all educational activity of the Government should be on basic education lines.
('91', 376, 3, 9, 742365) Adult education drives had been launched in several provinces.
('91', 376, 3, 10, 742428) If he had his way, he would conduct them also through a basic craft.
('91', 376, 3, 11, 742497) In his opinion, cotton spinning and the allied processes were crafts par excellence for this purpose.
('91', 376, 3, 12, 742599) But he would leave the choice of the craft to the people concerned in each case in the certain belief that in the end that craft alone which had the necessary intrinsic merit would survive.
('91', 376, 3, 13, 742789) It should be the job of the inspectors and other officers of the Education Department to go among the people and teachers of schools and by persuasion and argument, edu cate them in the value and utility of the Government’s new educational policy.
('91', 376, 3, 14, 743037) That was their primary job, not to lord it over them.
('91', 376, 3, 15, 743091) If they had no faith in it or if they were unwilling loyally to work out the new policy, he would give them the choice to resign.
('91', 376, 3, 16, 743221) But he did not think that it would be necessary, if the Ministers knew their job and put their shoulder to the wheel.
('91', 376, 3, 17, 743339) Merely issuing orders would not do the trick.
('91', 376, 4, 18, 743385) What he had said about adult education applied equally to university education.
('91', 376, 4, 19, 743465) It must be organically related to the Indian scene.
('91', 376, 4, 20, 743517) It must therefore be an extension and continuation of the basic education course.
('91', 376, 4, 21, 743599) That was the central point.
('91', 376, 4, 22, 743627) If they did not see eye to eye with him on that point, he was afraid they would have little use for his advice.
('91', 376, 4, 23, 743739) If, on the other hand, they agreed with him that the present university education did not fit them for independence but only enslaved them, they would be as impatient as he was to completely overhaul and scrap that system and remodel it on new lines consonant with the national requirement.
('91', 376, 5, 24, 744030) Today the youth educated in our universities either ran after Government jobs or fell into devious ways and sought outlet for their frustration by fomenting unrest.
('91', 376, 5, 25, 744195) They were not even ashamed to beg or sponge upon others.
('91', 376, 5, 26, 744252) Such was their sad plight.
('91', 376, 5, 27, 744279) The aim of university education should be to turn out true servants of the people who would live and die for the country’s freedom.
('91', 376, 5, 28, 744411) He was therefore of the opinion that university education should be co ordinated and brought into line with basic education, by taking in teachers from the Talimi Sangh.
('91', 376, 6, 29, 744581) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s report “Congress Ministries and Basic Education”.
('91', 376, 6, 30, 744659) The Conference had been convened by B. G. Kher to discuss the programme of basic education.
('91', 376, 6, 31, 744751) Ministers from all the Congress governed provinces except two attended.
('91', 377, 0, 1, 744823) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 377, 1, 2, 744865) The Ministers had accepted office as people’s representatives.
('91', 377, 1, 3, 744928) Their writ would not run beyond the four walls of the Council Hall unless they could carry the people with them.
('91', 377, 1, 4, 745041) What was taking place in Bombay and Ahmedabad today, was an ominous symptom, if it portended that the Congress had lost its hold over the people.
('91', 377, 1, 5, 745187) Nayee Talim was as yet a tender sapling but it held out big promise.
('91', 377, 1, 6, 745256) Its growth could not be forced by ministerial ukases, if popular support was lacking.
('91', 377, 1, 7, 745342) If, therefore, they could not command popular support, his advice to them would be to tender their resignations.
('91', 377, 1, 8, 745455) They should not be afraid of anarchy.
('91', 377, 1, 9, 745493) Theirs was only to do their duty according to their lights and leave the rest to God.
('91', 377, 1, 10, 745579) People would learn the lesson of true independence even out of that experience.
('91', 377, 2, 11, 745659) Q. Can basic education be conducted minus the self support basis?
('91', 377, 3, 12, 745725) A. You can certainly try.
('91', 377, 3, 13, 745751) But if you ask my advice, I will tell you that in that event, you had better forget basic education alto gether.
('91', 377, 3, 14, 745864) Self sufficiency is not an a priori condition but to me it is the acid test.
('91', 377, 3, 15, 745941) This does not mean that basic education will be self suppor ting from the very start.
('91', 377, 3, 16, 746027) But taking the entire period of seven years, covered by the basic education plan, income and expenditure must balance.
('91', 377, 3, 17, 746146) Otherwise, it would mean that even at the end of their training, the basic education students will not be fitted for life.
('91', 377, 3, 18, 746269) That is the negation of basic education.
('91', 377, 3, 19, 746310) Nayee Talim without the self support basis would, therefore, be like a lifeless body.
('91', 377, 4, 20, 746396) Q. We have accepted the principle of giving education through a basic craft.
('91', 377, 4, 21, 746473) But the Mussalmans are somehow opposed to the spinning wheel.
('91', 377, 4, 22, 746535) Your emphasis on spinning is perhaps all right in cotton tracts.
('91', 377, 4, 23, 746600) But do you not agree that it is unsuited to areas where the cotton crop is not grown?
('91', 377, 4, 24, 746686) May not some other craft be substituted for it in such places—agriculture for instance?
('91', 377, 5, 25, 746774) A. This is a very old question.
('91', 377, 5, 26, 746806) Any basic craft to serve as a medium for education must answer the test of universality.
('91', 377, 5, 27, 746895) As early as 1908 I came to the conclusion that to make India free and to enable her to stand on her own legs, the spinning wheel had to hum in every home.
('91', 377, 5, 28, 747050) If England can become an exporter of textiles to India and to the whole world, although she does not grow a pod of cotton, I cannot understand why we cannot introduce cotton spinning in our homes, merely because cotton would have to be obtained from a neighbour ing province or district.
('91', 377, 5, 29, 747338) As a matter of fact, there is no part of India where cotton was not at one time grown.
('91', 377, 5, 30, 747425) Localization of cotton culti vation in ‘cotton tracts’ is only a recent and anomalous development, forced upon India by cotton manufacturing interests at the expense of the poor tax payer and cotton spinner of India.
('91', 377, 5, 31, 747642) Even today tree
('91', 378, 0, 1, 747658) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 379
('91', 378, 1, 2, 747700) cotton grows everywhere in India.
('91', 378, 1, 3, 747734) Such arguments as yours speak ill of our capacity for taking initiative, for our enterprise and resource fulness.
('91', 378, 1, 4, 747848) It would kill all manufactures if transportation of raw mate rials from another place were to be regarded as an insuperable handi cap.
('91', 378, 1, 5, 747983) Moreover, to enable a person to clothe himself through his own effort, when the alternative is to go naked, is in itself an education.
('91', 378, 1, 6, 748118) An intelligent pursuit of the various processes related to cotton spinning has, besides, a very high instructional value.
('91', 378, 1, 7, 748240) In fact, it covers the whole education of man as perhaps no other craft does.
('91', 378, 1, 8, 748318) We may not today be able to dispel the doubts of the Mussalmans, as they are rooted in a delusion and delusion is a very real thing to its victim, while he is under its spell.
('91', 378, 1, 9, 748494) But if our own faith is clear and firm, and we can demonstrate the success of our method, the Mussalmans will them selves come to us and ask to be taught the secret of our success.
('91', 378, 1, 10, 748675) They do not seem to have realized that the charkha has done more for the poorest Mussalman masses than even the Muslim League or any other Muslim organization.
('91', 378, 1, 11, 748835) The bulk of the weavers in Bengal are Muslims.
('91', 378, 1, 12, 748882) Nor should it be forgotten that Dacca owed its world wide fame for its shabnams 1 to the deftness and skill of Muslim women spinners and Muslim weavers.
('91', 378, 1, 13, 749035) The same applied to Maharashtra.
('91', 378, 1, 14, 749068) The best cure for the delusion is to concentrate on the performance of one’s own duty.
('91', 378, 1, 15, 749155) Truth alone will endure, all the rest will be swept away before the tide of time.
('91', 378, 1, 16, 749237) I must, therefore, continue to bear testimony to Truth even if I am forsaken by all.
('91', 378, 1, 17, 749322) Mine may today be a voice in the wilderness, but it will be heard when all other voices are silenced if it is the voice of Truth.
('91', 378, 2, 18, 749452) AVINASHILINGAM CHETTIAR: To produce efficient teachers for Nayee Talim would take time.
('91', 378, 2, 19, 749540) What should be done to improve education in the schools in the meantime?
('91', 378, 3, 20, 749613) G. If you realize that the present system of education cannot bring India Independence but only serves to deepen her slavery, you will refuse to encourage it, irrespective of whether any other takes its place or not.

('91', 379, 2, 5, 750327) But to train men we again need institutions and therefore money.
('91', 379, 2, 6, 750392) How can we get out of this vicious circle?
('91', 379, 3, 7, 750435) A. The remedy lies in your own hands.
('91', 379, 3, 8, 750473) Begin with yourself.

('91', 379, 3, 10, 750698) That is not my way.
