('91', 386, 6, 12, 761053) 454. SPEECH AT INDUSTRIES MINISTERS’ CONFERENCE 1
('91', 386, 7, 13, 761103) POONA, July 31, 1946
('91', 386, 8, 14, 761124) Gandhiji explained his approach to Village Industries in the course of a thirty minute address.
('91', 386, 8, 15, 761220) The conception underlying both the Nayee Talim and the Village Industries programme, including khaddar, was rooted in the same thing, viz., concern for the dignity and status of the village unit as against the big cities and of the individual against the machine.
('91', 386, 8, 16, 761484) The concern was further augmented by the fact that India lives not in a handful of her big cities but in her 700,000 villages.
('91', 386, 8, 17, 761611) The problem was of re establishment of justice between the town and the village.
('91', 386, 8, 18, 761692) As it was, the balance was heavily tipped in favour of the former to the disadvantage of the latter.
('91', 386, 8, 19, 761793) Ours has been described as the machine age, because the machine dominates our economy.
('91', 386, 8, 20, 761880) Now, what is a machine?—one may ask.
('91', 386, 8, 21, 761917) In a sense, man is the most wonderful machine in creation.
('91', 386, 8, 22, 761976) It can neither be duplicated nor copied.
('91', 386, 9, 23, 762017) He had, however, used the word not in its wider sense but in the sense of an appliance that tended to displace human or animal labour instead of supplementing it or merely increasing its efficiency.
('91', 386, 9, 24, 762216) That was the first differentiating characteristic of the machine.
('91', 386, 9, 25, 762282) The second characteristic was that there was no limit to its growth or
('91', 386, 10, 26, 762353) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Congress Ministries and Rural Uplift”.
('91', 386, 10, 27, 762421) The Conference was convened by Vaikunthlal Mehta, Finance and Village Industries Minister of Bombay, and was attended by Bhimsen Sachar from the Punjab, Nityanand Kanungo from Orissa, R. K. Barlinga from C. P. and Ansari from Bihar.
('91', 387, 0, 1, 762654) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 387, 1, 2, 762696) evolution.
('91', 387, 1, 3, 762707) That could not be said of human labour.
('91', 387, 1, 4, 762747) There was a limit beyond which its capacity or mechanical efficiency could not go.
('91', 387, 1, 5, 762830) Out of this circumstance arose the third characteristic of the machine.
('91', 387, 1, 6, 762902) It seems to be possessed of a will or genius of its own.
('91', 387, 1, 7, 762959) It was antagonistic to man’s labour.
('91', 387, 1, 8, 762996) Thus it tended more to displace man, one machine doing the work of a hundred, if not a thousand, who went to swell the army of the unemployed and the underemployed, not because it was desirable but because that was its law.
('91', 387, 1, 9, 763220) In America it had perhaps reached the extreme limit.
('91', 387, 1, 10, 763273) He had been opposed to it, said Gandhiji, not from today, but even before 1908 when he was in South Africa surrounded by machines.
('91', 387, 1, 11, 763404) Their onward march had not only not impressed him but repelled him.
('91', 387, 1, 12, 763472) It then dawned on me that to suppress and exploit the millions, the machine was the device par excellence; it had no place in man’s economy if, as social units, all men were to be equal.
('91', 387, 1, 13, 763659) It is my belief that the machine has not added to man’s stature and it won’t serve the world but disrupt it, unless it is put in its proper place.
('91', 387, 1, 14, 763806) Then, I read Ruskin’s Unto This Last during a train journey to Durban 1 and it gripped me immediately.
('91', 387, 1, 15, 763909) I saw clearly that if mankind was to progress and to realize the ideal of equality and brotherhood, it must adopt and act on the principle of Unto This Last; it must take along with it even the dumb, the halt and the lame.
('91', 387, 1, 16, 764132) Did not Yudhish thira —the Prince of Righteousness, refuse to enter heaven without his faithful dog?
('91', 387, 2, 17, 764233) In the machine age these had no place.
('91', 387, 2, 18, 764272) Under it the fittest alone survived to the exclusion and at the cost of the weak.
('91', 387, 2, 19, 764354) That is not my picture of Independence in which there is room even for the weakest.
('91', 387, 2, 20, 764438) That requires that we must utilize all available human labour before we entertain the idea of employing mechanical power.
('91', 387, 3, 21, 764560) It was with that background that he was instrumental in founding the Talimi Sangh and the A. I. V. I. A. The object was to strengthen the Congress which claimed to be essentially the people’s organization.
('91', 387, 3, 22, 764766) The Congress had created these autonomous institutions.
('91', 387, 3, 23, 764822) The Congress Ministries could requisition the services of these organizations always and without any compunction.
('91', 387, 3, 24, 764936) They existed and laboured for the villagers who were the back bone of the Congress.
('91', 387, 3, 25, 765020) But the Ministries were under no obligation.
('91', 387, 3, 26, 765065) If they had no faith in what these organizations stood for, they should plainly say so through the Working Committee.
('91', 387, 3, 27, 765183) To play with a thing when they had no heart in it would be worse than useless.
('91', 387, 3, 28, 765262) They should take it up only if
('91', 387, 4, 29, 765293) 1 In June, 1904
('91', 388, 0, 1, 765309) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 389
('91', 388, 1, 2, 765350) they believed with him that it alone held the key to the economic and political salvation of the country.
('91', 388, 1, 3, 765456) They should not deceive themselves or others.
('91', 388, 1, 4, 765502) The base and foundation of village industries is agriculture.
('91', 388, 1, 5, 765564) Years ago I read a poem in which the peasant is described as the father of the world.
('91', 388, 1, 6, 765650) If God is the Provider, the cultivator is His hand.
('91', 388, 1, 7, 765702) What are we going to do to discharge the debt we owe to him?
('91', 388, 1, 8, 765763) So long we have only lived on the sweat of his brow.
('91', 388, 1, 9, 765816) We should have begun with the soil but we could not do so.
('91', 388, 1, 10, 765875) The fault is partly mine.
('91', 388, 2, 11, 765901) There were people, remarked Gandhiji, who said that no basic reform in agri culture was possible without political power.
('91', 388, 2, 12, 766023) They dreamt in terms of industriali zation of agriculture by large scale application of steam and electricity.
('91', 388, 2, 13, 766134) He warned them that trading in soil fertility for the sake of quick returns would prove to be a disastrous, short sighted policy.
('91', 388, 2, 14, 766264) It would result in virtual depletion of the soil.
('91', 388, 2, 15, 766314) Good earth called for the sweat of one’s brow to yield the bread of life.
('91', 388, 3, 16, 766388) People might criticize that approach as being slow and unprogressive.
('91', 388, 3, 17, 766458) It did not hold out promise of dramatic results.
('91', 388, 3, 18, 766507) Nevertheless, it held the key to the pros perity of both the soil and inhabitants living on it.
('91', 388, 3, 19, 766603) Healthy, nourishing food was the alpha and omega of rural economy.
('91', 388, 3, 20, 766670) The bulk of a peasant’s family budget goes to feed him and his family.
('91', 388, 3, 21, 766741) All other things come afterwards.
('91', 388, 3, 22, 766775) Let the tiller of the soil be well fed.
('91', 388, 3, 23, 766815) Let him have a sufficiency of fresh, pure milk and ghee and oil, fish eggs, and meat if he is a non vegetarian.What would fine clothes, for instance, avail him if he is ill nourished and underfed?
('91', 388, 4, 24, 767012) The question of drinking water supply and other things would come next.
('91', 388, 4, 25, 767084) A consideration of these questions would naturally involve such issues as the place of plough cattle in the economy of agriculture as against the tractor plough and power irrigation, etc., and thus, bit by bit, the whole picture of rural economy would emerge before them.
('91', 388, 4, 26, 767356) In this picture cities would take their natural place and not appear as unnatural, congested spots or boils on the body politic as they were today.
('91', 388, 4, 27, 767504) We stand today in danger of forgetting the use of our hands.
('91', 388, 4, 28, 767565) To forget how to dig the earth and tend the soil is to forget ourselves.
('91', 388, 4, 29, 767638) To think that your occupation of the Ministerial chair will be vindicated if you serve the cities only, would be to forget that India really resides in her 700,000 village units.
('91', 388, 4, 30, 767817) What would it profit a man if he gained the world but lost his soul in the bargain?
('91', 388, 5, 31, 767901) Q. You have called cities boils or abscesses on the body politic.
('91', 388, 5, 32, 767967) What should be done with these boils?
('91', 388, 5, 33, 768005) A. If you ask a doctor he will tell you what to do with a boil.
('91', 388, 5, 34, 768069) It has to be cured either by lancing or by the application of plasters and
('91', 389, 0, 1, 768144) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 389, 1, 2, 768186) poultices.
('91', 389, 1, 3, 768197) Edward Carpenter called civilization a malady which needed a cure.
('91', 389, 1, 4, 768264) The growth of big cities is only a symptom of that malady.
('91', 389, 1, 5, 768323) Being a nature curist I am naturally in favour of nature’s way of cure by general purification of the system.
('91', 389, 1, 6, 768433) If the hearts of the city dweller remain rooted in the villages, if they become truly village minded, all other things will automatically follow and the boil will quickly heal.
('91', 389, 2, 7, 768610) Q. What practical steps can be taken to protect our village crafts from the invasion of foreign and Indian manufactured goods under the present circumstances?
('91', 389, 3, 8, 768769) A. I can only speak in broad terms.
('91', 389, 3, 9, 768805) If you have felt in your heart that you have taken office as custodians and representatives of the interests of the masses, everything that you do, your legislation, your executive orders, the instructions that you issue, will breathe concern for the villager.
('91', 389, 3, 10, 769066) To protect his interests, you do not need the Viceroy’s sanction.
('91', 389, 3, 11, 769132) Supposing you want to protect the hand spinner and hand weaver against the competition of mills and solve the problem of cloth shortage for the masses, you will put aside red tape and send for the mill owners and tell them that, unless they want you to go out of office, they must make their production policy conform to the requirement of the masses, whose custodian and representative you are.
('91', 389, 3, 12, 769528) You will tell them not to send mill cloth to certain areas, which are put under hand production or produce a certain range of yarns and textiles which comes within the handloom weaver’s domain.
('91', 389, 3, 13, 769722) If you are in earnest, your word will go home and they will willingly give their co operation as they did recently, when they provided the required textiles for export to Indonesia, in return for Indonesian surplus rice for the relief of the Indian famine.
('91', 389, 3, 14, 769979) But there must be that inner conviction first, everything else will then be all right.
('91', 389, 3, 15, 770066) Harijan, 25 8 1946
('91', 389, 4, 16, 770085) 455. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('91', 389, 5, 17, 770115) POONA, July 31, 1946
('91', 389, 6, 18, 770136) Mahatma Gandhi told the audience in brief how the last three days since his return to Poona from Panchgani had been occupied.
('91', 389, 6, 19, 770262) First, there was a meeting with the Chiefs of the Deccan States.
('91', 389, 6, 20, 770327) The Rajas wanted his advice as a friend as to what their duty was.
('91', 389, 6, 21, 770394) He had told them that they must now shed their autocracy and be guided by the people’s will.
('91', 389, 6, 22, 770487) Up till now the princes had been ruled by the British and they, in turn, had ruled their people.
('91', 389, 6, 23, 770584) Now that power was coming into the hands of the
('91', 390, 0, 1, 770632) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 391
('91', 390, 1, 2, 770673) Indian people, it should come into the hands of States’ people too, for they were not different.
('91', 390, 1, 3, 770770) The Rulers had recognized that they could not exist if they were at perpetual variance with their subjects.
('91', 390, 1, 4, 770878) A true union with their people was the only way for them to live serve.
('91', 390, 2, 5, 770950) Ministers from various provinces had come here to discuss with the workers of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh and the All India Village Industries Association as to how best they could forward these two great schemes, which had been brought into being and had so far been sponsored by the Congress.
('91', 390, 2, 6, 771245) Gandhiji feared the audience were probably ignorant about Nayee Talim.
('91', 390, 2, 7, 771316) This was not as it should be.
('91', 390, 2, 8, 771346) After all the Congress Ministers were the elected representatives of the people and, therefore, their servants.
('91', 390, 2, 9, 771458) They could not force anything down the throats of the people.
('91', 390, 2, 10, 771520) It was up to the people to study and understand what Nayee Talim was.
('91', 390, 2, 11, 771590) It was up to them to be orderly and disciplined and eager to learn.
('91', 390, 2, 12, 771658) Only then could the Ministers take them along with them.
('91', 390, 2, 13, 771715) Nayee Talim was a grand thing.
('91', 390, 2, 14, 771746) It would help them and their children to become good citizens.
('91', 390, 2, 15, 771809) The same applied to khadi and all the other village industries.
('91', 390, 3, 16, 771873) Both these schemes were for village India which was the real India.
('91', 390, 3, 17, 771941) Really speaking, it was the farmers who fed them and ought, therefore, to be their masters, but things had been the other way round, and townspeople had been sucking the villagers’ blood.
('91', 390, 3, 18, 772129) It was now time that they became the servants of the villagers.
('91', 390, 3, 19, 772193) If they realized this, the work of the Congress Ministers would progress and India would become prosperous.
('91', 390, 4, 20, 772301) Gandhiji hoped, as this was his last meeting with them this year, that their daily association with him in prayer had been of benefit to them and they would continue the practice in their homes The Hindu, 2 8 1946

('91', 396, 1, 2, 781291) 465. LETTER TO D. D. JOSHI 1
('91', 396, 2, 3, 781320) URULI KANCHAN, VIA POONA, August 1, 1946
('91', 396, 3, 4, 781361) BHAI JOSHI, I have gone through your letter.
('91', 396, 3, 5, 781406) This is the answer to your ques tion 2. This thing is meant for villagers, for the villages.
('91', 396, 3, 6, 781499) Therefore there is no place here for a microscope or an x ray plant.
('91', 396, 3, 7, 781568) Nor is there any place in nature cure for quinine, emetin, penicillin and such other drugs.
('91', 396, 3, 8, 781660) Village sanitation, domestic cleanliness, per sonal hygiene and health care have the first place and also full scope, the underlying idea being that this done there can be no disease.
('91', 396, 3, 9, 781844) And in case disease has occurred, Ramanama is the basic remedy besides observance of the laws of nature.
('91', 396, 3, 10, 781949) As long as the practitioner has not personally expe rienced the efficacy of Ramanama, the latter treatment cannot be applied universally.
('91', 396, 3, 11, 782087) Hence, the treatment in the form of Ramanama cannot all of a sudden become universal.
('91', 396, 3, 12, 782173) However, the endeavour is to cure disease with the help of whatever energy we can churn out of the five elements, viz.,earth, water, ether, fire and air.
('91', 396, 3, 13, 782327) And this is where, I think, nature cure ends.
('91', 396, 3, 14, 782373) Hence the experiment that is being now conducted at Uruli Kanchan is one of instructing the villagers in the art of health care and curing those who are sick with the help of the five elements.
('91', 396, 3, 15, 782567) This includes the use of herbs locally available in Uruli, whenever the need is felt.
('91', 396, 3, 16, 782653) It also covers restrictions as to diet.

('91', 397, 1, 2, 783163) 466. LETTER TO SARALADEVI SARABHAI
('91', 397, 2, 3, 783198) URULI KANCHAN, DISTT.
('91', 397, 2, 4, 783220) POONA, August 1, 1946
('91', 397, 3, 5, 783242) SARALABEHN, Your letter of the 29th addressed to Rajkumari reached today.
('91', 397, 3, 6, 783316) I have come to Uruli for four days leaving Rajkumari and others at Poona.
('91', 397, 3, 7, 783390) If anyone of them has any business with me, they will come and return in the afternoon in good time.
('91', 397, 3, 8, 783491) I did not want to have a crowd here.
('91', 397, 3, 9, 783528) Your blood pressure is very high.
('91', 397, 3, 10, 783562) I cannot say I am wholly out of danger, but I think my blood pressure is under control.
('91', 397, 3, 11, 783650) Every one does not have [high] blood pressure for the same reason.
('91', 397, 3, 12, 783717) [High] blood pressure is not a disease in itself; it is a symptom of some other disease.
('91', 397, 3, 13, 783806) It may, for instance, be caused by kidney trouble.
('91', 397, 3, 14, 783857) A diseased kidney means the whole body becoming poisoned.
('91', 397, 3, 15, 783915) Kidney trouble is caused by worrying too much or working under tension.
('91', 397, 3, 16, 783987) In my view whatever the cause, fruit diet is an effective remedy.
('91', 397, 3, 17, 784053) This should not include starchy fruits such as bananas.
('91', 397, 3, 18, 784109) Oranges, pomegra nates, pineapples and grapes are best.
('91', 397, 3, 19, 784165) One must sleep well.
('91', 397, 3, 20, 784186) To sleep is to rest.
('91', 397, 3, 21, 784207) The fruits mentioned above may be taken as they are or their juice.
('91', 397, 3, 22, 784275) They can be taken in either form.
('91', 397, 3, 23, 784309) You may take gentle walks.
('91', 397, 3, 24, 784336) There are also some exercises that one can do lying in bed.
('91', 397, 3, 25, 784396) You should do such exercises.
('91', 397, 3, 26, 784426) Along with this, if you enshrine Rama in your heart, I am sure your blood pressure will be cured.
('91', 397, 3, 27, 784524) Ramanama means having God in the heart in the form in which we worship Him.
('91', 397, 3, 28, 784600) This is not superstition.
('91', 397, 3, 29, 784626) This is scientific deduction.
('91', 397, 3, 30, 784656) I shall not take you into the rationale thereof.
('91', 397, 3, 31, 784705) I am writing this because I have known you as a saintly woman for many years which you are.
('91', 397, 3, 32, 784797) I give no thought to the fact that you are the daughter of a rich father married to a rich man.
('91', 397, 4, 33, 784893) Blessings from BAPU

('91', 399, 5, 18, 787493) The Government can be asked to provide funds.

('91', 399, 5, 24, 787964) One more word of advice in general.

('91', 399, 5, 26, 788015) 29 could have been put in nine or ten lines.

('91', 399, 5, 28, 788113) I assume all these Resolutions were in Kannada and, when we think in our mother tongue or in the national language we do not do so in an orderly way.
('91', 399, 5, 29, 788263) And then we do not attempt to bring precision and brevity to them.
('91', 399, 5, 30, 788330) When we speak or write in English out of very shame we are more careful.
('91', 399, 5, 31, 788403) This shows that our love of our mother tongue is no real, or say, not deep enough.

('91', 400, 9, 18, 789474) 471. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('91', 400, 10, 19, 789506) URULI, August 1, 1946
('91', 400, 11, 20, 789528) The 25th anniversary of the late Lokamanya’s demise 3 which fell on the day Gandhiji reached Uruli, evoked poignant memories.
('91', 400, 11, 21, 789654) Speaking after the evening prayer, he recalled how he had gone to attend the Lokamanya’s funeral on receiving the sad news over the telephone.
('91', 400, 11, 22, 789797) The mammoth funeral procession was composed of Mussalmans and Parsis no less than Hindus.
('91', 400, 11, 23, 789887) He himself had got caught in the crush and narrowly escaped injury.
('91', 400, 11, 24, 789955) Those were the days when the atmosphere was not poisoned by communal bitterness.
('91', 400, 12, 25, 790036) 1 Uruli Kanchan nature cure clinic 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter” 5 8 1946 3 Tilak died on August 1, 1920. Vide “Tribute to Tilak”, 2 8 1920 and “Passing Away of the Lokmanya”, 8 8 1920.
('91', 401, 0, 1, 790236) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 401, 1, 2, 790278) Much water has flowed under the bridge since then, but the memory or Lokamanya remains enshrined in the hearts and affection of his countryman as ever before.
('91', 401, 1, 3, 790437) The lapse of time has only added to his popularity.
('91', 401, 1, 4, 790489) He is still with us, though he is physically no more.
('91', 401, 1, 5, 790543) He has given us the mantra that Swaraj is our birthright.
('91', 401, 1, 6, 790601) That birth right belongs equally to all.
('91', 401, 1, 7, 790642) Like the Infinite it is inexhaustible.
('91', 401, 1, 8, 790681) To divide it is not to take it away.
('91', 401, 1, 9, 790718) May be that some questionable things are today being done in the late Lokamanya’s name.
('91', 401, 1, 10, 790806) That is the way of the world.
('91', 401, 1, 11, 790836) Even divinity is not proof against abuse.
('91', 401, 1, 12, 790878) The evil, however, remains with the evil doer.
('91', 401, 1, 13, 790925) It does not detract from the lustre of divinity.
('91', 401, 2, 14, 790974) India was today on the eve of attaining her birthright, Gandhiji went on to say.
('91', 401, 2, 15, 791055) In his opinion, nature cure was an essential ingredient in the building of swaraj of his conception.
('91', 401, 2, 16, 791156) The attaining of true swaraj presupposed the triple purification of body, mind and soul.
('91', 401, 2, 17, 791245) Harijan, 11 8 1946
('91', 401, 3, 18, 791264) 472. LETTER TO THE GOVERNOR GENERAL OF PORTUGUESE INDIA
('91', 401, 4, 19, 791320) August 2, 1946
('91', 401, 5, 20, 791335) DEAR FRIEND, It was kind of you to write to me in reply to what I had written in Harijan 1 about Goa affairs.
('91', 401, 5, 21, 791445) 2 I suppose you know that I have visited Mozambique, Delagoa and Inhambane.
('91', 401, 5, 22, 791521) I did not notice there any Government for philanthropic purposes.
('91', 401, 5, 23, 791587) Indeed, I was astonished to see the distinction that the Government made between Indians and the Portuguese and between the Africans and themselves.
('91', 401, 5, 24, 791736) Nor does the history of the Portuguese Settlement in India prove the claim set forth by you.
('91', 401, 5, 25, 791829) Indeed, what I see and know of the condition of things in Goa is hardly edifying.
('91', 401, 5, 26, 791911) That the Indians in Goa have been speechless is proof not of the innocence or the philanthropic nature of the
('91', 401, 6, 27, 792021) 1 Vide “White Man’s Burden”, 26 6 1946. 2 In his letter of July 18 the addressee had inter alia observed: “If to authority is committed the preservation of the people’s physical health against pestilence and the use of narcotics and toxics, with the same reason it must look after the mental health not leaving it a prey to unsettling ideas.
('91', 401, 6, 28, 792363) I don’t believe that there is lesser liberty in the existence of a benevolent censorship trying to educate without party spirit than in other forms of State intervention.”
('91', 402, 0, 1, 792535) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 403
('91', 402, 1, 2, 792576) Portuguese Government but of the rule of terror.
('91', 402, 1, 3, 792625) You will forgive me for not subscribing to your statement that there is full liberty in Goa and that the agitation is confined only to a few malcontents.
('91', 402, 1, 4, 792779) Every account, received by me personally and seen in the papers here in this part of India, confirms the contrary view.
('91', 402, 1, 5, 792899) I suppose the report of the sentence by your Court Martial of eight years on Dr. Braganza 1 and his contemplated exile to a far off Portuguese Settle ment is by itself a striking corroboration of the fact that civil liberty is a rare article in Goa.
('91', 402, 1, 6, 793149) Why should a law abiding citizen like Dr. Braganza be considered so dangerous as to be singled out for exile?
('91', 402, 1, 7, 793259) Though the politics of Dr. Lohia probably differ from mine, he has commanded my admiration for his having gone to Goa and put his finger on its black spot.
('91', 402, 1, 8, 793415) Inhabitants of Goa can afford to wait for Independence, until much greater India has regained it.
('91', 402, 1, 9, 793513) But no person or group can thus remain without civil liberty without losing self respect.
('91', 402, 1, 10, 793603) He has lighted a torch which the inhabitants of Goa cannot, except at their peril, allow to be extinguished.
('91', 402, 1, 11, 793712) Both you and the inhabitants of Goa should feel thankful to the Doctor for lighting that torch.
('91', 402, 1, 12, 793808) Therefore, your description of him as “stranger” would excite laughter if it was not so tragic.
('91', 402, 1, 13, 793904) Surely the truth is that the Portuguese coming from Portugal are strangers, whether they come as philanth ropists or as Governors exploiting the so called weaker races of the earth.
('91', 402, 1, 14, 794086) You have talked of the abolition of caste distinctions What I see has happened is that not only no cast distinction has been abolished but at least one more caste, far more terrible than the system “caste”, has been added by the Portuguese rulers.
('91', 402, 1, 15, 794334) I, therefore, hope that you will revise your views on philanth ropy, civil liberty and caste distinctions, withdraw all the African police, declare yourself whole heartedly for civil liberty and if possi ble even let the inhabitants of Goa frame their own government, and invite from Greater India more experienced Indians to assist the inhabitants and even you in framing such Government.
('91', 402, 2, 16, 794724) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI [PS.] Since your letter was sent to the Press, I am publishing this in Harijan.
('91', 402, 2, 17, 794830) M. K. G. Harijan, 11 8 1946
('91', 402, 3, 18, 794858) 1 Dr. Tristo Braganza Cunha, who had started a Congress Committee in Goa

('91', 405, 8, 21, 798714) 478. TALK TO VILLAGERS 2
('91', 405, 9, 22, 798739) URULI, [August 2, 1946] 3
('91', 405, 10, 23, 798765) There were three ways, Gandhiji told the villagers of Uruli, of dealing with the case.
('91', 405, 10, 24, 798852) 4 The first was the stereotyped orthodox way of reporting to the police.
('91', 405, 10, 25, 798925) Very often it only provided the police a further opportunity for corruption and brought no relief to the victim.
('91', 405, 10, 26, 799038) The second way, which was followed by the general run of the
('91', 405, 11, 27, 799099) 1Vide the preceding item.
('91', 405, 11, 28, 799125) 2 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”, 5 8 1946 3 Pyarelal places this on the day following the 25th death anniversary of Tilak, which was on August 1. 4 A villager had been brought to Gandhiji with injuries inflicted upon him by thieves.
('91', 406, 0, 1, 799370) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 407
('91', 406, 1, 2, 799411) village people, was to passively acquiesce in it.
('91', 406, 1, 3, 799461) This was reprehensible as it was rooted in cowardice.
('91', 406, 1, 4, 799515) Crime would flourish, while cowardice remained.
('91', 406, 1, 5, 799563) What was more, by such acquiescence we ourselves became party to the crime.
('91', 406, 1, 6, 799639) The third way, which Gandhiji commended, was that of pure satyagraha.
('91', 406, 1, 7, 799709) It required that we should regard even thieves and criminals as our brothers and sisters and crime as a disease of which the latter were the victims and needed to be cured.
('91', 406, 1, 8, 799882) Instead of bearing ill will towards a thief or a criminal and trying to get him punished they should try to get under his skin, understand the cause that had led him into crime and try to remedy it.
('91', 406, 1, 9, 800081) They should, for instance, teach him a vocation and provide him with the means to make an honest living and thereby transform his life.
('91', 406, 1, 10, 800217) They should realize that a thief or a criminal was not a different being from themselves.
('91', 406, 1, 11, 800307) Indeed, if they turned the search light inward and closely looked into their own souls, they would find that the difference between them was only one of degree.
('91', 406, 1, 12, 800468) The rich, moneyed man, who made his riches by exploitation or other questionable means, was no less guilty of robbery than the thief who picked a pocket or broke into a house and committed theft.
('91', 406, 1, 13, 800664) Only the former took refuge behind the facade of respectability and escaped the penalty of law.
('91', 406, 1, 14, 800760) Strictly speaking, remarked Gandhiji, all amassing or hoarding of wealth above and beyond one’s legitimate requirements was theft.
('91', 406, 1, 15, 800891) There would be no occasion for thefts and therefore, no thieves if there was a wise regulation of riches and absolute social justice prevailed.
('91', 406, 1, 16, 801035) In the swaraj of his conception, there would be no thieves and no criminals, or else it would be swaraj only in name.
('91', 406, 1, 17, 801153) The criminal was only an indication of the social malady and since nature cure, as he envisaged it, included the triple cure of body, mind and soul, they must not be satisfied with merely banishing physical illness fro Uruli; their work must include the healing of the mind and soul too, so that there would be perfect social peace in their midst.
('91', 406, 2, 18, 801501) If they followed the nature cure way of dealing with the criminals, which, as he had already explained, was the way of satyagraha, they could not sit still in the face of crime.
('91', 406, 2, 19, 801679) Only a prefect being could afford to lose himself within himself and withdraw completely from the cares and responsibilities of the world.
('91', 406, 2, 20, 801818) But who could claim that perfection?
('91', 406, 2, 21, 801855) On the high seas a sudden calm is always regarded by experienced pilots and mariners with concern.
('91', 406, 2, 22, 801954) Absolute calm is not the law of the ocean.
('91', 406, 2, 23, 801997) It is the same with the ocean of life.
('91', 406, 2, 24, 802036) More often than not, it portends rough weather.
('91', 406, 2, 25, 802084) A satyagrahi would therefore neither retaliate nor submit to the criminal, but seek to cure him by curing himself.
('91', 406, 2, 26, 802199) He will not try to ride two horses at a time, viz., to pretend to follow the law of satyagraha while, at the same time, seeking police aid.
('91', 406, 2, 27, 802339) He must forswear the latter in order to follow the former.
('91', 406, 2, 28, 802398) If the criminal himself chooses to hand himself over to the police, it would be a different matter.
('91', 406, 2, 29, 802498) You cannot expect to touch his
('91', 407, 0, 1, 802529) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 407, 1, 2, 802571) heart and win his confidence if at the same time you are prepared to go to the police and inform against him.
('91', 407, 1, 3, 802681) That would be gross betrayal of trust.
('91', 407, 1, 4, 802720) A reformer cannot afford to be an informer.
('91', 407, 2, 5, 802764) And by way of illustration he mentioned several instances of how he had refused to give information to the police about persons who had been guilty of violence and had come and confessed to him.
('91', 407, 2, 6, 802959) No police officer could compel a satyagrahi to give evidence against a person who had confessed to him.
('91', 407, 2, 7, 803063) A satyagrahi would never be guilty of a betrayal of trust.
('91', 407, 2, 8, 803122) He wanted the people of Uruli to adopt the method of satyagraha for dealing with crime and criminals.
('91', 407, 2, 9, 803224) They should contact the criminals in their homes, win their confidence and trust by loving and selfless service, wean them from evil and unclean habits and help to rehabilitate them by teaching them honest ways of living.
('91', 407, 2, 10, 803446) Harijan, 11 8 1946
('91', 407, 3, 11, 803465) 479. STRIKES
('91', 407, 4, 12, 803478) The statement in the daily press that I had approved of the postal strike 1 is not true.
('91', 407, 4, 13, 803567) One day a postman asked to be allowed to just say ‘Vande Mataram’ to me.
('91', 407, 4, 14, 803640) Kanu Gandhi brought him to me.
('91', 407, 4, 15, 803671) The visitor, however, asked for my blessings for the postmen’s strike which had just then commenced.
('91', 407, 4, 16, 803772) I said to him that if the strike was justified and if they conducted themselves absolutely peacefully, they must succeed.
('91', 407, 4, 17, 803894) 2 This was no approval of the particular strike.
('91', 407, 4, 18, 803943) Apart, however, from what I said and apart from the merits of the postmen’s strike, I feel that as an expert in successful strikes of an absolutely peaceful nature, I owe it to the conductor of this strike as to those of all others and to the public to state the conditions of successful strikes.
('91', 407, 4, 19, 804240) Obviously there should be no strike which is not justifiable on merits.
('91', 407, 4, 20, 804312) No unjust strike should succeed.
('91', 407, 4, 21, 804345) All public sympathy must be withheld from such strikes.
('91', 407, 4, 22, 804401) The public has no means of judging the merits of a strike, unless it is backed by impartial persons enjoying public confidence.
('91', 407, 4, 23, 804529) Interested men cannot judge the merits of their own case.
('91', 407, 4, 24, 804587) Hence, there must be an arbitration accepted by the parties or a judicial adjudi cation.
('91', 407, 4, 25, 804676) As a rule, the matter does not come before the public when there is accepted arbitration or adjudication.
('91', 407, 4, 26, 804782) Cases have, however,
('91', 407, 5, 27, 804803) 1 This commenced in Bombay on 11th July and ended on 2nd August, 1946. 2 The Press had reported Gandhiji as having said: “If you conduct your strike in a peaceful manner success will surely be yours.”
('91', 408, 0, 1, 805004) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 409
('91', 408, 1, 2, 805045) happened when haughty employers have ignored awards or mis guided employees, conscious of their power to assert themselves, have done likewise and have decided upon forcible extortion.
('91', 408, 1, 3, 805230) Strikes for economic betterment should never have a political end as an ulterior motive.
('91', 408, 1, 4, 805319) Such a mixture never advances the political end and generally brings trouble upon strikers, even when they do not dislocate public life, as in the case of public utility services such as the postal strike.
('91', 408, 1, 5, 805525) The Government may suffer some inconvenience but will no come to a stand still.
('91', 408, 1, 6, 805605) Rich persons will put up expensive postal services but the vast mass of the poor people will be deprived during such a strike of a convenience of primary importance to which they have become used for generations.
('91', 408, 1, 7, 805818) Such strikes can only take place when every other legitimate means has been adopted and failed.
('91', 408, 1, 8, 805914) In the present case we have National Provincial Governments.
('91', 408, 1, 9, 805975) Postmen should consult these Governments before resorting to the extreme step.
('91', 408, 1, 10, 806054) So far as I am aware Shri Balasaheb Kher, Shri Mangal das Pakvasa 1 and Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel have intervened.
('91', 408, 1, 11, 806168) If their advice has been rejected by the men, they have taken a serious and dangerous step.
('91', 408, 1, 12, 806260) If all these powerful unions disregard their own Governments and the Working Committee members, they disown the Congress.They have a right to do so if the Congress sells their interest.
('91', 408, 1, 13, 806446) Sympathetic strikes must be taboo until it is conclusively proved that the affected men have exhausted all the legitimate means at their disposal and until the Congress has been proved to have a betrayed or neglected their interest or until the Congress has called for sympa thetic strikes in order to secure justice from obdurate and unsym pathetic authorities.
('91', 408, 1, 14, 806809) One hears of strikes all over the country to paralyse the Govern ment.
('91', 408, 1, 15, 806880) This paralysis is an extreme political step, open only to a body like the Congress, not even to unions, however powerful they may be.
('91', 408, 1, 16, 807014) If the Congress is the people’s arm par excellence for the purpose of winn ing Independence, paralysing action should be retained solely in the hands of the Congress.
('91', 408, 1, 17, 807181) At the present moment, the Congress is engaged in making a success of the proposed Constituent Assembly.
('91', 408, 1, 18, 807286) There are interminable difficulties in the way.
('91', 408, 1, 19, 807334) Paralysing strikes must seriously hamper Congress action.
('91', 408, 1, 20, 807392) It follows from the foregoing that political strikes must be
('91', 408, 2, 21, 807453) 1 President of Bombay legislative council
('91', 409, 0, 1, 807495) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 409, 1, 2, 807537) treated on their own merits and must never be mixed with or related to economic strikes.
('91', 409, 1, 3, 807626) Political strikes have a definite place in non violent action.
('91', 409, 1, 4, 807689) They are never taken up haphazard.
('91', 409, 1, 5, 807724) They must be open, never led by goondaism.
('91', 409, 1, 6, 807767) They are calculated never to lead to violence.
('91', 409, 1, 7, 807814) Therefore, my humble suggestion to all strikers is to make a frank declaration of submission to arbitration or adjudication, to seek the guidance of the Congress and abide by its advice and for all sympathetic strikes to stop whilst the Congress is engaged in making the contemplated Constituent Assembly a success and while Provincial National Government are functioning.
('91', 409, 1, 8, 808187) URULI KANCHAN, August 3, 1946 Harijan, 11 8 1946
('91', 409, 2, 9, 808236) 480. THE MEANING OF NATURE CURE 1
('91', 409, 3, 10, 808270) Many people wish to come to Uruli Kanchan to learn nature cure.
('91', 409, 3, 11, 808334) I dissuade them.
('91', 409, 3, 12, 808351) The institution that is working at Uruli Kan chan on behalf of the Trust is for the villagers.
('91', 409, 3, 13, 808446) Its three trustees are Dr. Dinshaw Mehta, Shri Jehangir Patel and myself.
('91', 409, 3, 14, 808520) Though Dr. Din shaw Mehta has a lot of experience of nature cure, he has gained this experience in towns.
('91', 409, 3, 15, 808626) When he was conducting his nature cure home in Poona, though he took in poor patients, he gave them the same treatment as he gave his rich patients.
('91', 409, 3, 16, 808775) As I conceived nature cure for the villagers, it should confine itself to such remedies as are available in the villages and should do without the aid of electricity and ice.
('91', 409, 3, 17, 808950) This would be the limit of this treatment.
('91', 409, 3, 18, 808993) Such work can only be for a person like me who has become a villager and whose heart is in the villages even though he be living in a city.
('91', 409, 3, 19, 809133) So the trustees have entrusted this work to me.
('91', 409, 3, 20, 809181) I have begun the work but I have no trained personnel.
('91', 409, 3, 21, 809236) It is another thing that I take help from Dr. Mehta when ever I need it.
('91', 409, 3, 22, 809309) I have found a good helper in Dr. Bhagawat whose heart is wholly in the villages and who himself lives very simply.
('91', 409, 3, 23, 809425) Even though he is an allopath, he believes only in nature cure, does not despise manual work and never tires of working.
('91', 409, 3, 24, 809546) The others are all new to the work though filled with the spirit of service.
('91', 409, 3, 25, 809623) I too am new to the work.
('91', 409, 3, 26, 809649) Shri Datar has given his house for our use.
('91', 409, 3, 27, 809693) He charges no rent, and so the work can go on.
('91', 409, 3, 28, 809740) But the house
('91', 409, 4, 29, 809754) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan 11 8 1946.
('91', 410, 0, 1, 809819) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 411
('91', 410, 1, 2, 809860) has not room enough for new students to be admitted.
('91', 410, 1, 3, 809913) I myself cannot permanently stay in Uruli Kanchan.
('91', 410, 1, 4, 809964) If God wills it I hope in future to spend six months in the neighbourhood of Poona and six months in Sevagram.
('91', 410, 1, 5, 810075) Those who wish to learn nature cure should therefore understand that in the present circumstances it is quite impossible for anyone to be put up here.
('91', 410, 1, 6, 810226) Now a few words as to my conception of nature cure.
('91', 410, 1, 7, 810278) I have written a little bit about it from time to time in previous issues.
('91', 410, 1, 8, 810353) But since the idea is growing, I may as well explain the limits of nature cure as carried on in Uruli Kanchan.
('91', 410, 1, 9, 810464) Diseases, whether in village or in town, are of three kinds: physical, mental and spiritual.
('91', 410, 1, 10, 810557) And what is true of the individual is true of society.
('91', 410, 1, 11, 810612) The majority of the inhabitants of Uruli Kanchan are business folk.
('91', 410, 1, 12, 810680) One part is inhabited by Mangs, another by Mahars, and yet another by Kanchans.
('91', 410, 1, 13, 810760) The name of the village is derived from this last group.
('91', 410, 1, 14, 810817) There are some Garudis living here too, who are classified as criminal tribes under the law.
('91', 410, 1, 15, 810910) The Mangs earn their living by making ropes, etc.
('91', 410, 1, 16, 810960) They were doing well during the war but are now having a lean time and living in penury.
('91', 410, 1, 17, 811049) The problem that faces the nature cure physicians is how to deal with this malady of the Mangs, which is by no means slight.
('91', 410, 1, 18, 811174) It is the duty of the businessmen to cure them of this disease.
('91', 410, 1, 19, 811238) No medicines from any dispensary are going to avail in this case and yet it is as fell a disease as cholera.
('91', 410, 1, 20, 811347) Some of the tenements of the Mangs are fit only to be burnt.
('91', 410, 1, 21, 811408) But burning will not provide new dwellings for them.
('91', 410, 1, 22, 811461) How would they protect themselves from rain and cold?
('91', 410, 1, 23, 811515) Where would they put their belongings?
('91', 410, 1, 24, 811554) All these are questions to which the nature cure physician cannot shut his eyes.
('91', 410, 1, 25, 811635) What is to be done about the Garudis?
('91', 410, 1, 26, 811673) They do not commit crimes for the love of it.
('91', 410, 1, 27, 811719) It is a habit ingrained in them for generations and so they are described as criminal.
('91', 410, 1, 28, 811806) It is for the residents of Uruli Kanchan to wean them from this habit.
('91', 410, 1, 29, 811877) The nature cure physician cannot neglect this work.
('91', 410, 1, 30, 811929) Several such questions face the nature cure worker.
('91', 410, 1, 31, 811981) Nature cure work thus becomes purely work for swaraj and its field also becomes very wide.
('91', 410, 1, 32, 812072) God willing, it can succeed, provided we, the workers and residents of Uruli Kanchan, follow truth and persevere.

('91', 413, 0, 1, 815275) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 413, 1, 2, 815317) 485. DOCTORS CRITICIZED
('91', 413, 2, 3, 815341) 1. Whether it is not a matter of common experience that the diagnosis by doctors is a very uncertain quantity and varies from time to time in the same case and often from doctor to doctor, and many cases remain undiagnosed until they recover or die?
('91', 413, 3, 4, 815591) 2. Assuming that the diagnosis is correct what useful purpose does it serve if it cannot be followed by remedial measures which lead to a cure, even on paper.
('91', 413, 3, 5, 815750) Medical books do not speak with a certain voice on this point.
('91', 413, 3, 6, 815813) If nature cure alone is to be followed, why is a diagnosis needed at all, considering that it recognizes the unity of disease and not hundreds of diseases which the doctors believe in?
('91', 413, 4, 7, 815998) 3. Do the doctors make any use of their knowledge of the body in prescribing medical treatment as distinguished from surgical treatment?
('91', 413, 4, 8, 816135) If not why should the doctors get credit for having once upon a time read physiology and anatomy which are soon forgotten for want of use in actual practice?
('91', 413, 4, 9, 816293) Are not the vaids entitled to equal credit or discredit for studying the physiology and pathology of tridosha 1 and not making but a nominal use of it in actual practice?
('91', 413, 5, 10, 816464) 4. Are not the defects attributed to the vaids really due to the omission of its duty by the State to provide institutions for research, etc.?
('91', 413, 5, 11, 816607) How can the system be blamed for the fault of the individual or the Government?
('91', 413, 5, 12, 816687) Even the doctors in private practice carry out no research and very few of them even read about researches carried on abroad.
('91', 413, 6, 13, 816813) 5. Does not the constant examination of Mahatmaji’s body by the doctors give them an undue and undeserved prominence in the public eye and so tend to put into the background the other systems of medicine which also have an equal if not greater claim on Mahatmaji’s attention?
('91', 413, 6, 14, 817089) These are Shri Brijlal Nehru’s questions to which I reply as follows: 1. What the question implies is very true.
('91', 413, 6, 15, 817202) Nevertheless doctors flourish.
('91', 413, 6, 16, 817233) This phenomenon should make us all think.
('91', 413, 6, 17, 817275) 2. My experience is that a correct diagnosis is followed by a re medial measure answering the diagnosis.
('91', 413, 6, 18, 817380) It will be wrong to blame medi cal books because they mention several alternative measures.
('91', 413, 6, 19, 817472) The complicated human system does not lend itself to one certain remedy.
('91', 413, 6, 20, 817545) It would be untrue to say that nature cure does not demand
('91', 413, 7, 21, 817604) 1 This attributes the case of disease to the imbalance of the three humours namely, Vata or wind, Pitta or bile and Kaf or phlegm.
('91', 414, 0, 1, 817735) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 415
('91', 414, 1, 2, 817776) any diagnosis.
('91', 414, 1, 3, 817791) As it believes in unity of disease and unity of cure, diagnosis adopted in nature cure is much simpler.
('91', 414, 1, 4, 817895) Unity of disease and unity of cure is a good generalization.
('91', 414, 1, 5, 817956) No nature cure man blindly applies earth poultices in all cases.
('91', 414, 1, 6, 818021) 3. It is highly unfair to say that in their practice doctors make no use of their knowledge of physiology and anatomy No comparison can be set up between doctors and vaids for they employ wholly dissimilar methods of diagnosis.
('91', 414, 1, 7, 818249) I am utterly ignorant of the value of the tridosha theory.
('91', 414, 1, 8, 818308) 4. I am unable to subscribe to the condemnation of the State for not providing institutions for research.
('91', 414, 1, 9, 818414) I have always blamed the vaids’ apathy in the matter of real research.
('91', 414, 1, 10, 818485) The top ones are busy making money.
('91', 414, 1, 11, 818521) The others are too ignorant to do so or are easily satisfied with what they find in the orthodox Ayurvedic books.
('91', 414, 1, 12, 818635) I am sorry for this view.
('91', 414, 1, 13, 818661) I come to it, in spite of my great regard for the Ayurvedic system and the Yunani which are suited to the soil.
('91', 414, 1, 14, 818773) 5. I do not think that constant examination by medical friends of my body gives them undue or any prominence.
('91', 414, 1, 15, 818883) They do not stand in need of any.
('91', 414, 1, 16, 818917) They were all flourishing before I appeared on the scene.
('91', 414, 1, 17, 818975) Nor does it tend to put into the background the other systems of medicine.
('91', 414, 1, 18, 819050) I have friends among vaids and hakims.
('91', 414, 1, 19, 819089) But they do not need elaborate or frequent diagnosis.
('91', 414, 1, 20, 819143) I submit my body to the diagnosis which is unfortunately advertised but I do not submit it to the treatment by drugs.
('91', 414, 1, 21, 819261) The treatment is principally confined to the use of the five agencies of nature, diet changes and massage.
('91', 414, 1, 22, 819368) My love of nature cure and of indigenous systems does not blind me to the advance that Western medicine has made in spite of the fact that I have stigmatized it as black magic.
('91', 414, 1, 23, 819545) I have used the harsh term and I do not withdraw it, because of the fact that it has countenanced vivisection and all the awfulness it means and because it will stop at no practice, however bad it may be, if it prolongs the life of the body and because it ignores the immortal soul which resides in the body.
('91', 414, 1, 24, 819854) I cling to nature cure in spite of its great limitations and in spite of the lazy pretensions of nature curists.
('91', 414, 1, 25, 819967) Above all, in nature cure, everybody can be his or her own doctor, not so in the various systems of medicine.
('91', 414, 1, 26, 820077) URULI KANCHAN, August 4, 1946 Harijan, 11 8 1946

('91', 415, 11, 22, 821079) DINSHAW, My idea of developing nature cure in Uruli Kanchan and the villages of India is fast expanding.
('91', 415, 11, 23, 821184) It means teaching the hygiene of the body, mind and soul of the individual and society.Thus the workers in Uruli Kanchan have, besides cleaning the streets of the village, and attending to their bodily ailments through the judicious use of earth, sum ether, light and water, to attend to the pauperism of the criminal tribes called the Garudis—described in law as one of the criminal tribes of India 1 —and the rapacity of Pathans in exacting interest , [which] are all social diseases demanding treatment by a real nature cure man.

('91', 418, 1, 2, 825457) 491. A KHADI LOVER’S COMPLAINT 1
('91', 418, 2, 3, 825490) A Gujarati khadi lover living in South India writes as follows:
('91', 418, 3, 4, 825554) In the Khadi Bhandar here, it is hard to get cotton, spindles, charkhas and their accessories.
('91', 418, 3, 5, 825649) I have up till now been carrying on with my own cotton.
('91', 418, 3, 6, 825705) The slivers from cotton bought here were not at all good.
('91', 418, 3, 7, 825763) I discovered it was of poor quality after I had bought it.
('91', 418, 3, 8, 825822) I found hand carding (tunai) of it difficult and could not get anyone here to teach me either.
('91', 418, 4, 9, 825917) I have just given my full quota of self spun and self carded yarn for 1946 to be woven into cloth.
('91', 418, 4, 10, 826016) At first one could procure coupons for self spun yarn and buy a certain amount of khadi with it.
('91', 418, 4, 11, 826113) The yarn given in is to be woven into saris and dhotis.
('91', 418, 4, 12, 826169) How are we to buy cloth for our other requirements of underwear, sheets, towels, etc.?
('91', 418, 4, 13, 826256) I went to the Bhandar recently and they demanded the same number of hanks as the amount of rupees the cloth was worth.
('91', 418, 4, 14, 826375) In addition I was told I had to be a member of the Bhandar.
('91', 418, 4, 15, 826435) I spend 2 to 21 2 hours daily in carding and spinning.
('91', 418, 4, 16, 826490) If I can spare any more time, I devote
('91', 418, 5, 17, 826529) it also to this work.
('91', 418, 5, 18, 826551) But, in spite of all my labour, I shall never be able to produce enough yarn for my requirements.
('91', 418, 5, 19, 826649) What am I to do?
('91', 418, 5, 20, 826666) The fact that I am unacquainted with the language is another difficulty.
('91', 418, 5, 21, 826739) It would be easier if all the rules regarding khadi were written up in Hindustani.
('91', 418, 5, 22, 826822) Moreover, it seems impossible to get anything done without outside influence.
('91', 418, 5, 23, 826900) Is one to call it one’s misfortune or part our nature?
('91', 418, 5, 24, 826955) One needs some backing even to buy a spindle, to say nothing about a charkha.
('91', 418, 5, 25, 827033) If the Charkha Sangh people themselves do not realize what difficulties one has to face in the matter of buying even small requirements to whom can one turn for help?
('91', 418, 6, 26, 827200) I spoke about this to a well known Gujarati friend here.
('91', 418, 6, 27, 827257) He got enraged.
('91', 418, 6, 28, 827273) ‘Gandhiji has constituted himself Viceroy.
('91', 418, 6, 29, 827316) Why then should he listen to anyone?
('91', 418, 6, 30, 827353) He does whatever comes into his head.
('91', 418, 6, 31, 827391) Let him do so.
('91', 418, 6, 32, 827406) We shall get khadi from wherever we can and what is more, we shall encourage uncertified khadi.
('91', 418, 6, 33, 827502) As for Pyarelalji he only puts up to Gandhiji what he chooses and throws the rest into the waste paper basket.’ The above angry criticism about my post does not need any comment, beyond saying that every worth while letter is put up before me and that if I were to be acquainted with or read every letter that comes, the whole of my time would be spent on the post and I would be rendered useless for my real work.
('91', 418, 6, 34, 827917) But what has been said about khadi demands consideration.
('91', 418, 6, 35, 827975) That Sales Bhandars may disappear under the new scheme only means that they should be converted into
('91', 418, 7, 36, 828076) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 18 8 1946
('91', 419, 0, 1, 828150) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 419, 1, 2, 828192) schools for teaching all the processes of khadi.
('91', 419, 1, 3, 828241) Therefore, cotton, charkhas, spindles and all other accessories of spinning, carding and ginning should certainly be available there.
('91', 419, 1, 4, 828375) Above all, the khadi worker should be polite and obliging at all times.
('91', 419, 1, 5, 828447) If he is not, it will mean the end of khadi and it will be a tragedy if khadi workers themselves were to be the cause of its death.
('91', 419, 1, 6, 828579) The criticism in the letter under reference can only be appli cable to one or two Bhandars.
('91', 419, 1, 7, 828671) This note is, therefore, only meant for those to whom it does apply.
('91', 419, 1, 8, 828740) All such should early set their house in order.
('91', 419, 1, 9, 828788) Khadi wearers who spin regularly and give in their self spun yarn for being woven into cloth should be, as they are, entitled to purchase against cash the amount of khadi which, according to the A.I.S.A. rules, their above mentioned yarn permits them to buy.

('91', 420, 3, 23, 831836) He was sick of it.
('91', 420, 3, 24, 831855) It could do not good either to him or to them.
('91', 420, 3, 25, 831902) True admiration consisted in carrying out the wishes of the person one admired, not merely staring at him and thus wasting his time and one’s own.
('91', 420, 4, 26, 832049) Unless there is an atmospheric calamity or some drasticaction by Government, my programme is to stay for six months here from August to January and later six months in Uruli Kanchan, Panchgani, Poona and near about.

('91', 421, 3, 4, 832939) 493. HORSE RACING 1
('91', 421, 4, 5, 832959) I have written before regarding the ruination of men and money through horse racing but a very strongly worded letter from a friend who says that gambling on the race course is not a lesser evil than the drink habit, constrains me to write again on this subject.
('91', 421, 4, 6, 833222) The writer further says:
('91', 421, 5, 7, 833247) Special trains are run for the races and are full of people who wear Gandhi caps, call themselves Congressmen and go there only to waste their money.
('91', 421, 5, 8, 833397) Where does this money come from?
('91', 421, 5, 9, 833430) We now have popular Ministries, but they too are silent and put up with the evil.
('91', 421, 5, 10, 833512) Although, in my opinion gambling at races is not as great an evil as drinking of alcohol, one ought not really to draw comparisons.
('91', 421, 5, 11, 833644) Less bad does not make gambling a good thing.
('91', 421, 5, 12, 833690) I do not know all the intricacies of horse racing.
('91', 421, 5, 13, 833741) All I can say is that if it is within the competence of the present Government to put an end to the evil; it should certainly do so.
('91', 421, 5, 14, 833874) SEVAGRAM, August 7, 1946 Harijan,, 18 8 1946

('91', 423, 1, 2, 836563) 496. TRIBUTE TO RABINDRANATH TAGORE 1
('91', 423, 2, 3, 836601) SEVAGRAM, August 7, 1946 Gurudev’s life was a continuous poem of service.
('91', 423, 2, 4, 836675) He served Hindustan to the last breath of his life.
('91', 423, 2, 5, 836727) The Hitavada, 9 8 1946
('91', 423, 3, 6, 836750) 497. QUESTION BOX
('91', 423, 4, 7, 836768) THE CENTRAL POINT MISSED The following questions have been given by a British military officer who read with great interest the article in the Harijan of July 28, 1946 on ‘Independence’ 2. The officer is a military engineer, widely travelled in America and Europe, and has seen with his own eyes the horrors of the war in Germany.
('91', 423, 5, 8, 837099) Q. 1. In this ideal State (there is no doubt that it is ideal) how can one be sure that outside aggression can be avoided?
('91', 423, 5, 9, 837222) If the State has no modern army with modern weapons which are the product of the machine age, an invading army with modern weapons could over run the country and subject and inhabitants to slavery.
('91', 423, 6, 10, 837420) A. The questioner, who claims to have read and reread my article carefully and says he has liked it and is a military man, has evidently missed the central point of my article, viz., that however small a nation or even a group may be, it is able, even as the individual, provided that it has one mind as also the will and the grit, to defend its honour and self respect against a whole world in arms.
('91', 423, 6, 11, 837821) Therein consists the matchless strength and beauty of the unarmed.
('91', 423, 6, 12, 837888) That is non violent defence which neither knows nor accepts defeat at any stage.
('91', 423, 6, 13, 837969) Therefore, a nation or a group which has made non violence its final policy, cannot be subjected to slavery even by the atom bomb.
('91', 423, 7, 14, 838100) WHY IN WANT OF FOOD?
('91', 423, 8, 15, 838121) Q. 2. India at the present time cannot grow enough food for its population.
('91', 423, 8, 16, 838197) To buy food from abroad, India must sell other goods to pay for it, and in order to sell such goods, India must produce at competitive prices which, in my opinion, cannot be done without modern machines.
('91', 423, 8, 17, 838401) How can
('91', 423, 9, 18, 838409) 1 The occasion was the death anniversary of Rabindranath Tagore.
('91', 423, 9, 19, 838474) 2 Vide “Independence”, 21 7 1946.
('91', 424, 0, 1, 838508) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 425
('91', 424, 1, 2, 838549) this be done, unless the machine replaces manual labour?
('91', 424, 2, 3, 838606) A. The statement in the first sentence of the question is wholly wrong.
('91', 424, 2, 4, 838678) I hold, in spite of opinions expressed to the contrary, that India is able at the present moment to grow enough food.
('91', 424, 2, 5, 838796) I have previously stated the condition for growing enough food, viz., that the Government at the head should be National and a Government that knows its business and is capable of dealing sternly with all profi teering, black marketing and, worst of all, laziness of mind and body.
('91', 424, 2, 6, 839078) The second part of the question really falls to the ground if my answer to the first is correct.
('91', 424, 2, 7, 839175) But for the sake of dismissing the plea on behalf of modern machines as against human labour of which there is plenty in a land like India, I would say that if all the able bodied millions work with one mind and with zeal, they could com pete on their own terms with any nation, however well equipped it may be with modern machines.
('91', 424, 2, 8, 839508) The questioner should not forget that modern machines have up till now gone side by side with the exploitation of the machineless nations, dubbed weak.
('91', 424, 2, 9, 839660) I use the parti ciple ‘dubbed’ because they will refuse to be weak immediately they realize the fact that they are even at the present moment stronger than the nations equipped with the most modern weapons and machinery.
('91', 424, 3, 10, 839881) SWARAJ THROUGH SPINNING A Congressman writes:
('91', 424, 4, 11, 839927) Q. You will perhaps agree that in spite of considerable publicity, spinning and weaving have not yet found favour with the public to the extent to which they should have done.
('91', 424, 4, 12, 840103) I think if every Congress Committee—at least those of the big cities—starts a sort of coaching class for the public for this purpose, it can do immense good.
('91', 424, 4, 13, 840261) Many people—particularly the poor— do not take to spinning because they do not know spinning and weaving, what type of wheels are more convenient to use and give greater output, how these are properly operated, how best they should dispose of or utilize the yarn thus produced, etc.
('91', 424, 4, 14, 840544) If once or twice a week, some such classes are undertaken after proper publicity and people are instructed in this technique by practical demonstrations, things should improve much.
('91', 424, 4, 15, 840726) At least the experiment is worth a trial by the Congress.
('91', 424, 4, 16, 840784) Even if regular classes are not held but a group or groups of experts of this technique undertake a tour and give demonstrations and instruction to the public for some days in each city, it can serve the purpose to a considerable extent.
('91', 424, 4, 17, 841022) Questions like the above often come to me from Congressmen.
('91', 424, 4, 18, 841082) Since this is exhaustive, I reproduce it as it is.
('91', 424, 4, 19, 841133) The signature is

('91', 425, 1, 10, 842135) SEVAGRAM, August 8, 1946 Harijan, 18 8 1946
('91', 425, 2, 11, 842179) 498. RAMANAMA AGAIN
('91', 425, 3, 12, 842199) A friend sends me a letter received by him for an answer.
('91', 425, 3, 13, 842257) The letter is long.
('91', 425, 3, 14, 842277) I have only copied here the relevant part:
('91', 425, 4, 15, 842320) India is in his blood but why should he cause resentment among his countrymen who are not of his religious faith by holding daily prayer meetings and chanting Ramanama (meaning the name of Rama, the Hindu God)?
('91', 425, 4, 16, 842531) He should realize that India is full of manifold faiths and most of the conservatives are apt to mistake him (and this is one of the pleas of the Muslim League) if he openly goes on talking in the name of the Hindu gods.
('91', 425, 4, 17, 842752) One of his pet terms is the establishment of Rama Rajya (the rule of Rama).
('91', 425, 4, 18, 842828) What would a devout Muslim feel about this?
('91', 425, 4, 19, 842872) I must repeat for the thousandth time that Ramanama is one of the many names for God.
('91', 425, 4, 20, 842958) The same prayer meetings have recitations from the Koran and the Zend Avesta.
('91', 425, 4, 21, 843036) Devout Muslims, for the very reason that they are devout, have never objected to the chant of Ramanama.
('91', 425, 4, 22, 843140) Ramanama is not an idle chant.
('91', 425, 4, 23, 843171) It is conceived as a mode of addressing the all pervasive God known to me, as to millions of Hindus, by the familiar name of Ramanama.
('91', 425, 4, 24, 843306) ‘Nama’ at the end of Rama is the most significant part.
('91', 425, 4, 25, 843362) It means the ‘nama’ without the Rama of history.
('91', 425, 4, 26, 843411) Be that as it may, why should an open profession by me of my faith offend anybody, much less the Muslim League?
('91', 426, 0, 1, 843523) VOL. 91: 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 427
('91', 426, 1, 2, 843564) one is obliged to join these meetings and having joined is not obliged to take part in the chant.
('91', 426, 1, 3, 843662) All that the visitors are expected to do is not to mar the harmony of the meeting and to tolerate the proceedings even when they are not in sympathy with any part.
('91', 426, 1, 4, 843826) As to the use of the phrase ‘Rama Rajya’, why should it offend after my having defined its meaning many times?
('91', 426, 1, 5, 843937) It is a convenient and expressive phrase, the meaning of which no alternative can so fully express to millions.
('91', 426, 1, 6, 844049) When I visit the Frontier Province or address predominantly Muslim audiences I would express my meaning to them by calling it Khudai Raj, while to a Christian audience I would describe it as the Kingdom of God on earth.
('91', 426, 1, 7, 844269) Any other mode would, for me, be self suppression and hypocrisy.
('91', 426, 1, 8, 844334) SEVAGRAM, August 8, 1946 Harijan, 18 8 1946
('91', 426, 2, 9, 844378) 499. IS GOD A PERSON OR A PRINCIPLE?
('91', 426, 3, 10, 844415) A friend from Baroda, who writes in English, says:
('91', 426, 4, 11, 844466) You ask us to pray to God to give light to the whites in South Africa and strength and courage to the Indians there to remain steadfast to the end.
('91', 426, 4, 12, 844614) A prayer of this nature can only be addressed to a person.
('91', 426, 4, 13, 844673) If God is an all perva ding and all powerful force, what is the point of praying to Him?
('91', 426, 4, 14, 844762) He goes on with His work whatever happens.
('91', 426, 4, 15, 844805) I have written on this topic before.
('91', 426, 4, 16, 844842) However, if one keeps on saying the same thing again and again in different words some new words or phrases used are likely to help someone or other to understand the matter better.
('91', 426, 4, 17, 845024) In my view, whether called Rama, Rahman, Ormuzd God or Krishna, He is that Supreme Power that man is ever trying to find a name for.
('91', 426, 4, 18, 845157) Man, though imperfect, strives after perfection and in so doing is caught up in the tides of thought.
('91', 426, 4, 19, 845259) Then like a baby learning to toddle, he now stumbles, now stands up.
('91', 426, 4, 20, 845328) Thus if we say that a reasoning man is only a few months’ old child, we shall not in the least be exaggerating, judging by the immensity of cosmic time; we shall be stating a simple truth.
('91', 426, 4, 21, 845517) Man can express himself only by means of language.
('91', 426, 4, 22, 845568) But there can be no such medium as language for the Power that is God.
('91', 426, 4, 23, 845639) Man however can describe this
('91', 426, 5, 24, 845669) 1 A translation of this was also published in Harijan, 18 8 1946, under the title “Is God a Person or Force?”
('91', 427, 0, 1, 845779) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 427, 1, 2, 845821) Infinite Power only with his imperfect means.
('91', 427, 1, 3, 845867) If one has grasped this there is nothing left further to ask.
('91', 427, 1, 4, 845929) Then it would be right to pray to Him in the language of man, for one can comprehend Him somewhat by yfitting Him into one’s own mould.
('91', 427, 1, 5, 846065) One ought always to remember, while dwelling on Him, that one is but a drop, the tiniest of creatures of the ocean that is God.
('91', 427, 1, 6, 846193) One may experience Him by being in Him, but one can never describe Him.
('91', 427, 1, 7, 846265) As Madame Blavatsky puts it, man, in praying, worships the Great Power residing within.
('91', 427, 1, 8, 846353) Only he who knows this may pray.
('91', 427, 1, 9, 846386) He who does not, need not pray.
('91', 427, 1, 10, 846418) God will not be offended by it, but I can say from experience that that man will be the loser by not praying.
('91', 427, 1, 11, 846528) So it is immaterial if some worship God as a Person and some others as Great Power.
('91', 427, 1, 12, 846612) Both are right, each in his own way.
('91', 427, 1, 13, 846649) Nobody knows what is intrinsically right and nobody is likely ever to know.
('91', 427, 1, 14, 846725) The ideal, to be an ideal, must forever remain out of reach.
('91', 427, 1, 15, 846786) All the other forces are static, while God is the Life Force, immanent and at the same time transcendent.
('91', 427, 2, 16, 846892) SEVAGRAM, August 8, 1946 [From Gujarati]

('91', 431, 0, 1, 851038) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 431, 1, 2, 851080) APPENDIX I
('91', 431, 2, 3, 851091) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE’S RESOLUTION 1
('91', 431, 3, 4, 851133) May 24, 1946
('91', 431, 4, 5, 851146) The Working Committee have given careful consideration to the Statement dated May 16, 1946, issued by the Delegation of the British Cabinet and the Viceroy on behalf of the British Government, as well as the correspondence relating to it that has passed between the Congress President and the members of the Delegation.
('91', 431, 4, 6, 851466) They have examined it with every desire to find a way for a peaceful and co operative transfer of power and the establishment of a free and independent India.
('91', 431, 4, 7, 851625) Such an India must necessarily have a strong central authority capable of representing the nation with power and dignity in the counsels of the world.
('91', 431, 4, 8, 851776) In considering the Statement, the Working Committee have kept in view the picture of the future, in so far as this was available to them from the proposals made for the formation of a Provisional Government and the clarification given by members of the Delegation.
('91', 431, 4, 9, 852041) This picture is still incomplete and vague.
('91', 431, 4, 10, 852085) It is only on the basis of the full picture that they can judge and come to a decision as to how far this is in conformity with the objectives they aim at.
('91', 431, 4, 11, 852241) These objectives are : independence for India, a strong, though limited, central authority, full autonomy for the provinces, the establishment of a democratic structure in the centre and in the units, the guarantee of the fundamental rights of each individual so that he may have full and equal opportunities of growth, and further that each community should have opportunity to live the life of its choice within the larger framework.
('91', 431, 5, 12, 852677) The Committee regret to find a divergence between these objectives and the various proposals that have been made on behalf of the British Government, and, in particular, there is no vital change envisaged during the interim period when the Provisional Government will function, in spite of the assurance given in Paragraph 23 of the Statement.
('91', 431, 5, 13, 853021) If the independence of India is aimed at, then the functioning of the Provisional Government must approximate closely in fact, even though not in law, to that independence and all obstructions and hindrances to it should be removed.
('91', 431, 5, 14, 853254) The continued presence of a foreign army of occupation is a negation of independence.
('91', 431, 6, 15, 853340) The Statement issued by the Cabinet Delegation and the Viceroy con tains certain recommendations and suggests a procedure for the building up of a Constituent Assembly, which is sovereign in so far as the framing of the Constitu tion is concerned.
('91', 431, 6, 16, 853588) The Committee do not agree with some of these recommendations.
('91', 431, 7, 17, 853651) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Pethick Lawrence” 24 5 1946.
('91', 432, 0, 1, 853703) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 433
('91', 432, 1, 2, 853745) In their view it will be open to the Constituent Assembly itself at any stage to make changes and variations, with the proviso that in regard to certain major communal matters a majority decision of both the major communities will be necessary.
('91', 432, 2, 3, 853990) The procedure for the election of the Constituent Assembly is based on representation in the ratio of one to a million, but the application of this principle appears to have been overlooked in the case of European members of Assemblies, particularly in Assam and Bengal.
('91', 432, 2, 4, 854261) Therefore, the Committee expect that this oversight will be corrected.
('91', 432, 3, 5, 854332) The Constituent Assembly is meant to be a fully elected body, chosen by the elected members of the Provincial Legislatures.
('91', 432, 3, 6, 854456) In Baluchistan there is no elected assembly or any other kind of chamber which might elect a representative for the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 432, 3, 7, 854594) It would be improper for any kind of nominated individual to speak for the whole province of Baluchistan, which he really does not represent in any way.
('91', 432, 4, 8, 854747) In Coorg the Legislative Council contains some nominated members as well as Europeans elected from a special constituency of less than a hundred electors.
('91', 432, 4, 9, 854902) Only the elected members from the general constituencies should participate in the election.
('91', 432, 5, 10, 854995) The Statement of the Cabinet Delegation affirms the basic principle of provincial autonomy and residuary powers vesting in the Provinces.
('91', 432, 5, 11, 855133) It is further said that Provinces should be free to form groups.
('91', 432, 5, 12, 855198) Subsequently, however, it is recommended that provincial representatives will divide up into sections which “shall proceed to settle the Provincial Constitutions for the Provinces in each section and shall also decide whether any Group Constitution shall be set up for those Provinces”.
('91', 432, 5, 13, 855485) There is a marked discrepancy in these two separate provisions, and it would appear that a measure of compulsion is introduced which clearly infringes the basic principle of provincial autonomy.
('91', 432, 5, 14, 855680) In order to retain the recommendatory character of the Statement, and in order to make the clauses consistent with each other, the Committee read paragraph 15 to mean that, in the first instance, the respective provinces will make their choice whether or not to belong to the section in which they are placed.
('91', 432, 5, 15, 855990) Thus the Constituent Assembly must be considered as a sovereign body with final authority for the purpose of drawing up a constitution and giving effect to it.
('91', 432, 5, 16, 856150) The provisions in the Statement in regard to the Indian States are vague and much has been left for future decision.
('91', 432, 5, 17, 856267) The Working Committee would, however, like to make it clear that the Constituent Assembly cannot be formed of entirely disparate elements, and the manner of appointing State representatives for the Constituent Assembly must approximate, in so far as is possible, to the method adopted in the Provinces.
('91', 432, 5, 18, 856570) The Committee are gravely concerned to learn that even at present moment some State govern ments are attempting to crush the spirit of their people with the help of armed forces.
('91', 432, 5, 19, 856749) These recent developments in the States are of great significance in the present and for the future of India as they indicate that their is no
('91', 433, 0, 1, 856892) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 433, 1, 2, 856934) real change of policy on the part of some of the State governments and of those who exercise Paramountcy.
('91', 433, 2, 3, 857040) A Provisional National Government must have a new basis and must be a precursor of the full independence that will emerge from the Constituent Assembly.
('91', 433, 2, 4, 857193) It must function in recognition of the fact, though changes in law need not be made at this stage.
('91', 433, 2, 5, 857292) The Governor General may continue as the head of the Government during the interim period, but the Government should function as a cabinet responsible to the Central Legislature.
('91', 433, 2, 6, 857471) The status, powers and composition of the Provisional Government should be fully defined in order to enable the Committee to come to a decision.
('91', 433, 2, 7, 857616) Major communal issues shall be decided in the manner referred to above in order to remove any possible fear or suspicion from the minds of a minority.
('91', 433, 3, 8, 857767) The Working Committee consider that the connected problems involved in the establishment of a Provisional Government and a Constituent Assembly should be viewed together so that they may appear as parts of the same picture, and there may be co ordination between the two, as well as an acceptance of the independence that is now recognized as India’s right and due.
('91', 433, 3, 9, 858133) It is only with the conviction that they are engaged in building up a free, great and independent India, that the Working Committee can approach this task and invite the co operation of all the people of India.
('91', 433, 3, 10, 858344) In the absence of a full picture, the Committee are unable to give a final opinion at this stage.
('91', 433, 4, 11, 858442) The Transfer of Power 1942 47, Vol. VII, pp.
('91', 433, 4, 12, 858487) 679 82. Also A.I.C.C. File No.
('91', 433, 4, 13, 858518) 1499K, 1946 47. Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('91', 433, 5, 14, 858579) APPENDIX II
('91', 433, 6, 15, 858591) LETTER FROM LORD PETHICK LAWRENCE 1
('91', 433, 7, 16, 858627) OFFICE OF THE CABINET DELEGATION, THE VICEROY’S HOUSE, NEW DELHI,
('91', 433, 8, 17, 858693) May 25, 1946
('91', 433, 9, 18, 858706) MY DEAR GANDHIJI,
('91', 433, 10, 19, 858724) I thank you for your letter of yesterday.

('91', 434, 8, 16, 860405) A parson said to a farmer who was worried about something, “Put your trust in Providence, my man.” “No,” said the farmer, “I have no trust in Providence.
