('91', 435, 2, 3, 861044) INTERVIEW WITH LORD WAVELL 1
('91', 435, 3, 4, 861073) June 11, 1946
('91', 435, 4, 5, 861087) 1. I told Mr. Gandhi that I had asked him to come to see me because there appeared to be a deadlock over the last stage of the Cabinet Mission’s work, the formation of an Interim Government.
('91', 435, 4, 6, 861278) It would be very great pity if after all the hard and successful work of the Mission there was a breakdown at this point; and we must avoid it in the interests of India.
('91', 435, 5, 7, 861448) The deadlock seemed likely to occur over the issue of parity between the Congress and the Muslim League in the Interim Government.
('91', 435, 5, 8, 861579) It was quite clear that this Government must be a coalition of the two main parties; and the trouble threa tened to arise because Mr. Jinnah would not commit the Muslim League to partici pation in the Interim Government unless he had parity with Congress, and it seemed that Congress would not come in on these terms.
('91', 435, 5, 9, 861897) I said parity between the Congress and the Muslim League, in view of the respective number of voters whom they represented, was obviously illogical; but what we were concerned with was an ex pedient, which would not form a precedent, to get over the difficult interim period.
('91', 435, 5, 10, 862173) I said that if both parties were determined to work for the common good of India in the interim period, parity had no real meaning; and that if one party was out to dominate the Government and order everything to its own advantage then obviously the Government would do no good.
('91', 435, 5, 11, 862452) I said that I was personally convinced that Mr. Jinnah, if he came into the Government, would work for good administration and not merely politically; and that I was sure that the same would be true of the Congress.
('91', 435, 6, 12, 862668) 2. I stressed the need for good administration in the forthcoming period, both to tide India over her present difficulties, the threatened famine and the railway strike, and also to lay the foundations of India’s future prosperity and independence.
('91', 435, 6, 13, 862917) I said that I thought it was the opportunity for the Congress to make a generous gesture and to agree to Mr. Jinnah’s condition, even if they thought it illogical and unreasonable, and that I hoped they would be able to do so.
('91', 435, 6, 14, 863144) The alternative to obtaining a stable Government in this interim period was likely to be chaos and disorder, and might ruin the last opportunity for a really united India.
('91', 435, 7, 15, 863316) 3. I suggested that perhaps the best way out of this difficulty would be for me to see Jinnah and Nehru together and to endeavour to arrive at an agreed composition for the Interim Government with them.
('91', 435, 8, 16, 863519) 4. Mr. Gandhi said that he was thoroughly anxious for a settlement, and that he agreed that a coalition was necessary.
('91', 435, 8, 17, 863638) What was required was a homogeneous team
('91', 435, 9, 18, 863679) 1 As recorded in a note by Lord Wavell.
('91', 436, 0, 1, 863719) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 437
('91', 436, 1, 2, 863761) which would work together.
('91', 436, 1, 3, 863788) It should not lean too much upon the Viceroy, who was, he said, only a bird of passage, but to work together as a team by themselves.
('91', 436, 1, 4, 863922) I said that this was undoubtedly the ideal but that it was the first step which was necessary and that a mediator between the two parties would undoubtedly be essential.
('91', 436, 2, 5, 864092) Mr. Gandhi then went off into a rather long digression about the poverty of India and the necessity for more food and cloth; but at the end of it came back to my suggestion and agreed that the best thing would be for me to see the leaders of the Congress and the Muslim League together; and that since he realized the difficulty of Azad meeting Jinnah, the meeting should be between Jinnah and Nehru; he would advise me to pin them down to make a Government and not to allow them to leave the room until they had done so; that parity was of no account, nor whether the members belonged to the Congress or the league or anyone, provided they were the best men available.
('91', 436, 2, 6, 864762) He said I should be prepared to go out of the room and leave them to themselves if necessary.
('91', 436, 3, 7, 864856) 5. He then turned on to the matter of the Europeans’ vote and said that it was a most important issue, and that the Europeans should make a declaration if they did not intend to vote.
('91', 436, 3, 8, 865040) I said that it was a matter which must be left to the commonsense of the Europeans.
('91', 436, 4, 9, 865124) 6. The conversation lasted for about forty minutes and Mr. Gandhi was quite friendly throughout.
('91', 436, 4, 10, 865221) It is always difficult to fathom how his mind is working, but he gave the impression that he would advise the Congress to come to terms and not to allow a breakdown on the parity issue.
('91', 436, 5, 11, 865407) The Transfer of Power 1942 47, Vol. VII, pp.
('91', 436, 6, 12, 865452) APPENDIX V
('91', 436, 7, 13, 865463) RESOLUTION OF MUSLIM LEAGUE COUNCIL 1
('91', 436, 8, 14, 865501) June 6, 1946
('91', 436, 9, 15, 865514) This meeting of the Council of the All India Muslim League, after having carefully considered the Statement issued by the Cabinet Mission and the Viceroy on May 16 and other relevant statements and documents officially issued in connection therewith, and after having examined the proposals set forth in the said Statement in all their bearings and implications, places on record the following views for the guidance of the National and direction to the Working Committee :
('91', 436, 10, 16, 865988) 2. That the references made, and the conclusions recorded, in paragraphs 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 of the Statement, concerning the Muslim demand for the establishment of a full sovereign Pakistan as the only solution of the Indian
('91', 436, 11, 17, 866216) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Pethick Lawrence” 12 6 1946 and “Letter to Lord Pethick Lawrence” 13 6 1946.
('91', 437, 0, 1, 866316) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 437, 1, 2, 866358) constitutional problem, are unwarranted, unjustified, and unconvincing, and should not therefore have found place in a State document, issued on behalf and with the authority of the British Government.
('91', 437, 1, 3, 866560) These paragraphs are couched in such language and contain such mutilations of the established facts, that the Cabinet Mission have clearly been prompted to include them in their Statement solely with the object of appeasing the Hindus, in utter disregard of Muslim sentiments.
('91', 437, 1, 4, 866837) Furthermore, the contents of the aforesaid paragraphs are in conflict and inconsistent with the admissions made by the Mission themselves in paragraphs 5 and 12 of their Statement, which are to the following effect: First, the Mission “were greatly impressed by the very genuine and acute anxiety of the Muslims lest they should find themselves subjected to a perpetual Hindu majority rule.” Second, “this feeling has become so strong and widespread amongst the Muslims that it cannot be allayed by mere paper safeguards.”Third, “if there is to be internal peace in India, it must be secured by measures which will assure to the Muslims a control in all matters vital to their culture, religion, economic or other interests.” Fourth, “very real Muslim apprehensions exist that their culture and political and social life might become submerged in a purely unitary India, in which the Hindus, with their greatly superior numbers, must be the dominating element.” In order that there may be no manner of doubt in any quarter, the Council of the All India Muslim League reiterates that the attainment of the goal of a complete sovereign Pakistan still remains the unalterable objective of the Muslims in India, for the achievement of which they will, if neces sary, employ every means in their power and consider no sacrifice or suffering too great.
('91', 437, 2, 5, 868184) 3. That notwithstanding the affront offered to Muslim by the choice of injudicious words in the preamble to the Statement of the Cabinet Mission, the Muslim League, having regard to the grave issues involved, and prompted by its earnest desire for a peaceful solution, if possible, of the Indian constitutional probem, and inasmuch as the basis and the foundation of Pakistan are inherent in the Mission’s plan by virtue of the compulsory grouping of the six Muslim provinces, in Sections B and C, is willing to co operate with the constitution making machinery proposed in the scheme outlined by the Mission, in the hope that it would ultimately result in the establishment of complete sovereign Pakistan, and in the consummation of the goal of independence for the major nations, Muslims and Hindus, and all the other people inhabiting the vast sub continent.
('91', 437, 3, 6, 869046) It is for these reasonss that the Muslim League is accepting the scheme, and will secession of Provinces or Groups from the Union which have been provided in the Mission’s plan by implication.
('91', 437, 4, 7, 869239) The ultimate attitude of the Muslim League will depend on the final outcome of
('91', 437, 5, 8, 869318) the labours of the constitution making body, and on the final shape of the
('91', 437, 6, 9, 869393) constitutions which may emerge from the deliberations of that body jointly and
('91', 438, 0, 1, 869472) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 439
('91', 438, 1, 2, 869514) separately in its three sections.
('91', 438, 1, 3, 869548) The Mulim League also reserves the right to modify
('91', 438, 2, 4, 869599) and revise the policy and attitude set forth in this resolution at any time during the
('91', 438, 3, 5, 869686) progress of deliberations of the constitution making body, or the Constituent
('91', 438, 4, 6, 869764) Assembly, or thereafter if the course of events so require, bearing in mind the
('91', 438, 5, 7, 869844) fundamental principles and ideals herebefore adumbrated to which the Muslim League
('91', 438, 6, 8, 869927) is irrevocably committed.
('91', 438, 7, 9, 869953) 4. That with regard to the arrangement for the proposed Interim Government
('91', 438, 8, 10, 870028) at the Centre, this Council authorizes its President to negotiate with the Viceroy and
('91', 438, 9, 11, 870115) to take such decisions and actions as he deems fit and proper.
('91', 438, 10, 12, 870178) The Transfer of Power 1942 47, Vol. VII, pp.

('91', 440, 6, 9, 875210) LORD WAVELL’S STATEMENT 1
('91', 440, 7, 10, 875236) NEW DELHI,
('91', 440, 8, 11, 875247) June 16, 1946
('91', 440, 9, 12, 875261) 1. His Excellency the Viceroy, in consultation with the members of the Cabinet Mission, has for some time been exploring the possibilities of forming a coalition Government drawn from the two major parties and certain of the minorities.
('91', 440, 9, 13, 875498) The discussions have revealed the difficulties which exist for the two major parties in arriving at any agreed basis for the formation of such a Government.
('91', 440, 10, 14, 875655) 2. The Viceroy and the Cabinet Mission appreciate these difficulties and the efforts which the two parties have made to meet them.
('91', 440, 10, 15, 875786) They consider, however, that no useful purpose can be served by further prolonging these discusions.
('91', 440, 10, 16, 875887) It is indeed urgently necessary that a strong and representative interim Government should be set up to conduct the very heavy and important business that has to be carried through.
('91', 440, 11, 17, 876069) 3. The Viceroy is therefore issuing invitations to the following to serve as members of the Interim Government on the basis that the constitution making will proceed in accordance with the Statement of May 16 :
('91', 440, 12, 18, 876280) Sardar Baldev Singh Sir N. P. Engineer Mr. Jagjivan Ram Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru Mr. M. A. Jinnah Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan Mr. H..
('91', 440, 12, 19, 876412) K. Mahtab Dr. John Matthai

Rajagopalachari Dr. Rajendra Prasad Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel It any of those invited is unable for personal reasons to accept, the Viceroy will, after consultation, invite some other person in his place.
('91', 441, 1, 3, 876812) 4. The Viceroy will arrange the distribution of portfolios in consultation with the leaders of the two major parties.
('91', 441, 1, 4, 876930) 5. The above composition of the Interim Government is in no way to be taken as a precedent for the solution of any other communal question.
('91', 441, 1, 5, 877070) It is an expedient put forward to solve the present difficulty only, and to obtain the best available coalition Government.
('91', 441, 1, 6, 877194) 6. The Viceroy and the Cabinet Mission believe that Indians of all communities desire to arrive at a speedy settlement of this matter so that the process of constitution making can go forward and that the Government of India may be carried on as efficiently as possible in the meantime.
('91', 441, 1, 7, 877481) 7. They therefore hope that all parties, especially the two major parties, will accept this proposal so as to overcome the present obstacles, and will co operate for the successful carrying on of the interim Government.
('91', 441, 1, 8, 877701) Should this proposal be accepted the Viceroy will aim at inaugurating the new Government about 26th June.

('91', 442, 2, 3, 878502) INTERVIEW WITH SIR STAFFORD CRIPPS 1
('91', 442, 3, 4, 878539) [June 20, 1946] 2
('91', 442, 4, 5, 878557) I saw Gandhi at 1.10 p.
('91', 442, 4, 6, 878581) and stayed with him till 2.40 p.
('91', 442, 4, 7, 878614) He started by saying that I should address my arguments to the Maulana.
('91', 442, 4, 8, 878686) I told him I had done so and the Maulana had suggested I should see him (Gandhi).
('91', 442, 4, 9, 878768) To this he replied “he has done a disservice to both of us”.
('91', 442, 5, 10, 878829) I made as strong an appeal to him as was possible on both the points, repeating all the arguments I had put to the Maulana.
('91', 442, 6, 11, 878953) On Engineer, which I dealt with first, he said he had no personal objection against him, indeed he had heard favourable accounts of the honourable way in which he had conducted the I. N. A. prosecutions.
('91', 442, 6, 12, 879157) His objection was first that Congress had not been consulted on his name and second that as he was in an official post he would merely be another vote for the Viceroy.
('91', 442, 7, 13, 879325) I explained to him why Congress could not be consulted under the procedure we had adopted and I strongly stressed that his other fear was quite groundless as that was not the spirit in which the Viceroy was entering upon this task.
('91', 442, 7, 14, 879557) He admitted that he had no reason to suspect it but maintained his objection “in principle” arising from his long experience of former Government and in South Africa.
('91', 442, 7, 15, 879724) I pointed out the conditions of this Government would be quite different and one amongst 14 was not a basis for objection to “officials”.
('91', 442, 7, 16, 879862) I also pointed out that Engineer was not an official though he happened to hold an official post and that any way as he had accepted we were not able to make any alteration as it would be a wrong and impossible way of dealing with an individual.
('91', 442, 7, 17, 880108) With this he agreed.
('91', 442, 8, 18, 880129) We then went on to the other point and he reiterated that he had always said this was the wrong way for forming a Government, that it should be left to one party or the other and not be a coalition forced on the two parties by the British.
('91', 442, 8, 19, 880369) He did not regard a breakdown on this as final since it might lead to a better arrangement.
('91', 442, 9, 20, 880461) It was quite clear that he could not be influenced from his point of view and therefore, after a final appeal to him to at least let this method be tried, I left him.

('91', 443, 11, 13, 881581) Statement of 16th May.
('91', 443, 11, 14, 881604) Mr. Gandhi explained that he had taken legal opinion which
('91', 443, 12, 15, 881663) did not support his anxieties and said that he had seen the Press Communique put out
('91', 443, 13, 16, 881748) by the Government of India.
('91', 443, 13, 17, 881776) If he had seen this Communique originally he would not
('91', 443, 14, 18, 881831) have been troubled to the same extent that he had been.
('91', 443, 14, 19, 881887) In addition to the legal
('91', 443, 15, 20, 881912) difficulty, however, he felt a moral difficulty about this matter.
('91', 443, 16, 21, 881979) The Secretary of State and Sir S. Cripps pointed out that the telegram
('91', 443, 17, 22, 882050) from Assam was based on a complete misunderstanding of what members of the
('91', 443, 18, 23, 882125) Constituent Assembly were required to undertake.
('91', 443, 18, 24, 882174) Mr. Gandhi was shown the
('91', 443, 19, 25, 882199) form of undertaking required by the Bengal regulations and agreed that it
('91', 443, 20, 26, 882273) contained no obligation of the kind he feared.
('91', 443, 20, 27, 882320) The Secretary of State emphasised that
('91', 443, 21, 28, 882359) by signing the undertaking a member of the Constituent Assembly was not accepting
('91', 443, 22, 29, 882441) anything in addition to what was in the Statement of 16th May already.
('91', 443, 23, 30, 882512) The Viceroy said that it was clear that grouping was an essential part of
('91', 443, 24, 31, 882586) the Delegation’s proposals.
('91', 443, 24, 32, 882614) Sir S. Cripps pointed out that what was essential
('91', 443, 25, 33, 882664) was the forming of the constituent Assembly in sections for the purpose of
('91', 443, 26, 34, 882739) framing the constitution.
('91', 443, 26, 35, 882765) Mr. Gandhi said that he felt that the regulations should
('91', 443, 27, 36, 882822) have referred to the Statement of May 16th as a whole and not specifically to
('91', 443, 28, 37, 882900) paragraph 19 was the only one which referred to the setting up of the Constituent
('91', 443, 29, 38, 882982) Assembly.
('91', 443, 29, 39, 882992) There were other parts of the Statement as a whole to which members of
('91', 443, 30, 40, 883063) the Constituent Assembly could not be expected to give concurrence, for example,
('91', 443, 31, 41, 883144) the paragraphs rejecting a sovereign Pakistan.
('91', 443, 31, 42, 883191) Mr. Gandhi said that at the Press
('91', 443, 32, 43, 883225) Conference Lord Pethick Lawrence had interpreted the Statement to mean that the
('91', 443, 33, 44, 883305) Constituent Assembly must meet in sections.
('91', 443, 33, 45, 883349) He (Mr. Gandhi) had dissented from
('91', 443, 34, 46, 883384) this view and his interpretation of the document was upheld by eminent lawyers.
('91', 443, 35, 47, 883464) 1 Vide “Interview with Cabinet Delegation”, 24 6 1946.
('91', 444, 0, 1, 883519) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 445
('91', 444, 1, 2, 883561) was clear that the Delegation were the law givers and could not interpret their own
('91', 444, 2, 3, 883645) It must be the Federal Court which would interpret the meaning of the Statement.
('91', 444, 3, 4, 883726) His trouble was that by signing the declaration required by the electoral rules a
('91', 444, 4, 5, 883808) member of the Constituent Assembly might be bound morally to accept the
('91', 444, 5, 6, 883880) Delegation’s interpertation.
('91', 444, 5, 7, 883909) Sir S. Cripps said that any doubt on the point might be
('91', 444, 6, 8, 883965) solved by the fact that the person who sent the telegram from Assam was under a
('91', 444, 7, 9, 884045) misapprehension as to what members of the Constituent Assembly were in fact asked
('91', 444, 8, 10, 884127) to sign.
('91', 444, 8, 11, 884136) Mr. Ganghi had agreed that the form of declaration was innocuous morally
('91', 444, 9, 12, 884209) and his lawyers had agreed with the interpretation of it which Sir Stafford himself had
('91', 444, 10, 13, 884297) expressed to Mr. Gandhi earlier.
('91', 444, 10, 14, 884330) The First Lord said that what mattered was what a
('91', 444, 11, 15, 884380) person signed.
('91', 444, 11, 16, 884395) Mr. Gandhi agreed that whatever views a man might have about
('91', 444, 12, 17, 884456) sections or groups he could sign the form of declaration in the Bengal regulations.
('91', 444, 13, 18, 884540) 2. Mr. Gandhi said he wanted to make his position about the Constituent Assembly clear.
('91', 444, 13, 19, 884628) His view was that the Europeans had no vote and could not stand as candidates.
('91', 444, 13, 20, 884707) He would like to ask the Delegation whether they had made any further progress or did they ask Congress to rely on whatever local assistance they could get if the Europeans say that they want to assert their right.
('91', 444, 13, 21, 884922) Sir S. Cripps and the Viceroy said there was nothing more to be said about the Europeans since the statements issued by the European repressentatives.
('91', 444, 14, 22, 885073) 3. Mr. Gandhi said there was one very delicate matter which he would like to raise.
('91', 444, 14, 23, 885157) Mr. Sudhir Ghosh had reported to him his conversation with Sir S. Cripps on this subject and he felt that he would like to clear his mind.
('91', 444, 14, 24, 885296) What he wanted to know was whether, if the whole thing was scrapped, would the undertakings to Mr. Jinnah also be scrapped, would the undertakings to Mr. Jinnah also be scrapped, or would the whole Statement be scrapped, or what would happen.
('91', 444, 14, 25, 885539) It would not be a satisfactory thing from his point of view if this were the case.
('91', 444, 14, 26, 885622) If the Government of India is appointed personally by the Viceroy he will be responsible only to the British Government.
('91', 444, 14, 27, 885743) It would not be satisfactory to Mr. Gandhi nor did he think it would satisfy the Congress or, for that matter, the Muslim League.
('91', 444, 14, 28, 885873) He thought the Delegation owed it to the Congress, the Muslim League and the public to tell them what they proposed to do.
('91', 444, 14, 29, 885996) If the Delegation said that they could tell him nothing he would take that answer, but if they had anything to say to him so that he could advise the Working Committee with full knowledge, he would be obliged.
('91', 444, 15, 30, 886206) The Indian people would have to work this Constituent Assembly which had no statutory existence.
('91', 444, 15, 31, 886303) It would be a difficult thing to do as the Delegation had created the Statement which had no legal existence.
('91', 444, 15, 32, 886413) There were bound to be differences of opinion as to what it meant.
('91', 444, 15, 33, 886480) The Congress, the Muslim League and the British Government used the same terms to mean differennt things.
('91', 444, 15, 34, 886586) For example, the Congress independence meant independence now.
('91', 444, 15, 35, 886649) To the Delegation it meant
('91', 445, 0, 1, 886676) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('91', 445, 1, 2, 886718) independence when “this Charter is passed”, but it would only become a Charter if the people went for it and the British Government afterwards legalized the Charter.
('91', 445, 1, 3, 886884) Suppose that there were a change of Secretary of State or a change of Government and that the intention of the British Government changed.
('91', 445, 1, 4, 887023) The Secrtary of State here interrupted Mr. Gandhi to say that he would like to answer that point at once.
('91', 445, 1, 5, 887129) It was not the practice of British Government to repudiate definite pledges given by their predecessors to third parties.
('91', 445, 1, 6, 887251) They were not capable of doing that but if it were assumed that they were then the answer was that no statute would be any protection because a new statute could be passed altering the old one.
('91', 445, 1, 7, 887445) He thought that this suggestion of a statutory basis for the Constituent Assembly would add nothing to the dignity or security of the Indian people.
('91', 445, 1, 8, 887594) It would make the Constituent Body a creature of a British statute and if legislation were introduced attempts might be made to alter or amend the Statement.
('91', 445, 1, 9, 887752) He thought that Mr. Gandhi would have been the first person to object if the Delegation had said that the Constituent Assembly could only be set up by an Act of the British Parliament.
('91', 445, 1, 10, 887937) Sir S. Cripps said that apart from these considerations the lack of rigidity in basing a Constituent Assembly on the Statement and not on an enactment was very desirable.
('91', 445, 1, 11, 888108) The origin of a Constituent Assembly should be the popular will and not the act of another State’s Legislature.
('91', 445, 1, 12, 888220) This gave the Assembly the right constitutional status.
('91', 445, 1, 13, 888276) It did not give it legal status.
('91', 445, 1, 14, 888309) Mr. Gandhi said that the Delegation did contemplate a statute after the Constituent Assembly had met.
('91', 445, 1, 15, 888411) Sir S. Cripps said this was not for the purpose of enacting the new Constitution but of removing the existing legislation.
('91', 445, 1, 16, 888534) The First Lord said that there was no question as he understood it of any legislation except to cancel the existing constitution and the British Government had said that they would enact this legislation at the proper time provided two factors were satisfied.
('91', 445, 1, 17, 888794) First, adequate provision for the protection of minorities as to the necessity of which there was no controversy at all and both major parties had said that they intended to make such provision, and secondly, reasonably formal engagements to be entered into between the united Kingdom and India covering matters arising out of the transfer of power.
('91', 445, 1, 18, 889144) This would deal with formal matters such as the arrangements in regard to the Services.
('91', 445, 2, 19, 889232) 4. Sardar Patel said he understood that the Europeans would not put up candidates but he would like to know whether it was contemplated that they should vote.
('91', 445, 2, 20, 889391) The First Lord said that the Secretary of State had fulfilled his undertaking to do what he could to arrange this matter.
('91', 445, 2, 21, 889513) No European would now vote for a European to sit in the Constitution making Body.
('91', 445, 2, 22, 889595) That was the major point.
('91', 445, 2, 23, 889621) Sardar Patel said that voting was very important.
('91', 445, 2, 24, 889671) Sir S. Cripps said that the position on the Statement of 16th May was that members of the Legislatures were entitled to vote and therefore Europeans were entitled to vote.
('91', 445, 2, 25, 889843) The document clearly did not intend that no one other than Indians should be members of the Constituent Assembly so that that
('91', 446, 0, 1, 889969) VOL. 91 : 20 MAY, 1946 8 AUGUST, 1946 447
('91', 446, 1, 2, 890011) question was on a different footing.
('91', 446, 1, 3, 890048) Whether the Europeans exercised their vote was legally a matter for them.
('91', 446, 1, 4, 890122) The First Lord said that the Europeans had gone a very long way from the position which obtained when the Congress complained about this matter.
('91', 446, 1, 5, 890267) He thought that the original complaint had had justification but 75 per cent of it had been met.

('91', 446, 4, 8, 890421) LETTER FROM LORD WAVELL TO ABUL KALAM AZAD
('91', 446, 6, 9, 890464) June 22, 1946
('91', 446, 7, 10, 890478) I understand from Press reports that there is strong feeling in Congress circles
('91', 446, 8, 11, 890559) that the party should insist on their right to include a Muslim of their choice among the representatives of the Congress in the Interim Government.
('91', 446, 9, 12, 890708) For reasons of which you are already aware it is not possible for the Cabinet
('91', 446, 10, 13, 890786) Mission or myself to accept this request, but I would draw your attention to paragraph 5 of the Statement of the 16th June which reads as follows :
('91', 446, 11, 14, 890934) “The above composition of the Interim Government is in no way to be taken
('91', 446, 12, 15, 891008) as a precedent for the solution of any other communal question.
('91', 446, 12, 16, 891072) It is an expedient put forward to solve the present difficulty only, and to obtain the best available coalition Government.”
('91', 446, 13, 17, 891197) In the light of this assurance that no precedent is established we appeal to the
('91', 446, 14, 18, 891278) Congress not to press their demand, but to take part in the strong Interim Government which the country so urgently needs.
('91', 446, 15, 19, 891401) The Transfer of Power 1942 7, Vol. VII, p.

('91', 446, 17, 21, 891457) GROUPING CLAUSE CONTROVERSY
('91', 446, 19, 22, 891485) It has been reported in the Press that the text of a Bengal Government
('91', 446, 20, 23, 891556) communique requires every delegate to the Constituent Assembly to sign a declaration accepting Clause 19 of the Cabinet Delegation’s Statement of May 16. This allegation is without any foundation.
('91', 446, 20, 24, 891753) The A. P. I. has been authorized to state that according to the instructions actually issued a candidate for election to the Constituent Assembly from any province is required to declare that he has not been proposed for candidature to represent any other province and that he is willing to serve as a representative of the province for the purpose of paragraph 19 of the
('91', 446, 21, 25, 892125) 1 Vide “Interview with Cabinet Delegation”, 24 6 1946. 2ibid

('91', 447, 1, 2, 892228) Cabinet Delegation’s Statement.
('91', 447, 2, 3, 892260) The plain purpose of paragraph 19 is the framing of a new Constitution for India and this has been made further clear in the actual form of a declaration prescribed for the purpose by the Governor of Bengal which is as follows :
('91', 447, 3, 4, 892489) “I hereby agree to this nomination and declare that I am willing to serve in the Constituent Assembly as a representative of the General or Muslim part of the Bengal Legislative Assembly for the purpose of framing a new Constitution for India.
('91', 447, 3, 5, 892733) I further declare that I have not been proposed as a representative of any part of the Legislative Assembly of any other province in India in the said Constituent Assembly.”
('91', 447, 4, 6, 892907) The other reference to paragraph 19 of the Statement in the instructions issued by the Bengal Governor is with regard to reporting the result of the election.
('91', 447, 5, 7, 893066) This reads as follows : “The returning officer shall report the result of the election to the Governor who shall cause the names of the candidates declared elected, to be published in the Calcutta Gazette on July 15, 1946 or as soon as may be thereafter; and the persons whose names are so published shall be representative of Bengal for the purposes of paragraph 19 of the above mentioned Statement.”
